text: Usually when someone asks if they have a problem, they believe they do have a problem!The first step is to understand your own theory and definition as to what problem you feel you have.  Some possibilities are feeling unhappy in the relationship to your boyfriend, not having enough discussion between the two of you, not feeling cared about by your boyfriend, not liking your boyfriend.Did you grow up in a family in which the grownups drank to the point of excess at the times they felt stressed?Family modeling of how to handle problems may have left you no knowing how to handle stress except to drink to excess.Ask yourself what it is you feel guilty of doing?The guilt may point you in a good direction if it is your sense of self-esteem telling you to find better ways of managing your life.Do you drink alone or together with friends?Try defining your specific reasons for drinking because this is the first step to know how to handle the situation differently.

There's two things this post relays - one, which I'm sure you've already looked into - is working with the school to address this problem. Sure, sometimes kids don't get along, but most schools look at bullying seriously, and this sounds serious. The other, though, is additional tools to consider to help your daughter. If you haven't already read Greene's Explosive Child, you might give it a shot. While it's a little preachy, many of the tools are wonderful and can help parents navigate tantrums. https://www.amazon.com/Explosive-Child-Understanding-Frustrated-Chronically/dp/0062270451 Another tool that can redirect a child that's losing it is a task. If her tantrums, say, involve throwing things, maybe she's in charge of throwing all the sticks and acorns off the driveway into the garbage bin. Ie: 'Hey Jenny, you seem really angry right now, let's use all that energy and get some work done!' Go with her, throw with her, even - if possible - making a game out of getting the acorns into the bin from a distance. I wish you all the best~

Hi Kansas,I think your first instinct was good; you broke up with him. You deserve respect, but right now you're not acting as if you deserve it when you push to see him as he's moving on with a new relationship. It's appropriate now for you to respect that relationship and listen to what he says he wants, which is space. Do you think he's going to be any different with her? This a common, unfounded fear we have. I wonder if maybe you miss the feeling of being in love and having a partner more than you miss him. The bottom line is you can't make someone love you, and you can't make someone be loving towards you, because how someone treats you (and the choices they make) has everything to do with who they are, and nothing to do with who you are. I hope you gather support from others and move on in hope and strength for your own future.

I think we all go through a period of time where we think we aren't worth anything. Sometimes these feelings are a result of low self esteem or because of shame. The most important part of dealing with this thought is to separate feelings from reality. "I don't feel worth anything, but I know what I do is important, I know who I am matters to others. I know I am loved and cared about."When you find yourself having these thoughts, stop, take a few deep breaths and try to reframe what you're thinking.

I understand that discovering your fiancé's infidelity is a painful experience. The decision of whether to work through this issue and try to save the relationship is a complex one and depends on many factors. Here are some things to consider:

1. The reason for the affair: Understanding the motivation behind the infidelity is crucial. Was it due to feeling neglected or unappreciated in other areas of the relationship, or was it a result of an unmet desire or need that went unfulfilled? It's important to identify the root cause of the behavior.

2. Communication and trust: Effective communication and trust are essential components of any relationship. Both you and your fiancé need to have honest and open conversations about the affair, why it happened, and what steps can be taken to rebuild trust and prevent similar situations in the future.

3. Repair and forgiveness: Healing from the pain of infidelity takes time and effort from both partners. If your fiancé genuinely takes responsibility for his actions and shows sincere remorse, there may be room for forgiveness. Forgiveness is not about excusing the behavior but rather about letting go of the resentment and moving forward.

4. Professional help: Consider seeking help from a therapist or counselor to navigate this process. A professional can provide guidance on effective communication strategies, trust-building exercises, and healing techniques for both of you.

5. Personal reflection: Evaluate whether the relationship is truly worth saving based on your personal values, desires, and emotional well-being. Don't make this decision solely based on fear or guilt. If you believe that the relationship has more potential for growth and happiness, consider giving it another chance. However, if you feel that you deserve better or that the relationship is no longer serving your needs, it may be best to move on.

Ultimately, the decision is a personal one, and it depends on your own feelings, values, and sense of what is best for you moving forward. I would encourage you to take the time to reflect on your relationship, the causes of the affair, and the actions you need to take to move forward in a manner that aligns with your authentic self and your goals for personal growth and happiness.

This quiet wonder that you have is something you can easily explore. There is a part of you that you can access anytime, anywhere. It is the part that has always been with you. Find a quiet place where you can be alone for a while and get comfortable. Settle in. Let your thoughts go by like a river. Stay with that connection for a while. What you find in the silence is yours alone, your "you".

I understand your frustration, but it's important to recognize that while you cannot force your family to undergo therapy, there are things you can do to help improve the situation for yourself. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Seek support from other sources: Reach out to friends, teachers, coaches, or other adults who care about you and can offer guidance or advice.

2. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that promote your physical, emotional, and mental wellbeing. Exercise regularly, maintain a healthy diet, and make time for hobbies and interests.

3. Develop coping strategies: Learn techniques for managing stress and anxiety, such as deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation.

4. Educate yourself and your family: Share resources, books, or articles about the importance of mental health and therapy. Explain how therapy can benefit your family as a whole, and how it can support you individually.

5. Consider seeking therapy on your own: Talk to a mental health professional or your primary care provider about starting individual therapy to help you develop the skills and strategies for addressing challenges within your family while also focusing on your own personal growth.

6. Consider joining a support group: Connecting with peers who may be experiencing similar challenges can provide a sense of community, insight, and understanding.

7. Explore community or school resources: Look into support groups, counseling services, or educational programs offered by schools or community organizations.

Remember, change can take time and patience, but small steps in the right direction can lead to significant improvements in your overall wellbeing.

HelloYes many couples have survived infidelity. How sincere is he with wanting to work it out?That means alot in recovery. The key is to understand that cheating is a choice. Please don't take the betrayal personal.Look at the foundation of the relationship.  Is there cracks that can be healed? How do you feel about betrayal? Honest communication is the key to healing. Never assume monogamy discuss it. No one can tell you if you should stay or go. That is a very personal decision. Start by setting up face to face time to discuss the affair and emotions.  If this may be hard please get a counselor or therapist that can meditate this journey. Just remember even if you decide to leave you still need support to heal. Just because you leave the situation,  the trauma still exists.

I am wondering who is telling you that sex is dangerous.  Is this medical advice, or is this someone’s
opinion trying to scare you from having sex? 
And if so, how old are you? Is it ok to have sex, do you want to have
sex?  It sounds like you want to make
your partner happy, and that you are taking care of protecting yourself and
your partner, but maybe you are forgetting to consider what do you really want.  Having sexual relations is a very personal decision;
you and your partner have to consent.  It
is also important to talk about the possible consequences and being responsible
for them as well.  But sex should be something
that you enjoy, not that you should be fearful of.  A therapist can help you to process those
negative thoughts and feelings that may impair you from enjoying your sexual
life. ¿Cómo puedo superar mi miedo de un
embarazo no deseado y poder tener sexo otra vez?Estoy
aterrorizado de tener sexo porque me han dicho una y otra vez que el sexo es
peligroso, inclusive cuando yo y mi pareja usamos dos métodos de protección.  Mi pareja no está contenta y simplemente
quiere más sexo, y honestamente, yo quiero darle lo que ella quiere.Me pregunto quién
te está diciendo que el sexo es peligroso. 
¿Esto es aviso medico, o es alguien intentando asustarte para que no
tengas relaciones?  ¿Y si es así, que
edad tienes?  ¿Es apropiado que tengas
sexo a tu edad?  ¿Quieres tener sexo? Me
parece que estas enfocado en hacer feliz a tu pareja, y te estás protegiendo y protegiéndola,
pero tal vez están olvidando analizar que tu quieres realmente.  Recuerda que tener una relación sexual es una
decisión personal, en la que tú y tu pareja deben de estar de acuerdo.   También es importante hablar de las posibles
consecuencias de tener relaciones, como un embarazo, y discutir sus opciones e
intenciones, si eso ocurriera.  Ya que
han tenido comunicación al respecto, el sexo debe ser algo que disfruten,  no que temen. 
Un terapista te puede ayudar a procesar esos pensamientos negativos y
los sentimientos que te pudieran impedir disfrutar de tu vida sexual.

I understand that your mother's words have had a profound impact on you and may have left you feeling worthless, unmotivated, and low in self-esteem. It's important to remember, however, that your mother's words are not an accurate reflection of your value as a person. Your worth is not determined by others' opinions, but rather by your own thoughts, abilities, and personal qualities. It's natural to feel hurt and affected by negative comments, but it's essential to learn to challenge those thoughts and focus on the positive aspects of yourself. Consider seeking out therapeutic support, such as talking with a mental health professional or joining a support group, to help you work through these challenges and develop healthy coping strategies. Remember, you are worth more than your mother's words suggest.

It seems like you may be experiencing depression symptoms, they could be the triggered by unexpected life changes, or building up throughout time.The important part is that you have identified them and wanting to change them.  The first step is to establish a self-care routine that will help you to feel centered and motivated: go for walks, or make any physical activity that you enjoy ( be kind to yourself, anything helps at this point), eat balanced, add whole grains and fibers to your diet, make a point to rest at night and avoid naps, practice a hobby that you love, or look for a new one that you are curious about. You mentioned that you feel unsettled in your soul: explore your spirituality, meditate about what makes your soul at peace, and find ways to practice that or surround yourself by those activities.If you find it difficult to begin, talk to your therapist to identify roadblocks and ways to find motivation. Suicidal and homicidal thoughts are common but serious depression symptoms, discuss them with your therapist, contact your doctor or psychiatrist, and call 9-1-1 if its and emergency.Once you feel stable, you can focus on exploring the source of the problem and see if you need to make changes or learn coping skills that will help you manage it.  It will also be a good time to explore your spirituality and your purpose in life, that may help you to feel better with yourself and then happier around others.¿Cómo puedo volver a ser la persona que realmente soy?Siento que mi mente no está bien.  My espíritu está intranquilo.  No me siento feliz con las decisiones que tomo, lo cual me hace infeliz con los demás. Me siento como un fracaso la mayoría del tiempo.  Siento que ya no soy bueno para nada. Siento que soy menos que los demás.Al parecer estas experimentando síntomas de depresión, la cual puede ser causada por cambios recientes en tu vida o estarse acumulando a través del tiempo.Lo importante en este momento es que tú reconoces los síntomas y estas buscando cambiar la situación.  El primer paso sería trabajar en restablecer una rutina de cuidado personal que te ayude a sentirte emocionalmente estable y motivado: Sal a caminar o hacer alguna actividad física(ten compasión contigo mismo, cualquier cosa funciona para comenzar), comienza a comer balanceado, especialmente granos y fibras integrales, , procura descansar en las noches y evita las siestas, y practica algún tipo de actividad que hayas disfrutado en el pasado o que te de curiosidad.  Mencionaste que tu espíritu esta intranquilo, explora tu espiritualidad, y que te ayudaría a encontrar la paz, busca la manera de hacer esa práctica una rutina.Si te cuesta mucho trabajo iniciar estas actividades, será bueno buscar a un consejero para que te ayude a identificar formas de estar motivado o obstáculos que te estén deteniendo.  Es común tener pensamientos que atentan en contra de tu vida o la de otros, discútelos con tu terapeuta, con tu medico primario o psiquiatra, y llama al 9-1-1 si es una emergencia.  Ya que consigas estabilidad, puedes comenzar a trabajar o explorar la causa del problema y ver si hay cambios mayores que debes hacer o destrezas que debes aprender para manejar el mismo. También es un buen momento para explorar tu espiritualidad mas profundamente y tu propósito en la vida, cuando encontramos un propósito y como ejercerlo, tendemos a ser más felices con nosotros mismos y con los demás.

I understand that the thought of expressing your emotions in a therapy session can be intimidating. But please remember that there's no right or wrong way to feel or express yourself in therapy. In fact, crying and expressing your emotions can be a sign of healing and a step towards growth. So, try not to worry too much about it. Instead, focus on the potential benefits that can come from this therapeutic process. Remember, the goal is to feel supported, understand yourself better, and work through your concerns in a safe and confidential environment.

I understand that coming out as transgender can be a challenging experience, especially when you anticipate a negative response from loved ones. It's important to prioritize your mental and emotional health in the face of gender dysphoria. Here are a few suggestions that might help you cope:

1. Seek out supportive resources and communities: You don't have to face this alone. Connecting with other transgender individuals or online communities can provide valuable support and validation.
2. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that bring you joy and help reduce stress, such as exercise, arts and crafts, or reading.
3. Consider professional therapy: A mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, can provide you with coping mechanisms and strategies for managing gender dysphoria. They can also help you navigate personal relationships and family dynamics.
4. Explore your identity and express yourself: Experimenting with gender presentation and identity can be a helpful way to understand who you are and find what feels authentic for you.
5. Consider reaching out to organizations: There are many organizations that offer resources and support for transgender individuals, such as Gender Spectrum and the Human Rights Campaign.
6. Stay informed about your rights: Educating yourself about your legal rights and protections as a transgender person can be empowering and help you feel more in control of your personal and professional life.

Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace and prioritize your safety and well-being above all else. I'm here to support you and answer any questions you have.

What's most important is that you recognize that what you've been doing is off base - that what you've been feeling is "overreacting," that you have "insecurities," and you suspect your actions and reactions are connected to your own past and not to the current situation or to your partner. That's an excellent first step because without recognizing these things about yourself, it's unlikely that you would change.That said, you sound as if you are really ready to start some therapy to work on your own personal growth... not because there is something "wrong" with you, but because you're ready to learn more about yourself and make some creative changes in your behavior. Yes, there are lots of self-help books and courses, but we humans often make the most progress when we have support in  real-time from another human being who can sit with us, point out our blind spots, and teach us some skills that are hard to learn on our own.

This answer could be very different depending on the fear, the degree of it, and what it connects to.I wonder the following:On a scale of 1 to 10, how upset, anxious, or scared to you get when you think about overcoming this? If it's more than a 5/10, I would definitely recommend talking with a therapist in your area.A lot of fears that we have come from something that at one time was self-protective and important. Do you know where your fear started? If you think it is still protecting you or helping you in some way, talk with someone (like a therapist) about it.If it is something that you know is irrational (for example, fear of being hurt by static cling from winter clothing), is there some part of that that you are not afraid of?I really encourage you to consider whether your fear has a lot of emotions connected to it or if it ties from something in your past that was very emotional for you at the time. If it does, consider working with a therapist to establish emotional safety before taking away the fear or anxiety that may actually be helpful to you.Also, the fact that you notice that you are afraid of something and you don't want to be afraid of it anymore is a big step in the forward direction.

This is a very personal decision that you make when you have evaluated the issues in your couple that you feel are affecting your happiness and well being in your couple. I recommend completing a compatability checklist to evaluate which areas are making you unhappy. It is important to discuss these feelings with your partner and determine if together you want to work on these differences. If there is no agreement to working together to resolve the issues  and you cannot accept the issues as they are then a break up may be best.

Is really difficult to tell whether he honestly forgot about someone or whether he was really lying again.I don't know whether he would be open to having a discussion with you about your concerns about this and whether you would be actually willing to listen to your thoughts about it.This might be something to discuss with a local therapist so that you can look at the patterns of lying in the past as well as whether you have a way to discuss this with your husband in the way that you would feel comfortable feeling vulnerable with your own feelings and also listening to what his responses are.This is difficult because I imagine you have a react very quickly and strongly to things like this because of what has happened in the past between you. All of this make sense. Having said that, there is also a question of whether he is telling the truth in this particular case and your reaction is based on past events.There's no easy way to know.If you do decide to have a discussion with your husband about it,  consider these things:Ask if this is a good time to have a conversation about something that is important to youMaybe you will be able to listen and ask questions about what came up for him (emotionally) when he realized that he didn't tell you about this other personMaybe he would be willing to listen to what you are thinking about if you are both able to do so without blaming, pointing fingers, or asking the other person to change. This would just be an exchange of information. Ideally this part of the competition would not be about you saying he did something wrong, but just expressing how you felt when you heard about itIt may be helpful to discuss these things with a therapist first so you have some coping skills for being able to listen to him without being overly defensive and also expressing your feelings without blaming, both of which would be very natural in this situation.

I hear you, patient, and I understand that you have been struggling with depression for a long time, which was triggered by a history of bullying and academic pressures in high school. It's also important to acknowledge that you've experienced self-harming behaviors in the past.

I'd like to validate your experience and emphasize that depression is a complex mental health condition, often influenced by multiple factors, including genetics, environment, and personal experiences. Your feelings of hopelessness, stress, and overreaction to problems when they arise are common symptoms of depression.

It's essential to recognize that managing depression isn't about eliminating stress or avoiding problems altogether. Instead, the focus is on developing coping skills and strategies to effectively manage stressors and reactions.

As a psychologist, I would recommend exploring evidence-based treatment options for depression, like cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or interpersonal therapy (IPT). These therapies can help you identify and challenge negative thought patterns, learn problem-solving skills, and build healthier interpersonal relationships.

Additionally, stress management techniques like deep breathing exercises, mindfulness meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation can help you manage day-to-day stressors more effectively.

Finally, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for additional support and guidance. You're not alone, and seeking help is an important step towards overcoming depression and learning to cope more effectively with stress.

I understand that you are feeling lost and uncertain about your identity. It's not uncommon for people to go through periods of self-exploration and questioning. I would recommend taking some time for introspection. Try to identify your strengths, values, interests, and passions. You may also find it helpful to ask for feedback from others to gain a better understanding of how they see you. Remember, everyone has a unique identity that evolves throughout their life. Let's work together to help you explore yours.

It's completely normal to feel nervous or anxious when going to therapy sessions, especially if you're new to the experience. Therapy is a process that involves delving into personal and sometimes challenging emotions, thoughts, and experiences. Feeling nervous can be a sign that you're facing important issues and taking steps towards growth. However, if the anxiety is debilitating or preventing you from fully participating in therapy, it may be helpful to discuss this with your therapist. They may be able to provide you with additional support and coping strategies. Remember, it takes courage to seek help and to work through personal issues, and every step taken towards healing is a step in the right direction.

Your doctor might be required to tell your psychiatrist - especially if your doctor is concerned about your safety.It was definitely a good thing that you told your primary care physician about what is going on.  I know that must have been difficult to talk about with him.  By having that conversation, you are helping your primary care physician and your psychiatrist work together to best support your health.

I understand that you're in a difficult situation, and it's not uncommon for people to feel deeply connected to someone despite their negative behaviors. However, it's essential to prioritize your emotional and mental well-being. Narcissistic behaviors, such as lying and cheating, can be toxic and detrimental to a relationship. Constantly going back and forth, even after trying to move on, can keep you locked in a cycle of emotional pain. You may want to consider seeking therapy to help you process your emotions and develop healthier relationship patterns. It might also be helpful to explore new hobbies, social circles, or personal growth opportunities to build a strong sense of self-worth and independence. Remember, you deserve respect and a partner who values and cherishes you.

Definitely. Therapy helps us work through the tough stuff. It’s a safe place where we can let our guards down. When you are getting things out verbally, a physical and emotional response is completely natural. Crying is a healthy release. Many people cry during therapy - some perhaps once in a while, and others may every session. Wherever you are on that spectrum, it is absolutely normal and you are not at all alone.

I see. It sounds like you're describing a young mother who is dealing with the challenges of raising a toddler in her early 20s. This can be a demanding and stressful period in a person's life. It's normal for young mothers to feel overwhelmed at times, particularly if they're also trying to balance other responsibilities such as work, school, or relationships. If she's feeling particularly distressed, it may be helpful for her to seek out support from friends and family, or consider reaching out to a healthcare professional such as a therapist or her doctor for additional guidance. Remember, it's important for her to take care of herself as well as her child, as her own mental and physical health will be important in providing the best possible care for her toddler. Does this make sense? Feel free to ask if you have any other questions.

Going through a divorce is often a very low point for the people involved.Are you surprised that your soon to be ex doesn't help with your teenage daughter?Usually patterns and dynamics in parenting are not  sudden developments.Is it possible that what you're feeling now is more intensity to the stress of parenting by yourself, not that this is a sudden problem?This is relevant because you may be more familiar and more capable than you're giving yourself credit.  The lack of emotional support is definitely stressful.Your parenting skills may still be at the level at which they were prior to the divorce.Take your emotional weariness seriously and reflect on the various ways of stress relief which are available and interest you.Give yourself extra time to rest, nurture yourself and be flexible in finding what feels right for stabilizing yourself.Since you talk about your daughter and help in physical ways, if it is a matter of strength that you need, talk with your attorney so that the child custody agreement includes whatever is physically necessary in the way of strength, in taking care of your daughter.The Courts are very good at making effort that the custody agreement offers proper care to the kids.

It's important to remember that effective communication requires both parties to listen actively. Here are some steps you can take to encourage your husband to listen more to you:

1. Use "I" statements instead of "you" statements: For example, instead of saying "You never listen to me," say "I feel unheard when we have conversations and I share my thoughts and feelings."
2. Show that you value his perspective: Make sure to give him your full attention when he's speaking. Nod, make eye contact, and use verbal cues like "uh-huh" and "yes" to show that you're listening.
3. Practice active listening: This involves giving your full attention to what your husband is saying, without interrupting or judging him. Reflect back what he has said in your own words, to show that you understand.
4. Look for opportunities to listen to him when you are busy: Offer to listen to him when you're cooking dinner, instead of watching TV, for example. This shows that you value his perspective even when you're occupied.
5. Use non-verbal communication: Smile, touch his arm, and make eye contact to show that you're engaged in the conversation.
6. Schedule regular conversations: Make a regular time for conversations, where both of you can fully focus on each other without distractions.
7. Practice patience: Changing a long-term pattern of communication takes time and effort on both sides. Be patient with your husband and give him the opportunity to respond in kind.

I hope this information is helpful, and please let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

I understand how difficult it is for you to deal with complex emotions, especially when it comes to your child's well-being. The situation you're in is not an easy one, but I'll try to help you with some guidance based on psychological principles.

First and foremost, it is essential to focus on what's best for your child. Children often thrive on consistency and stability, even if their parents are divorced or living separately. Hence, frequent and meaningful contact with both parents is generally recommended, assuming the situation is safe, healthy, and mutually respectful for all parties involved.

However, in situations where there's a great deal of animosity, manipulation, or conflict between parents, you may need to limit your contact or seek professional guidance to ensure a healthy environment for your child's development. In such cases, it's essential to prioritize your mental health as well, as children can sense their parents' emotions and may be negatively affected by ongoing conflict.

In your specific situation, if it feels confusing or detrimental to your emotional wellbeing to continue engaging with your ex, whose behavior seems manipulative, consider seeking guidance from a mental health professional or a mediation service to help establish boundaries that respect your emotional needs and your child's wellbeing.

Remember, focusing on moving on doesn't mean denying the past or your feelings, but rather finding a way to live your life in a healthy, meaningful way for yourself and your child.

Without knowing the details, it would be very difficult to say! But, that's also the point of my response. Because even with the details, it's very hard to say, as no one is experiencing the relationship in your shoes, except for you. It might be helpful to process this in therapy, or with your boyfriend directly and voice your concerns about the relationship. In any successful relationship, the research has shown that openness in communication is vital.That all being said, I would also add, with a lot of curiosity...if you have to ask the question, does that say something about what you feel is the quality of the relationship?

Let me first say that I am sorry you are going through this. Yes, this is a symptom of an ugly disease, but that does not make experiencing it any easier. If your mother was a sweet and understanding lady, I am sure this change in personality feels awful! On the other hand, if your relationship with her has always been difficult this can definitely open up old wounds and anger. I have walked alongside many families as they care for a loved one with Alzheimer's disease. It is unfortunately common to see mothers become cruel and mean toward their daughters. In your case, it sounds like she is not directing her anger at just you. While this may feel less personal, I am sure it makes finding supportive care for her very difficult. I have several quick tips that might help you cope with this situation. 1. Stay tuned in to your level of anger and frustration. If you can limit the amount of time you or anyone else is with your mother you can limit the caregiver burnout. It is completely NORMAL to feel what you are feeling!! However, these are the feelings that can lead to acting out and abuse when not acknowledged. It doesn't sound like this is the case for you, but healthy boundaries and exercising respite will help with your feelings of guilt as well. So, rotate care as much as possible.2. If you find yourself arguing with your mom, STOP. Don't worry, we have all been there before. No need to feel guilty, but this only serves to agitate someone. None of us enjoys being wrong and getting into an argument. For those of us who are able to logically engage with others, sometimes this type of interaction is necessary. Alzheimer's disease has robbed your mother of her logic, therefore arguing with her will only make matters worse. Try redirecting her instead. For tips on how to do this check out Teepa Snow (teepasnow.com)3. Take care of yourself and seek support. Support groups and counseling are a great way to tend to your needs during this long journey. Caregiving can be overwhelming, lonely and heartbreaking. You don't have to go through this alone. Check out Alz.org for support groups in your area.

Finding the right person is a tricky thing to do. Why did you and your ex break up 3 months ago? In relationships with others you get to see a reflection of yourself.  Sometimes you may enjoy that reflection, other times it may not feel so good. I'm not sure where you are in your life and relationships and what you do from here depends on what you desire more of in your life. But I'm not simply talking in the moment desire, I'm referring to the direction you want your life to go. If one of these guys was to support you...who would help you reach your dreams? And who would you enjoy spending time with? It's complicated and no one can answer the 'what to do' question but you.  Slow down. Tune into your heart. Listen.

I understand that you feel disconnected from your husband in terms of sexual intimacy and are worried that this is a sign of a deeper problem. It's important to recognize that every relationship is unique, and what works for one couple may not work for another. Your concerns about low sex drive or not knowing what you're doing are common and valid.

You could consider several approaches to improve your sexual relationship with your husband. First, consider having an open and non-judgmental conversation with your husband about your feelings and concerns. You may discover that he has similar feelings and that together, you can try new things or explore ways to make sexual intimacy more enjoyable for both of you.

Additionally, you could consider seeking the help of a sex therapist or counselor. They can provide you with guidance and techniques to improve your sexual relationship and help you overcome any underlying issues that may be contributing to your low sex drive or lack of sexual connection with your husband.

It's also important to remember that a healthy sexual relationship goes beyond just physical intimacy. This includes emotional connection, communication, and mutual respect. So, focus on building a strong emotional connection with your husband and addressing any underlying emotional or communication issues.

Overall, I would encourage you to take a holistic approach to improving your sexual relationship with your husband. This may involve seeking professional help, having open and honest conversations, and focusing on building a strong emotional connection between you both. Remember, it takes time and effort to build a fulfilling and satisfying sexual relationship, and no relationship is perfect. But with dedication, love, and support, you can overcome any challenges and enjoy a healthy and fulfilling sexual relationship with your husband.

I understand that rejection can be difficult to deal with, especially when it comes to matters of the heart. It's natural to feel disappointed and confused when someone you care for doesn't reciprocate your feelings. However, it's important to remember that everyone experiences relationships differently, and not every instance of romantic attraction will result in a successful long-term relationship. Continuing to treat people with kindness and respect is a positive trait, and it's important to focus on the personal growth and self-care that will help you move on from these experiences. As a psychologist, I would be here to help you process these feelings and develop healthy coping mechanisms. Would you like to discuss this topic further?

While you can take steps to manage your symptoms, I would strongly recommend seeking professional help. Treatment for PTSD and related conditions is most effective when provided by mental health professionals. This typically includes therapy, such as Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) or trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy, as well as medication if necessary. These interventions are proven to be helpful and can offer you the tools and understanding needed to live a fuller and more peaceful life. If you're not able to see a mental health professional in person, online therapy or support groups can be excellent alternatives as well. Remember, it's okay to ask for help – taking care of your mental health is an essential part of self-care and overall well-being.

I'm here to help you, teenager. The first step to stopping this behavior would be to acknowledge that it's a problem, and you've already taken that important first step. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Identify the triggers: Try to understand what makes you want to sneak out in the first place. Is it stress, loneliness, or the thrill of the unknown? Once you identify these triggers, you can start finding healthier ways to cope with them.
2. Set achievable goals: Decide on a specific goal for why you want to stop sneaking out. It could be to improve your relationship with your parents, to focus on your studies, or to build stronger friendships in the daytime. Having clear, achievable goals can help you stay motivated.
3. Create a plan: Come up with a detailed plan on how you can achieve your goal. This might include finding healthier ways to cope with stress or boredom, such as joining a club or hobby group, meeting new people, or finding other ways to spend your time.
4. Share your plan with a trusted adult: It's important to be open and honest about your desire to stop sneaking out. Share your plan with someone you trust, such as a parent, teacher, or counselor, and ask for their support.
5. Practice self-care: Make sure to take care of yourself, both physically and emotionally. This can include getting enough sleep, eating healthy food, and engaging in regular physical activity. Good self-care can help you build the resilience and energy you'll need to make positive changes in your life.
6. Reach out for support: If you're struggling to stop on your own, consider reaching out for additional support. This might include talking with a therapist, attending a support group, or seeking advice from a trusted adult or mentor. Remember that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.
7. Take it one day at a time: Making big changes can be challenging. Focus on taking things one day at a time, and celebrate each small success along the way. Over time, you'll build the skills and confidence you need to live a healthier, happier life.

I understand your concern. Lying repeatedly about significant aspects of one's life can indicate underlying issues related to self-esteem, trust, or emotional regulation. It's important to remember, however, that every individual's situation is unique. The best course of action would be for your loved one to seek professional help from a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist. They can provide a safe and confidential environment where they can explore the underlying reasons for their deceptive behavior and work on developing more healthy coping mechanisms. If they are not willing to seek help on their own, you may be able to suggest it to them in a gentle and supportive way, expressing your concern for their well-being and the potential consequences of their actions. It's also crucial for you to set healthy boundaries in your own life to protect yourself and those you care about from being negatively impacted by her deceptive behavior.

I'm sorry to hear that you've been feeling worthless and unwanted recently. These feelings can be intense and debilitating, but they're not uncommon. However, it's important to acknowledge that your thoughts aren't always an accurate reflection of reality. Here are some things that might help you begin to shift your perspective and feel more valued:

1. Challenge negative thoughts: Negative self-talk is often a product of our own thoughts and biases, not an accurate reflection of reality. When you notice these thoughts, try to challenge them by considering alternative, more positive perspectives.
2. Practice self-care: Focus on taking care of yourself, both physically and emotionally. Make time for activities that bring you joy and reduce stress. This might include things like regular exercise, healthy eating, getting enough sleep, and finding time for hobbies or interests.
3. Build a support network: Surround yourself with people who care about you and make you feel valued. Reach out to friends, family, or a mental health professional for support if you need it.
4. Practice self-compassion: Treat yourself with kindness and understanding, as you would treat a close friend in the same situation. Don't be too hard on yourself for having negative thoughts or making mistakes. Instead, focus on learning and growing from these experiences.
5. Set small, achievable goals: Setting and working towards achievable goals can help build your confidence and sense of self-worth. Start with small, manageable goals and build from there. This might include things like getting out of bed by a certain time each day, making a healthy meal, or reaching out to a friend for support.
6. Consider therapy: If your negative thoughts and feelings persist despite your efforts to address them, it might be helpful to seek the support of a mental health professional. A therapist can offer guidance, support, and insights into why you might be feeling the way you do and can help you develop effective strategies for managing your thoughts and emotions.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when you need it. And remember that your feelings don't define your worth. You are valuable and deserving of happiness and fulfillment, regardless of what your thoughts might tell you.

Well, it's generally okay to feel anxious or nervous about going into therapy, particularly in the beginning because the process of being open about what you are going through, much less to someone who you don't know well, can be anxiety-producing. It's also common to feel anxious when you are discussing something that is important, difficult to discuss, or you are making changes that are very difficult for you.The most important thing I can tell you, though, is to discuss with your therapist this idea that you feel nervous and shaky. Some anxiety can actually help to motivate or lead you toward change. There are also level of anxiety that can be counterproductive, so it's a good thing to discuss. Personally, I can tell you that I would want my clients to tell me about anxiety they feel 100% of the time. That opens the dialog to discuss whether it is the level of anxiety that they want to sit with and learn about in discovering more about themselves and their experiences and/or whether they would like to do something to lessen the feeling of anxiety.Thanks for writing here. If it caused anxiety for you to do so, I hope that feeling is diminishing for you, at least related to writing here.

Human attractions can be tricky things, and in this case - a power dynamic. In the workplace, a boss usually has the power to hire, fire, set schedules, approve vacations, and evaluate performance. Because of this power dynamic, most employee handbooks expressly forbid supervisors and their direct employees being in a romantic relationship. Perhaps you should check your employee handbook.  It is possible that if you or your supervisor act on your feelings, one of you might have to be reassigned, or if no reassignment is available, asked to resign. While you may be attracted to your boss, and your feelings may be strong, it might be in your best interests to resist acting upon them.

Hi there. Being 15 years old can be a very difficult time in your teenage life. I remember when I was 15 and how I often felt my parents weren’t listening to me. It’s even more difficult when you feel that you do not have a friend that you can confide in. Having depression in the past and being able to get through it shows me that you can get through anything! Depression alone is a very difficult problem to work through. In addition to the communication problem with your parents, it appears that you are also struggling with stress and anxiety. We all have stress and anxiety in our lives. If we didn’t, none of us would be living. Anxiety & stress keep us on our toes! Often, I have to remind myself of this as well. However, it is how we manage stress and anxiety, so it will not overcome our lives. Are you familiar with relaxation techniques, such as: deep breathing exercises, meditation or yoga? Relaxation Techniques can help you tremendously in reducing your stress and anxiety. Deep breathing exercises are helpful when you are on the go, such as school, shopping, out with friends or whatever extracurricular activities you engage in. Most people do not take full advantage of their lung capacity. I know, that sounds silly. But, it’s true. You would be surprised how much air you lungs can hold. Imagine being in the Doctor’s office and taking deep breaths. This is what you want to do when you are feeling overwhelmed and/or stressed. Take a moment to take in at least 10 deep breaths and let them out slowly. You will be surprised how well you feel afterwards. Meditation and Yoga are also healthy forms to working through stress and anxiety. You will need a quiet place for your meditation. You want to be “in the moment” and take in the peace and serenity. All it takes is a quiet place, closing your eyes and thinking of your “happy place.” Some people use meditation music as well. If you have access to this type of music and or the internet for more ways to practice meditation, please go for it! Yoga on the other hand will take a little more work and practice. I would not suggest you learning this on your own, if you have never attempted yoga before. Find an experienced Yoga instructor to teach you the ropes and/or ask your school counselor about the possibility of getting someone to come to the school to teach the students. Lastly, in regards to your parents it is very important to be able to have a relationship where you feel comfortable communicating. I would recommend writing a letter to them, if you are unable to express how you feel in person. A letter is more intimate and requires a little more effort on their end. If they are open on working on this relationship, maybe suggest family counseling to fully work on this issue. I hope this was helpful for you and I wish you the best!

I understand that your past experiences have left you feeling self-conscious and unattractive, and that these feelings are affecting your self-esteem and your engagement experiences. It's important to recognize that these negative feelings are not a reflection of your true worth. In therapy, we can explore the root causes of these feelings and work together to challenge the thought patterns that contribute to them. We may also explore techniques to help you build a more positive self-image and learn to celebrate your unique qualities. If you're interested, I can help you find healthier ways to cope with these emotions and build a stronger self-concept.

You'll know you have the right therapist when after the first few sessions you feel comfortable enough to tell them things you wouldn't tell anyone else. It's important in therapy for that rapport to be built from the beginning and that you as the client feel comfortable enough to share what you need to share. You shouldn't feel judgement from your therapist and you should be able to trust the advice your therapist provides. Therapy isn't about advice, don't get me wrong, but to truly implement the changes that need to be implemented to improve your life you need to trust the person giving the advice. Your therapist should have your best interest at heart and truly listen to what you have to say. The therapist should be willing to meet you where you are in your world and attempt to see the world from your perspective to truly understand what you have been through. You need to feel comfortable in therapy to be yourself and say what's on your mind. Therapy shouldn't be something that should be dreaded but it can get uncomfortable depending on the depth of the things being discussed.

I understand that your past experiences have left you feeling traumatized and wary of trusting women again. It's natural to feel hesitant and cautious after being hurt in the past. However, it's important to recognize that not all women are like the one who caused you pain. Trust is built over time through honesty, reliability, and consistency. It can be helpful to set clear boundaries in new relationships and communicate openly about your fears and past experiences. If someone makes false claims or attempts to manipulate or control you, it's important to prioritize your own safety and well-being and consider ending the relationship. Additionally, seeking therapy can help you process your past experiences, learn healthy relationship dynamics, and develop new coping skills. Remember, it's okay to take things slow and only engage with people when you're ready.

I understand the situation you're in, and it can be challenging when there's a mismatch in sexual desire between partners, especially when it's coupled with feelings of guilt and inadequacy. The fact that you both love each other and are open about your concerns is a positive sign, as it shows that you're willing to work through this issue together.

It's worth noting that low libido and difficulty reaching orgasm are common experiences for women, and they can be influenced by a range of factors, including hormonal changes, stress, emotional issues, and lack of sexual pleasure or intimacy. In your wife's case, it might be a good idea to explore any potential underlying issues that could be contributing to her low desire and inability to orgasm.

One approach could be to seek out the help of a therapist or sex therapist who specializes in these issues. They can help you and your wife identify any underlying emotional or relational issues, and develop strategies for enhancing your sexual connection and improving communication around sexual needs and desires.

Another important step would be for both of you to prioritize creating a sexually safe and supportive environment. This could involve setting aside dedicated time for intimacy, creating a comfortable and private space for sex, and finding out what works best for both of you in terms of sexual activities and techniques.

In the meantime, it might be helpful for you to express your own feelings and concerns in a non-judgmental and understanding way, and to encourage and support your wife in exploring her own needs and desires. Avoid making assumptions or judgments, and instead focus on finding solutions that work for both of you. Remember, sexual connection and pleasure are complex experiences, and it's normal for couples to have ups and downs throughout their lives.

I hope this information is helpful, and I wish you both all the best in your journey towards enhancing your sexual relationship and deepening your connection as a couple. Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.

Let's just start with acknowledging that trust is huge and betrayal hurts. You're entitled to your feelings; all of them and you need to know that your husband understands you. That said some ways are more effective at rebuilding and repairing relationships that others. I am a big fan of The Gottman Method for couples therapy, especially following infedienity. You can read about this approach in Gottman's books: "The Science of Trust" and "Making Love Last" and/or you can seek a Gottman Certified couples therapist here: https://www.gottman.com/private-therapy/

Hi, and thanks for your question. I agree with my colleagues about researching asexuality, but I want too add a couple of things about that:Here is a website that you can start with to get some information about asexuality - http://www.asexuality.org/home/There are a whole lot of myths surrounding asexuality. One is that people who are asexual have absolutely no interest in sex, and that is not always the case. There are variations of asexuality. Some people who are asexual have an interest in sex and others don't. Also, once you read more on this topic, you may find that you don't connect with asexuality either, and that is okay. Our society usually thinks of sexual orientations as only being straight, gay, lesbian, or bisexual, but the truth is there are many variations of sexual orientations. Keep exploring. There is a good chance that there is a community of people who feel like you do. Finally, labels are important for a lot of things, but labeling ourselves can sometimes lead to some painful feelings. Try not to feel pressured to label yourself too quickly. This is your journey. Your experience. Take all the time you need. You may never feel the need to label how you feel, and that is okay, too. Hope this helps. Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

The dilemmas you present are giving you a great chance to understand your true reasons for being in a relationship.Continue developing some points you've written here.That you grew up sensing and/or witnessing your mom's emotional pain from your dad cheating on her, very likely set a standard in your inner self, to expect similar circumstances in your relationship life.This is a natural dynamic which happens for all of us.  What we observe in our growing up households is what we understand as "normal", no matter how bad it actually is.After all, children don't have the ability to separate that what their own parents do, is wrong compared with the rest of our culture.It is natural to long for a relationship.What you have the chance to do now, is distinguish the reasons for your longing.Is it to attach to someone who has hurt you, hasn't shown you any understanding of having hurt you, and whose validation, even if he says validating words, has little meaning because people who validate are not the ones who harm us?If you're able to teach yourself that those who love us do not harm us, and to develop new expectations for yourself of feeling good from how your partner treats you, then you will be showing yourself a road that will benefit you for your entire lifetime.

I understand that your father's behavior can be frustrating and invalidating, especially when it comes to your anxieties and feelings. It's important to remember that everyone has the right to their own perspective and it's okay to feel the way you do. However, it can be challenging when those feelings are consistently dismissed or disregarded, especially by someone as influential as your father.

From a psychological perspective, it's important to focus on what you can control in this situation. While you may not be able to change your father's behavior or attitude towards your anxieties, you can work on building your self-confidence and self-esteem. This may involve seeking out alternative sources of validation and support, such as therapy or supportive friendships. It's also important to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that your feelings and concerns are valid, even if they may not be acknowledged by others.

In terms of the more specific issues you mentioned, such as body image and self-confidence, you may find it helpful to explore these issues further in therapy or through self-help resources. It can be especially challenging to navigate these concerns when they are compounded by feelings of invalidation and pressure from others.

At the same time, it may be important to consider setting boundaries with your father and other family members around how you are discussed or treated. This may involve communicating your feelings and needs clearly, even if they are met with resistance or disbelief. It's important to remember that you have the right to be heard and respected, and that you deserve to be treated with kindness and understanding. While it may be difficult to change others' behaviors, focusing on your own self-care and self-validation can be an important first step.

It sounds like you are experiencing symptoms of depression. Depression can present itself in various ways, and it can affect a person's mood, energy levels, motivation, and social interactions. Feeling worthless, having little interest in things, sleep disturbances, and decreased energy are common symptoms of depression. It is important to note that depression is a complex condition that can have many contributing factors, and it is not a sign of weakness. I would encourage you to speak with a mental health professional for an assessment and to explore treatment options, such as therapy and medication. They can help you develop a plan to improve your mood and overall well-being. In the meantime, consider engaging in self-care activities to help boost your feelings of happiness and self-worth, such as exercise, healthy eating, getting enough sleep, practicing mindfulness or relaxation techniques, and reaching out to supportive loved ones or support groups.

Based on your description, it is possible that you may be experiencing symptoms of depression. However, I would recommend that you reach out to a mental health professional for an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan. Depression is a complex condition and can manifest differently from person to person. If you're feeling overwhelmed, isolated, or have thoughts of self-harm, it would be important to speak with a mental health professional as soon as possible. They can provide you with the support and resources you need to feel better. Remember, seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Yes, it is normal to experience some level of anxiety when attending therapy sessions, especially if it is a new experience for you. However, if your anxiety is preventing you from fully participating in therapy or causing significant distress outside of the sessions, it may be helpful to discuss this with your therapist. They may be able to offer strategies or adjustments to make the sessions more comfortable for you. Remember, therapy takes time and effort. It's important to give yourself credit for taking this step towards improving your mental health and keep an open mind.
Few people are actually 100% straight or 100% gay.  Sexual preference exists on a continuum. Over the course of many years a person's sexual preference may shift.

It sounds to me like you have had a lot going on and now you are afraid you are going to lose the last things you care about, your pets.  I do not know what all is going on in your family, and I cannot answer for your dad’s actions or his reasoning behind this.I would recommend that you focus on developing healthy coping skills.  We cannot change what others do but we can change how what they do affects us.  If you have all of your emotions and all of yourself tied up into one thing (like your pets) then when that thing is taken away it causes a lot of emotional distress.  It is really good to have a wide variety of interests such as friends, hobbies, games, etc.  Develop other things that you care about and are passionate about.Another reason for developing healthy coping skills to deal with whatever might be going on in your life is if you don’t have healthy ones, you may develop some very unhealthy ones.  You have to cope somehow, right?  Developing unhealthy ways of coping with life is only going to make life more difficult for you.I don’t know if this is what it is like for you at your house, but there are two kinds of household environments that can cause dysfunction in children. One is when you grow up in a very rigid stern household where all decisions are made for you and you feel like you have no control over anything. The other is a household where things were chaotic and you never knew what was going to happen next and had no stability. People need to have some stability in their lives and need to feel in control over some things in order to feel safe.  Both of these environments can lead you to develop some unhealthy ways of coping with life.  Please talk to a trusted adult about your feelings before it gets any worse.

It is absolutely normal to cry in therapy. Therapy is a place to be honest about and explore your feelings without feeling judged. Honesty is the only way you will benefit from therapy and that means being willing to look at your true emotions rather than avoiding them.

Hi there, Thank you for your question. It's absolutely ok to feel nervous going to therapy. I have experienced anxiety going to see my own therapist. There can be a few reasons why you might feel this way. First, it is always unnerving to see a person who is a stranger and to share intimate things with that stranger. You mentioned it has only been a couple of sessions. Your anxiety might subside as you continue to see your therapist and grow more comfortable with him/her. Another reason why you might feel particularly nervous is perhaps you are not comfortable sharing things. As children, we might have bad experiences opening up to others. Someone might bully or ridicule us, and that experience can stay with us for a long time, making it extra scary to share our intimate feelings and thoughts with others. If this the case, as you continue with your sessions and have positive interactions with your therapists, this anxiety will subside with time and you will re-learn that it is safe to share. And the last thought why you might feel the shakes is perhaps you know that you need to talk about some past experiences or memories that are uncomfortable and difficult. Regardless of the reason, it might help you to bring up your nervousness in your session and share how you feel with your therapist. Having an open dialogue about your anxiety with your therapist can help you resolve some of that anxiety and built greater trust with your therapist.

I am so sorry to hear of your boyfriend's passing. Grief is something that can take a long time to recover from. Have you considered speaking with a grief counselor? Being able to speak with someone that specializes in grief would be very beneficial. Do not get down on yourself for not recovering quickly. This is one of the hardest aspects to deal with in life but eventually you will be able to move forward. In the mean time, immerse yourself with positivity (i.e. Good friends, hobbies, exercise) and try to schedule a time with a counselor. Perhaps there will be a support group you could also join. Oftentimes, it is comforting to meet others who share the same experience as you.Good luck to you. I hope you will find peace and comfort soon.

I understand that you have strong needs for attention, companionship, and intimacy, and it can be challenging when these needs aren't being met. However, it's essential to respect your partner's physical limitations, such as her hysterectomy and bad knee, as well as her comfort level. Consider finding alternative ways to meet your needs, such as engaging in activities that don't put too much strain on her body, or seeking out other sources of companionship and attention, like friends or hobbies. Remember, healthy relationships are built on mutual respect and understanding. If you find it difficult to navigate these complex emotions and needs on your own, it might be helpful to seek guidance from a therapist or counselor.

It sounds as if your ex-girlfriend is trying to figure out what type of relationship she is looking to have with you. There are lots of levels of relationships, from a basic acquaintance, to a more friendly acquaintance, to a friend, close friend, best friend, early romantic partner, committed romantic partner, and many more.If she is willing to have a conversation with you about her feelings, it may be helpful to have her explain her feelings to you while listening as an investigative reporter and asking questions that cannot be answered with yes or no, but are what are called open-ended questions, which ask her to provide more information. During this process, it would be helpful for you to try to think of it as not being personal, but just listening and trying to understand the experience from her perspective. After you have done this for five minutes (it's a rough estimate, but basically until you can restate what she is saying and she says you have it right), you can switch so she is asking you questions about how you are feeling. The goal is not necessarily to change the outcome, but to learn more about yourselves and each other.Then you may have an idea of where you stand in each other's eyes.

I understand your frustration, Patient. It can be very challenging when the presence of a loved one's pet impacts your living environment negatively. It's crucial to remember that the dog is not the cause of the problem but rather the behavior. Your boyfriend may not be aware of the extent of the destruction caused by his pet when he's not around.

Here are some suggestions for you:

1. Have a calm and open conversation with your boyfriend about the situation. Tell him how the dog's behavior affects you and your living situation. Emphasize that you're bringing it up as a concern, not an accusation.
2. If possible, enroll the dog in a behavioral training program to address the destructive behavior and house training issues. Provide your boyfriend with resources and information about these programs.
3. Implement routine walks and potty breaks to establish a regular schedule for the dog. This routine can help reduce accidents in the house.
4. Crate train your boyfriend's dog, which can help prevent them from destroying items when they're unsupervised in the house.
5. If your boyfriend can't or won't resolve the issue, you might need to consider other options, such as rehoming the dog with someone who can provide them with a more suitable living environment or finding a local farm or ranch that would benefit from having a large dog.

Remember that it's essential to communicate openly and effectively about your concerns with your boyfriend. It may take some time, but by working together to find a solution that benefits everyone involved, you can hopefully find a happy resolution for both your relationship and your home.

Sure, I'd be glad to help clarify this from a therapist's perspective. In psychology, we use theory and research to help us understand the complex nature of personality. One widely used framework for understanding personality is called the Five-Factor Model. This model includes five broad dimensions, or traits, that are believed to underlie much of what we see as personality variation:

1. Openness to Experience: This trait includes characteristics such as imagination, insight, and a preference for novelty and variety.
2. Conscientiousness: This trait includes characteristics such as being organized, reliable, and goal-oriented.
3. Extraversion: This trait includes characteristics such as being sociable, outgoing, and energized by the outside world.
4. Agreeableness: This trait includes characteristics such as being friendly, compassionate, and empathetic.
5. Neuroticism: This trait includes characteristics such as emotional instability, anxiety, and moodiness.

When working with a client, a therapist will observe their behavior, interactions, thoughts, and feelings, as well as take into account information from interviews, self-report questionnaires, and other sources, to help assess their personality. The therapist may consider the presence and intensity of characteristics related to each of the five personality traits to help understand the client's unique personality profile.

Please note, however, that personality is complex and multifaceted. No single assessment method provides a complete understanding of a person. And personality is not a fixed trait; it can change and develop over time. Consulting a mental health professional for a thorough assessment and diagnosis is always recommended.

I understand that this situation is concerning for you and your adolescent son. The behavior you're describing, also known as enuresis or bedwetting, can be a sign of various underlying causes, including developmental, psychological, or physiological factors.

It's important to note that punishing your son for this behavior may not be effective in the long run, as it does not address the underlying causes. Instead, I would recommend considering a more empathetic and supportive approach.

First, it's essential to rule out any medical conditions that may be contributing to the enuresis, such as a urinary tract infection or constipation. A visit to a healthcare professional, such as a pediatrician, may be helpful in this regard.

If a medical cause is ruled out, it may be beneficial to use techniques geared towards behavior modification, such as bladder training or the implementation of a rewards system for going long periods without an accident. Additionally, there are various interventions and therapies, like cognitive-behavioral therapy, that can help your son learn strategies to manage and eventually overcome this challenge.

Remember, progress can take time and patience, and setbacks are common in this process. It's important to provide a supportive and understanding environment throughout this journey.

Should you have any further questions or concerns, please feel free to ask.

I'm sorry to hear of your problem.First step as always when a possible medical explanation exists, go for a urology check up to either your internist or a urologist.Once you know there is no medical reason which would prevent an erection, then we can consider the psychological and emotion based factors.Maybe you're nervous about your sexual performance or that your gf may be disappointed in your performance.Men often mistake their own fears of performance failure with the assumption that their partner thinks about sex as a performance.Talk with your gf about whatever is on your mind which may inhibit you from enjoying sex.The reasons are endless.What matters is to have a heartfelt dialogue with each other.The emotional support which comes through such an intimate conversation may very well be the catalyst for a more relaxed and satisfying approach to sex w your gf.

I understand that you're going through a challenging time, and it's important to prioritize your mental health and well-being. Here are some suggestions:

1. Seek support from trustworthy sources: Reach out to mental health professionals, support groups, or organizations that specialize in gender identity issues. They can provide you with resources, information, and guidance.
2. Self-care and coping mechanisms: Focus on activities that help you manage stress, improve your mood, and promote a positive self-image. Meditation, mindfulness, exercise, arts, and creative pursuits are excellent options.
3. Create a safe and accepting environment: Surround yourself with individuals who accept and support you. You can confide in close friends, or make new connections in supportive communities.
4. Consider starting hormone therapy and/or gender-affirming medical procedures: With the guidance of a healthcare professional, you can explore the option of medical interventions to bring your body more in alignment with your gender identity.
5. Prepare strategies for potential confrontations: Consider potential ways to respond to confrontations with family members or others who may not accept your gender identity. You can assert your identity in a firm but respectful manner, or set limits on conversations that are hurtful or invalidating.

It's crucial to remember that your identity is valid, and you deserve respect and acceptance. Take things one step at a time, and continue seeking support and information from trusted resources. Good luck, and know that there are people who care about you and want to support you on your journey.
I offer that getting a professional assessment is in order to look at your relationship with alcohol.

Hi there Mom! Just look at all of the things that a teen has to juggle and it's no surprise they're stress out. There are simply not enough minutes in the day to get everything done.  So, they react by cutting into important times such as social interaction and sleep.  Our fast paced, fast food, society is taking its toll on our teen generation. While multi-tasking seems to be a hot pop word, it simply doesn't work.  We aren't wired to do our best at multiple things at once.  We are not machines but rather humans who are going to quickly expire if we don't get a handle on our stress.As adults, it's time we intervene and teach our teens how to maintain a healthy balance between work and play.  We need to help them prioritize and put first things, first.  Are you putting first things, first in your life?  If not, it's a good time to start. Best of luck to you and your daughter in whatever you decide to do.

I understand your concerns, and it's important that you reach out for help. Expressing anger through physical violence is unsafe and damaging to relationships. Given your history of unresolved emotions and recent escalation, it's crucial for you to begin therapy as soon as possible. Cognitive-behavioral therapy and anger management techniques can be particularly effective. I also recommend reaching out to organizations that specialize in domestic violence prevention and support for victims. Remember, it's essential to address these issues before they irreparably damage your relationship and potentially harm your partner. Starting the counseling process involves several steps. First, you recognize that you need support and are willing to make a change. Next, you can contact your healthcare provider or a mental health professional directly to schedule an initial appointment. During this session, you'll discuss your concerns, goals, and expectations for counseling. It's essential to be open and honest with your therapist, as building a strong therapeutic relationship is crucial for a successful counseling experience.

I understand that you have a complicated situation here, and I will do my best to provide you with some perspective as a psychologist.

Firstly, it's essential to recognize that relationships can take many forms, and the nature of your friendship with your ex doesn't necessarily mean that you've done something wrong in your current relationship. However, open communication and honesty are crucial in any relationship, including friendships.

It's understandable that spending time with an ex can be perceived as betrayal or infidelity by a current partner. It's important to discuss such situations with your boyfriend and express to him the nature of your relationship with your ex. Maintain transparency and assure him that there's nothing romantic or inappropriate.

Reassure him that your focus is on your current relationship and that there's no negative energy or attachment left from past experiences. Remember, it's essential to maintain trust and respect within any relationship, and open communication can help strengthen that bond.

Overall, the key takeaway is maintaining open and honest communication with your boyfriend about spending time with your ex, acknowledging his concerns, and rebuilding trust through transparency.

As a psychologist, I cannot provide a definitive answer without knowing the specific employment laws in your location. However, generally speaking, an employer cannot force you to see a therapist of their choice against your will. Employers can only require employees to undergo a medical examination when it is job-related and consistent with business necessity. In the case of your coworkers' allegations, if they rise to the level of creating a hostile work environment or affecting your ability to perform your job duties, then you may want to consider speaking with a human resources representative or consulting an employment lawyer for guidance. If mental health concerns are impacting your work, I would recommend seeking mental health treatment voluntarily as a beneficial step for your overall wellbeing. Confidentiality and options for affordable or covered therapy can be discussed with your healthcare provider and/or insurance company.

When it comes to trauma, especially in the event that it has caused you to develop PTSD, there can be a lot of difficulty in attempting to resolve these issues on your own simply because of how strong your urge to avoid it whenever thoughts of the traumatic experience come up. PTSD is best treated with the help of a mental health professional and if using the Cognitive Processing Approach can be treated in as few as 17 weeks. As for your other concerns, many of these can be treated independently if you have the motivation to manage your way through. Panic attacks and depression, specifically, often respond well to self-help treatment manuals. The Centre for Clinical Interventions is a great online resource for workbooks to help you learn to manage the depression and panic attacks. Whether you decide to work through these concerns on your own or in professional therapy, just know that your panic attacks must be managed prior to addressing your trauma. Hope this is helpful and if you have any other questions don't hesitate to ask.
