I'm glad to hear that you were able to make a decision that was best for you. Healing from the end of a relationship, especially one that was particularly challenging, can take time. Nightmares and flashbacks are common symptoms of post-traumatic stress and can hinder your current relationship.

Firstly, it's important to establish a bedtime routine that promotes relaxation. This can include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in a calming hobby like knitting or journaling.

Secondly, consider seeking professional help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with coping mechanisms and cognitive behavioral techniques to process your negative emotions and improve your overall mental wellbeing.

Finally, if your relationship is causing stress or triggering your flashbacks, consider setting clear boundaries and communicating openly with your partner about your feelings and needs. It's essential to create a safe and supportive environment where you feel comfortable sharing your emotions and asking for help when you need it. If your partner is unwilling or unable to provide you with this kind of support, it may be necessary to reconsider the relationship.

I understand your predicament, and it's essential to communicate openly and honestly with your girlfriend about this situation. Here are some steps you can take:

1. Set up a calm and private conversation: Find a time and place where you can talk to your girlfriend without interruptions and distractions.
2. Share your feelings and concerns: Explain to her how the other woman's behavior made you feel uncomfortable and why you decided to distance yourself from her. Be specific about what she did that made you uneasy and how it affected you.
3. Be transparent: Provide evidence if possible, such as text messages or emails from the woman that make you feel uneasy. However, ensure that you're not sharing anything that violates her privacy or trust.
4. Listen actively: Allow your girlfriend to express her concerns and feelings about the situation. Try not to become defensive or dismissive, and show that you value and respect her perspective.
5. Work together on a solution: Brainstorm ways to address any misunderstandings and build trust. This might include rebuilding transparency in your relationship or finding ways to reassure her that there is nothing going on with the other woman.

Remember, open and honest communication is key to a healthy and strong relationship. Good luck!

Attention is often something that is both wanted and sometimes not wanted all the time. Maybe when you're in a relationship with someone you can discuss the amount of attention that you are both comfortable with and/or what you are both looking for as far as amount of connection.

I suggest that you work on emotional awareness. Emotional awareness basically means knowing what you are feeling and why.Emotional awareness also means that you can identify the link between the way you are feeling and your actions. In other words knowing that your feelings dictate what you do.Often feelings of hurt or insecurity can come out as anger if we cannot properly identify and express the feelings.Being emotionally aware also means that you are able to express your feelings to others. Being unable to do so leads to feelings of frustration and being misunderstood.Many people for many different reasons are not in touch with their emotions. For example, men traditionally have been brought up taught to not express sadness or weakness. Therefore, many men learned to turn feelings of sadness, insecurities, or fears into anger and express these feelings as anger. Being taught not to feel a certain emotion does not make that emotion disappear. Instead it makes us learn how to express it in other, incorrect, ways. If a man never learns to say “I am sad” or “that really hurt my feelings” and instead lashes out in anger, then the response they get from those around them will be to the anger and not a response to the underlying true feeling, which will leave the man feeling alone and misunderstood.You can control yourself and not explode. Walk away, remove yourself from the situation, do whatever you have to do to not lash out. Instead of reacting the way you normally would, go somewhere by yourself and think about what just happened and try to understand why such a “simple” thing upset you. What is the real feeling driving these outbursts? Maybe you can begin to recognize an underlying pattern. It might help to keep an anger journal. Write down everything that gets you upset. That might help you see a pattern and pinpoint what may be setting you off. Talking with a therapist about this would be beneficial in helping pinpoint the underlying cause of the outbursts you are experience.

Thank you for sharing your question.  I imagine it feels overwhelming and discouraging at times if you feel like there are too many issues to address in a counseling session.  I would encourage you to share these concerns with a counselor because a counselor can help you organize the concerns into a list of specific goals.  For example, a list of goals may look similar to this:1.  "I will learn about the effects of medication on the symptoms of depression and anxiety."2.  "I will learn about the factors that affect insomnia."3.  "I will learn about resources and support groups in my local area to help me cope with my traumatic experiences."4.  "I will practice self-care exercises each day and write about my thoughts and feelings in a journal so I can measure whether or not I"m making progress."This is an example of some of the possible goals a counselor can help you work toward each week.  Working toward a specific goal can lead to a feeling of accomplishment once you've completed it, and this may have a positive impact on your self-esteem.  I hope this information helps, and I wish you all the best!

Hello, I am sorry to hear about you feeling verbally abused, trapped without an escape, and emotionally drained. Sounds to me like you are being treated more like a child than an adult.  It's time to learn about healthy boundaries and being treated like an adult. This process will take time, but beyond elevating your self-esteem and worth, you will be modeling to your children a healthy adult. Model to them an empowered, confident, and person that is worthy of respect. Please invest in yourself. Find yourself a therapist that encourages and empowers you to have a voice and not feel invisible. You'll be so glad you did!

I will not say that you can't but I will say it will be much harder and the time may take much longer.  Getting help and having someone to be there with you through the ups and down of PTSD makes the journey much easier.

I'm sorry to hear that you've been feeling this way after the departure of your close friends. It takes time to adjust to such big changes, and it's natural to feel lonely and perhaps even experience some depressive symptoms.

Here are some suggestions for making new friends, despite the challenges:

1. Explore new social activities: Try new hobbies, classes, or clubs that you've always wanted to join but didn't have time for before. This can be a great way to meet like-minded individuals who share similar interests.

2. Utilize technology: Use social media and other online platforms to connect with others. There are many groups and communities based on various interests and geographic locations. Engaging in online interactions can be a good stepping stone towards developing in-person relationships.

3. Attend events in your community: This could be anything from a local festival, a neighborhood meeting, or a charity event. These events provide ample opportunities to meet new people.

4. Volunteer: Volunteering for a cause that you care about is an excellent way to meet new people while making a positive impact. Plus, it's a meaningful activity that can help improve your mood and sense of connection.

5. Reach out to family and colleagues: Sometimes, the people closest to us can offer a listening ear and help introduce us to their own networks. Don't hesitate to reach out and ask for their support.

Lastly, I strongly encourage you to prioritize self-care and consider seeking professional help if your feelings of sadness or loneliness persist, as it sounds like you might be experiencing more than just transient feelings – it could be the manifestation of clinical depression. A mental health professional can help assess your situation and provide effective coping strategies or recommend treatment if necessary.

I understand that you are feeling neglected and unappreciated in your relationship with your husband. His continuous working hours and lack of time for family activities are causing significant stress in your lives. This is a common issue for many couples, especially in today's fast-paced world.

It's essential to have a healthy work-life balance to maintain a happy and healthy relationship. I would suggest initiating a conversation with your husband about this issue. Let him know how you feel about his absence and the impact it has on your family life. Be specific about your needs and request a compromise that could better balance his work and family commitments.

Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Set aside time for family activities and date nights, even if it means organizing a babysitter or rearranging schedules.
2. Encourage him to take breaks throughout the day to manage his workload and stress levels.
3. Suggest that he delegates tasks or outsources them to colleagues or other team members to lighten his workload.
4. Be supportive of his work goals, while also making it clear that your family needs also need to be a priority.
5. If things don't improve, consider seeking the help of a family therapist or counselor.

Remember, communication and compromise are key to maintaining a healthy and balanced family life.

I understand how you feel, and I assure you that it is not uncommon for women in your situation to experience feelings of identity loss and dissatisfaction. It's important to recognize that being a mom and wife are valuable roles, but they don't define you as a person in their entirety.

Consider exploring your personal interests and hobbies outside of your family. Reconnecting with these activities can help you rediscover a sense of independence and personal fulfillment. It may also help to set aside time for self-care and self-reflection.

Remember, feeling unhappy or trapped does not mean that you are a bad mother or wife, and it's essential to learn to accept and deal with these emotions without self-loathing. You deserve to be happy, and pursuing your own interests and personal growth is an essential aspect of achieving that happiness.

You might find it helpful to speak with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, to work through these emotions and develop strategies for coping with feelings of identity loss and dissatisfaction.

I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I can't provide a definitive answer in just this one conversation. It's important to recognize that feeling worthless is often a symptom of deeper emotional issues, and it takes time and effort to work through these feelings.

First, it's crucial that you take care of yourself, physically and emotionally. Get enough rest, eat well, and engage in activities that bring you joy. Reach out to loved ones, friends, or community resources for support.

Consider seeking help from a professional, such as a psychologist, therapist, or counselor. They can provide you with effective strategies and tools to help you challenge your negative self-talk and reframe your thoughts. Through therapy, you can learn valuable coping skills to manage your emotions more effectively and develop a stronger sense of self-worth.

Lastly, remember that self-worth isn't something you can "fix" or "achieve" overnight. It's an ongoing process, and it's okay to make mistakes and stumble along the way. Keep pushing forward, take small steps towards your goals, and don't give up on yourself. You deserve love, validation, and respect, regardless of what your mind tells you.

I understand how difficult it can be to trust your boyfriend after he revealed that he cheated on you during your relationship. This is a normal reaction given the circumstances. Trust is a crucial aspect of any relationship, and its absence can lead to feelings of insecurity, jealousy, and even resentment. However, it's important to note that rebuilding trust takes time, effort, and commitment from both parties. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Communication: Open and honest communication is essential for rebuilding trust. This means discussing your feelings of mistrust and your concerns with your boyfriend. It's also important for him to acknowledge his past mistake and reassure you of his commitment to being faithful in the future.

2. Consistency: Consistency is key when it comes to demonstrating trustworthiness. Your boyfriend can show you that he is committed to being faithful through consistent actions that highlight his dedication to the relationship. This could include being transparent about his activities, being reliable in his commitments, and actively working to build trust.

3. Patience: Rebuilding trust takes time, so be patient with yourself and your boyfriend. Trust isn't something that can be regained overnight, and it's important to remember that setbacks are normal. Stay focused on the progress that you've made and the efforts that your boyfriend is making to rebuild trust.

4. Seek outside help: If you're struggling to move past your relationship difficulties, consider seeking outside help from a trusted therapist or counselor. A mental health professional can provide you with tools and resources to help you work through your emotions and develop healthy coping strategies.

5. Take things one step at a time: Focus on the present moment and take things one step at a time. Remember that trust is a process, and it's important to build it incrementally. Each day, take stock of the small victories that you and your boyfriend have made towards rebuilding trust, and use these successes to fuel your continued growth.

Overall, rebuilding trust in a relationship after an infidelity can be a challenging but rewarding process. By focusing on communication, consistency, patience, seeking outside help if needed, and taking things one step at a time, you and your boyfriend can work towards rebuilding a strong foundation of trust and commitment in your relationship.

I understand your concern, Patient. Effective communication in a relationship relies on both parties actively listening to each other. Here are some strategies that might help your husband become a more attentive listener:

1. Practice "I" statements: Instead of starting sentences with "you never" or "you always," express feelings and thoughts with "I" statements. For example, "I feel unheard when you're speaking, and it makes me sad."

2. Set aside undisturbed time: Allow yourselves some uninterrupted time for conversation, turning off electronic devices and other distractions.

3. Validate his emotions: When your husband speaks, show that you appreciate his thoughts and feelings. Use phrases like "That sounds really difficult," or "I understand why you would feel that way."

4. Be specific: Use clear and specific language, focusing on facts rather than generalizations. Provide examples to help better illustrate your thoughts and feelings.

5. Reflective listening: Show empathy and make an effort to understand your husband's perspective. Paraphrase and summarize what he says to make sure you have a good understanding of his point of view.

6. Discuss the importance of active listening: Share with your husband the impact it has on your relationship when you both actively listen to each other.

7. Nonverbal communication: Make eye contact, nod occasionally, and use appropriate facial expressions. This will help your husband feel engaged and understood.

8. Be open to change: Remember that communication is an ongoing process and requires both parties to make an effort. If you have tried these strategies and seen no change, consider seeking help from a couple's therapist or relationship counselor.

Finally, practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, can help reduce stress and anxiety around time management. Does that make sense to you? If you have any questions or would like to explore this further, feel free to ask.

Answers about our inner lives are most successfully reached from a sense of feeling grounded in oneself.First step is to accept your nervousness and restless sleep.  As often as possible, sleep during daytimes in order for your body to catch up on its need for rest.Accept too about feeling down.  It is normal to feel down once in a while.  From this place of self-acceptance, trust any answers which come up to your mind.  Often answers about complicated topics come in small pieces, not all at once as a whole unit.Also, your description about panic attacks is also completely normal.   They often arise unrelated to particular conditions at a given moment.  They are a healthy symptom your body is trying to expel bad feelings and does this by having the anxiety erupt at times.So, self-acceptance, tolerance of being on a process of clearing out worn out emotional clutter, and sleep at odd times if possible, are all ways to stabilize yourself, which will also feel calm and good!

Hello. You are asking a very good question about how to sustain a long-distance relationship. Although maintaining a long-distance relationship has its challenges, with the proper communication, commitment, and understanding, many long-distance couples are able to thrive and maintain a close connection. Without knowing more about the "complicated" nature of your relationship, I wonder whether your boyfriend has given you reason not to trust him that makes afraid that he will find someone else. Has he cheated on you in the past and has shown romantic interest to another person that made you fear losing him?  Or, is your thought just a fear but not based on evidence? Knowing that distinction is important because if it is the latter, you may benefit from refocusing on the wonderful qualities about your partner that makes you feel good about him and the relationship rather than focusing on the unknown or uncertainty of the future. The more you focus on "what if" situations, the more you may feel anxious about a reality that is not accurate and make you act in ways that are insecure. However, if there is reason for you to question his fidelity, you may have to speak to your boyfriend about how to build trust in the context of a long-distance relationship. To help the conversation, you may need to consider what you may need to experience or receive as support to feel safe in the relationship to build trust. Is that you wish him to contact you regularly, or to include you more in his life, or to make a clear commitment? For many of my clients in my private practice, that may include talking to their partner often and using a variety of modalities including text, phone, and Skype. It's hard to believe in a relationship when you never talk to your partner, and it's hard to build a relationship when you don't know what's going on in your partner's life. Other times, it is Making sure they talk often to their long-distance partner so that they can participate in each others lives and to feel their presence.. Regular communication, understanding and caring is the key to sustaining any relationship, but this is especially true for long-distance ones. Dr. Virginia Chowwww.PsychologyResource.ca

I'm so sorry to hear about the traumatic experience you went through. It's common for survivors of sexual assault to have negative feelings about their bodies and to struggle with intimacy. However, it's important to remember that sex should be a consensual and enjoyable experience for both partners. The use of lingerie as a tool to increase arousal can be a healthy part of a relationship for some people. However, if it's not something you feel comfortable with or if it's causing distress, it may be helpful to explore other ways to connect with your partner and build intimacy. Therapy, such as trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, can also be helpful in processing the trauma and working through these feelings. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about?

I understand that you're feeling conflicted and unsure about your therapist's actions towards you. It is important to recognize that therapists should maintain clear boundaries in the therapeutic relationship to ensure safety and trust. This includes not entering into friendships or financial relationships with their clients.

Given your situation, I would recommend that you speak with the therapy board or ethics committee of your therapist's professional organization. They may be able to provide guidance on how to proceed and report any ethical concerns. Additionally, you may wish to find a new therapist, especially one who will adhere to professional ethical standards. Your safety and well-being in therapy are paramount.

Furthermore, it's essential for you to seek support during this time. Reach out to trusted family members, friends, or a support group to discuss your feelings and gain validation during this difficult situation. If you need help finding these resources, your primary care physician, medical personnel, or the mental health department at a local hospital may be able to direct you to appropriate organizations or professionals.

I'm sorry to hear that you have been experiencing increased anger and that it's impacting your daily life, especially with your young children present. The dynamic of a relationship can sometimes affect our emotions and behaviors, as you've noticed with your partner's moods affecting yours. It's important to recognize this and take steps to manage your anger in healthy ways.

First, it's crucial to identify the triggers that elicit your anger, as well as any underlying emotions, such as stress, anxiety, or frustration. Once you're aware of these triggers, try practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation, to help de-escalate and calm your body when you start to feel angry. Furthermore, it's essential to communicate effectively and assertively in your relationships, rather than resorting to yelling. This could involve expressing how you feel in a calm and respectful manner and actively listening to your partner's perspective.

Additionally, considering seeking support from a mental health professional, such as a therapist, who can provide you with additional skills and strategies to manage your anger effectively and help you regain your prior self.

Lastly, practice self-care regularly by engaging in activities that you enjoy and find relaxation and calmness from, such as reading, painting, or taking a warm bath. Remember, it takes time and effort to change, but with the right tools and support, you can overcome these challenges and create a healthier, more balanced emotional response for yourself and your children.

It depends on the specific circumstances of your relationship and dynamic. In general, communication and mutual respect are important in a healthy relationship. I understand that seeing your partner text frequently with a coworker can be concerning. It's important to approach this situation with openness and honesty. Here's how you could ask him about it:

First, consider choosing a time and place where you both can have a private, uninterrupted conversation. You may want to start by sharing your feelings and concerns with him, expressing how seeing the texts made you feel. Be sure to avoid accusatory language and express your thoughts as your own observations, focusing on how the situation has affected you.

Next, ask him questions to better understand the nature of his texts with the female coworker. You could ask him about the content of their messages, how often they text, and if there's anything in particular that has you concerned. Listen actively to his response and seek to understand his perspective.

Remember to maintain a calm and nonjudgmental tone throughout the conversation. Avoid jumping to conclusions or making assumptions based on the information you have, and instead focus on the facts and your feelings. Allow him the opportunity to provide explanations and reassure you of the nature of their relationship.

Finally, establish a clear and agreed-upon plan moving forward. This could include setting boundaries, such as limiting texting during certain hours, or implementing transparency measures like allowing each other to view each other's phones periodically. Ultimately, the goal is to rebuild trust and find a solution that works for both of you.

Please note that this is just one approach and may not be suitable for everyone. If you find that the conversation does not provide the answers or closurity you were seeking, it could be beneficial to involve a therapist to help you work through these emotions and navigate future conversations with your partner.

Hi there! It sounds like you have already started to answer
your own question by stating that you love cross dressing very much, and I am
glad you enjoy it! Cross dressing is something many people enjoy, and there is
no harm in it whatsoever. My question to you would be: What is making you feel torn
about it? There is unfortunately still a lot of negative stigma associated with
people who express their gender or sexuality in ways that differ from the
majority. (And sometimes certain sexual interests are actually very common or
even in the majority, but because people carry shame about being different when
it comes to gender and sexuality we assume we are all alone!)Being a sexual or gender minority or someone who
participates in kink or expresses their sexuality or gender identity in a
unique and personal way often means suffering from something called
"internalized oppression". We grow up being exposed to certain
assumptions and beliefs about what is "acceptable" behavior and even
face consequences sometimes if we don't "fit in" the way others tell
us to. Even if those assumptions are harmful and wrong, we still internalize
them and feel guilty about who we are. There is nothing wrong with us, but
feeling stigmatized and isolated can lead to feelings of shame, embarrassment,
or like something is "wrong" with us.But there is absolutely nothing wrong with you, so be proud
of who you are and what you enjoy. You can continue to simply enjoy it
privately, or maybe you'd eventually like to share it with a partner or maybe
even join a community with similar interests. I'll leave you with a quote from
comedian Eddie Izzard, who identifies as, in his own words, a "straight
transvestite": "They’re not women’s clothes. They’re my clothes. I
bought them!" Take care, and thanks for your question!

As a counselor, I make the decision to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client based on several factors. These factors may include the client's progress toward their goals, their readiness to continue their personal growth without ongoing counseling, and the establishment of a stable support system outside of counseling. It's important to remember that it's not always necessary for counseling to go on indefinitely, and that ending sessions can be a positive step in the client's journey toward self-sufficiency and personal growth. However, this is always a collaborative decision between the counselor and the client, and it is made with the client's best interests in mind. If you have any specific concerns about your own counseling, it would be best to discuss them openly with your counselor.

I understand that your past experiences are causing you distress during intimate moments with your boyfriend. This response is a common symptom of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The flashbacks are a way for your mind to relive the trauma as if it is happening in the present. It's important to remember that these reactions are not a reflection of your current situation or your boyfriend's actions. Our brains can sometimes get mixed signals and react to triggers in our environment, even if they are not related to the actual danger or trauma. The good news is that there are effective treatments, such as therapy, that can help you manage these symptoms and reduce their frequency and intensity. Would you like to discuss this further or explore resources and options for seeking help?

I understand how challenging it can be to deal with a loved one who is living with Alzheimer's and exhibiting difficult behaviors. It's important to remember that the person you know and love is still in there, and their behavior is often a reflection of the disease and their confusion, rather than a deliberate attempt to upset you.

Here are some suggestions to help you cope:

1. Practice patience and compassion: It can be difficult to stay patient when dealing with unreasonable requests or upsetting behavior. However, it's important to remember that your mother is not doing this on purpose and that she is likely experiencing frustration and confusion herself. Try to respond with kindness and understanding.

2. Set boundaries: While it's important to be compassionate, it's also important to set boundaries for your own well-being. If certain requests or behaviors are causing you too much stress, you may need to limit your interaction with your mother or find ways to redirect the conversation.

3. Find support: Caring for a loved one with Alzheimer's can be emotionally challenging, and it's important to have a support system in place. Consider joining a support group, speaking with a therapist, or leaning on friends and family for help and understanding.

4. Focus on the positive: While it can be easy to get frustrated by the difficult behaviors, it's important to also focus on the positive moments and memories you have with your mother. Try to find ways to engage with her in a meaningful way, even if it's just a simple activity like holding her hand or listening to her favorite music.

5. Seek professional help: If the behavior is becoming overwhelming and is negatively impacting your mental and emotional health, it may be helpful to seek professional help. A therapist or counselor can provide additional support and guidance.

Remember, it's okay to feel frustrated and guilty, but it's also important to take care of yourself. Hang in there, and know that I'm here to support you in any way I can.

The best way to work on a relationship is for both people to engage with the problem and start communicating with each other more effectively.  One of the hardest things about this, however, is getting both people within the relationship to recognize that they are both responsible for the successes and failures within the relationship and remove all the all-or-nothing blame. The best style of communication is open and asking for clarification; why not try asking your mother why this particular fight/situation is eliciting such an angry response.  Often, the simple act of expressing that we don't understand the other person's point of view can open the doors to better levels of communication. The hardest part is trying to remain humble as we seek out that clarification and avoid the blaming language we are so used to using in such times.

One of the first steps is to manage anxiety and depression symptoms are to establish a good self-care routine.  Start with the most basic things: Eating balanced meals, sleeping at from 6-8 hours and exercise at least 30 minutes a day.  These will help you to regulate the chemical imbalance that affects your mood, plus exercising gives you time to vent and be distracted from your thoughts.  Once basic self-care is established, I suggest that is a good time to start exploring the source of these feelings, and address them trough therapy.  If you have difficulty initiating self-care routine talk to your therapist about what motivates you and pushes you to do things, you might find the key during the process.  You could also contact your physician or a psychiatrist to discuss medication options if it’s too challenging to begin basic self-care.¿Cómo puedo controlar mi ansiedad?Uno de los primeros pasos para manejar la ansiedad y la depresión es establecer una buena rutina de cuidado personal.  Comienza con las cosas más básicas: Comer comidas balanceadas, dormir de 6-8 horas en la noche, y ejercitarte por lo menos 30 minutos al día. Esto te ayudara a regular el desbalance químico que afecta tu estado de ánimo, además de que te da tiempo para desahogarte y distraerte.  Ya que la rutina de cuidado eta establecida, es un buen momento para comenzar a explorar la fuente de tus sentimientos negativos, y explóralos a través de terapia. Si se dificulta comenzar a crear una rutina puedes consultar con tu terapista para identificar motivaciones que te impulsen a comenzar.  También puedes contactar a tu medico primario o psiquiatra para discutir medicamentos que te pueden ayudar a manejar estos síntomas e iniciar cuidado básico.

First step is to remove the label of your behavior as a syndrome and instead understand the reasons for it."Imposter syndrome" sounds like a name someone made up to write a book and have lots of people buy it bc it gives the feeling they know themselves by calling themselves this name.Instead, consider your own unique qualities including your fears of being recognized as adding value to people's lives.If you were told growing up that you're worthless, or if your chosen career goes against family advice and expectations, or if you simply are a shy person, then these would be the starting points to understand your reluctance to believe in yourself.The more you understand yourself and trust the truths you find as to who you are, the less you will feel fraudulent.Good luck in your career work!

Although some people managing depression feel sad or "down",  it is a possible to have depression without an obvious sad mood.  Many people indicate that they feel numb or flat.  People managing depression often have low motivation. They may stay in bed for long periods of time and only get up for absolutely necessary activities.  People with depression may also feel inappropriate guilt or shame.   If you have been experiencing the symptoms you described for more than two weeks, I recommend that you see a counselor to get a more in-depth evaluation.   The symptoms you are experiencing are typical of depression, and with a bit of support, you could regain energy and improved self-esteem.  The stigma surrounding mental health can make a diagnosis or a label of depression seem scary.  The important thing to remember is that mental health disorders are as important as and as treatable physical health disorders.    Hang in there.  Healing is possible!

Hi Biddeford,This is a super goal. Feeling powerless is something parents are wise to get used to; there's a creature in the home whose job it is to find and use their power in the family and in the world. Of course your toddler defies you, and that's healthy. I worry more about the overly compliant ones. She is wanting to know what the rules are, and all you have to do is show her clearly where the lines are. I'll give you some tips.First, remind yourself that it's her job to learn what the rules are, and where her power is. Don't be so surprised when she wants it her way. If we go through our days being ready and prepared for these beautiful creatures to have minds of their own, we're less caught off guard when it happens. Avoid situations that invite power struggles. Any time you tell your daughter "do this now", you set up a power struggle. The good thing is that she's young enough you can pick her up; now is the time to teach her that mom's (or dad's) word means something. So, if you say "let's get you dressed", then be prepared to pick her up right away and show her that when you say something will happen, you can make it happen. And I'm talking about gently picking her up here...not roughly. Pick your battles; only give instructions when you have the power to make it happen.Give her choices, so she can see her power. Instead of opening her drawer and asking what she wants to wear, give her two choices. Here's an example...she's on the ipad and you say ipad time is over. She says "no". You can say "ipad time is over. If you put it down, you can play later. If I have to take it away, you don't play it later." The choice is hers. Then follow through."When...then" statements are really helpful. Your child asks for something. Instead of saying no, try "as soon as the toys are picked up, we can have a snack". You're simply a pleasant parent who wants the same thing they do...but they have to earn it. Staying calm yourself is the key, because then at least you will feel in control of yourself, which is the ultimate goal. Use self-talk to calm yourself. Remind yourself her behaviour is normal and healthy. Breathe through a moment in which you would have reacted, and it will be over by the time the breath is done. You can give yourself time to think before you make parenting decisions. Time is a useful tool not enough parents use. Good luck!

I understand that this situation is causing you distress. Trust is a fundamental component of a healthy marriage. However, it's essential to recognize that past issues do not necessarily define the present. I understand that you're concerned about your girlfriend's well-being. Your girlfriend might be going through a withdrawal process both from the alcohol and the social and emotional contexts she associated with it.

First, it's essential to validate her feelings and support her in this challenging time. Encourage her to express her emotions and listen actively without judgment. Offering a stable and comforting presence, as well as being patient and understanding, can help ease her stress and anxiety.

Second, suggest that she reach out to her healthcare professional or a support group for individuals in recovery. They can provide her with the resources and knowledge she needs to navigate this transition effectively.

Third, help her establish new routines and activities that promote a healthy and fulfilling lifestyle, such as exercising, cooking healthy meals, and exploring hobbies.

Lastly, if she feels comfortable and safe discussing it, try to understand the underlying reasons for her desire to move. You may be able to address some of her concerns or find alternative solutions together. Remember, you are there to provide love and support during her recovery process, even if she decides to move.

I'm sorry to hear about the difficult situation you're in. The decision to stay in or leave a relationship after an infidelity can be complex and deeply personal. It depends on various factors like the root cause of the affair, the level of remorse and commitment shown by your partner, the state of communication and trust in your relationship, and most importantly, how you feel about it.

Infidelity can be a sign of underlying emotional or relational needs not being met, and in some cases, it may not be a deal-breaker for some people. However, it's essential to address the underlying issues that led to the affair and ensure that they don't repeat.

If you feel that the relationship has more positives than negatives, and you want to give it another chance, you might consider counseling to help both of you work through the issues and rebuild trust and communication.

On the other hand, if the betrayal feels too great, and you can't imagine going forward, then moving on might be the best option. In the end, you should make the decision based on what feels right for you, rather than what is expected by others. I wish you all the best in your decision-making process.

Patient, it's essential to remember that the therapeutic relationship is not a one-size-fits-all process. The effectiveness of therapy depends on the therapeutic fit between you and your therapist, which can take some time to develop. Here are some ways to help determine if the therapist is right for you:

1. Comfort level: Do you feel comfortable talking to your therapist? Can you share your thoughts and feelings openly with them?

2. Experience: Is your therapist experienced in treating the specific issues you are dealing with?

3. Approach: Do their therapeutic approach and communication style resonate with you?

4. Connection: Do you feel a sense of genuine care and concern from your therapist?

As for training your therapist, psychotherapy is a collaborative process. You can express your preferences, needs, and goals, but ultimately, it is the therapist's role to apply their professional knowledge and skills to help you. Ongoing dialogue and consistent feedback between you and your therapist are invaluable in the therapeutic relationship, enabling productive growth towards your desired goals.

Patient, it's important to remember that the therapeutic relationship is a collaborative process, and it is normal to feel unsure about finding the right fit with a therapist. You cannot "train" a therapist to meet all your specific needs, as every therapist has their own unique style and approach, and we can adapt to one another.

However, a good therapist should be open to feedback, create a safe and trusting environment, and strive to understand and address your unique concerns. During the initial sessions, take note of your feelings towards the therapist, such as comfort level, the ability to connect with them, the therapy approach being used, and whether your concerns are being addressed.

If you don't feel a strong connection, it's essential to speak openly about your concerns with your therapist. They may be able to make adjustments or refer you to someone who might be a better fit. Keep in mind that finding the right therapist can sometimes take some time, so be patient. Don't hesitate to try multiple therapists to find the best match for your needs.

Some of the symptoms listed here in this question (i.e. trouble sleeping, constant fatigue, too much sleep, anger & anxiety) are all common symptoms of depression. Often times, these symptoms can be overlooked and mistaken for "just being tired." Furthermore, it's important to ask yourself, if you are feeling worthless, problems with concentration and recurrent thoughts of death. If you are having these symptoms, please seek help IMMEDIATELY. Lastly, considering your stated symptoms I would recommend reaching out to your Doctor for further consult. I understand that it can be difficult and painful when relationships experience challenges. It's important to remember that no relationship is perfect, and that occasional issues and misunderstandings are normal. However, when things get to a point where one or both partners feel disconnected or unhappy, it's important to take a step back and assess the situation.

In your case, it sounds like your partner felt overwhelmed by the demands of the relationship and needed some space to breathe. This doesn't necessarily mean that there's something fundamentally wrong with the relationship, but rather that both of you may need to make some adjustments to ensure that the relationship remains healthy and sustainable for both of you.

Some things you might consider doing could include:

* Reflecting on what specific demands or expectations you might be placing on your partner, and whether they are reasonable and necessary
* Being open to listening to your partner's perspective and validating their feelings
* Communicating clearly and respectfully with each other about your needs and expectations
* Taking time for self-care and mindfulness, which can help you feel more centered and able to approach the situation with clarity and compassion
* Seeking outside support, such as couples therapy or counseling, if necessary

Remember that every relationship will encounter challenges, and that how you respond to those challenges can either strengthen or weaken the bond between you and your partner. By approaching the situation with an open and compassionate mindset, you can work together to find solutions that benefit both of you and help you build a stronger, healthier relationship.

Hello, and thank you for your question. Guilt is one of those things that nearly everyone has experienced at one time or another, and it can feel like a huge weight around your neck. Unfortunately, it is unlikely that we can give you some words of wisdom that will make it all go away. However, I will give you some ideas and hopefully this will help.One of the things that we know about guilt is that it doesn't usually do much to help us in the long-run. People may make changes for a short-term period of time because they feel guilty about something they did, but usually they will go back to their old behaviors if they don't have something else to help them change permanently, such as a new skill. So, guilt doesn't necessarily help us. In fact, as I write this someone out there is eating an entire key lime pie because they feel guilty about falling off their diet. Someone may be drinking alcohol because they feel guilty about drinking alcohol. For whatever reason, this is just a common thing that we do. Now accountability is different than guilt. Accountability can actually be constructive.  When you hold yourself accountable you can admit that you have done something wrong. That it hurt others and you deeply regret it. That you are prepared to take steps to make sure it doesn't happen again. That you have done what you can to make amends, if necessary. That you are sorry. And then you move on. Why is moving on necessary? Well, for one thing, it doesn't usually help the people who you hurt. In fact, someone's guilty behavior may serve to remind the people who were hurt, over and over again, about what happened. Guilt is usually 100% about us, and not about those we hurt. Also, guilt can lead us to behave in ways that may even hurt people more. Having said all of that, guilt is a normal human emotion. Sometimes we experience it for a while and it goes away. Sometimes we need help to work through it. There are many self-help books about forgiving yourself. You can try Amazon to find some, or consider getting help from a counselor. Be well,Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

I understand that your girlfriend is going through a difficult time after quitting drinking. It's important to remember that quitting alcohol can lead to withdrawal symptoms, which can include depression and anxiety. Here are some suggestions on how you can help her through this period:

1. Be supportive: Let her know that you are there for her and that you care about her.
2. Listen actively: Encourage her to express her feelings and concerns.
3. Encourage self-care: Help her find healthy activities that can help her manage stress and improve her mood, such as exercise, meditation, reading, or taking a relaxing bath.
4. Encourage professional help: If her depression is severe, encourage her to seek professional help from a mental health practitioner or counselor.
5. Be patient: Quitting drinking is a major change, and it can take time for her to adjust.
6. Avoid enabling behavior: While you want to support her, be sure not to enable her to return to drinking or engage in other unhealthy behaviors.
7. Be flexible: Be open to changing your plans if she needs more time to rest or take care of herself.
8. Set healthy boundaries: Establish clear and respectful boundaries that promote a healthy and mutually supportive relationship.

I'm here to listen and offer guidance to the best of my ability. I understand that you are experiencing high levels of anger, anxiety, and stress. It's important to remember that you don't have to cope with these feelings alone. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization can help you calm down when you feel your anger building up.
2. Engage in physical activity: Exercise is a great way to release built-up energy and reduce stress. Try going for a walk, run, or bike ride whenever you feel your anger escalating.
3. Identify triggers: What sets you off and makes you angry? Once you've identified your triggers, you can work to avoid or cope with them more effectively.
4. Seek support: There are many free or low-cost resources available for mental health support, such as local community mental health clinics, support groups, and online resources. Reach out to your health care provider or a mental health professional for guidance.
5. Practice self-compassion: It's normal to feel overwhelmed and hopeless at times. Be kind to yourself and remember that everyone makes mistakes.
6. Avoid dangerous behaviors: I understand that you may be feeling extremely angry and out of control, but it's important to remember that throwing things, punching walls, or acting violently towards yourself or others is not a healthy or productive way to cope. If you are feeling suicidal or homicidal, reach out for help right away.

Remember, you don't have to deal with these feelings on your own. Seek out support from trusted friends, family, or professionals to help you navigate through this difficult time. Take care of yourself and remember that it's okay to ask for help.

I understand how scary it can be to experience anxiety, especially when you're in a new situation and far away from home. Here are some tips that might help you manage your anxiety while you're traveling for work:

1. Prepare as much as you can: Make a list of any supplies or resources you might need, such as medication, a therapist's contact information, or calming techniques. You might also want to research the area you'll be traveling to and familiarize yourself with the transportation system and local resources.
2. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation can all help you reduce anxiety and stay calm in the moment. You might find it helpful to practice these techniques before you travel, so that you're familiar with them when you need them.
3. Connect with others: Reach out to colleagues or people in your industry who might be able to offer advice or support. You could also consider joining a support group for people who experience anxiety while traveling.
4. Prioritize self-care: Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and getting regular exercise. These simple steps can help improve your overall mental and physical health and reduce your anxiety levels.
5. Seek professional help: If your anxiety is severe and is interfering with your ability to function at work or at home, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for additional support. They can help you develop a plan to manage your anxiety and provide you with coping strategies and resources.

Remember, it's normal to feel anxious in new situations, but there are several steps you can take to help manage your anxiety and feel more confident while traveling for work.

I'm sorry to hear about your struggle with finding appropriate care for your conditions, especially during these challenging times. Here are a few suggestions that may help:

1. Reach out to mental health organizations or support groups in your area for recommendations on qualified mental health professionals. You may also ask your local hospitals or clinics if they have any specialists in adult ADHD, anxiety disorders, and depression.

2. Inquire with your insurance provider for a list of contracted mental health providers, as some plans may have a network of mental health professionals or offer lower out-of-pocket costs.

3. Consider teletherapy or teleconsultation services, which are cost-effective and flexible. These services can be provided via video conferencing or over the phone.

4. Reach out to local community mental health centers, which may offer sliding fee scales for uninsured or underinsured individuals.

5. You may also get in touch with the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) National Helpline (1-800-669-6860) for resources and support. They can connect you with treatment programs and services in your area.

Lastly, remember to take care of yourself, eat healthy, get enough rest, and engage in regular physical activity. These simple acts can help improve your overall mental and emotional health.

I agree with Sherry that in a close intimate relationship, you are entitled to ask questions about his relationship with significant others. These questions help couples to build connection and trust. It's based on the idea that if you reach out to him for whatever reason (support, openess, understanding, empathy), you can count on him and can expect him to be responsive. How he responds to your question will give you an idea whether he helps you to feel more emotionally secure and builds trust or if you feel that you cannot be open with him. If your partner responds in an open and understanding manner, it usually indicates that he cares about your feelings and values your importance. If he responds in a defensive manner, it could mean that he does not like that you are questioning your trust in him or that he has something to hide. Either way, you may wish to explain that building trust is something that is very important to you in a relationship and that talking to him openly helps to foster that. If he continues to be defensive or evasive, then there might be some bigger issues at stake and the two of you may benefit from couples counselling or having a discussion about the values that are important to you in the relationship and how the two of you will go about supporting those values with actions.Dr. Virginia Chowwww.PsychologyResource.ca

Good for you for recognizing that a change has to be made quickly. Regardless of whether or not your girlfriend leaves your relationship, taking control of your anger needs to happen sooner than later. If left unresolved, it will follow you into any relationship you have. Have you talked to a therapist? I would suggest you take that step first. A therapist will help you explore the source of your anger and teach you new, adaptive ways of dealing with your anger. Until you're able to get some professional help, I would advise that you start recognizing when your emotions are becoming escalated and take a time out before the anger turns into aggression. If you feel yourself becoming heated, excuse yourself from the situation, go to a quiet place or on a walk, and practice some deep breathing. Clear your mind of the problem and focus only on your breathing as you inhale slowly counting to four and exhale slowly counting to six. Don't get discouraged if it doesn't work right away. Deep breathing takes practice! Return to the situation or your girlfriend only once you have calmed down and are confident that you are not going to hurt anyone. You might also want to ask your girlfriend to remind you to take a break when she recognizes that your emotions are escalating. Know that with help and support, especially from a therapist, the issues you have can be resolved and new ways of coping can be learned. Good luck!

Hi there,I first want to let you know that having these thoughts is completely normal. Studies have been done that show that 80% of human thoughts are "negative" so you are not alone. I like to think of thoughts as a tornado... if you are in a tornado, you are completely consumed by it and it is nearly impossible to do anything beneficial. However, when you are, let's say, a mile away from a tornado, it is still scary but you have the option to do something that is important to you such as get shelter or make sure your family and friends are safe. When unhelpful or scary thoughts arise, we tend to start a "war" with them, which is the equivalent of jumping into the tornado. This makes the thoughts and emotions bigger and intensifies the feelings that go with them. So the question I imagine you have is "how do I get out of the tornado?" There are 3 steps to doing this:Get distance from your thoughts by adding "I am noticing I'm having the thought that...." to the front of them. For example, "I am noticing I am having the thought that something bad is going to happen to me."   The purpose of this is not to decrease your fear or get rid of the thought. These thoughts might always be there and that is okay because that is how the mind naturally works so struggling with that is a waste of time and energy. The purpose is to gain some distance from the thoughts so you don't get swept away by them. You can imagine them floating along like leaves in a stream or clouds in the sky (and often the same thought will come back again and again but that's okay... just continue to notice it with curiosity). I imagine the thoughts get in your way of doing what really matters to you so if you can get a little bit of distance, you can do things that are fulfilling and meaningful to you. Tune into your body and notice what sensations come up and where you feel them most intensely. Then breathe into them and make room for them. Our 5 main emotions are: joy, sadness, fear/anxiety, shame, and anger. ALL of these emotions are part of being human and there is no escaping them. So again, struggling with them ends up intensifying them. Instead, let them be and make a little bit of room for them. Often a side effect of this is the intensity will decrease but it might not. The purpose is to keep them from becoming more intense. Contact the present moment. Notice what is happening here and now. One way of doing this is tuning into the five senses. What are some things you hear, see, taste, smell, and feel? Another way is to notice what is happening in your body (without trying to change it). How deep are your breaths, what is happening with your heart rate, are you cold/warm, etc?Implementing these three steps can help you to refrain from getting caught up in your unhelpful thoughts. Unfortunately there is no way to get rid of thoughts or feelings completely. So the only option that works in the long run is to accept them while continuing to do what matters to you and what is fulfilling to you.I hope this helps!

I understand that you have a complex and challenging set of issues. It's important to remember that the number of issues doesn't determine whether counseling is beneficial or not. In fact, many people with complex histories find that working through their experiences in therapy can help them gain a better understanding of themselves and develop effective ways to cope with the challenges they face. The goal of counseling is to provide you with the tools and support you need to improve your overall well-being and quality of life.

That being said, it's also important to recognize that counseling is a process that takes time, commitment, and effort. It may be helpful to prioritize which issues are causing the most distress or interfering with your day-to-day functioning, and to address those first. This does not mean that other issues will be ignored, but rather that they may be addressed at a later stage in the counseling process.

I would encourage you to consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can help you navigate this complex set of challenges. They will be able to provide you with a thorough assessment, and develop a personalized treatment plan that takes into account the unique needs of your situation.

Remember, seeking help is a brave and important step towards improving your mental health and overall well-being. I wish you all the best in your counseling journey.

As a psychologist, I cannot make the decision for you. However, I can suggest some factors to consider in making a decision that is right for you.

First, think about your feelings towards the relationship as a whole. Do you feel happy and fulfilled in the relationship, or do you feel more often than not that you are unhappy or dissatisfied? Are the good times outweighed by the bad times?

Next, consider if the issues that are causing distress in the relationship are things that can be worked on and improved with communication and effort, or if they are fundamental incompatibilities that are unlikely to change.

Additionally, reflect on your personal goals and values, and consider whether your relationship supports and aligns with those goals and values, or if it is hindering or blocking you from achieving them.

Ultimately, the decision to end a relationship is a deeply personal one, and one that only you can make. It is important to carefully weigh the pros and cons, and to seek the support and guidance of trusted friends, family members, or a mental health professional if needed.

I understand that these unwanted thoughts can be distressing and difficult to manage on your own. It sounds like you're experiencing thoughts consistent with what's known in psychology as "negative thoughts" or "thoughts of self-deprecation."

These thoughts can be a sign of underlying mental health issues like depression, anxiety, or even obsessive-compulsive disorder. It's important to address the root cause of these thoughts to alleviate them effectively. Here are some steps you can take:

1. Identify the triggers: Be aware of situations, emotions, or even certain thoughts that lead you to have these negative thoughts.
2. Challenge the thoughts: Question the validity of these thoughts. Are they based on facts or just an emotional response? It's essential to separate your emotions from objective reality.
3. Replace negative thoughts with positive ones: Practice positive self-talk by focusing on your strengths, accomplishments, and abilities. It may take some time, but with practice, you'll be better equipped to replace negative thoughts with positive ones.
4. Mindfulness and meditation: You can practice mindfulness meditation to help reduce stress, anxiety, and negative thoughts. This technique involves focusing on your breath and being present in the moment.
5. Consult a mental health professional: If the thoughts continue to persist or are impacting your daily life, it's important to speak with a mental health professional who can help you explore the underlying causes and develop a more comprehensive treatment plan.

Keep in mind that it's completely normal to have occasional unwanted thoughts. However, if they become persistent, frequent, or are causing significant distress or impairing your daily life, it's essential to seek help from a mental health professional.

I hope this information is helpful. Please let me know if you have any further questions.

I understand that you're feeling conflicted about your fascination with women's clothing and the potential implications it may have for your identity as a heterosexual man. It's important to remember that sexual interests and expressions can take many forms and are not always indicative of one's core identity. Moreover, the absence of a history of sexual abuse doesn't automatically exclude other possibilities for the origin of this fascination. Many individuals have unusual or unconventional sexual interests, and labels such as "fetish" are often used to describe these variations.

However, it's also crucial to reflect on the potential emotional and social consequences of indulging in this activity, especially if it's impacting your daily life or causing significant distress. You might consider seeking guidance from a mental health professional to help navigate these feelings in a safe and productive way. Alternatively, you could explore online communities or support groups specifically designed for individuals with similar interests to connect with others and share experiences and resources. Remember that there's no need to feel ashamed for having unusual sexual interests; however, it's essential to ensure they're not causing harm to yourself or others.

It's worth noting that wearing women's clothing as part of cross-dressing or gender exploration is an entirely different matter from fetishes and should be approached differently. If your fascination revolves around the act itself rather than the clothing, it may be worth exploring whether this behavior is adversely affecting your life in any way and, if so, how to manage those impacts.

Lastly, keep in mind that personal growth and self-understanding are ongoing processes, and it's normal to encounter complex emotions and feelings at different stages of life. The most crucial thing is to learn to accept and understand yourself as best you can, with the support and guidance of trusted friends, loved ones, or healthcare professionals.

Hello, and thank you for reaching out to ask for help. Surely this is a very confusing time for you! If you have never had these
feelings and desires it could certainty shake everything you thought you knew
about yourself. 
My guess is that you becoming sick around the time that this
started is likely a coincidence, but I understand how you would make the
connection. 
I have a feeling that a few things may be going on here. It
is really hard to say since I don’t know you, how old you are, etc. But, I will
share you with you some thoughts. 
Some people, when they have undesirable thoughts that really
surprise them, have a really tough time getting rid of them. Our reaction to
the thought can be very strong and our tendency to try to block it out, stuff
it, avoid it, etc. is not always successful. In fact, it’s usually not. 
It’s like telling you not to think of pink elephants. I
would be willing to bet that you thought of a pink elephant just now. 
So, rather than fighting thoughts that you find confusing,
sometimes it is helpful to allow yourself to explore the thought with curiosity
and without judgement. Where is this thought coming from? What are my feelings
about it? Asking yourself these questions may help you come to a resolution
about what is going on. 
One possibility is that you have developed an anxiety about
your thoughts and now you are in the process of obsessing about them, but
another possibility is that you are legitimately exploring your sexuality and
gender. I get the feeling from your question that you do not want to believe
that it is second possibility. And that is okay. 
You can try some of my suggestions, but you can also see a
counselor who may be able to help you work through your confusion. I would
suggest someone who has experience working with sexuality issues. You can
usually find out what a counselor works with on their website. What is
important is that you find someone who is non-judgmental about what you are
experiencing. 
 
I wish you well.
Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

Anxiety is simply your system communicating to you that you are in danger. The issue that I see in most of my clients is that they try to reason with this anxiety. You do not reason with sensory states in the body. If your system tells your in danger (your stomache feels like it is knots, your heart is beating out of your chest,) validate by just being present with it. Take your breath to it. Breath in and out of that space. Say ok, I am in danger. I always tell my clients, "a crying baby wants to be held, not told to shut up." Listen to your system, validate it like you do a child and see what happens.
