The therapist may also be able to help both of you figure out where the anger is coming from and where she has learned to react this way.If it is abuse, it may be even more difficult to have these important discussions. It may be helpful for you to see a local therapist by yourself to assess things like physical and emotional safety.

I am sorry that you lost your mother. That is a really hard thing for someone to go through.There is really no set time for grief to be over, but I agree that if it has been three years and you are still crying every day then this is past the time for normal grief. I do not know how old you are and if you are in school or have a job, but I would imagine that if by now you literally were doing nothing but crying every day all day, someone would have noticed and would have gotten you some help. For one thing, bills have to be paid.There are typically five stages of grief and they can come in any order. You can go back to another stage that you previously experienced. Denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance are the stages. At first, people are usually in denial over the fact that they lose someone or are losing someone. This may mean that you deny they are ill or deny that they have actually died.Then comes bargaining, in which you may beg God that if you can only have this person back then you will do whatever. Depression is when the reality has settled in and when we cry and really feel the loss. It sounds like you are stuck in this phase.Finally, acceptance is when we accept that it has happened and we pick up the pieces of our life and move on.When we lose someone we never forget them. We may always have certain days that are tough, such as holidays or any special remembrance of your loved one. But we do get to the place where we accept that death is part of life and that it is inevitable, and that life goes on.A therapist can help you explore the reasons for your extended grief and can help you with coping skills to better deal with it. One suggestion I have is not to try to run from the sad feelings, don’t try to not feel them. Embrace the feelings. Let the feelings wash over you and accept them. Trying not to feel something is not going to help. Sadness is a part of life and needs to be felt just like happiness does. Unpleasant feelings are not to be avoided.I am sincerely sorry that you lost your mother and that you have had such a hard time of it for three years now. You deserve to be happy and to live a full life. I am sure your mother would not want you being sad for so long. I wish you all the best as you continue to try to heal from this loss and deal with your grief.

I understand that you desire to improve your current relationships and have more positive interactions with others. Here are some suggestions: 

1. Practice active listening: This means giving your full attention to the speaker, understanding their perspective, and responding appropriately.
2. Be empathetic: Put yourself in the other person’s shoes and understand their feelings.
3. Communicate effectively: Use "I" statements, express your feelings clearly, and avoid criticizing or blaming language.
4. Show appreciation: Let others know that you appreciate and value them.
5. Set healthy boundaries: Learn to say "no" assertively and prioritize your time and energy with those who respect and value you in return.

Building positive relationships involves effort, practice, and patience. I'm here to support you in your journey towards better connections with others. If you have any further questions or would like clarification on any of these suggestions, please feel free to ask.

I'm here to help you, Patient. The thoughts you're experiencing are not uncommon, but it's important to know that you have the power to challenge and replace them with healthier ones. Mindfulness practices, such as meditation and deep breathing techniques, can help you manage those thoughts and reduce negative emotions. You can also try engaging in activities that bring you joy and help distract you from the thoughts. Finally, consider seeking support from a mental health professional who can provide you with additional tools and strategies to effectively manage your thoughts and improve your overall wellbeing. Remember, it's not easy, but with practice and commitment, you can learn to manage your thoughts and find peace.

Oftentimes we can change our feelings about ourselves by building a better relationship with ourself.  It sounds like there is a very critical aspect of your self that is alive and taking over.  Sometimes when we are stuck it is because a part of ourselves, a way that perhaps we learned to cope with difficult situations earlier in our lives, has decided to run the show.  Like a highly critical part that may actually be desperately attempting to protect us from a past hurt. Slowing down and even forming a relationship with this critical internal part will help you get some space from it.  When we can begin to observe parts of ourselves, be curious about them, get to know them like a new friend, then we have room for other ways of being.  Beginning therapy could be a great way to change this feeling of worthlessness.  Beginning to build a better relationship and understanding of yourself will deeply influence the relationships around you.  This first step may feel hard, to reach out to someone, and it could be the beginning step to a path of radically shifting your relationship with yourself and others in your life.

I understand that coming to terms with past trauma can be a complicated and intimidating process. It's important to realize that you are not alone in feeling this way, and that healing is possible with time and support. traumatic experiences can shape who we are in profound ways, but they do not define us completely.

One way to begin the process of discovering who you are beyond the trauma is to explore the things that bring you joy and fulfillment. This could be hobbies, relationships, or even small things that make you happy. These experiences can help you connect with your inner self and build a stronger sense of identity.

Another approach is to work with a therapist to process the trauma and develop coping skills for dealing with the emotional pain. This can help you gain a deeper understanding of your experiences and how they have influenced you.

It's also important to remember that healing is a process, and that setbacks and difficult emotions are a normal part of the journey. Be gentle with yourself and remember that every step, no matter how small, brings you closer to healing and growing as a person.

I'd be happy to answer any further questions or provide additional resources if you have any. Remember, you are not alone, and there are many people and resources available to support you on your journey to healing.

Based on the information you've provided, it's not uncommon for someone in your age group to experience feelings of low mood, disinterest in social activities, and self-doubt.However, these symptoms may indicate depression if they persist for a significant period of time or interfere with your daily functioning in various areas of your life, such as school, work, or relationships. Depression can manifest differently for everyone, and it's important to remember that everyone's experience is valid. You've shared some signs that may be indicative of depression, but the only way to truly know for certain would be to speak with a mental health professional. They can help you better understand your symptoms and provide you with effective treatment options. Depression is a treatable condition, and many people recover with the help of therapy and medication. I encourage you to reach out to a mental health professional to discuss your concerns further and explore options for getting the support you need.

This seems like two questions.  The first is what may have happened to prompt him to back off.  The second is what it means to you to have a boyfriend who takes anti-depression medication who says he has "a lot on his mind."  Both give you opportunity to look at yourself.  Having expectations can be a huge trap.  I write about this extensively in the first chapter of my book Living Yes (www.LivingYes.org).  Is there any way that you can enjoy your time together without expecting anything down the road?  Are there wonderful lessons for you to take from the relationship - even if it only lasts three weeks?  Can you create a mindset of gratitude for what is and let the future expectations (and future demands) go?  Are there new ways to communicate that might bring you together?  What are the lessons for you about allowing the relationship to develop its own course on its own time?  Again, let go of all expectations, and see what happens. That's what "Living Yes" requires.I am sure this will work out well for you - either with him or without him.  ~Mark  (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

Of course not. Counseling is a process, whereby you and your therapist will help you create goals- starting with issues that are most pressing and interfering with your daily functioning. When anxiety and daily stress is more manageable then you and your therapist can examine more deep rooted or more chronic issues.

I understand that addressing this concern can be a complex and challenging issue. It's important to remember that every person and every relationship is unique, and what works best for one person may not work for another. Here are some suggestions that might help guide you in making a decision:

First, it's essential to consider the potential impact of sharing your crossdressing on your relationships. It's essential to reflect on how much importance you place on this aspect of your identity and how you believe your partners might respond. Some people may be open-minded and accepting, while others might have negative reactions. You should also consider the level of trust and communication in the relationship. Has the topic come up before? Have you had open and honest discussions about sensitive topics previously?

Another consideration is your own feelings about the situation. How important is crossdressing to your overall well-being and happiness? If it's a significant part of your identity, you may feel compelled to maintain it, regardless of the reaction you might receive.

One approach you could consider is having an open and honest conversation with your potential partners about your crossdressing. Expressing your thoughts, feelings, and concerns in a clear and calm manner can help to ensure that both parties have an accurate understanding of each other's needs and wants. It's essential to listen carefully to their responses and work together to determine whether this is a deal breaker or not.

Keep in mind that the decision is ultimately yours to make, and there's no right or wrong answer. It might be helpful to seek the support of a trusted therapist, support group, or trusted friend as you navigate through this process. Remember, the goal is to find a balance between your needs, identity, and the expectations of potential partners that allows for a healthy, mutually respectful, and satisfying relationship.

I understand that this situation is causing you pain and confusion. It's important to acknowledge that everyone's behavior in relationships can sometimes be complex and ambiguous. It's crucial to communicate openly with your partner about how you both feel and what each of you expects from the relationship. However, if he continues to send mixed messages, it may be necessary to consider whether this relationship is serving your emotional needs in a healthy way. If you are uncertain, you may benefit from therapy to help you process your emotions and gain clarity about your next steps. Remember, the most important thing is your emotional well-being.

I understand that discovering past deceit in a relationship can be incredibly painful. However, it's essential to differentiate between minor infidelity, such as forgetting to disclose past acquaintances, and substantial betrayals, like physical or emotional infidelity. Based on the information you've provided, it appears that your partner may have engaged in a less severe form of infidelity.

However, it's important to remember that the impact of such disclosures depends not only on the actual events but also on your interpretation of the situation and your partner's intentions. It is a delicate issue to address, and trust is indeed essential in a relationship.

Ask yourself if there might be any logical explanations for their actions and whether you're willing to consider the possibility of forgiveness. Discuss the situation openly with your partner, express your feelings and the impact on your trust, and listen to their perspective as well. This could be a chance for both of you to learn, grow, and strengthen your communication skills.

Lastly, considering seeking the support of a therapist or trusted confidant to help navigate this challenging situation and make informed decisions with the best interests of your relationship at heart.

You definitely don't have too many issues for counseling. In fact, counseling can help you understand how most of these things can be related to one another. For example, insomnia, depression, low self-esteem and anxiety are very common to experience after a traumatic event or events. Once you begin to work through processing these life altering events that you have experienced, the hope is that you would see a decrease in your other symptoms.

I believe there's always hope. I also believe that you are worthy of respect and love. I'm curious if you felt loved, cherished, and respected by your husband during your time together. Feeling willing to go to any extreme to save the marriage is common, but having to do things that go against your values sets you up to develop a lot of resentment. It sounds like you did not want to be separated from your husband, but now that it's happened, you can make the choice to focus on yourself, rediscovering, or discovering for the first time, what you really want out of life. Taking some time to grieve the loss of your marriage and practice self-care can help in the immediate aftermath. Are there dreams that you put on a shelf during your marriage that you could reignite? I understand that you've been feeling extremely low and that this depression has been impacting your daily life significantly. It's important to acknowledge the severity of your feelings. Depression can make it difficult to manage even the simplest tasks, let alone engage in activities that used to give you joy. The fact that you can only find peace when you're asleep hints at a potential issue with sleep patterns or, perhaps, an escape from your daily struggles. I would recommend reaching out to a mental health professional, such as a therapist or psychiatrist, for further evaluation and treatment options. They can work with you to identify the underlying causes of your depression and help you develop strategies to cope and improve your overall mental health. In the meantime, try to prioritize self-care activities, such as regular physical exercise, healthy eating, and practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation. Remember that overcoming depression takes time and patience, but with help and effort, you can regain control of your life and find joy in the little things once again.

I will work with clients and continually review progress with them and determine if counseling is helping.  If a client appears to have less to talk about in sessions, appears more stable for a period of time and has reached therapeutic goals I will talk about termination.  Some clients however I may continue with on a monthly or bi monthly process to allow for check-ins to see how they are doing and if they need more help at that time.

How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?Communication with our loved ones can be tricky, but it is the key to maintaining a healthy and functional relationship with them. At times, it seems difficult to communicate with our family because many feelings and “undercover” messages are attached. Especially with our mothers, who often provide advice and feel responsible for us, it may feel like they are making everything about themselves as they express their worries and concerns.So what to do? First will be important to practice active listening skills, to ensure that you are receiving and understanding the message, without filtering it trough your own emotions or preconceptions of the person who speaks.  Second, learn and practice assertive communication skills.  Those will help you to communicate a message clearly and in pieces.  It also emphasizes using I-statements to express how you feel at times when emotions become affected by the interaction.  Third, you should practice, by writing your I-statement or role playing with your counselor.   The trick with communication skills is that we need to practice them as often as possible until you to master them.  You can also contact a family therapist to improve those skills if it becomes challenging, or contact a mediator if more issues arise.¿Cómo puedo lograr que mi mamá me escuche sin alarmarse tanto?La comunicación con nuestros seres queridos puede ser dificultosa, pero es la clave para mantener relaciones saludables y funcionales con ellos.  A veces, nos parece aun más difícil comunicarnos con nuestra familia, porque hay muchos sentimientos y mensajes envueltos en la comunicación.  Especialmente nuestras  madres,  pueden hacer parecer que están convirtiendo el asunto en algo personal, cuando se sienten preocupadas y responsables por nosotros y nuestras acciones.¿Y qué hacemos?  Primero debemos aprender a escuchar activamente, para asegurarnos de que comprendemos el mensaje, y que no lo estemos filtrando a través de nuestras emociones e ideas de la otra persona. Segundo, aprende y practica comunicación asertiva.  Esto te ayudara a comunicar un mensaje claramente y en pedazos.  También te ayudar a aprender expresiones del Yo, para identificar sentimientos afectados durante la interacción.  Tercero, es importante que practiques estas destrezas, ya sea escribiendo o con tu consejero.  El secreto está en practicar las técnicas de comunicación cuantas veces sea posible, hasta que las uses espontáneamente.  Si tienes dificultad aprendiendo estas técnicas, o el conflicto con tu mama es uno muy difícil de resolver, puedes contactar un consejero o mediador familiar para que te asista.

As a psychologist, I cannot take sides with one parent over another. Maintaining impartiality is a fundamental ethical principle for mental health professionals. While it is within your rights as a parent to seek counseling for your child, any information shared during therapy should be kept confidential. The counselor cannot be used as a tool to gather information for a custody case, and any efforts to coerce a child to disclose sensitive information goes against ethical and legal guidelines. If you have specific concerns, I would suggest consulting with a family law attorney or mediator instead.

It's completely understandable that you would have male friends and that you would want to spend time with them.  When you cross over from friends to a relationship, it does change things.  Some people are very easy going and wouldn't feel threatened by what you did  Others would be upset.  If your boyfriend is upset by you spending time with this male friend, then you need to talk about it.  Each of you needs to express your feelings about the situation and listen to the other with patience and respect.  Then you can make a decision on what is best for you and your relationship.  Maybe he wouldn't be upset if you saw this friend while you were with your boyfriend.  Or maybe your boyfriend would feel better if he got to know this person better and could trust him.  Most likely you can come up with a situation that will make both of you comfortable going forward.  You didn't do anything "wrong" because it doesn't sound like you intended to hurt your boyfriend.  But if you really care about your boyfriend, then you probably care about making him upset.  Instead of looking at this issue as a problem, try to look at it as an opportunity to connect.  If you can both listen to each other and understand each other, your relationship can become even closer.

How someone feels when they forgive another, is at peace with themselves and their understanding of what went wrong, who was responsible for what in the situation, and clarity on their own motivation, actions, emotions including pain, regret, resentment, sadness.These steps ideally allow a new door to open in order to develop new paths in the existing relationship or accept that this will not be possible due to either person's way of handling themselves.The long answer would be that you're not yet through with this process.I commend you on being truthful with yourself about yourself.You're on the right track by expecting to feel resolved when you've reached resolution, and not before.Finding patience with the unpredictable amount of time needed to thoroughly examine all the details of the incidents you mention, sometimes is a frustration of its own.Keep up your good work of knowing your own life.It is a worthwhile endeavor!

I understand that you're feeling frustrated, angry, and guilty about your mother's behavior towards you and others, despite knowing it may not entirely be her fault due to her Alzheimer's disease. coping mechanisms for such situations might include the following:

1. Practice patience: Alzheimer's disease can challenge a person's ability to communicate effectively, remember things, and sometimes even recognize their loved ones. Try to be patient with your mother instead of losing your temper.

2. Set clear boundaries: It's essential to communicate openly about what you will and won't tolerate. Set reasonable boundaries and be firm in maintaining them.

3. Find alternative communication methods: Consider using visual cues, writing things down, or utilizing simple yes or no questions to help facilitate better communication.

4. Focus on the positive: Try to remember fond memories of your mother or highlight positive experiences shared between you two. This can help maintain a sense of connection and warmth in your relationship.

5. Seek external support: Joining a support group, talking with a trusted friend, or consulting a mental health professional can help alleviate the emotional burden you're experiencing.

6. Self-care: Don’t forget to take care of yourself. Exercise, eat well, and get enough sleep. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you relax.

7. Encourage professional help: If your mother's condition is causing harm to herself or others or making it difficult for her to care for herself, consider looking into in-home care or assisted living facilities.

Remember, coping with difficult emotions and caregiving responsibilities are daily challenges, and it's okay not to feel like you have everything figured out right now. Take one day at a time, and remember that it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

While it would be impossible for me to say whether your marriage can be saved it sounds like you are both willing to give it a try and to get professional support. I commend your willingness to put effort into creating the strong loving relationship that you want for both of your sakes and of course for your children. The following links provides more information regarding common behaviours that predict staying together or separating and also videos and other resources that can help you get started. Wishing you and your family all the best on your journey of healing and discovery.

I understand that giving presentations as a shy person can be an overwhelming experience. Here are some suggestions that may help you build confidence:

1. Preparation: The more preparation you do before a presentation, the more confident you will feel. Make sure you understand the material, rehearse your presentation, and be familiar with the format of the presentation.
2. Visualization: Visualize yourself giving a successful presentation. Picture yourself delivering your points with confidence and the audience responding positively.
3. Practice: Practice, practice, practice! Find opportunities to give presentations in supportive environments, such as to friends or a small group. Get feedback from others and use it to improve your presentation skills.
4. Breathing exercises: Deep breathing exercises can help you calm your mind and reduce anxiety. Try taking deep breaths in through your nose and exhaling through your mouth. Repeat this several times before a presentation to help relax yourself.
5. Positive self-talk: Speak kindly to yourself and focus on your strengths. Remind yourself that mistakes are a natural part of the learning process and that everyone makes them.
6. Body language: Use positive body language during your presentations. Make eye contact with the audience, maintain an open posture, and use gestures to emphasize your points.
7. Seek support: Don't hesitate to seek support from others, such as a therapist, a mentor, or a peer. Sharing your concerns and receiving guidance can help you build confidence and overcome your fears.

It sounds like you are feeling helpless and out of control, you are concerned about your behavior, and at the same time you feel compelled to continue it. In working with a therapist, you may be able to get insight into what is motivating these behaviors, develop strategies for taking care of yourself, and get a stronger sense of who you are motivated to be when you are your authentic self.

I understand your concerns about the role of medication in managing your depression and regaining a sense of self. It's important to note that the decision about whether or not to continue taking medication should be made in consultation with your prescribing doctor. They can help assess the severity of your symptoms and provide guidance about the potential benefits and risks of continuing or discontinuing your medication.

While it's commendable that you've identified some negative behaviors and thoughts that may be contributing to your depression, it's also important to remember that depression is a complex condition that can't always be addressed through lifestyle changes alone. Medication can help to stabilize your mood, reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety, and provide the emotional energy needed to engage in therapeutic work.

At the same time, therapy, self-care practices, and lifestyle changes can all be effective tools in managing depression and improving overall well-being. If you decide to continue without medication, you might consider working with a mental health professional to explore these options and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

It's ultimately essential that you consult with your healthcare provider before making any decisions about your treatment. They can help you weigh the potential risks and benefits and work with you to determine the best course of action for your unique situation.

I understand that living with a family member who has bipolar disorder can be challenging for you, and the stress of managing that relationship can make it difficult to focus on other areas of your life, such as employment. It's important to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out for help when things feel overwhelming.

Given your situation, it might be helpful to consider community resources that could provide support or potentially low-cost therapy options. This could include reaching out to local mental health clinics, community health centers, or non-profit organizations that specialize in mental health care for individuals in your situation. In the meantime, there are coping strategies you can practice to manage the stress you're experiencing in the present. Setting small, achievable goals for yourself can also help boost your confidence and motivation, such as making a simple meal or taking a short walk outside each day.

It's important to remember that no one else's challenges define you, and seeking help is a brave and essential step towards taking control of your own life. You deserve to live a fulfilling and self-empowered life, and I'll help you explore ways to find stability and growth in the face of your circumstances.

I'd be more worried generally about a fiancee who assumes you are responsible for tracking what in fact are his responsibilities, than about the anger per se.What you describe holds the seeds of classic abusive behavior, which is blaming the partner for what in fact are the person's own responsibilities.Start by withdrawing yourself from paying his bills.If he is on his own in terms of tracking what and when is due regarding his auto policy, then surely the only one for him to blame will be himself.Stay clear of involving yourself in doing favors for him if the favor involves something that he is the one accountable.Tell him it is so the relationship remains fair for each of you.

I understand that this experience is very distressing for you. Maybe you need more time to reflect and organize your thoughts.Try to figure out what would make you feel more relaxed about talking to your dad or stepmom.Also its possible you simply don't feel safe around either of them and so intuitively realize you're better off not talking with them about a delicate matter.Depending on whether you trust talking to dad and stepmom, you may simply wish to excuse yourself from speaking about yourself.There's no good reason to be heartfelt with people whom you don't feel are willing to accept or understand who you are.

Remember, it's important to reach out for help if you're feeling overwhelmed with your emotions, and a mental health professional can provide guidance and support to help you manage these feelings effectively.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time right now. It's normal to feel unsure and needy after a break-up, especially if you were in a long-term relationship. However, it's important to remember that your worth and value as a person don't depend on your relationship status or validation from others.

To help you learn to be content and at peace with yourself, there are some things you can focus on:

1. Self-acceptance: Practice self-acceptance and self-compassion. Remind yourself that you are valuable and deserving of love and respect, regardless of your circumstances.
2. Identity: Focus on building a strong sense of identity based on your values, interests, and passions, rather than on external factors like your relationship status or career.
3. Self-care: Prioritize self-care, including physical activity, healthy eating, and time for relaxation and fun.
4. Mindfulness: Practice mindfulness, such as meditation or deep breathing exercises, to help reduce anxiety and increase focus and self-awareness.
5. Support: Surround yourself with supportive people, including friends, family, and therapy, if needed.
6. Reframe your thoughts: Challenge negative thoughts and reframe them in a more positive and realistic way.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to feel unsure and have ups and downs along the way. But by focusing on these practices, you'll be able to build a stronger, more resilient sense of self that will help you feel content and at peace, regardless of your relationship status.

I'm so sorry to hear of your loss.  This sounds like a really difficult situation for the whole family.  Since the answer to this question will depend a lot on the applicable state laws, I would suggest talking with a local attorney.  That being said, I see two competing issues here.  On the one side is the duty of confidentiality the counselors owed to your relative.  On the other side is the duty the counselors had to act reasonably to protect your relative from harm.  Generally there is not a requiremt for substance abuse treatment centers to notify family members if an adult client relapses.A local attorney will be able to provide more specific guidance on the legal obligtions and liabilities in this situation.

I am sorry to hear of your relationship struggles. One thing I wonder is did you volunteer the information about your past or is this something that he asked about? In the future, it is probably best to leave details out of conversations like this. I think it is common and natural for partners to ask about the sexual history. For one thing, it is a good idea to be checked for STD’s before entering into a sexual relationship with someone, and it is fair to share that information with each other. Partners usually want to know how many you have been with and what kind of sexual preferences you have or if there is anything you don’t like to do. This gets into a gray area for some people. I don’t necessarily want to know how many people my partner has been with and I certainly don’t want a whole lot of details. Sometimes that is an image I just don’t want in my head about my partner. Vague details are usually enough.However, I understand that your partner has the details and is not happy with your past. This is a reflection on him, not you. This shows insecurities on his part. You cannot control how he will react to information that you provide to him and you cannot control how he feels about the information. The past should remain in the past and not be held against you in the present or future. If he cannot handle your past then it is going to cloud your relationship. You can offer couples counseling to him and see if he will go with you. I have seen relationships recover from some very serious problems such as infidelity. It takes two people who both want it to work to make it work though. If your boyfriend cannot get over your past, you may have to let him go. Don’t keep yourself tied to someone who is not right for you. Constantly holding your past over your head and holding that against you is only going to bring you down and eventually you may start having insecurities or low self-esteem due to this type of treatment. I don’t see that you have done anything wrong. If you aren’t cheating on him now and you answered his questions about your past honestly, how he handles that information is on him. Ultimately, relationships have a tendency to come and go. Don’t fight to hold onto someone who is not right for you. It is okay to be single and enjoy being the best you that you can be. In time, the right person for you will enter your life.

In the best case scenario, it's a mutual discussion and decision. If not,  I've had the discussion initiated both ways, by me, when I sense the client has gone has far as they want, by lack of interest in accepting or completing homework assignments, missing or cancelling appointments, usually at the last minute, lack of participation during sessions.  Client initiates by asking me pointed questions about why the need for homework assignments,, by forgetting their calendar, or their checkbook :) , by suggesting that we make appointments over longer intervals (once a week to once a month, for example).  I rarely have had to terminate a working relationship--that's why I don't charge for the first visit, so we know if we are a good fit before we start working together.  Then I periodically ask whether the client feels we are making progress, moving in the right direction, talking about the most relevant issues etc.

I understand that you are feeling frustrated and unhappy with your current situation, especially with regard to your relationship with your wife. It's important to acknowledge that all relationships encounter difficulties from time to time, and it's a normal part of the human experience. However, the frequency and intensity of your conflicts indicate that there may be underlying issues that need to be addressed.

Here are some suggestions that might help you and your wife improve your relationship:

1. Open Communication: Try to discuss your feelings and concerns with your wife in a calm and respectful manner. Avoid accusatory language and focus on expressing your own thoughts and emotions rather than blaming or criticizing her.
2. Active Listening: Make sure that you listen attentively to your wife when she speaks, and try to understand her perspective as well as your own. This can help build empathy and reduce misunderstandings.
3. Seek to Understand: Attempt to understand the root causes of your conflicts, and consider whether there might be recurring themes or patterns in your interactions. This can help you address underlying issues rather than just dealing with symptoms.
4. Family Therapy: If your conflicts are particularly severe or persistent, you may benefit from seeking the help of a family therapist. A trained therapist can help facilitate communication and provide tools and techniques for improving your relationship.
5. Self-Care: Make sure that you are taking care of your own physical, emotional, and mental health. This can help you cope with stress and better manage difficult emotions.

I hope that these suggestions are helpful, and I encourage you to explore them further with your wife or with a qualified therapist. Best of luck in your efforts to strengthen your relationship.

It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of social anxiety. Social anxiety is a type of anxiety disorder where individuals have excessive fear or anxiety about social situations and interactions with others. This fear can manifest in physical symptoms, such as a racing heart or difficulty speaking. For some people, the fear and anxiety can be so intense that they have significant difficulty carrying out routine activities, such as going to the grocery store by themselves.

It's important to note that everyone experiences nervousness or anxiety in social situations from time to time. However, if your symptoms are interfering with your daily life and causing you distress, it may be helpful to seek professional help. A mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, can help you learn ways to manage your anxiety and improve your overall mental health.

Please keep in mind that I cannot diagnose or provide treatment through this interaction, and my responses should not replace the care of a qualified mental health professional. If you have concerns about your mental health, please consider reaching out to a mental health professional for an assessment and personalized treatment plan.

Absolutely, talking to a mental health professional could be very helpful in this situation. You're describing a common issue called "enmeshed" or "over-involved" relationship with your mother. It's important to remember that each individual has the right to live their own life and make decisions that are best for them. Therapy can help you understand this concept further and equip you with strategies to manage your situation. So yes, I'd encourage you to consider seeking help.

I understand that you experience increased sadness during the winter months. This is a common condition known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). There are several ways to alleviate your symptoms:

1. Light therapy: Use a light box that mimics natural sunlight for 30 minutes to an hour a day, ideally in the morning.
2. Exercise regularly: Physical activity releases endorphins that boost your mood and energy levels.
3. Maintain a healthy diet: Eating nutritious foods and staying hydrated can help improve your overall mood and energy levels.
4. Keep in touch with friends and family: Socializing is essential for mental health. Connecting with loved ones, even if it's virtually, can provide emotional support.
5. Consistently engage in activities you enjoy: Pursue hobbies, read, watch your favorite shows, or take up a new skill to boost your mood.

Remember, I cannot diagnose or treat you, but I can provide guidance and support. If your symptoms are severe, consider seeking professional help from a mental health professional.

What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?I have anxieties about everyday stressors, i.e. finances, work, relationships, kids, and maintaining a household.Our everyday life is filled with pressures and deadlines that are common to cause anxiety.   Here are some basic tips to handle those stressors.·         Learn thought stopping techniques: There are multiple ways to teach your brain to refocus.  If you allow your brain to focus on the source of anxiety, the anxiety will be in charge.  But you can learn to put those anxiety-provoking thoughts on a parking lot, and focus on pleasurable thoughts, or the activity that you need to complete on the time being.·         Plan, organize, delegate:  Create a schedule to manage demands, organize priorities, and delegate or share responsibilities.   Work as a team with your family, so you can share the load.   Prioritize actives, shores, and expenses. Focus on the urgent, necessary, and spread apart the not so urgent.·         Identify triggers:  Once you understand what causes your anxiety, you can learn to channel process and refocus your thoughts.  You can also learn coping strategies to manage the problem or give up the desire to control it if needed.·         Learn coping skills:  Having a balanced lifestyle helps tremendously to reduce and manage anxiety symptoms.  Looking at your eating, sleeping, physical activities, spirituality and leisure time is key to find that balance.If you find yourself struggling with anxiety, you can contact a Counselor or mental health provider.  I provide teletherapy for Texas residents and psychotherapy in Puerto Rico, you can reach me at 787-466-5478 for appointments.¿Cuáles son las mejores maneras de reducir la ansiedad?Tengo ansiedad por preocupaciones diarias, como las finanzas, relaciones, niños y mantener mi casa.Nuestra vida está llena de retos y presiones que comúnmente nos causan ansiedad.  Aquí unos consejos básicos para manejar esas preocupaciones.·         Aprende como detener tus pensamientos: Hay múltiples maneras de enseñarle a tu cerebro a reenfocarse.  Si permites que tu cerebro se enfoque en la fuente de ansiedad, entonces la ansiedad se apoderará de ti.  Pero puedes aprender a poner a un lado esos pensamientos que causan ansiedad, y enfocarte en pensamientos positivos, placenteros o simplemente enfocarte en la actividad que estás haciendo. ·         Planifica, organiza, delega: Crea una agenda para manejar las demandas diarias, organizar prioridades y delegar o compartir responsabilidades.   Trabaja en equipo con tu familia, de manera que puedas compartir la carga.  Organiza las actividades, gastos y tareas por prioridad.  Enfócate en lo urgente y necesario y distribuye lo que no es tan vital. ·         Identifica la fuente:  Ya que comprendes donde o qué inicia la ansiedad, puedes aprender a canalizarla, procesarla o reenfocar tus pensamientos. También puedes aprender a manejar la fuente de ansiedad, resolver el problema, o aceptar que no lo puedes controlar, si ese fuera el caso. ·         Aprende mecanismos de defensa: Tener un estilo de vida balanceado ayuda tremendamente a manejar síntomas de ansiedad.  Observar tus patrones de alimentación, descanso, ejercicio, espiritualidad y tiempo de ocio es clave para encontrar el balance. Si notas que continuas batallando con la ansiedad puedes contactar a un consejero profesional de salud mental.   Proveo teleterapia a residentes de Texas y Consejería en Puerto Rico, me puedes contactar al 787-466-5478 para hacer una cita.

Something to remember about anxiety is that it's a useful and necessary response to stressors, and we all have a level of anxiety that falls somewhere on the spectrum from very slight to very overwhelming. Anxiety is our brain's way of prompting us to deal with the stress in our lives by getting us geared up for action. Some helpful ways of managing anxiety are actually very simple. The first I'd recommend is a calm breathing technique - breathe in for 4-5 seconds, and then out for 7-8 seconds. Try to repeat this for 3-5 minutes. Another suggestion is to pay closer attention in the moments you feel the physical symptoms of anxiety and see if you can describe - without judging - the sensations to yourself. Try to be very specific, such as "my palms are feeling very sweaty, and I can feel the slight tightness and fluttering in my belly of the butterflies." Then try to sit with these sensations without deciding if they are good or bad - just experiencing them as intentionally as possible.  Combining the calm breathing with this technique can also be very helpful. If you feel that these techniques don't help and your anxiety about everyday stressors are inhibiting you from being able to engage in life the way you want to, then I'd highly recommend going for an assessment or even just consultation with a professional. This professional can help you determine if therapy/counseling would be helpful for you to develop additional skills for managing those interfering anxiety symptoms.

In response to Tim's feelings and the potential end of his current relationship, here are some things you can do to help support him:

1. Be a listening ear: Allow Tim to express his feelings freely and validate them. Let him know that it's okay for him to feel sad, hurt, and confused. He needs someone to talk to and process his emotions.

2. Offer perspective: Help him see that the feelings of loss and heartache are a natural part of relationships ending. Encourage him to view this experience as an opportunity for growth, rather than a sign that he's unable to love in the future.

3. Encourage self-care: Recommend activities that can help him take care of himself during this time, such as exercising, practicing mindfulness meditation, reading a book, or engaging in creative pursuits.

4. Encourage reaching out for professional help if needed: If Tim's feelings of sadness and despair persist for an extended period, it may be helpful to encourage him to seek the guidance of a mental health professional.

5. Establish boundaries: It's important to communicate clearly and set boundaries around feelings of romantic attraction to ensure that you can continue to be a supportive friend, rather than making things more complicated between the two of you.

6. Be a friend first: Keeping in mind that you're ultimately there for him as a friend, focus on providing emotional support and being there for him during a difficult time.

It's also important to keep communication open and respectful, so discuss your feelings and concerns with Tim as well. Be empathetic and try to understand his perspective, and let him know that you're there for him, regardless of romantic feelings. Helping him deal with the end of this relationship can strengthen your friendship and provide a foundation for future growth.

This is a great question! I personally don't believe that any client could ever have too many issues for counseling. In fact, that type of thinking may be stopping you from seeking counseling, so it may be hindering you from getting the help you need. In fact, all of what you described points to the importance of you seeking help in order to cope with the many challenges in your life. If you seek counseling, it will be important for you to understand that you may need to remain in counseling for a sustained period of time in order to work through each of these issues. First of all, congratulations on your new role! Transitions can be challenging, and it sounds like you are experiencing a lot of change.  This would be difficult for many people, and it seems that you have an added layer of challenge.  I recommend visiting a therapist to determine the root cause of your anxiety and working to unravel those causes piece by piece. I know seeing a therapist can be challenging when traveling, and online counseling could be a good solution. In the meantime, here are a few of my favorite anxiety stopping strategies.  1. Grounding Exercises: When you feel your anxiety increasing, take a deep breath and begin things in your room (or where ever you are) that have things in common. For example, name all of the blue things that you can see.  You can also do non-visual grounding exercises like naming all of the hte sports teams you can think of or all of the state capitals.  This will get your mind off of your anxiety and connect you to space.  2. The pretzel: This is a seated pose that will stop any anxiety attack in its tracks.  Start in a seated position and cross your dominate leg over your nondominant leg. Then, stretch your arms out in front of you with the back of your hands facing one another.  Cross your arms in front of each other so that your palms are touching.  Flip your arms into your body.  You will end with your elbows by your side and your hands crossed under your chin.  Close your eyes and take long breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.  This calming pose will help you get through even the toughest of panic episodes. 3. Bilateral stimulation and visualization: Start in a seated position with your hands placed on your knees. Tap each knee in an alternating pattern. Close your eyes and begin visualizing a peaceful setting. The combination of bilateral stimulation and visualization will help calm your body and mind.  I could go on and on, but these techniques should get you started.  These techniques should help you manage anxiety in a pinch.  Best of luck!

Your fear is somewhat reasonable.  No one wants to be raped and I imagine everyone is afraid of what being raped would feel like.Do you mean that this fear is on your mind more often than you would like?If this is the case, then try understanding the reason behind your fear.Is it because you personally know or know of someone who was raped?  One general direction of what would help is to regain confidence in your decisions of keeping yourself safe.  The more you trust yourself to avoid social situations with lots of drinking, isolated physical surroundings, and being in isolated locations with someone with whom you're not very familiar, probably your fear will decrease.The other general direction to understand is if in your family history, people have been violated severely, either emotionally, mentally, or physically.In families in which people have suffered severe violations of themselves, often the emotional patterning of expecting to be hurt by others, plants itself very deeply and transmits to the younger generation.Its possible then, that you are suffering from fears established in other family members who have not yet been able to fully understand and accept their own suffering.The good news is that individual therapy, with a credentialed and licensed therapist, is ideal for a safe place to open and clear this type of emotional burden.

I understand your concern, and it's important to note that everyone's sex lives and desires differ. Sexual frequency can vary greatly among couples, and there is no "normal" number. It could be helpful to explore this topic with the guidance of a sex therapist or counselor, who can offer you evidence-based techniques and strategies to enhance your sexual relationship. Additionally, ensuring that both partners address any underlying physical or emotional issues might be beneficial for improving your sex life.

I'm sorry to hear about your experience with your ex-fiancé. Your symptoms of dizziness and sickness when you stand up could be related to the stress and anxiety you're experiencing. From a psychological standpoint, having a close friend who is also an ex-partner can be a normal part of the healing process after a relationship ends. Crying during therapy is quite common and normal. Emotional expression is an important part of the therapeutic process. I'm sorry that you lost your first born child.  Death of a child always leaves a permanent reminder to the parents of a very painful time in their lives.The good news is your awareness that you and your wife are not connected in a satisfying way.There are many possible areas to examine in your relationship as partners and as parents.If what you write here are your observations and theories about your wife's outlook and conclusions, then the first step is to directly have conversations together on the topics you write here.What needs clarifying is what her reasons are for wanting to leave the marriage.Often, a crisis such as a child's death, motivates someone to look deeply into other intimate relationships.  Keep in mind that looking deeply doesn't necessarily mean leaving the marriage.Also, be aware of your own frustrations and marital discontent.  Be ready to talk about your feelings and uncertainties.There is no such thing as one happy partner in a marriage and one unhappy partner.   Each person is part of a system and can only be as satisfied as their partner.The conversations that open relationship hurts and disappointments, hold a lot of emotion.  They are difficult to keep on track.Best recommendation is to find a couples therapist who will be neutral to each of you as individuals, and help both of you examine the true health of the relationship.

I understand that reaching out for help can be a difficult and intimidating process. It's important to remember that seeking therapy is a sign of strength, not weakness. You can start by making an appointment with your primary care physician and expressing your concerns. You might say something like, "I've been dealing with some emotional issues lately and I think it would be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. Can you help me get started with that process?" Your physician can then provide you with resources and referrals. Alternatively, you can also contact a mental health clinic or organization directly to schedule an appointment. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and prioritize your mental health. Your feelings are valid and deserving of care.

Great question. The decision to pursue therapy can be a very difficult one and the fact that there seem to be so many profiles that you have to wade through can be particularly daunting. Here's what I suggest to make the process a bit easier: 1) Narrow down your preferred geographical area. Are you in a rural, suburban, or urban environment? If it's either of the latter two, you'll probably have a mental health professional close by. Decide now if it's important to you that their office be within walking or short driving distance. 2) Decide if you need it to be covered by your insurance. You'll have more options if you're willing to pay out of pocket and get reimbursed by your insurance, but more and more people are accepting insurance these days. 3) Find someone whose profile has the key words that you're looking for. If you're struggling with traumatic flashbacks, make sure they have "trauma" or something along those lines in their profile.4) Make sure they have a friendly and professional picture. This is small, but this detail shows that they really care about how they present to the world. 5) Come up with a list of about 3 people and rank them from most appealing to least. Set up an appointment with the person who seems like the best fit and give it a try for the first session. You'll know by the end of it if it's a good fit.It can be scary, but finding the perfect fit makes it so worth it. Good luck!

I understand that you're feeling anxious and uncertain about your relationship, and it's natural for you to have concerns when you suspect infidelity. However, it's essential to approach this situation with a balanced perspective.

Your gut feelings and instincts can often be valid indicators of potential issues in your relationship. Still, constant accusations and mistrust can harm the bond between you and your boyfriend and create a pattern of toxic communication.

It's crucial to have open and honest discussions with your partner when you have concerns. Affective communication, where both parties express their concerns and feelings in a non-blaming and compassionate tone, can lead to productive conversations.

In this particular instance, you've provided some evidence of potentially concerning behavior. It may be helpful to bring up this conversation in a calm and non-confrontational manner. You can approach the discussion by expressing your feelings and concerns, sharing the evidence you have, and giving him an opportunity to explain himself. Make sure to listen actively and be open to his perspective.

If the conversation leaves you feeling uncertain, it may be beneficial to seek the help of a professional counselor or therapist who can provide guidance and support in navigating this situation. Sometimes an objective third party can help facilitate more productive conversations between partners and offer valuable insights and advice.

It's important to note that feeling uncertain and questioning your partner's loyalty doesn't necessarily mean there's something inherently "wrong" with you. Many people experience these thoughts and emotions during the lifespan of a relationship. The key is to respond to them in a healthy, open, and communicative way.

In summary, you can go about checking if there truly is something wrong by having a calm, open, and honest conversation with your boyfriend about your concerns. If the conversation doesn't lead to a resolution, seeking the help of a professional counselor or therapist may be a valuable next step. Remember that feelings of suspicion and anxiety are common, but how you respond to them is crucial.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a tough time right now. It's understandable to feel hopeless and alone when dealing with a chronic illness. However, it's important to remember that while we may not be able to change certain circumstances in our lives, we can change how we respond to them and how we view ourselves.

First, focus on what you can control. This could include your attitude towards your illness, your self-care routine, your environment, and your daily activities. It's also essential to seek professional help, such as therapy, to develop strategies to cope efficiently with your illness.

Second, you can learn to embrace being alone. This doesn't meant that you have to be completely isolated from others. Instead, it means developing a deeper connection to yourself, which can lead to greater self-acceptance and happiness. This can include engaging in activities that bring you joy, practicing mindfulness and meditation, keeping a journal, and setting achievable goals for yourself.

Lastly, you're not alone in experiencing these feelings. Reach out to loved ones, support groups, or hotlines to connect with others who may be going through similar experiences. It's essential to remember that recovery from illness or learning to be happy alone is a process and not a one-time event. Keep in mind that progress may be slow, but it's important to stay consistent and patient with yourself.

Crying during therapy is quite common and normal. It is a way for people to express their emotions and can be a sign of progress in therapy. It allows individuals to release and process emotions that may be difficult to articulate through words alone. You are not alone in this experience. It is an integral part of the healing process. Feel free to express your emotions without any judgment from me.

Patient, rest assured that finding the right therapist for you is not about training them, but rather about building a therapeutic relationship that works best for you. This relationship is built on trust, understanding, and effective communication. You can consider several factors when evaluating if a therapist is the right fit:

1. Chemistry: Does the therapist create a feeling of safety and trust during sessions?
2. Technique: Does the therapist use approach(es) that resonate with you?
3. Engagement: Are you actively engaged in the therapeutic process?
4. Empathy: Does the therapist show genuine concern for your well-being and feelings?
5. Progress: Are you seeing improvements in your emotional and mental health?

To build an effective therapeutic relationship, focus on being open about your feelings and needs. Also, do not hesitate to let your therapist know if you're not feeling satisfied or making progress, as open communication is essential for a successful therapy journey.

I'm sorry to hear about your experiences, and I understand that it's been a challenging few months for you. However, it's important to note that the inability to feel emotions, also known as emotional numbness, is a common response to traumatic experiences such as rape. It's not uncommon for people to feel disconnected or detached from their emotions as a coping mechanism.

However, it's crucial to remember that this is a temporary state and not a permanent condition. With appropriate support and interventions, you can learn to reconnect with your emotions and heal from the traumatic experience.

I would recommend speaking with a mental health professional, such as a licensed psychologist or therapist, who can help you process the rape and other distressing events you've experienced. They can provide you with various therapeutic interventions, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), to help you work through your emotions and develop effective ways to cope with the trauma.

In the meantime, consider engaging in self-care activities that promote emotional regulation and help you connect with positive emotions, such as mindfulness practices, meditation, or gentle exercise. Building a support system of friends, family, or fellow survivors can also be helpful in your healing journey.

Remember, it's normal to need time to heal, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. Your feelings will return with time and appropriate support.

I understand that having a cat in the house may not be something you're used to or comfortable with, and it's natural to feel jealous or unsettled when something new is introduced into your living situation, especially if it's an animal that you dislike. However, it's important to consider the emotional well-being of all parties involved, including the cat and your boyfriend. Instead of wanting to throw out the cat, have you considered ways to make the living situation more comfortable for you? This could include setting boundaries, such as certain rooms in the house being off-limits for the cat, or finding ways to minimize contact with the cat. There are also potential solutions that could benefit both you and your boyfriend, such as finding a cat sitter or hiring a professional pet-sitter to take care of the cat when you're visiting or staying at a friend's place. It's important to communicate your feelings honestly and respectfully with your boyfriend, and see if a compromise can be reached that accommodates everyone's needs. It may also be helpful to explore any underlying feelings of jealousy or anxiety that come up in this situation, as these may be worth delving into in future therapy sessions.

It's important to recognize that your current behavior patterns, particularly when you're feeling upset or angry, are causing distress not just for yourself but also for your loved ones. This is common, but if you truly want to grow as a person and improve your relationships, there are a few steps that may help.

Firstly, understanding the root cause of your anger and learning healthy ways to manage it is crucial. Consider implementing techniques like deep breathing exercises, mindfulness meditation, or engaging in physical activities like exercise or sports to help channel your energy in a productive way.

Secondly, practice effective communication skills. When feelings of anger or hurt arise, reflect before responding, and try to express your thoughts and emotions clearly and calmly. The goal should be to resolve conflicts, not escalate them.

Thirdly, strive to focus on your own emotions and behaviors instead of blaming others. This can be challenging, but practicing self-compassion and self-awareness will help you in the long term.

Lastly, it may be helpful to seek counseling to work through any underlying issues that may be contributing to your angry outbursts. A psychologist or therapist can provide additional guidance and support in your journey towards becoming a calmer, more compassionate, and happier person.

As a psychologist, I cannot make definitive statements about the intentions of a specific social worker. However, I can provide some perspective on the situation. Remember that your mental health is a priority, and it is essential to find a caring and responsive mental health professional to support you on your journey towards well-being.

I'm here to help you sort through your emotions, but I can't make decisions for you. It sounds like you're in a complex emotional situation. Moving on from a past relationship while also experiencing strong feelings for someone new can be challenging.

Ultimately, the decision is yours. I'd be happy to help you explore your thoughts and feelings further in sessions if you'd like. Remember, it's important to consider what is best for you in the long term.

I understand how frustrating and painful it can be to feel misunderstood and hurt by a loved one's tone and behavior. Your feelings are valid, and it's important to acknowledge the impact his words and actions have on you. Being sensitive does not mean that you are in the wrong, or that your feelings are not important. It's natural for us to feel emotionally affected by the way people treat us, especially when it's someone we care about.

It may be helpful to try to communicate with your father in a calm and assertive manner about how his words and tone make you feel. Use "I" statements instead of "you" statements to avoid placing blame and to focus on your own feelings. For example, "I feel upset when you speak to me in a shouting voice," rather than "You are hurting my feelings."

You may also want to consider seeking the support of a counselor or therapist to help you process your emotions and find effective ways to communicate with your father. It can also be helpful to practice self-care activities to help manage your emotions and build resilience. Remember, it's okay to set boundaries and prioritize your own emotional health.

Absolutely not, patient. Your experiences and feelings are valid, and it is common for individuals to have multiple issues that they are dealing with in therapy. I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this, but it's important to remember that everyone has different ways of expressing and showing love. I understand that this can be a confusing time for you, and it's absolutely normal to question your sexual orientation. There's no need to rush into identifying yourself with a label. Give yourself credit for what you already know.For instance, you do know that you're unsure about your life direction. Take off any pressure on yourself to decide an answer in a certain amount of time.  Inner reflection work takes time and has its own course.   Trust that answers will show once you've done the work to understand yourself and circumstance, and the relationships in your life.From what you describe, your interest is in a broad scope life change. One direction is to start with only one specific part of your life you would like to change.  By examining one area in detail you will gain self-trust and confidence in handling your life.   And, you will have clarity as to which area to change first.

Since you are saying that you know that the thoughts are yours and your thinking of them in a different person's voice to make them easier for you to follow through on, it doesn't sound like it could develop into another personality.It may be helpful to also find other things that give you comfort and to practice telling yourself that it will be okay in your own voice. I understand that letting go of a deep, meaningful relationship is a challenging process. The feelings you experienced with this person may be intense and hard to forget. Here are some suggestions that may help you move forward:

1. Acknowledge your feelings: Allow yourself to feel the pain and sadness that comes with ending a relationship. It's important to process these emotions rather than ignoring or suppressing them.
2. Refocus on self-care: Make sure you are taking care of your physical, emotional, and mental health. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you relax.
3. Connect with support: Consider reaching out to trusted friends or a therapist to discuss your feelings. It's important to have a safe and understanding space to share your thoughts.
4. Practice positive thinking: Replace negative thoughts with positive ones. Remind yourself of your strengths and accomplishments, and focus on the future.
5. Set small goals: Break your goals into manageable steps. For example, focus on one aspect of your life at a time, such as work or social connections, before moving on to others.
6. Engage in new experiences: Try new hobbies or activities to help you meet new people and broaden your horizons. These experiences will help to distract you from your past relationship and make it easier to let go.
7. Practice forgiveness: Try to forgive any wrongs done in the relationship, not only for the other person's sake, but for your own well-being. Holding onto resentment will only keep you stuck in the past.
8. Remember that time heals: Allow yourself the time and space to heal. Keep in mind that the pain will lessen with each passing day, and eventually, you will find yourself moving forward.

Remember, moving on from a relationship is a process and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Take care of yourself and trust that you will eventually find peace and happiness.
If you connect with your therapist and can say whatever you want to say and not be judged. If you feel like things, situations, your outlook are shifting for you.

I understand that this is a stressful situation for you and your family. Anxiety is a common response to new challenges and changes in life. Here are a few steps you can take to help manage your anxiety related to traveling for work:

1. Prepare: Make a list of things you need to do before leaving for your trip. This can help you feel more in control and less overwhelmed.
2. Relaxation techniques: Practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation, to help calm your mind and body.
3. Healthy lifestyle: Eat a healthy diet, get enough sleep, and engage in regular physical activity to help boost your mood and energy levels.
4. Support system: Build a support system. Talk to your family about your concerns and fears. Reach out to friends or colleagues who have experience traveling for work.
5. Professional help: If your anxiety is interfering with your ability to function daily or if it is severe, consider seeking professional help. A mental health professional can help you develop effective coping strategies and provide additional support.
6. Distractions: Bring items that bring you comfort or help you relax, such as music, books, or a favorite hobby.
7. Safety plan: Make a safety plan for dealing with a potential anxiety attack while traveling. This can include things like identifying safe places around your work location, carrying a calming object, and knowing emergency contact numbers.
8. Seek out resources: Look for resources and information about traveling with anxiety, such as articles, books, or support groups.

Remember, experiencing anxiety in a new situation is normal and it is possible to learn effective ways to manage it. Don't hesitate to reach out for help if you need it.

I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing distressing nightmares and hearing voices. This can be a very challenging experience. It's important to note that having occasional vivid dreams or hearing the voices of loved ones in your head is a normal part of being human. However, if these experiences are frequent, causing you significant distress, or interfere with your daily functioning, it may be a sign of a psychological condition, such as sleep disorders or psychosis.

I would recommend that you speak with a healthcare professional or mental health practitioner to explore the possible causes of your experiences and to determine if any treatment may be beneficial for you. Cognitive-behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and medication may be helpful in managing symptoms. Additionally, stress management techniques such as relaxation exercises, mindfulness meditation, and regular physical activity may help reduce anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

It's crucial that you don't try to cope with this on your own. Seeking professional help is the best way to ensure that you receive an accurate diagnosis and the most effective treatment. I understand that talking about these experiences can be difficult, but I'm here to support you and help you through this process. Remember, you're not alone in dealing with these issues, and there are many resources available to help you.

Hi Montgomery, Your first sentence says it all. He might be an amazing person, but there's something missing for you. I'm curious...you say this is a long distance relationship. Did you make a connection through social media or email first? Maybe a dating website? I'm just wondering if this is the case. These modern ways of meeting people are awesome because we can be exposed to a wide variety of people who we never would meet in the grocery store or a friend's party. There are complications, though, and one of the drawbacks is you can feel very connected to someone and care about them a great deal before you ever meet them in person. Then, when you finally meet them and there isn't that spark of magnetic physical attraction, you're in a bit of a difficult spot because you've already established that you're drawn to each other in other ways; you're already connected. It can be very awkward then to say "Now that I meet you, it doesn't feel the way it should for me". In the future, I suggest meeting up in person early on, to answer that crucial question "Are we physically attracted to each other?". Clearly, this is not only important for you, but it is for most of us.My guess is that you feel you owe this man your affection and commitment even though you're not really all that into him (lusting after other men is a sign of that), because you like absolutely everything else about him. But honesty is crucial here, both with yourself and this man. Just because you don't find yourself attracted to him doesn't mean that you're a bad person, or that he's not attractive. Someone else might drool over him and I think he deserves someone who does just that. You can have both love and lust. For most people, only one of them isn't enough.

Hi Winters, I learned a long time ago that I can't ever predict who will change and who won't. I meet couples who seem to have all the ingredients but can't make it work, and others who have severe issues and they decide to make better decisions and things change. But in reading your story, the image of a slot machine came to mind. You're gambling your life away on the chance that this guy will change. Only you can decide how many years to give it. I see him giving you clear signs that he doesn't even believe in himself or want to change though. What are you waiting for?Although you say you know his behaviours aren't your fault, something tells me that you're hoping your love for him will turn the key that unlocks something and makes him want to change. It doesn't work that way. Just like the slot machine, you have no power to change him or make this work. You can only decide when you've paid too much. I bet there's someone out there who loves and misses you. He's not your only support.

I understand that creating an imaginary friend, Solace, can be an effective coping mechanism for you as a teenager, especially when dealing with stress or anxiety. This is a common phenomenon, and it's not unusual for children and even adults to develop imaginary friends or companions. This "mental companion" can be a valuable tool for self-comfort, problem-solving, and gaining perspective.

However, it is essential to understand that Solace is a product of your own thoughts and creativity. While this imaginary friend can help provide comfort and advice, it is crucial not to confuse it with an actual, separate personality developing within you. Maintaining the awareness that Solace is, in fact, an extension of your own self, rather than a separate being, is vital for your mental health. Keeping this distinction in mind would help prevent any potential confusion or complications in the long run.

At this age, developing healthy coping mechanisms and practicing self-compassion can be crucial for your growth and emotional wellbeing. Embrace Solace as a helpful tool and be aware that she is an embodiment of your thoughts, feelings, and advice to yourself. Keeping a balance between imagination and reality is the key. If you feel this coping method is becoming detrimental in any way or if you feel overwhelmed by emotions or situations, it would be a good idea to reach out to a mental health professional who can help you navigate your feelings and develop new, effective coping strategies.
