I understand that this situation is causing you distress, as you feel that you're putting in a lot of effort but not receiving the same trust or understanding from your boyfriend. This dynamic can be challenging, and it is essential to address the underlying issues. It seems that you both have different needs and desires, and finding a compromise may be difficult.

First, it's important to communicate openly and honestly with your partner about how you feel. Express the hurt and frustration that comes from feeling untrusted and misunderstood. Also, share your fears, concerns, and needs, as well as your hopes for the relationship.

Second, you may consider couples therapy to work on the underlying issues in a safe and guided environment. A therapist can help you identify the sources of mistrust and negotiate compromises that work for both partners.

Lastly, it's crucial to remember that building and maintaining trust is a two-way street. Both partners need to make efforts to communicate, listen, respect each other's boundaries, and work towards finding solutions that meet both of their needs. If your relationship is truly worth saving, consider these steps to build a stronger foundation of trust and communication.

I'm sorry to hear that this has happened. Counselors are legally and ethically required to make sure that they always put the wellbeing of their clients above their own interests. In addition, counselor ethical rules, and the laws in just about every state, make it illegal for counselors to take advantage of a client financially. A counselor borrowing money from a client (even if the counselor pays it back) would usually be considered to be taking advantage of the client.There are a few options you have at this point if you can't (or don't want) to continue to try to contact him directly. You can file a complaint with your states' regulatory board and let them know what has happened.  An investigator will then look into the situation for you.  Another option would be for you to find a different counsleor who can provide you with an independent and netural point of view to help you figure out how you want to handle this situation.

I understand how difficult it can be for you as a teenager to experience so much emotion in your first job. I want to validate your feelings and assure you that it's normal to experience stress and emotions in the workplace. However, it's crucial to address the situation with your boss effectively to improve the working relationship. Here are some suggestions:

1. Prepare a calm and assertive message: Plan what you want to say to your boss beforehand. Focus on the facts and express how you felt upset, but not defensive.

2. Choose a private and appropriate time: Schedule a conversation during a less hectic time when both of you have focused attention.

3. Use a nonjudgmental and respectful tone: Use positive language and try not to blame or criticize yourself or your boss during the conversation.

4. Share your perspective and ideas: Explain why the situation affected you and offer potential solutions for resolving the issue collaboratively.

5. Listen actively to their response: Reflect on their feedback and try to understand their perspective. Be open to their suggestions and ideas.

6. Work together for solutions: Brainstorm potential solutions to the problem that work for both you and your boss.

As a psychologist, I encourage you to take action to address the concerns with your boss and maintain an open line of communication with them. Remember that every workplace will present challenges, and it's essential to find ways to cope with the stressors to grow and thrive as an employee. Good luck!

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a distressing experience. Erectile dysfunction can be caused by a variety of factors, both psychological and physiological. Some common psychological causes include stress, depression, anxiety, Guilt, and relationship issues.

Physiological causes can include conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, obesity, alcoholism, and sleep disorders. It's important to rule out any underlying medical conditions that may be contributing to your symptoms.

You mentioned that this issue has been occurring more frequently in recent years, and that it's causing major problems for your ego, self-esteem, and even your marriage. These psychological factors may be exacerbating your physical symptoms.

Here are some things you can try to help alleviate your symptoms:

1. Reduce stress: Identify the sources of stress in your life and find ways to manage them. This may include relaxation techniques such as meditation, yoga, or deep breathing.

2. Address any underlying mental health conditions: If you're experiencing depression, anxiety, or guilt, consider seeking the help of a mental health professional. They can help you identify the root causes of these conditions and develop a plan to address them.

3. Communicate openly with your partner: It's important to be open and honest with your partner about your concerns and feelings. This can help alleviate any relationship stressors that may be contributing to your symptoms.

4. Consider sexual therapy: If your symptoms persist despite your efforts to address the underlying causes, you may want to consider working with a sexual therapist. They can help you explore the psychological and emotional factors contributing to your symptoms and develop strategies to improve your sexual health and relationship.

5. Rule out medical conditions: I strongly recommend that you speak with your doctor about your symptoms to rule out any underlying medical conditions that may be contributing to your symptoms.

Please keep in mind that this is a complex issue and there might not be one simple solution. I encourage you to seek the help of a mental health professional who can help you explore the root causes of your symptoms and develop a personalized plan to address them.

I understand this is a difficult situation for you. It's important to prioritize your emotional and physical wellbeing. Here are some suggestions:

1. Focus on your own health and wellbeing: prioritize your own needs and the needs of your child, if applicable.
2. Seek social support: surround yourself with a strong support system.
3. Communicate clearly: share your concerns, feelings, and needs with your partner. Be assertive but compassionate.
4. Establish boundaries: make it clear what you will and will not tolerate in your relationship.
5. Consider all options: evaluate the viability of a future with your partner based on his actions and commitment to change.
6. Seek professional help: consider working with a therapist to process emotions, gain clarity, and develop coping skills.

Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and care, and your child deserves a healthy and stable living environment. Take things one step at a time and trust yourself to make the best choices for yourself and your child.

I understand that it can be deeply painful to experience repeated emotional abandonment, particularly in relationships, and it's not uncommon to feel a sense of self-blame or wondered if there might be something intrinsically wrong with you. However, it's essential to remember that every relationship is unique, and external circumstances, such as other people's busy schedules or personal issues, can significantly impact how things develop.

It's essential to examine your emotions and thought patterns when you experience these painful feelings. When you begin to feel that you're being abandoned or rejected, try to identify whether these emotions are based on present reality or past experiences. Are there any patterns you can observe in your relationships? Do you assume that people will leave you or abandon you based on previous experiences?

It's also essential to remember that all relationships require effort, communication, and mutual respect. If you find yourself in a relationship where you constantly feel emotionally drained, consider whether it's a healthy and reciprocal partnership.

As a first step to bettering yourself, focusing on self-care is essential. This includes taking care of your physical health, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or yoga, and engaging in activities you enjoy that promote happiness and positivity. Additionally, seek out a therapist or counselor to help you explore past experiences and develop coping strategies to manage your emotions when you feel abandoned or rejected.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and it takes courage to take the first step towards healing and growing as a person.

I'm sorry to hear that you're struggling with your past experiences. Coping with such memories can be extremely challenging, and it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. You may benefit from speaking with a mental health professional who can help you process your feelings in a safe and supportive environment. This can include techniques such as cognitive behavioral therapy, psychoeducation about development and behavior in childhood, and mindfulness practices. Engaging in healthy coping mechanisms, like exercise, writing, or hobbies, can also be beneficial. Remember, working through difficult memories takes time and patience, but it is possible to heal and grow from these experiences. Hi there! It sounds like you have already started to answer
your own question by stating that you love cross dressing very much, and I am
glad you enjoy it! Cross dressing is something many people enjoy, and there is
no harm in it whatsoever. My question to you would be: What is making you feel torn
about it? There is unfortunately still a lot of negative stigma associated with
people who express their gender or sexuality in ways that differ from the
majority. (And sometimes certain sexual interests are actually very common or
even in the majority, but because people carry shame about being different when
it comes to gender and sexuality we assume we are all alone!)Being a sexual or gender minority or someone who
participates in kink or expresses their sexuality or gender identity in a
unique and personal way often means suffering from something called
"internalized oppression". We grow up being exposed to certain
assumptions and beliefs about what is "acceptable" behavior and even
face consequences sometimes if we don't "fit in" the way others tell
us to. Even if those assumptions are harmful and wrong, we still internalize
them and feel guilty about who we are. There is nothing wrong with us, but
feeling stigmatized and isolated can lead to feelings of shame, embarrassment,
or like something is "wrong" with us.But there is absolutely nothing wrong with you, so be proud
of who you are and what you enjoy. You can continue to simply enjoy it
privately, or maybe you'd eventually like to share it with a partner or maybe
even join a community with similar interests. I'll leave you with a quote from
comedian Eddie Izzard, who identifies as, in his own words, a "straight
transvestite": "They’re not women’s clothes. They’re my clothes. I
bought them!" Take care, and thanks for your question!

My first question for you would be to see if you've talked with her about it yet? You mentioned you found out....and I know this can be so painful. It can also be frightening to bring up the experience when it hurts a lot, when you feel so unsettled as you mention. But you can look at this as a vital and important piece of information about what's happening in your relationship, and an invitation to get really honest and genuine with each other. You have a long history, being together 9 years, and a son, so you are very bonded no matter what changes happen in your relationship. It may be incredibly helpful to find a counselor you can both go talk with. Having a third party who is neutral and cares about your process and hers can be such a relief when you need to discuss things you feel scared about. Even just a few sessions can make a huge difference. If this doesn't feel possible for you right now.....ask your fiancee for time to set aside for a meaningful heart-to-heart talk. Say you'd like to set it up on the calendar, and make sure you have a babysitter for your son. Set aside at least 4 hours. Let her know that you'd like to hear her honest truth about what's going on, and share with her your truth as well. It's not a time for criticizing or condemning, and I don't sense that is your intention at all--you have a great deal of love for her. Speaking honestly and listening openly is an amazing gift, both for yourself and for your partner. You can do it.

Hello, and thank you for your question. While counselors work closely with medical providers, and sometimes have discussions about medications with people, we rarely make recommendations about how much or what type of medication a person should be taking. This is because prescribing and advising on medication is out of our scope of practice. The only exception would be if a counselor is also a physician, nurse practitioner, physician's assistant, etc. Having said that, I certainly understand that anxiety is a real serious problem that many folks struggle with. If you are currently not in therapy to help you with these panic attacks, you should consider it. Medications can be helpful for anxiety, and medications like Xanax may help for immediate relief, but they do nothing to deal with the root of anxiety and may not help with anxiety long-term. Therapists who have experience in exposure therapies would be good people to start with. Exposure therapy has good outcomes for people with anxiety disorders and panic attacks. If you are interested in speaking with your provider about the Xanax, I think explaining it the way you did on here is just fine. The provider will then decide if they feel comfortable increasing your medication. Please remember that medical providers are not trying to give people a hard time. Medications like Xanax really are highly addictive. The more you take, the more you may feel you need. The more often you may feel you need to use it. Depending on the frequency and amount of use, some people suffer serious withdrawal symptoms when they do not take the medication. It is a good idea to talk to medical provider about all of those things so that you can partner on right course of action to manage this anxiety. I certainly hope that you get some relief.... I know anxiety is awful.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

You can "move on and not live in the past" in the context of your ex-relationship, but that does not mean moving on from your child. "Moving on" then would involve accepting the end of the relationship and developing a civil relationship with your ex-partner as far as is possible for the sake of your child's development.Generally, it's good for a functional (non-abusive) parent to spend time with his/her child, but only insofar as that doesn't cause your child unnecessary stress. That requires the two adults to act like adults with each other for the sake of their child.What's confusing for children is seeing their parents act uncivilly or manipulatively. Children also do well with routines so regular dependable visitation is preferable to random visitation or, worse, not following through on commitments.But if one person is exploiting their child to harm their ex-partner, then visiting your child in that context may be stressful to him/her (depending on what you mean by using your child as a pawn). When dealing with a hostile ex-partner, your first challenge is to negotiate rules and boundaries with your ex-partner about appropriate behavior for the good of your child. If you cannot come to an agreement, a counselor can help mediate a conversation. If that's not an option, then it may be possible to turn to family court to stipulate visitation rules (for which you'd have to consult with an attorney).

I understand that it can be very distressing to feel that your significant other consistently puts you down or dismisses your feelings. This type of behavior can have negative effects on your mental health and relationship. Here are some suggestions:

1. Open communication: Express your concerns in a calm and non-accusatory manner. Ask your fiancée to listen to your perspective and validate your feelings. Try to understand the root cause of her behavior.
2. Seek professional help: Consider visiting a relationship counselor or therapist together. They can provide insight and tools for improving communication and resolving conflicts.
3. Explore personal growth: Consider the possibility that your own behavior or emotions may be contributing to the tension in the relationship. Self-reflection and personal growth can lead to emotional maturity and improved communication skills.
4. Look for other sources of support: Keep a strong support network of friends and family. Building relationships outside of the romantic relationship can provide validation and emotional security.
5. Set healthy boundaries: If your fiancée continues to put you down or dismiss your feelings, consider setting healthy boundaries in the relationship. This may include limiting the frequency of arguments or ending the relationship if the behavior does not change.

It sounds like you have been struggling with this for quite some time, using many of the same coping techniques that feel tried and true to no avail. Often, we fall back on coping techniques that would be helpful in other problems (stress, social anxieties, etc.) for our depression, but the truth is that depression requires it's own little tool kit. Depression is all-encompassing, and, based on what you've written, the symptoms are already affecting work and your personal life in myriad ways.  The best route forward would be to seek out counselling, admittedly, but if your insurance deductible is too high, that can be very expensive. I would recommend contacting your Employee Assistance Program (EAP) if offered by your employer. If not, you can look into community centres for counselling options, check if your doctor will give you a referral or your local religious organization. If, however, you are motivated to get your depression under control, there are some great workbooks out there that you can use on your own or with your therapist (as long as your therapist is trained in Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, or CBT), such as "Mind Over Mood".

I'm sorry to hear that you've been struggling with binge eating, especially during times of stress. It's important to know that you're not alone, and that many people experience this issue.

The first thing I would suggest is practicing mindfulness and self-compassion. When you feel the urge to binge eat, try to recognize the emotions you're experiencing and validate them. Instead of criticizing yourself for feeling overwhelmed, try to be kind and understanding towards yourself.

Another coping mechanism that can be helpful is engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you manage stress, such as reading, taking a walk, practicing yoga or meditation, or talking to a trusted friend or therapist.

Additionally, it can be helpful to keep a food journal to identify triggers and patterns in your eating behavior. This information can then be used to develop a plan to address the underlying causes of your binge eating.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for support and guidance. They can help you develop a personalized treatment plan and provide you with tools and resources to manage your binge eating and improve your overall mental and emotional well-being.

What your are experience is normal for most women.  We usually forget about self and totally focus on our children putting our personal wants and needs aside.  So to answer your question of how do you get to know yourself I usually do a 6 session course with my client by having them answer questions such as the following in the first session:  What do I love? (other than your children)  What are my own needs and desires?  What 3 things have I accomplished in my life that I'm most proud of?  What are 5 strengths or qualities I have?  What is one event that had a major impact on my life?  How have that event affected my life today?   For their homework assignment after the 1st session, they are asked to write a letter to self tell self what they love, cherish, appreciate and even admire about themselves.  Most women feel awkward at first, but I remind them that the truth is that only to the extent that you are able to love and value yourself, you are to love and support others.

I really love that you're taking responsibility for your pessimism here. There's a modern parable about two young brothers. One child is in a room full of every toy you could imagine, and he's miserable; the other is in a room full of horse manure, and he's flinging it around with joy. So then someone comes and asks the first boy why he's so miserable, because he has so much. He says that he's missing the one toy that he really wants. Then the brother is asked why he's so happy in a room full of manure, and he says "With all this sh-t, there's gotta be a pony in here somewhere!"Happiness is a state of mind, and I hear you saying that you used to be happy, so maybe this means you believe it's possible. That's a wonderful start.Research on depression shows us that it is very linked to pessimism. You say "I always see the worst end of things". That's pessimism. Life is like an elephant. If all you see is roughness, backup and walk around; the view will change. The key to optimism is to build your ability to see the bad things in life as 1. temporary (this will pass. I know how to fix friendships), 2. Specific (not involving the whole of your life), and 3. not your fault (tons of people fail road tests). On the flip side, it helps if we can see good things as 1. more permanent, 2. bleeding into other areas of our lives, and 3. something YOU created. Not taking credit for good things and blaming yourself for the bad ones is typical especially of women. The feelings you are having are temporary; you're in a slump and it's a good time to sit down and look at how you can make the picture look different. I think you know how; but you lack energy right now. If tackling this on your own isn't enough, a therapist can help you take that step back to look at the big picture and help you rebuild your natural resilience and capacity for joy. I wish you the best.

With the way you described your anxiety, it sounds like you have different types of anxiety. I'm not sure whether you have anxiety of public places, large crowds, being alone  (sometimes called separation anxiety), or some combination thereof.One thing that would be helpful would be to track your anxiety and see how anxious you are (on a scale of 1 to 10) in different situations. Also, if you know what leads up to your anxiety, it would be good to know this as well so you can look for patterns.As for forgetting things, you could be anxious because you are forgetting things or you could be forgetting things because you are anxious. When you are having anxiety, certain parts of your brain are overactive because you are in a kind of protective mode. It's also possible that forgetting things and anxiety are not related.Something else to try would be to notice where you feel your anxiety in your body and put your hand there is a way of giving yourself comfort.Another thing about anxiety is that having anxiety can lead to more worry about having more anxiety. One thing that helps for some people is to go to the regular primary care doctor to make sure that there are no physical problems (just for the regular physical) so they know that there are no physical problems and that the anxiety will lessen in a few minutes.Also, if you are able to notice your feet on the floor or your hips in the chair, this is helping you to be mindful of your body and connecting you to your surroundings. During this in combination with naming your emotions can be soothing as well. For example, in the grocery store, if you are feeling anxious, you could say to yourself "I'm anxious right now and I'm okay" while gently shifting your weight from one foot to the other. No one around you would notice what you were doing and the motion may be soothing to you.Anxiety can have a lot of different causes and things that trigger it. If it is difficult for you to work it out on your own (which is very common), consider talking with a local therapist so you can have more specific ideas.Also consider making a list of people who you trust and what it is about them that makes you feel comfortable.

I understand that this is a difficult topic for you, and I appreciate your openness in sharing your concerns with me. Having thoughts about harming others does not necessarily mean that you are a threat to yourself or others. However, it's important to acknowledge that such thoughts can be distressing and troubling. There are a few things that could be contributing to these thoughts:

1. Underlying emotional distress: Depression, anxiety, or other emotional disorders can lead to intrusive and distressing thoughts.
2. Traumatic experiences: Past traumatic experiences, such as abuse, violence, or neglect, can impact your emotional well-being and contribute to destructive thoughts.
3. Psychological conditions: Conditions such as dissociative disorders, psychosis, or borderline personality disorder, can manifest in thoughts or impulses that are not in line with your true character or intentions.
4. Influence of media, literature, or movies: Exposure to violent media or literature can sometimes influence our thoughts and perceptions.
5. Biological factors: Certain medical conditions or neurological disorders can affect brain chemistry and contribute to unwanted thoughts.

It's important to note that having these types of thoughts does not make you a bad person or a danger to others. However, if you feel that these thoughts are becoming increasingly frequent, intense, or distressing, it's best to speak with a mental health professional who can assess your situation and provide you with the support and resources needed to address the underlying causes and manage your thoughts effectively.

Remember, it's never too late to seek help, and by reaching out for support, you're taking an important step towards improving your mental health and overall well-being.

Patient, it sounds like you're experiencing intrusive thoughts or negative self-talk. These thoughts can be distressing and painful, but they don't necessarily represent the truth. They're often a manifestation of underlying stress, anxiety, or depression.

As a psychologist, I would recommend several strategies to help you manage and reduce these thoughts. One effective method is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which involves identifying and challenging the negative thoughts with evidence-based reasoning. Another approach is mindfulness meditation, which can help you stay focused on the present moment and reduce the impact of intrusive thoughts.

You may also find it helpful to practice self-compassion and engage in activities that bring you joy and a sense of accomplishment. Consider seeking support from friends, family, or a mental health professional, who can offer encouragement and guidance as you work to overcome these thoughts. Remember, it takes time and effort to change the patterns in your thought habits, but with commitment and the right tools, you can make progress toward greater mental wellness.

However, if this behavior is causing you distress, it might be worth exploring in more depth. I understand that you are going through a difficult time, and it's commendable that you want to overcome your PTSD and depression. Living with these conditions can be challenging, and it's normal for you to feel scared, paranoid, and vivid memories of past traumas. However, it's essential to know that you don't have to face this alone.

I would recommend seeking professional help, such as meeting with a mental health specialist or a therapist. They can provide you with evidence-based treatments, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), or trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, which are effective in treating PTSD and depression.

Medication, such as antidepressants and anti-anxiety meds, can also provide relief and help you manage your symptoms. It's essential to find a healthcare professional who can offer an integrative approach to your treatment, addressing both your PTSD and depression.

Practicing self-care, engagement in pleasurable activities, establishing a consistent sleep schedule, practicing mindfulness meditation, and seeking support from loved ones and support groups can also be effective ways to improve your overall well-being.

Remember, taking care of your mental health is just as important as caring for your physical health, and you are not alone in this journey. Help is available, and I encourage you to seek it out.

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling very depressed, and it's important that you reach out for help. There are several ways to find someone to talk to:

1. Your Primary Care Physician: Your doctor can refer you to a mental health professional in your area.
2. Mental Health Hotlines: There are several free and confidential crisis hotlines available, such as the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (1-800-273-TALK) or the Crisis Text Line (text HOME to 741741).
3. Online Therapy: There are also various online therapy services that you can explore. Many of these services offer free initial consultations, so you can try a few different ones to find a good fit.
4. Support Groups: Joining a support group for people dealing with similar issues can be very helpful. You can find local support groups through organizations like the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) or Mental Health America.

Whichever option you choose, remember that it's okay to ask for help, and taking this step towards improving your mental health is a courageous one.

I understand that you're feeling a lot of pressure and anxiety about your virginity and lack of romantic relationships. It's normal to want to feel like you're not falling behind your peers, especially when it comes to matters of love and intimacy. However, it's important to remember that everyone's timeline and experiences are unique, and there is no right or wrong way to navigate these things.

The fact that you've had these experiences with strangers online doesn't make you any less valuable or desirable as a person. It's understandable that you may feel used or dirty afterward, but it's important to remember that your worth isn't defined by these experiences.

It's important to focus on your own values and priorities, rather than societal expectations or pressure from others. Consider focusing on self-care, building healthy friendships, and pursuing hobbies and interests that bring you joy and fulfillment.

It's also important to work on building a healthy and positive body image. Comparing yourself to others and seeking validation through relationships or sexual experiences can contribute to negative feelings about yourself and your worth.

As for dating and relationships, it's important to remember that it's okay to take your time and not rush into things. Building a strong foundation of communication, trust, and mutual respect with a partner is worth waiting for. Rather than focusing on finding a partner to lose your virginity to, focus on finding someone who values and cares for you as a person. This can include seeking out opportunities to meet new people, joining clubs or organizations that align with your interests, or even seeking the help of a dating coach or therapist to work on building your confidence and communication skills.

Ultimately, it's important to remember that no one can define your worth or determine your timeline for relationships and intimacy except for you. Focus on being true to yourself, practicing self-care, and seeking support from trusted friends, family, or professionals when needed.

Basically, your response is the fight, flight or freeze reaction
which is hard wired into the human nervous system, specifically, the autonomic nervous system (called the autonomic response).  This system
is responsible for regulating the heart, digestion, respiratory rate
as well as other aspects which match the symptoms you describe.  It is largely an unconscious function, but
with training it can be managed such as a public speaking course in which you
prepare and even have some exposure to smaller experiences to help you prepare
and cope for larger presentations.  One of the greatest applications of
addressing this response is the NASA program which exposes the astronauts to situations
they will encounter while in space which will trigger the response so that when
it does happen (not if but when) that they are able to move through the
challenge with success.  You can learn
more about his by going to TED Talks “What I learned about going blind in space” It is
a truly inspiring look at what you are experiencing as well as how to deal with
it. 
With that being said, finding a program
like a Dale Carnegie Public Speaking program can help.  Working with a counselor who can help you
utilize visualization of an upcoming speech has been shown to help and you can
always talk to your doctor to see what options might be available there as
well. Good luck!

Hello. First, I am so sorry you are experiencing these feelings. They can be intense, I will do my best to offer some suggestions or thoughts that I hope will be helpful to you. There could be a number of things occurring. Therapy is a delicate, private decision and I would first like to commend you for the fact that you are not giving up, that you are working to figure this out, and make this work, it sounds like you are engaged and motivated to receive support from a professional, your continued  dedication and motivation will take you far. I would first start by asking if you have discussed this with your therapist, if you feel comfortable enough telling your therapist what is going on, maybe inform the therapist that  that you feel nervous and shaky. I am a firm believer in open communication between the client and therapist as this builds a healthy therapeutic relationship that yields positive outcomes, if this can be obtained and well received. This is YOUR time for healing and therapy should be a safe, supportive environment to not only process but to seek support and guidance from a professional who can help you move past the barriers. If you feel you are comfortable and able to speak to your therapist, that would be my first suggestion, is to tell he or she how you are feeling. If they know then they can help determine the potential cause and allow you to process and move forward. If this is left un resolved it will be hard for you to move forward. If you are not comfortable discussing this with your therapist, this may be something to take into consideration and worthy of thinking about: why you are not comfortable speaking to the therapist. I understand this is difficult. If I may offer one more suggestion, breathing exercises are very beneficial. Remind yourself what you are working to achieve, close your eyes in a safe moment and breathe in and out slowly, in slowly through your nose and out through your mouth with pursed lips. Breathe in for approximately 5-10 seconds, then let it out slowly. Be sure and do this when you are in private, and feel safe environment. When you begin, I suggest putting your hand on your stomach, over your belly button to feel yourself actually taking in those deep breaths. I know it may sound kind of silly but they really work and are incredibly helpful. We often forget to breathe, especially when we  are feeling anxious. You are supported here and try taking yourself through the above thought process and breathing and practice the breathing several times a day. I hope this shaky and uneasy feeling eases. Wishing you the very best!Laura Cassity, LMSW, LMAC

I understand that discovering new information about your partner's past can be upsetting. It's important to remember that trust is a fundamental component of a healthy relationship. Lying and broken promises can be signs of dishonesty or secrecy, which can undermine that trust. In your situation, you've asked about women your partner works with, and he's disclosed some information, but he forgot to mention a girl. The fact that he forgot may indicate that the connection was not significant. However, the lying and broken promises from the past are concerning.

If you are considering reconciling, it might be helpful to have an open and honest discussion about this and any other incidents from the past. This conversation should be focused on understanding the root causes of those actions and making a commitment to move forward with trust and honesty. If the explanation seems insufficient or if you feel that the trust is irreparably damaged, you may want to reconsider the relationship. Only you can decide what feels right for you.

It sounds like you're in a complicated situation in your relationship. I want to assure you that having doubts and asking questions about a partner's actions is a normal part of a relationship. However, it's also important for both partners to maintain trust and open communication. In your case, it seems that trust has been broken, and you both may be struggling to understand each other's perspectives.

I would suggest trying to have an honest and calm conversation with your wife about your concerns. It might be helpful to express your feelings and concerns, without making accusations or blaming her. Ask her to be open and honest with you as well. Try to listen actively to her responses and validate her feelings and concerns. This can help both of you gain a better understanding of each other and find a resolution to the issue at hand.

It's also important to talk to a mental health professional for support. They can provide guidance and insights based on your specific situation. Remember, it's natural to feel uncertain and have questions in a relationship, but it's how you and your partner communicate and handle those questions that can make all the difference.

There are an infinite number of possibilities here. You included a lot of things that you don't have. Is there anyway that you can have some freedom for a few hours a week, at least? A lot of times stay at home moms have groups when they meet at different public places where their children can play together and they can talk together. I don't know how old your child or children is/are, but perhaps going back to work is something that can happen in the future.I wonder if you may consider who you have in your life who can support you. I don't know whether you have a spouse or parents or siblings who could help out with some different things. I wonder if you could consider where you would like to go if you had two or three hours that you could do whatever you wanted? If you can sort out some possible answers to that, maybe you can work together with friends or family to make it happen.Also, again depending on the age of your children, some parents can do things while the children are sleeping, even if you are in the same room. For example, if your children are sleeping for about two hours, maybe 30 minutes of that could be reserved for you and the rest could be for cleaning or other things you need to do.

One thing that comes to mind is making a list of some things that happen each day. It could be that there are things that are affecting how upset you are, but because so many other things are going on, you may not notice.Another idea to try is to keep a list for a month of one good thing that happened each day. This way, when you're having a rough day, you have a list to think of and take a look at.Are you eating and sleeping in ways that are typical for you (typically at least two meals per day and roughly 8 hours of sleep that night (may be different depending on your age)? These two ideas are closely related to changes in your mood.From where do you have support? Friends or family?Can you take 5 or 10 minutes per day to do something that you enjoy?If you think back to the last time that you felt "content," what was contributing to that?Another possibility is to try to be mindful of things that you do every day. For example, rather than eating a turkey sandwich as fast as possible on your lunch break, consider actually tasting it and enjoying it. Also consider giving yourself praise for doing something well. For example, when you finish your paperwork, take a moment to notice that and maybe reward yourself by checking your e-mail, reading five pages of a book, or something else that can be done quickly before you get back to your next task.

I imagine this is very difficult and confusing for you.It sounds like there are things for which you are proud of yourself, which is really good. I hope there are also other people in your life that are currently able to recognize the good things that you're doing.If you think your mom would be willing to go to see a local mental health professional with you, that may be a good place to have some discussions about the relationship that the two of you have. The reason I'm suggesting that it may be easier to have the conversations there is because sometimes the mental health professional can point out parts of conflict that are not easy for the people who are involved to actually see by themselves.If you want to try to talk with you mom to see how she is feeling, maybe she would be willing to discuss it with you. If you're going to have a conversation like that, I would suggest you try these things:Ask her if this would be a good time to have an important conversation. If she says no, consider asking her when would be a better time.Try to have the conversation with the goal of taking about five minutes to learn more about where she is coming from on this. If you can ask questions to learn more about that, you may be able to know more about what she is thinking and feeling.This doesn't mean that you have to agree with her, but just that you are able to hear where she is coming from.Try to ask questions that start with the words who, what, how, where, when. Questions that start with the word "why" can be difficult to answer and can lead to a lot of extra emotion.Try to summarize what she is saying to see if you have it right.If you want your mom to know how you feel, after you can listen to what she is saying and see if she is willing to listen to what you would like to say.If you're going to tell your mom about how you feel, consider having some points written down ahead of time so you can explain yourself the way that you want to.It will probably be really hard to listen to her without being defensive right away. I know I would be wanting to jump right into the conversation. Remember that jumping in right away will probably make it more difficult to learn where your mom is coming from.Also, if she says she doesn't want to have a conversation, remember that she has that choice.If your mom does not want to go to see a counselor with you, remember that you could go on your own. Depending on your state and exactly how old you are, you may need your parent's permission to be in treatment, but not always. If you need help to figure that out, try contacting a couple of local mental health agencies to see if they can help you figure out what to do if you want to talk to someone.

I understand your struggle with imposter syndrome, and it's commendable that you recognize your accomplishments despite the inner voice that questions them. Imposter syndrome is a common experience, particularly in academic settings where high achievement and excellence are expected. Here are a few suggestions that may help you manage these feelings:

1. Reframe your mindset: Instead of focusing on the fear of being found out as a fraud, reframe your thoughts to acknowledge your achievements and the effort you have put into them.
2. Challenge your inner critic: When the feeling of being an imposter arises, challenge those negative thoughts by providing evidence that contradicts them.
3. Practice self-compassion: Be kind to yourself and allow yourself to experience emotions like fear or doubt without judgment.
4. Seek support: Talk to friends, family, or colleagues about your feelings and gain a perspective from outside of your own internal dialogue.
5. Focus on the present moment: Instead of dwelling on past mistakes or potential future outcomes, focus on the present moment and the work you need to do right now.

Remember, imposter syndrome is a common experience, and many successful individuals have felt the same way at some point in their careers. It takes time and effort to silence that inner critic, but with practice, it is possible to overcome these feelings and continue to thrive in your academic pursuits.

It sounds like you have the perception that people are frequently disappointed in you, wish you were different or someone else, and ultimately reject you. One question I would have for you is what is your evidence that people feel this way? Is there anything in people's words or behaviors that gives you this impression? If your not sure, it may be useful for you to try to notice what people say and do in response to you, even though you perceive these attitudes within them. Additionally, working with a competent therapist may be a great way to get an answer to your question as well as developing ways to move forward with that answer and gain a sense of self-esteem and security in your relationships.One possibility that comes to mind, of which there may be more, is that as we grow up, we often develop relational templates, or sets of expectations about how people are and will relate to us, which influence our experiences and behavior in relationships. Sometimes the templates that we develop to stay connected growing up are not particularly adaptive for adult life and can hamper our self-esteem and capacity for comfortable intimacy as an adult. You ask a great question here, and one that can be very hard to see through, given the difficulty of feeling that people think of you in this way, and I hope that you will stay curious about this and consider working with a therapist who is trained to help you discover the answer.

I understand your concern, and it's essential to acknowledge that past experiences can influence current relationships. I would recommend the following steps to help you and your boyfriend improve your sex life and alleviate your fears related to pain during intercourse:

1. Open Communication: Discuss your past experiences, fears, and concerns with your boyfriend. Be honest about how it affects you in the present and how it has impacted your sex life. Reassure him that you trust him and that you're working through this issue together.

2. Address Fears Proactively: You might consider seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor specializing in sexual health. They can help you develop coping strategies and techniques to address your fears and improve your sexual experiences.

3. Educate Yourself: Learning about sexual health, pain during sex, and communication skills can help you feel more empowered and confident in your relationship. You might find reading books, attending workshops, or watching educational videos beneficial.

4. Set Boundaries: Allow your boyfriend to respect your boundaries during intimate moments. Communicate your comfort level and discuss what works best for both of you. You may need to explore different positions, paces, or techniques to find what feels good and comfortable for you.

5. Practice Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques: Engaging in relaxation practices like mindfulness meditation or deep breathing exercises can help you feel more relaxed and focused when dealing with anxiety or fear during sexual experiences.

6. Seek Medical Advice: If your fear of pain is severe, consider consulting a healthcare professional, like an obstetrician-gynecologist, for an assessment to rule out any medical issues contributing to your pain and discomfort during intercourse. Receiving a professional medical evaluation may provide peace of mind and alleviate any concerns related to your physical wellbeing.

Good observation on your part, to distinguish that your feelings in relation to your mom are not necessarily connected to the way she handles her part of the relation toward you.Has your mom usually ignored your opinions and wishes in relating to you?If prior to the onset of Alzheimer's, she never examined her way of relating to you, and if both of you have never had an open conversation about your sense of feeling hurt by her attitudes and manner with you, then the relationship between you and your mom will change in ways other than rational dialogue.She may continue ignoring or overlooking your wishes because she's been stuck in this attitude for most of your life.The good news for you about this is realizing that who you are and your way of relating to your mom, has very little to do with the way she relates to you.This is a more profound disappointment because it shows that her disconnect from you has been for longer than when the Alzheimer's began.You can however, feel a little more free knowing that you're not deserving of being ignored.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time. It's not uncommon for people to experience strong emotions after a breakup, especially when there were deep feelings involved and a long-term commitment was present. The fact that you're still suffering a year later suggests that there might be some unresolved feelings or unmet needs that you're grappling with.

It might be helpful for you to consider a few things. First, it's essential to understand that healing from a breakup takes time. This process involves grieving the loss of the relationship, allowing yourself to feel the painful emotions, and gradually working to rebuild your sense of self-worth and confidence. This can be a lengthy process, and it's essential to be patient with yourself during this time.

Secondly, it may be valuable to explore the reasons why the long-distance relationship didn't work out. Often, when we're apart from our partners, we miss the connections that we had when we were together. However, it's also crucial to acknowledge that being in a long-distance relationship presents unique challenges, and that even if both partners are committed to making it work, there are often logistical and emotional obstacles that can be challenging to overcome.

Another consideration is whether there are any unmet emotional or psychological needs that you're seeking to fulfill through the memories of your past relationship. This can be a challenging topic to explore on your own, and it may be helpful to work with a therapist to gain some insight into the underlying emotions and motivations that are driving your continuing attachment to your ex.

Lastly, it's important to consider taking steps to move forward in your life. This might involve engaging in activities that bring you joy, connecting with friends, pursuing new hobbies or interests, or even considering meeting new people and possibly starting a new relationship. While it's natural to feel hesitant or uncertain about this, it's crucial to remember that healing from a breakup involves taking steps to rebuild your sense of self and your life.

In summary, healing from a breakup takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself during this process. Grappling with the reasons why the long-distance relationship didn't work, addressing any unmet emotional or psychological needs, and taking steps to move forward in

You are right that his insecurities are at the root of the issue.  You cannot change that for him.  He will have to do the work to handle those emotions on his own.  What you can do is reassure him in whatever ways possible, but always recognizing that you can't "fix" this for him.  When I work with people who struggle with their partner's past experiences, I always frame it like this:  Everything that you've experienced has resulted in you being the person you are today.  The person they claim to love.  If you had not gone through some of those experiences, you would not be in the position you're in now, ready to commit to him and know that you're satisfied with that.  Just as when bad things happen to us, we have to find a way to appreciate the lessons learned your fiance has to accept that you're the person you are today because of what you have gone through.  Celebrate that you have moved through that and have landed in this perfect position with him!Hope that helps, Allison

I understand that a breakup can be a difficult experience, and it's normal to feel sadness or preoccupation with the memories of the relationship. However, dwelling excessively on the past can prevent you from moving forward. Here are some suggestions to help you move on:

1. Allow yourself to grieve: It's important to acknowledge your feelings and give yourself time to heal.
2. Practice self-care: Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally will help you feel better and improve your overall well-being.
3. Set boundaries: Avoid contact with your ex if it's causing more pain than good.
4. Keep busy: Engage in activities that bring you joy and help take your mind off the breakup.
5. Seek support from loved ones: Talking to trusted friends and family members can be helpful in getting a different perspective and feeling less alone.
6. Write down your thoughts and feelings: Journaling can be a helpful way to process your emotions and gain clarity.
7. Consider therapy: If you find that you're having a difficult time moving on, consider seeking the help of a mental health professional. They can provide you with tools and strategies to help you work through your emotions and move forward.

Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can also support a healthy sex drive. Reach out to your healthcare provider or local mental health resources for further support and guidance.

Counselors consider several factors when deciding to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client. The first and most important factor is the therapeutic relationship. If that relationship has reached a point where the client is able to effectively manage their mental health and emotional wellbeing independently, the counselor may suggest termination.

Another factor is the client’s progress towards their therapeutic goals. If a client has achieved the objectives they sought out when they began counseling, the counselor may discuss the possibility of termination.

The client’s readiness for termination is also important. Sometimes a client might be reluctant to end sessions even when they are no longer in need of counseling. In these cases, the counselor might help the client explore their feelings about termination and prepare for life outside of sessions.

Additionally, a counselor may need to terminate a therapeutic relationship if they themselves are no longer able to provide effective counseling. This could be due to personal reasons, such as illness, or professional reasons, such as a move to another location.

Termination is always a collaborative process between the counselor and the client. They will discuss the reasons for termination, review the client’s progress, and make a plan for continuing successful mental health management after counseling sessions end.

Yes, it's normal to feel anxious or nervous when attending therapy sessions, especially when you're new to the experience. Many people do feel this way initially. This feeling can be due to various reasons such as uncertainty about what to expect, fear of being judged, or apprehension about discussing personal issues. However, if the anxiety is so intense that it prevents you from attending sessions or participating fully in them, then it may be helpful to discuss this with your therapist. They can work with you to help you manage your anxiety and make the therapy session a more comfortable and productive experience for you. Remember, therapy is a process, and with time and effort, you may find that your anxiety lessens and you begin to feel more at ease.

I understand your situation, and I want to clarify that I can't make this decision for you as a psychologist, but I can provide some guidance. It's essential for children to maintain a relationship with both parents when it's safe and in their best interest. However, I also understand that your daughter's experiences with her father have been traumatic.

In this case, I would recommend that you explore other options before forcing her to attend therapy to see her father. You could try alternative methods for resolving her conflicted feelings toward her father, such as:

1. Family therapy: You could consider attending family therapy sessions with your daughter, which can help her process her emotions and develop coping skills. A therapist can help facilitate these conversations and provide a safe environment for all parties involved.
2. Supportive therapy: Your daughter could benefit from individual therapy sessions to help her cope with her emotions and develop healthy ways to deal with her difficult experiences.
3. Gradual reintroduction: Consider a gradual reintroduction of your daughter to her father, with the involvement of a trusted adult or professional. This could include short, supervised visits or even engaging in activities that your daughter enjoys with her father from a safe distance.
4. Open communication: Have open and age-appropriate conversations with your daughter about her feelings and concerns. Let her know that it's okay to have mixed emotions and that she doesn't have to see her father if she doesn't want to.
5. Legal support: If necessary, consult with a lawyer or legal authority to ensure the best interests of your daughter and help establish a safe and balanced solution.

Remember, it's essential to prioritize your daughter's emotional well-being and ensure that she feels safe and supported throughout this process. If she isn't ready to see her father yet, it's crucial to respect her wishes and continue to provide her with a stable and loving environment.

It sounds like you are experiencing symptoms of intrusive or obsessive thoughts, which can be a sign of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) or other related conditions. These thoughts, which you describe as unwanted and distressing, can be particularly upsetting due to their intensity and repetition. The good news is that with appropriate interventions, you can effectively manage these thoughts.

First, it's essential to understand that having unwelcome thoughts, even those related to self-worth or worthlessness, does not define your identity or character. These thoughts exist in our minds, and they don't necessarily reflect reality or your true values.

Some strategies you can try to minimize the impact of these thoughts include:

1. Mindfulness and relaxation techniques: These techniques, such as deep-breathing exercises, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation, can help you develop greater awareness of your thoughts and emotions and reduce anxiety or stress that may exacerbate intrusive thoughts.
2. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): CBT is a form of psychotherapy that can help you challenge and reframe negative thoughts. Through this process, you will learn to recognize and replace destructive thought patterns with healthier and more balanced alternatives.
3. Exposure and response prevention (ERP): ERP is a form of cognitive behavioral therapy that specifically targets OCD symptoms. In this therapy, you will be gradually exposed to stimuli that trigger the unwanted thoughts, while learning techniques to prevent yourself from engaging in compulsive behaviors that serve to alleviate anxiety.

It's essential to seek professional help from a mental health professional or psychologist to discuss the best course of action for your specific situation. They can assess your condition, provide you with evidence-based treatments, and support you throughout your recovery process. Remember, experiencing unwanted thoughts is normal and doesn't define you as a person. With the right tools and professional guidance, you'll be equipped to manage these thoughts effectively and improve your quality of life.

At present, the American Disability Association (ADA) only allows protection and guiltiness for Service Animals, which is fall under a separate distinction from Emotional Support Animals. Emotional support animals are untrained animals (typically pets or other domestic animals) that provide wonderful services to their owners, and there are many benefits to having one.Service animals who are trained to provide specific services for an individual with limitations that make them fall under what the ADA defines as "disabled" are protected under specific laws, and must be accommodated in public places where the human they serve is present. While it may be beneficial to request that the therapist who "prescribed" the dog to you write a letter to the apartment manager, it sounds like the manager is aware of ADA guidelines, and the simplest course of action may be to find an alternative residence, if that is a plausible option.

Ouch. Losing someone you love hurts so much. We all long to be loved and to love and to have that experience and then lose it is awful. While it is easy to feel angry or start doubting yourself under these circumstances, I would encourage you to recognize the agony of what you are experiencing as an indication of how much you value loving relationships and how much you want to make this happen in your life. If you are not comfortable with going to those in your life it may be a good time to see  a counsellor to help you cope with your distress and learn how to move past this and find the love that you are looking for.

This is a fantastic question. In one sentence, I would say the following:Recognize that while you and your partner probably have common interests and areas of commonality, you are separate people, each with different wants, wishes, and desires – if you consider a diagram of two overlapping circles, they may share perhaps a third of the circle with overlap to indicate commonality (could be more or less) and then there are parts of the circles that are not overlapping, indicating separate interestsAs for ways that may strengthen any relationship, even the great ones, this is what came to mind. There are certainly more specific unique answers or elements for different people as far as the details, but here are some general ideas:Try to have at least 15 minutes a week where you are spending time together and not problem-solvingRealize that listening to your partner does not mean that you are agreeing with them, it just means that you are saying that you hear where they are coming fromLearn to hold on to your own wants, wishes, and desires while also recognizing those of your partnerSet boundaries for what is and isn't acceptable behavior during an argument or difficult discussionDiscuss how having important discussions can be anxiety-producing and consider having an understanding that if one of you (or both of you) feels overwhelmed, you can take a timeout for a certain amount of time. For example, you may say "okay, I'm feeling really stressed about this right now. Let's discuss it in an hour." And at that time, go back to the discussionConsider what your partner's top three or four complaints about you may be. Check in with them and see how accurate you are. If you see validity in their responses, consider whether or not you may want to make changesDiscover what makes your partner feel loved, valued, appreciated, or specialRelationships are always in progress and constantly changing. Some anxiety around change is typical. Being able to effectively discuss the anxiety and actually listen to one another without being defensive, name calling, finger-pointing, or asking each other to change is a true gift.You may enjoy this quote: "Connection is the energy that is created between people when they feel seen, heard, and valued; when they can give and receive without judgment." ~Brene Brown

Based on the information you've provided, it does seem that your alcohol consumption is causing significant distress and negative consequences in your life. Your anger and regrettable behaviors while drunk, as well as the lingering feelings of guilt you experience afterward, are all red flags that suggest a potential problem.

It's important to note that not everyone who drinks excessively or makes mistakes while drinking has an alcohol use disorder. However, your experience of guilt and regret, particularly if it's a regular occurrence, may be indicative of a more problematic relationship with alcohol.

To be sure, it may be helpful to assess the extent to which alcohol is impacting your life and weigh the potential benefits and harms of your drinking patterns. A psychologist or other mental health professional can help you explore your relationship with alcohol and provide you with strategies to manage it in a healthy way.

In the meantime, you might consider limiting your alcohol intake or abstaining from drinking altogether for a period of time to see how you feel. This can help you gain a clearer perspective on how alcohol is affecting your mood, behavior, and overall well-being.

Remember, you're not alone in experiencing these concerns, and there are many resources available to help you address them. I encourage you to reach out for support and take steps to prioritize your mental and emotional health.

I understand that you feel overwhelmed with the number of issues you're currently facing. Having a history of sexual abuse, surviving breast cancer, dealing with depression, anxiety, insomnia, and low self-esteem, are indeed significant challenges. However, it's important to note that mental health concerns and personal experiences are interconnected, and addressing each issue can have a positive impact on the others.

While it is true that having multiple concerns can make counseling feel more complex, it's not unmanageable. In fact, many therapies, such as trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy or integrative psychotherapy, are specifically designed to address the interconnected nature of these issues.

I would suggest reaching out to a mental health professional, such as a licensed therapist or psychologist, to discuss your concerns and explore treatment options. A mental health professional can help you develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses your specific needs and goals, leaving you feeling more equipped to handle the challenges you're currently facing. It's essential to remember that seeking help is a courageous step towards improving your overall well-being.

I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling depressed. You are not alone in this, and it's important to reach out for support. Here are some options you could consider:

1. Reach out to friends or family members you trust and feel comfortable talking to about your feelings.
2. Consider joining a support group where you can meet others who may be experiencing similar emotions.
3. Seek professional help such as a therapist or counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to manage your depressive symptoms.
4. Call a helpline like the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255) in the US, if you are feeling hopeless or suicidal.
5. Look into online communities and forums where people share their experiences and provide support to one another.

Remember, talking to someone about how you're feeling can be an important step towards improving your mental health. It's essential that you prioritize your emotional wellbeing. Please let me know if you have any questions or need more information.

Hey!  It takes a lot of courage to share your feelings with someone!  And it sounds like you have been lucky to meet someone who makes you feel safe enough to explore some of your more painful feelings.  A big part of the process, however, of strengthening your self-concept is learning how to tell yourself those positive messages that you heard from your friend!  Leaving for college may also be contributing to your feelings of unsteadiness.  Try this - Make a list of all of the positive things that you know are true about yourself.  Ask your friends and family to contribute to the list.  Then carry it with you in your wallet - and when you need a self-esteem boost, take a look at it!  You are in a season of life that presents lots of challenges and opportunities.  Reach out to your long-distance friend when you need support - and take a walk over to the campus counseling center and check out what they might have to offer.  Be Wise!

I'm glad you've reached out to me to talk about your feelings, and I can understand how difficult it can be to feel like you were born in the wrong body. What you're experiencing is known as gender dysphoria, which is a feeling of distress because there's a discrepancy between your biological sex and your gender identity. It's important to recognize that feeling this way isn't a choice, and that there are resources and support available to help you.

I'd encourage you to begin by seeking out a mental health professional, such as a therapist or psychologist, with experience in working with transgender individuals. They can help you navigate your feelings and provide you with resources and guidance throughout your transition process. This might include referring you to other medical professionals, like an endocrinologist or a gender affirming surgeon, for medical treatment if that's what you ultimately decide you want.

It's also important to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being. In the meantime, you might find it helpful to start exploring your feminine identity through experimenting with clothing or makeup, or by using a female name. These steps can often be helpful in helping individuals feel more congruent with their true selves.

Regarding your family, I understand that it can be a challenge to come out to them, especially if they have negative attitudes towards the transgender community. It's understandable that you might be concerned about their reaction. However, it's important to remember that their opinions do not dictate your identity. It can be helpful to practice self-care and prioritize your own emotional well-being during this time, and to seek out supportive communities or organizations where you can meet others who understand your experiences. Ultimately, coming out to your family can be a process that occurs over time, and you'll have the opportunity to decide when and how you want to share this information with them. I encourage you to take things at your own pace and remember that your safety and emotional well-being should always come first. If you need additional support or resources, there are many online communities and organizations dedicated to helping transgender individuals navigate their journey. I'm here to support you through this process as well.

It sounds like you may be asking two different questions.With regard to what you said about your husband dressing as a female in your bedroom, I wonder if you would consider asking him more about this. If you choose to do that, I would suggest that you ask him whether a certain time is a good time to have a conversation and asking questions for five minutes or more that are related to you learning more about his experience. This can be difficult to do at times, particularly when you may want to offer your own opinions or become very anxious or of type. Consider thinking of a phrase that may help you to stay calm during the discussion. It may be helpful to think of yourself as asking questions as if you were an investigative reporter and using questions that start with words like "what, how, who, where, when." Questions that start with "why," can be very difficult to answer for some people and can be overwhelming because it often links to answers involving emotions that may or may not be understood. Also try restating what your husband is saying to make sure that you are understanding correctly. If what he is telling you is different than what you have heard or thought of for many years, it may be challenging to follow his meaning initially. Remember that listening to your husband does not imply agreement with what he is saying, just that you are following and looking to understand what he is experiencing. I also recommend sticking to one topic for the conversation, but this could be done with many different topics over time.You could also see if he would be willing to have a discussion where he listens like an investigative reporter to learn more about the experience that you are having.As far as what you mentioned about the sexual experience, maybe if you can discuss what it is that you don't like and/or understand what it is that he does like, you could see if there is some middle ground here. It depends on what you both prefer.These types of conversations can be difficult to have for some couples, at least initially. Having structured conversations, such as the ones I've described briefly above, can feel awkward initially, but the reason it can be helpful is because it can lead to further understanding in a way that decreases the chances of having an argument.Also consider seeing a therapist in your area who specializes in couples to discuss some of these ideas.

It sounds like you are feeling pretty stuck, lonely, and hopeless; like you have a desire to be more connected to people and to find purpose in life, but are not sure what to do. Additionally, anything you can do to give yourself a little break from the feeling of pointlessness and any ruminating thoughts you may be having may be of help. I know it may sound pointless in the moment, and you may feel a great deal of inertia in doing so, but you may find that if you force yourself to do something small that is pleasurable, like taking a walk for example, there's a good chance you will be glad that you did so after the fact. Thank you for reaching out.

It's important to acknowledge that feelings of attraction can change over time and aren't always consistent. Relationships require effort and commitment, and it's normal for challenges to arise. In your case, it seems that you're grappling with the idea of long-term compatibility based on physical attraction.

The concept of the "perfect guy" is subjective and can vary greatly from person to person. It's possible that your current partner may not be as physically appealing to you as others, but he might possess other qualities that make him the better match for you in terms of emotional and intellectual compatibility.

When considering marriage, it's essential to weigh the importance of physical attraction versus other aspects, such as mutual respect, trust, communication, and shared values. If you find that, despite your physical attractions, you have a strong foundation built on these fundamentals, it might be worth considering the long-term potential of your relationship and the benefits it offers beyond physical attraction.

That being said, it's always important to communicate openly with your partner about your feelings and concerns to determine whether you both can work towards improving your relationship. If you find that the issues at hand are not resolvable, then it might be time to consider whether staying in the relationship is truly best for your emotional well-being.

In summary, while physical attraction can play a role in the success of a relationship, it's not the only factor. Consider addressing the underlying causes of your feelings and discuss them openly with your partner to gain a clearer understanding of the health and viability of your relationship.

I'm sorry to hear that you've been through a painful experience. Love can be a complex emotion, and its impact on us can be intense. Reach out to friends, family, or a support group for emotional support, engage in activities that bring you joy, and consider seeking psychotherapy if the pain persists for an extended period. Remember, it takes time to heal, and everyone's healing process is unique. Be patient and kind to yourself.

I'm sorry to hear about the difficult situation you and your brother are facing. As a psychologist, I cannot provide you with legal advice. According to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), I cannot disclose any confidential information about your brother's mental health diagnosis or treatment without his consent. Additionally, in most jurisdictions, it is typically the legal responsibility of the parent or guardian of a minor to make such decisions, but in your case, since you are not the legal guardian, there may be limitations to your ability to commit your brother to a mental health facility. It would be best for you to consult with a mental health professional or legal advisor in your area for specific guidance about your situation and potential options, such as a possible involuntary commitment process. It may also be helpful to try to engage your brother's mother in seeking help for your brother's well-being, as her involvement could make a significant difference in his treatment and care.

One way to concentrate is that if your mind starts to wonder then remind yourself to bring your attention back.Start with short time spans of expecting yourself to concentrate.  You'll more likely succeed with concentrating with small time spans than longer ones.Once you start seeing your success, this will motivate you to try increasing the length to expect yourself to concentrate.The task of self-reminding is the same, whether for long or short time periods.Also, before starting this exercise ask your medical doctor if the problem can be related to a physical health problem.If there is, then have the possibility ruled out that your difficulty concentrating comes from the mental ability to concentrate, and not some medical reason preventing this.Before someone can engage their psychological will there must be a clean medical body and mind with which to work.
