It's important to understand that everyone's situation is unique, and the number of issues you may be dealing with does not determine the value or effectiveness of counseling. In fact, counseling can be especially helpful for individuals with complex histories and challenges, as it provides a safe and supportive space to explore and address these issues in a thoughtful and methodical way.

The goal of counseling is not to tackle every issue all at once, but rather to work collaboratively with your counselor to identify priorities, set goals, and develop strategies to address each concern in a manageable and effective manner. Keep in mind that counseling is a process, and progress may not always be linear. Embrace the journey, trusting that with the help of a trained professional, you have the capacity to make meaningful improvements in your life.

It's worth noting that your long-standing marriage is actually an asset and can be a major source of resilience during this time. Engaging in couple therapy, if appropriate, can also complement your individual counseling to address any relationship-related concerns and strengthen the bond between you and your spouse.

Thus, instead of perceiving your situation as presenting too many issues, think of it as an opportunity for growth and transformation through counseling and self-exploration.

I'm really sorry to hear that you've been experiencing such a difficult time. It's important to remember that everyone reacts to traumatic experiences differently, and the absence of emotions isn't necessarily a sign of being a sociopath. Given your experience, it sounds like you might be dealing with complex emotional responses, including shock, dissociation, or even depression.

The first step would be to seek professional help from a qualified mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist. They can provide you with a safe, non-judgmental environment where you can process your emotions and work through your experiences. You might also find it helpful to explore therapeutic strategies, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, trauma-focused therapy, or even mindfulness practice, to help you manage your feelings more effectively.

Remember that it's normal to take time to heal from trauma, and everyone moves at their own pace. Be kind to yourself and allow yourself to feel whatever emotions come up, even if they're uncomfortable. And don't hesitate to reach out to trusted friends or family members for support during this process.

Being stuck in life is difficult, especially when you are feeling it in many different areas of your life. So you if you are ready for a change... time to make one! Self love and self acceptance is something that many of my clients struggle with, so I can assure you that you are not alone. We are bombarded by media and advertisements everyday that try to sell us things to make us somehow better, thus leading us to believe that we are not enough. Unfortunately, I believe that low self esteem is a social epidemic.On a more personal level, do you have any sense of what types of messages you have received in your life that have led to these self defeating thoughts? For example, did a parent or another loved one criticize you or put you down often? Were you bulled in school? Has a romantic partner emotionally abused you? Usually, there are factors such as these which insidiously lead to low self esteem and self loathing. Once you can identify some of the factors that lead to your self hatred, you can make a decision to not let these things from your past have such power over you any more. You learn to take control of how you feel about yourself, rather than letting others dictate that for you. I do think it is possible to heal from self hatred. It doesn't happen over night, and it takes time and effort. It is about re-training your brain to focus on your strengths rather than on your weaknesses. None of us are ever going to be perfect, and if we look for a flaw we are bound to find one (or two, or three...). Try keeping a self esteem journal. Every night, write down three things that you were proud of that day about yourself. Try reciting positive affirmations every day (such as "I am lovable and beautiful just the way that I am today"), to re-program your mind into thinking highly of yourself, rather than poorly.

Hi Attica,This is a question I think a lot of people deal with...they feel confusion about why they can't forget about or get over (or stop connecting with) someone who they absolutely know isn't good for them. In your case, part of the problem is that he keeps trying to get back in touch with you. For some people, honestly, it's a game... to see how much power they have over you or it's their need to control you. If you don't want contact from this person, it's really important to give him clear messages about boundaries ("Don't contact me again"), and then ignore all of their communications. Any interactions or responses from you at all will feed their behaviour. Remind yourself why you don't want to be with them. I hear you doing that already when you say "he has nothing to offer me". That's great self-talk.But let's get back to the question of why we have a hard time letting go of people like this. Sometimes it's because we still hope they will change. Maybe we remember who they used to be or how they used to treat us, and we think it can go back to the way it felt in those "good old days". The problem there is that, over the first few years, as intimacy grows, people tend to show more of who they are, not less. So what they're eventually showing you is who they are and what they're capable of. People do change and grow, but it won't happen at your pace. Accept that person for who they are and stop expecting them to change. Another reason we can't let go is because we picture our ex with someone new in the future and we wonder if they will be a better person for the next partner in their life. This is a normal... but not a healthy... thought. It's as though we want them to stay, maybe apologize, and heal our hurts; maybe make up for past mistakes. You deserve that healing, you deserve better than you got, you deserve apologies, but to expect that from the person who hurt you and hasn't demonstrated that compassion as yet is probably foolhardy. It is my belief that underlying some of the above scenarios is the deep belief that we must somehow be responsible for the hurts our exes have caused. If you blame yourself in any way for someone's poor treatment of you, you will be dancing around trying to do things differently so that they can treat you better. It will be impossible to let go, because you blame yourself for their behaviours.Draw a line. Their behaviours are about them, not you, and the only solution is to challenge and reduce thoughts of them, and create physical and emotional distance. These things plus time will help the events of the past fade from importance.

First, it's essential to identify what brings you joy and fulfillment in life. Try making a list of activities, experiences, or relationships that make you feel happy and at peace. Once you have identified these sources of contentment, prioritize them in your daily life and make active efforts to engage in them regularly.

Additionally, practicing self-care, such as getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, exercising, and engaging in activities that help you relax and reduce stress, can also contribute to a greater sense of contentment.

It's also essential to work on challenging negative thoughts and emotions, such as anxiety, depression, or anger, that may contribute to feelings of dissatisfaction or unhappiness. This can involve therapy, mindfulness practices, or other self-help strategies.

Lastly, cultivating meaningful relationships, particularly with supportive and understanding individuals, can be an essential source of contentment and happiness. These connections can help us feel valued, loved, and understood, contributing to a greater sense of well-being.

I understand your concern for your brother's wellbeing under the current circumstances. However, I cannot provide you with a definitive answer as I am not a legal professional. In some cases, you may be able to petition the court to pursue such an arrangement, but this would require the involvement of a lawyer and potentially a hearing. Given the urgency of the situation, I strongly recommend that you contact your local mental health crisis team or a lawyer who specializes in elder care or mental health to discuss the specifics of your case and explore your options. Additionally, you should also continue to express your concerns to your brother's mother and consider involving other family members or friends for support.

I'm sorry to hear about the situation you're in. It's natural to feel hurt and confused when a partner reveals they have feelings for someone else. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Process your emotions: Allow yourself to feel the full range of emotions that come up. This might include sadness, anger, betrayal, or guilt. Don't try to suppress or ignore these emotions.

2. Communicate with your girlfriend: Try to have an open and honest conversation with your girlfriend about what she's feeling and what this means for your relationship. Remember to listen actively and express your thoughts and feelings clearly.

3. Seek support from others: Reach out to trusted friends or family members for support and guidance. You may also find it helpful to speak with a mental health professional, who can provide you with a safe and confidential space to process your emotions.

4. Consider your options: Think carefully about what you want in a relationship and what you're willing to tolerate from your partner. Decide whether you're willing to continue the relationship as it is, or whether you'd rather end it.

5. Take care of yourself: Focus on taking care of yourself during this difficult time. Engage in activities that bring you joy, get regular exercise, eat well, and try to get enough sleep. Remember that self-care is crucial to your emotional and physical well-being.

I'm glad you're reaching out for help, and it's a good sign that you want to improve your relationship. Listening effectively and being emotionally present are crucial skills for maintaining healthy relationships. Here are some suggestions:

First, try to give your full attention to your partner. During conversations, minimize distractions, and try to maintain eye contact.

Second, practice active listening. This involves not just hearing the words that are being spoken but also understanding their meaning and emotions behind them. Paraphrase what your partner has said to show that you understand and reflect back on their feelings.

Third, avoid interrupting or judging your partner. Allow them to finish their thoughts before responding.

Fourth, show empathy and validation. Express feelings of compassion and understanding towards your partner's experiences and emotions.

Finally, focus on your own emotional regulation. Practice stress reduction techniques like deep breathing, mindfulness meditation or progressive muscle relaxation to help manage strong emotions, particularly when those emotions may lead to reactivity or defensiveness. Additionally, consider exploring underlying issues that may be contributing to relationship stress through therapy or other forms of support.

These skills take time and effort to master, but with practice, they can help improve your communication and strengthen your relationship.

As a psychologist, I would consider several factors before deciding to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client. These factors may include:

1. Client's progress: If a client has achieved their therapeutic goals, they may no longer need counseling sessions.
2. Mutual agreement: If both the counselor and client feel that counseling has been beneficial and they have reached a point where they are prepared to move on, they may decide to end the sessions.
3. Client's stability: If a client is stable and able to manage their mental health on their own, the counselor may consider ending the sessions.
4. Client's readiness for termination: Some clients may be reluctant to end counseling sessions, while others may be eager to move on. The counselor needs to consider the client's readiness for termination when making this decision.
5. Counselor's availability: If the counselor is unable to continue to provide counseling sessions due to scheduling or personal reasons, they may need to terminate the sessions.

Overall, the decision to end counseling sessions should be made collaboratively between the counselor and the client, taking into consideration the client's progress, stability, readiness for termination, and the counselor's availability.

Hello,This question describes a very typical setup of what is called the  Binge, Repent, Repeat cycle. This means that typically after you binge, you experience emotions as you described "shame and disappointment" and then because of these emotions you "repent" (i.e. vow to never binge again, promise to "do better," go to the gym, etc.) and then ultimately end up bingeing again. There are many coping mechanisms for binge eating and one of the best is actually attempting to NORMALIZE eating. Meaning you need to attempt to eat normally, eating appropriately portioned meals 3 times a day, with snacks in between. IF you binge, then it may be helpful to remind yourself that when you attempt to compensate for your bingeing behaviors, and you end up feeling restricted from over exercising or undereating, then this actually leads to a binge again. Thus, reverting you back to the cycle. If you binge, it will be helpful to try and get back on a normal schedule of eating instead of trying to compensate for the binge. Although it may feel counterproductive, getting back on a normal eating schedule will prevent you from entering into the restrictive cycle. It can also be helpful to remind yourself that the binge has already occurred, it is in the past and the goal is to move forward without focusing on the past. Focus on what you can do differently next time. What emotions or situations led up to the binge? What can you to do prevent or change the circumstances that led to the binge, or the way that you handled the situation? Lastly, if you're struggling with "normalizing" eating, it can be helpful to work with a professional that can provide counseling and coaching to help you learn how to eating normally, mindfully and without feeling the guilt and other harmful emotions sometimes associated with disordered eating. I would be more than happy to assist you if you ever have any questions or want to reach out to somebody. You can contact me via my website: http://www.maddenwellnessky.com/

Hi Enid, You sound like a sensitive parent; I like that you talked to your son to see if anything is wrong. There is some key information here (I don't know your son's age, whether he spent any money, whether he put the card back, or how many times he's stolen), and my answer might be different depending on those details, but I'll give you my thoughts.I see it as every child's job to figure out the rules and find where their power is in the world. In order to accomplish that, many of them test limits. "What can I get away with?" is a question they have to find the answer to. If a child knows the rules, they're much more likely to not test limits (because they already know the limits). So, part of testing limits is experimenting with stealing and lying. Not all kids steal, but I would say pretty much every child lies at some point. It's a normal behaviour, and most of the time it's about small things that don't matter and we don't even find out. Stealing a debit card is a bit more serious, and I'm not surprised he lied about it. If you absolutely know that he took it, it's okay to tell him that you believe he did this thing and also lied about it. It's appropriate to give a consequence for this type of behaviour, so that the child doesn't do it again. The consequence should be as natural and logical as possible. The behaviour (stealing) was harmful to you, so doing you a favour with extra chores might be a good idea. It's funny, because as parents we try to tell our kids that lying is bad, but they know they'll get a consequence if they tell the truth so there are natural deterrents to being honest (we don't want people to know our mistakes). It's a dilemma. If you really want to focus on the lying part, you can tell him that you won't give him a consequence for the lying if he decides to come clean with the truth within one day. That gives him incentive to come to you with truth. It sometimes works with kids to give them a chance to come clean and then reward them for telling the truth. You can set your child up for success and train them to tolerate honesty. Put a cookie on the counter. Tell your child to take the cookie at some point in the day. Then ask them later if they took the cookie. You're making honesty fun. Kids love games. Basically, there's as much power in rewarding the positive behaviour as punishing the negative. If this is the first serious offence for your son, don't make a big deal of it; consequence him and see if he learns. If it's a pattern, that's different and you may want the input of a therapist.

I think giving yourself the space to realize that this was a significant relationship and it really had an impact on you. I think you should honor that relationship and then talk about it to someone. The more you try to not think of it, the more you will think of it. I think you should instead, say "thank you" to that relationship. Thank you for showing you what qualities you like, what you desire. Maybe even come up with a list of what that specific relationship did for you. After you say "thank you" to that relationship then it may be time to say goodbye. You obviously want to get over that person, so figure out why you want to get over them. Why did it not work out? What negative parts of the relationship do you keep forgetting to think about. Oftentimes, people glamorize the past. So for your goodbye part of this phase, I would focus on the negative parts of the relationship. You can also work on emotionally saying goodbye to that time in your life. You are probably different than you were 7 years ago, and to be honest, they are probably different too.I know it sounds weird. But I would recommend that you mentally say "thank you" and "goodbye" to that relationship.

Is there any abuse in the relationship (physical, emotional, psychological)? - if the answer to this question is yes - please seek immediate help. Good luck with you decision.

It's normal to feel anxious or nervous about sexual performance, especially in new relationships or situations where you're not used to having sex regularly. The inability to get an erection despite strong sexual desires is a common condition called erectile dysfunction (ED). ED can be caused by several factors including physical health issues, emotional stress, anxiety, or relationship problems.

However, from what you've shared, it seems more likely that you're experiencing performance anxiety. Performance anxiety is a common cause of ED, and it can be caused by a fear of not being able to please your partner, a fear of judgement, or a fear of failure. The fact that you can get an erection thinking about your girlfriend, but not during sex, is a classic sign of performance anxiety.

To help overcome performance anxiety and improve your sexual functioning, here are some suggestions:
1. Communicate openly with your girlfriend about your feelings and concerns. Discussing your anxiety with her can help reduce the pressure you feel during sexual situations.
2. Practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help reduce anxiety and tension.
3. Focus on the pleasure of the experience rather than the outcome. Try to stay present in the moment and enjoy the sensations instead of worrying about whether or not you'll be able to get an erection.
4. Seek professional help if your ED persists. A psychologist or sex therapist can help you identify the underlying causes of your ED and develop strategies to overcome it.
5. Consider taking steps to improve your overall health, such as getting regular exercise, eating a healthy diet, and reducing stress, as these factors can all impact sexual functioning.

Additionally, implementing healthy communication skills, setting clear boundaries, and practicing self-care can help improve your mental and emotional wellbeing. Remember, it takes time to heal, but with patience and support, you'll be able to rebuild your social life and strengthen your resilience.
