Remember, it's okay to not have all the answers right now. The most important thing is that you're taking the time to consider your identity and figure out what feels authentic to you. If you need additional support or guidance, please don't hesitate to reach out to me or other trusted resources.

During these encounters did you feel safe? accepted? Where you able to experience something new in your life? It is natural to feel attraction to all people. As young children we love everyone. It was as we got older that the social constructs had us make a "choice". It could have been that you were always attracted to the same sex, but now are allowing yourself to feel and explore. But also know that life is interesting as we grow and mature we find that we like things we never liked before, things we said we would never do now seem appealing. What is the story you are telling yourself about having these interests? Try to not overthink your attractions. See where they take you. You are on a journey to discover yourself.

It's not uncommon for children to go through phases where they seem to regress in their development. This is often referred to as "regression." Regression can be a response to stress, trauma, or a challenging new situation. In your daughter's case, it might be due to feeling overwhelmed or insecure in some way. It's also possible that there may be underlying social or emotional issues. However, to better understand her behavior, it would be helpful to rule out any medical, developmental, or learning issues. I suggest consulting with a pediatrician or a child psychologist for a thorough assessment. They can help identify any underlying causes and recommend appropriate interventions. If there are no underlying issues, we can explore ways to help her feel more confident and secure as she navigates the challenges of growing up.

Let yourself know what you feel.   There is no timetable or known length of how much time a particular person requires in order to feel that the dissolved relationship is behind them.Probably the more you allow yourself to acknowledge your sadness from seeing the reminders, the sooner you will feel fresh and new again.

I can understand how confusing and painful it can be when someone's words and actions don't align. It sounds like you're in a complex situation. There are a few things to consider. First, it's essential to acknowledge your feelings and validate your pain. Grief from the loss of a relationship can take time and the process may feel prolonged when the other person hasn't fully closed the door.

Second, try to assess and accept the reality of the situation. If the man in your life is unsure about the relationship, it may not be healthy for either of you to continue the way things are. The ongoing contact could be preventing both of you from moving forward and finding closure or healing.

Lastly, focus on taking care of yourself instead of trying to control another person's feelings or actions. Spend time on things that nurture your mind, body, and emotional well-being. Seek out social support from friends, family, or other trusted people in your life. Consider speaking with a mental health professional to explore your thoughts, feelings, and options in more depth. It takes courage to acknowledge pain, take steps towards healing, and move forward, but these efforts will be crucial for your long-term wellness.

I understand that this change in your relationship dynamic can be distressing for you, especially when it comes to feelings of disconnection and lack of intimacy. It seems that your fiancé's busy schedule may be a contributing factor to this issue. Communication and understanding are key in addressing this concern. Try scheduling a time to have an open and honest conversation with him about how you both can prioritize your relationship amidst his demanding commitments. It may also be helpful to discuss the impact of his texts when you're apart causing hurt feelings. It's essential to find a balance between his work/gym schedule and the time and attention you need from him in the relationship. If the issue persists despite efforts, it may be worth considering couples therapy or seeking guidance from a relationship counselor.

I understand your dilemma, patient. The belief in Santa Claus is often seen as an essential part of the Christmas experience for many children. Loss of this belief can be painful and may lead to feelings of disappointment and betrayal. On the other hand, honesty and trust are important values to uphold in any relationship, including the one between a parent and a child.

One possible approach could be to explain to your children that Santa Claus is a symbol of joy, love, and giving. You could tell them that the idea of Santa Claus was created to spread happiness and that many people continue believing in him, including themselves. This way, you can keep the magical aspect of Christmas alive, while also maintaining honesty and trust.

If your ex-husband's revelation has already caused distress and confusion, you can have an open and honest conversation with your children about the situation. Share your own feelings and help them understand the reasons behind their father's actions. You may also want to encourage them to express their own thoughts and feelings, and assure them that they are loved and supported.

Lastly, if you feel that your relationship with your children has been significantly negatively impacted by this situation, you might consider seeking further support from a mental health professional or other trusted resources.

Maybe the reason is not having confidence in the love you give to yourself.Possibly you consider the quality of your self-love as inferior to love someone else gives you.The best way to push through to your own self-comfort and acceptance is to be aware of this tendency so you can remind yourself to practice appreciating the unique love you give to yourself.

One way is to bring one's concerns or desires to the therapist directly, rather than trying to subtly 'train' them. Here's why I say that: One quite important healing factor in a psychotherapy is discovering that problems in the therapy and the therapeutic relationship can be solved together. It is a safety zone or bridge for practicing that. If it can be done with a trained, usually safe person (the therapist), the client might think, wow--what are the implications for my outside life and relations? Could I get what I want outside of therapy, too, even if it feels not as safe?If the therapist can deal with feedback (and any good therapist should be able to), this can be very productive. Cooperation in this way, in the moment, with a live person who is supposed to have authority and knowledge in these matters, can be profoundly healing.If the therapist can't take feedback or doesn't want to--or does nothing to act on it--maybe we could say the client has the wrong therapist.

Absolutely, patient. Counseling and psychotherapy have been proven to be effective in helping people deal with a wide range of emotional and psychological issues. Therapy can help individuals improve their mood, reduce anxiety and stress, build healthier relationships, and increase their sense of self-worth and self-understanding. By providing a safe, confidential space for people to explore and address their emotions, counseling can lead to real and lasting improvements in their lives. It's important to remember, though, that therapy is most effective when the patient is fully engaged and committed to the process.

Use this time to explore who you are...imagine what your life would be like if you were gay and not, ask yourself what is different? What scenario do you find yourself gravitating to?  What is important is that you are happy. My message to you is that you do not need to define yourself with your sexual preference or feel the need to label yourself, especially if you are confused and exploring what your sexual preference is.

I'm sorry for so much stress in your relationship life.In what ways does your boyfriend express his commitment and positive feelings about you, to you?From what you write, you feel more aggravation, stress, loneliness and insecurity, than satisfaction by being in this relationship.Does he care that you don't trust him?Very often people stay in relationships from fear of knowing who they really are.  The feeling is of needing a partner in a way that is similar to how a fearful child needs staying nearby a parent.My suggestion is to think over how much your sense of need for a partner, may be preventing you from actually seeing the amount of love and investment in your relationship, your boyfriend actually has.These realizations are sometimes painful and frightening to understand, especially if you grew up in a family that largely ignored or didn't adequately nurture you as a child.A therapist for your Self may be a good investment of time and cost in giving yourself a safe and trustworthy space to think deeply about your best interest.

A counselor typically decides to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client when they have helped the client achieve their goals, the client shows significant improvement, or the client no longer needs the therapeutic support. But, it's important to note that termination should be a collaborative process between the counselor and the client. The counselor should facilitate a discussion on the progress made, readiness for termination, and steps for maintaining growth and progress outside of counseling. The counselor should also ensure that the client has a plan in place for ongoing support and resources, if needed. If you have any more questions or would like to explore this topic further, please feel free to ask.

I understand that coming out as transgender can be a challenging and emotional process, especially when it feels unsafe to do so within certain circles. It's important to prioritize your own mental and emotional well-being. Here are some strategies that may help you manage your gender dysphoria:
1. Seek professional help: Consider working with a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, who specializes in gender identity issues. They can provide you with ways to cope, offer support, and help you develop a plan for coming out to others.
2. Connect with the trans community: Reach out to local or online transgender community groups. They can provide you with a sense of belonging, support, and understanding that may be hard to find elsewhere.
3. Educate yourself: Learn as much as you can about gender identity and the transgender community. This knowledge can help empower you and give you a better understanding of your own experiences.
4. Practice self-care: Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you relax, such as exercise, hobbies, or creative pursuits. Remember that taking care of yourself is an important step in managing your gender dysphoria.
5. Create a support network: Identify trusted friends, family members, or mentors with whom you feel comfortable discussing your gender identity. Building a network of supportive individuals can make coming out and dealing with gender dysphoria easier. Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace, and reaching out for help when you need it is a sign of strength. I wish you all the best on your journey.

I understand that you're experiencing complex emotions regarding your recent sexual encounter with a friend. As a psychologist, I want to emphasize that your feelings are valid, but let me clarify that guilt or shame can serve various functions in our lives. While it's true that you have the autonomy to make decisions regarding your body, emotions can be influenced by various factors, including societal norms, personal values, and relationships.

Feeling guilty could indicate that you have violated a personal value or standard, or that you've hurt someone's feelings or trust. Conversely, it's possible that the guilt may serve as a reminder of the importance of maintaining healthy relationships and boundaries, encouraging self-reflection, and fostering emotional growth.

It's essential to consider the implications of your actions both in the short-term and the long-term. Reflect on feelings of guilt, and ask yourself whether these emotions are serving as a reminder to make amends, learn from the situation, or maintain stronger relationships and commitments in the future.

It may also be helpful to communicate openly with your friend and your spouse regarding your feelings and thoughts about the encounter. Honesty, transparency, and empathetic communication can lead to a stronger understanding of your emotions and relationships and facilitate healing.

Ultimately, the decision to feel guilty or not lies within your personal value system and emotional response. It's essential to consider the potential benefits of feeling guilty and the potential consequences of suppressing these emotions. The goal is to reach a place of self-awareness, emotional healing, and growth, both as an individual and in your relationships.

You can, for sure... and the first step is to believe you are worthy TO YOURSELF. Recognizing you are in a quest is already a big first step. Taking the time to start figuring out who you are is definitely the next... do so with SELF COMPASSION and kindness. Know this is a process and just look forward for what you might find.  I do recommend you find someone to talk to (there are many options out there that can fit the situation you are in), and I also recommend you start by giving yourself the importance to invest some time and effort in this quest. YOU DESERVE IT. There are some excellent TED Talks you can google, great books you can read, or even joining a yoga practice, team or some kind of hobby may help. Anything that shows yourself you are worthy of this effort. Have patience and start!!!! the answer is out there waiting for you. Asking these questions already set you on the right path.

My answer is going to be super simplistic but I believe this may be what you need. Ask your husband if he wants to stay married to you.  If he says yes, then it would be helpful to go to a marriage counselor and work this out with a professional.  If he says no, then you can file for divorce.

Wow, I'm so sorry that this has happened to you.  My heart goes out to you.  Please find a therapist who specializes in working with PTSD.  Brainspotting, Internal Family Systems Therapy, and Somatic Experiencing are all highly effective therapies for complex interpersonal trauma.  If you are interested in reading about trauma from a compassionate and scientific perspective I highly recommend Bessel van der Kolk's The Body Keeps the Score.

Don't think that you can't afford the help you need on your own.  There are several counselors that see people on a sliding scale that can be as low as $5 (based on your income).  Find a center that is non-profit, they have great counselors as well. It sounds like you know what you are experiencing and know that you need someone to talk to, someone that is willing to listen.  Your parents may not understand what your are feeling right now and that is not totally abnormal.I would encourage you to seek help immediately so you can live the best live you can...which is not being depressed.

It’s very normal to be nervous going into therapy. You are being vulnerable and honest, which is always scary, no matter how many times you do it. The best part about therapy is that the more you go, the more confident you are in your ability to work through those difficult feelings, and while you still may sometimes get nervous, you will have confidence too!

This is so very common in this crazy looks-obsessed world! I meet so many beautiful people who can't see their beauty. Is there something getting in the way for you? Was there a time in your life when people teased you or told you something hurtful, or did something to you that made you feel ugly? If so, this can be addressed first. Sometimes stories are told about us when we're young and the best thing we can do is see the author's evil or careless intent and not take that on. A therapist can help you with this part.Once you've addressed any past barriers to feeling confident, you can focus on a few simple things. First, your thoughts. If you keep telling yourself that you don't like what you see, then you will never feel okay about your looks. Experiment with telling yourself something different. Look in the mirror and I dare you to find something that's lovely about your face. Focus on that. Describe what you see? If you were your own best friend, what would you say about your face? Eliminating those negative scripts and building new positive ones will help you feel more accepting of how you look. You can't change your face, but you can change your attitude towards your face. Confidence is the things that will make you beautiful!Accepting how you look is important. Without going to plastic surgery (the popularity of which is a testimony to how nuts this whole thing has become), you were born with that nose, those eyes, those lips. Accepting yourself and knowing it won't change is a good idea, because wishing it were different won't make it so!Looking good is also about minimizing flaws and building on your assets. Are you in a rut about hairstyle or makeup? Ask a good friend to give you a make-over. Play with your features and wardrobe. There are plenty of average looking people who know how to make themselves shine because they are creative!

I understand that feelings of not knowing oneself can be overwhelming and confusing. It's important to remember that identity development is a lifelong process. It's normal for our sense of self to evolve and change over time as we gain new experiences and knowledge about ourselves and the world. If you're feeling lost or uncertain, consider exploring your interests, values, and relationships to help you identify what makes you unique. Additionally, talking with a mental health professional can provide a safe and supportive space to explore these feelings further.

I understand that trust is a crucial component of any relationship, and it can be incredibly painful when it feels violated. From what you've shared, it seems there are legitimate reasons for you to feel uneasy about your fiancé's behavior towards his ex-girlfriend.

It's essential to communicate openly and honestly about your concerns with your partner. Try to have a calm and non-confrontational conversation where you express your feelings of distress and ask for clarification regarding his texting and phone-hiding behavior.

It's not about accusing your partner of anything, but discussing your concerns and asking how he would feel if the roles were reversed. Be open to listening to his perspective, but also make it clear that these actions are making you feel insecure and anxious.

If the situation doesn't improve after the conversation or if you feel threatened or disrespected, it may be important to consider seeking further support and guidance from a therapist or a trusted friend. Trust takes time and effort to build, and it's essential to ensure that both partners are investing that effort equally.

I understand that caring for a loved one's child can be a significant responsibility and that constant complaints from your mother can be emotionally draining. It's important to recognize the boundaries of your support and well-being. You can tell your mother that while you empathize with her situation, you're unable to listen to the complaints daily. You might suggest that she seek additional resources or support networks to alleviate her stress. This can include professional counseling or support groups for caregivers, which can provide her with valuable coping mechanisms and a community to share her experiences with. It's crucial for your own mental health to prioritize self-care, and it's essential to communicate this to your mother in a loving and understanding manner. If need be, you could offer to help her find these resources or even accompany her to her first appointment if she feels more comfortable that way.

I understand your frustration, patient. It can be challenging when we feel like our partners aren't fully engaged in our conversations. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Practice assertive communication: Be clear about what you want to express and how you feel. Use "I" statements instead of "you" statements, because they are more likely to be received as less accusatory or critical.
2. Create a safe space: Make sure neither of you is distracted by external factors, like phones, TVs, or children. Find a quiet and comfortable place to have this conversation.
3. Use active listening: Make sure your husband feels heard by repeating back what he's said in your own words or asking questions to clarify.
4. Set aside regular time: Schedule dedicated time to talk about important matters. Make sure it's a time when both of you are well-rested and focused.
5. Be patient: Changing a long-standing communication pattern can take time. Be consistent and persistent with your efforts to improve the communication in your relationship. 

Remember, it's important for both partners to be attentive and engage in active listening. It's not just about getting your husband to listen to you, but also about making sure you're creating an environment where both of you feel valued and heard.

I work with many couples that experience a wide range of sexual and relationship challenges. The one aspect I tell many folks that I work with, is this: Every person and relationship is different. There really isn't a "normal" amount of sex a person should have or want to have. If having sex 4 to 5 times in the course of your relationship is satisfying to you and your husband, there is nothing wrong with it. If you or your husband would like to have sex more often, I suggest talking with a counselor about this to find ways to engage in a sexual life in which you are both satisfied. The aspect of connectedness is an important one. While sex can be very connecting for many couples, it isn't the only way to connect. I find that communication about the matter of frequency of sex, checking in to see how you and your husband feel, as well as communicant about your needs for connection are an important start to fulfilling this need.

Sometimes we let our insecurities get the best of us, causing us to make some interesting choices. Honesty is always the best policy, but honesty comes with risk.  Perhaps you may want to start with your family first, explaining to them what you have done and why.  Perhaps they can help you to practice talking about your insecurities with your friends. Another way is to start, slowly, to dress more and more like yourself and your true body shape. Some of your "friends" may make fun of you, true, but then you must ask yourself...why do you want to be friends with people like that?

I'm glad you're aware to expect more satisfaction from being part of a couple, than you currently describe yourself as having.Are you and your husband able to talk about any or all of what you've written here?His answers would be a starting point for knowing how he understands his share of your relationship and whether and how he would like making any changes.If the two of you feel too much tension in the relationship to bring up any of the topics you write about here, then ask yourself the reason for this.Very commonly, people are afraid to ask questions of their partner, even when feeling unhappy and that they'd like changes to the relationship.Often, people are fearful of harsh criticism by the partner and worry that by simply stating the reasons for feeling unhappy, will mean hearing judgments against them, spoken by the partner.It is always a good idea to utilize the services of a professional, credentialed and licensed therapist, if after trying to start a conversation on the topics you bring up here, does not go well or very far.For all of us, the emotions in our intimate relationships are deep and powerful.  They are not easy to handle, especially under tension and frustration.Sending lots of good wishes for future happiness!

I understand that you're feeling lost and stuck in your current situation. It's not uncommon to feel uncertain about our goals and aspirations at times. It sounds like you're experiencing a lack of clarity and direction in your life.

One way to address this is to take some time for self-reflection. This can involve exploring your values, interests, and passions. Identifying what truly matters to you can help you gain perspective and focus on what's important.

Another helpful strategy is to break down your goals into smaller, manageable steps. Focusing on the process rather than the end result can make the journey feel less overwhelming and more achievable.

It's also important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and it's okay if your path doesn't look like someone else's. Take things one step at a time, and don't be too hard on yourself if things don't go as planned.

If you're having trouble getting started, consider working with a therapist or counselor to help guide you through this process. They can provide you with additional tools and support as you work to clarify your goals and move forward.

Sounds like a lot is going on right now at such a young age. I'd start with discussing with mom your concerns and ideal situation. I'm unsure what prevents you from staying there, but whoever you are staying with, it should be brought to their attention. In regards to your anxiety attacks, deep breathing is always a benefits. I have a link you can use to help to do this online if you are interested. In addition, finding ways you usually cope with anxiety and what's worked before can help and if it isn't, exploring new way to calm you down can be beneficial. This is something you can speak with your therapist about going forward when they are available.In regards to feeling suicidal: I would call suicide prevention hotline (You can google them) if you truly feel the ideation is getting worse. They are professional agents who can speak with you about your ideation and help you through the process. Hope this helps.

After the initial meeting, also known as an intake session, the counselor will carefully assess the client's needs and develop a treatment plan. This may involve further sessions for diagnostic evaluation, gathering more background information about the client's history and current situation, and deciding on the most effective therapeutic approach. The counselor may also provide resources, referrals or homework for the client to do between sessions. Throughout this process, open communication, empathy, and respect are key.

Does the voice in your head sound different or the same as your own voice when you talk to people and go about your usual daily life?There is a great big difference in the type of problem you're having if you feel the voice belongs to someone besides who you are.If you are hearing "self-talk" of turning over in your mind what goes on in your life, reflecting on alternatives either of what you would like to have done differently in a certain matter, or anticipating what you will do in a future situation, then the problem of the voice in your head may be from a high degree of stress or uncertainty in your life right now.Talking out loud can be a symptom of severe agitation, restlessness, loneliness, and a sense that you are not understood by other people.I would be as concerned about the voice in your head as I would be about the actual content of what the voice is talking about with you.

I understand that you're feeling overwhelmed and isolated right now, but it's important to remember that everyone experiences these feelings from time to time. However, if you're consistently avoiding social interaction, it might be helpful to explore the underlying reasons. Sometimes, feelings of loneliness can stem from past traumas, negative thought patterns, or even physical health issues. If you're finding it hard to cope on your own, consider reaching out to a therapist or trusted loved one for support. They can help you identify the root cause of your feelings and develop strategies to reduce your isolation and increase your sense of connection. Remember, it's normal to need help sometimes, and reaching out for support is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Absolutely it's normal to cry in therapy sessions. Sometimes clients have stories they never shared with anyone or never said out loud and that results to crying. Crying is a normal reaction to feeling hurt or sad or sometimes angry. I welcome all crying to my therapy room.

The easiest way to start the counseling process is to do a little research online. A quick search for the type of counseling you are looking for can be helpful. There are lots of Counselors out there to choose from, so many times you will have to take it a few steps further than that. Check out their website, social media, and any reviews (but remember, people are not always very nice). If you plan on using insurance to pay for at least part of the services, look for one that is in your network. You can find out if someone is in your network by looking for providers on your insurance's website. If your coverage isn't that great and you know you're going to be paying for it all anyway (because you're an all-star and verified your coverage already with the insurance company), then you can really pick any Counselor you want, but working with one that is at least out of network will give you the benefit of having it applied to your deductible. If you have any questions about that process or just want some help in getting your benefits from the insurance company once you've started counseling, Better is a good option. Once you've found a Counselor you think is a good fit for you, normally the best step to take here is to call and schedule your very first appointment. With many Counselors you can now send an email, but a phone call can normally tell you quite a bit about someone and their clinic. Once you're all scheduled, they will either get you to do some paperwork before you come in, or many times they just let you fill it out once you get there. From there, all you have to do is show up!

Communication involves a listener and a speaker.  Both have to be willing to do their part to make communication work.  This is something that takes both and not just one.  Without both, communication is impossible.   Staying together and the kids observing unhealthy communication is already broken.  Seek help to improve communication.    Couples' counseling would be helpful.

Hello, and thank you for your question. I am so glad that you reached out for help. I know that the dysphoria can feel nearly impossible to handle, especially since you have limited support from people who accept who you are. You may already know some of these resources, but I am going to share a few. 1. The website www.letsqueerthingsup.com is a blog from a very good writer that I know. His name is Sam Dylan Finch, and he is transgender. He writes about mental health, transgender issues, and many other topics. I know he has frequently written about gender dysphoria and ways to manage it. You may want to check out his site and do a search on there. 2. The website www.everydayfeminism.com employs many transgender writers and several have written about gender dysphoria and have given ideas for managing it. If you search for gender dysphoria on their site, many articles pop up. It may be a good resource for you, especially if you ever feel lonely and start to forget that there are others out there who are like you and have your back. 3. I am not sure where you live, but there are counselors who specialize in affirmative therapy, which is what is recommended for folks who are part of the LGBTQ community. So, if you decide to see a counselor about the dysphoria, try to find one that specifically says they have been trained in the affirmative approach. In addition, feel free to ask questions of the counselor before agreeing to see them for counseling. An ethical counselor would have no problem answering them before having you come in. 4. If there are some LGBTQ resource centers in your area, try to reach out to them and see if there are support groups. Gaining more support from others would be helpful. Sometimes LGBTQ-friendly counselors leave their contact information for people in resource centers. 5. Finally, I know you have not mentioned being depressed or suicidal, but I also know that it is very common for people to consider suicide when they are struggling with dysphoria, dealing with transphobia, etc. If this ever happens to you, please call 911 or the Trans Lifeline. It's free at 877-565-8860. Visit their site at www.translifeline.org. I hope some of these ideas help. Feel free to send another message if you have a follow-up question.Be well....be YOU.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

I understand that this is a difficult situation for both of you. It's important to remember that sexual desire and satisfaction can vary greatly from person to person and can be influenced by numerous factors. The fact that you have an open and honest communication about this issue is a great first step.

Several things could be contributing to your wife's lack of sexual desire and difficulty reaching orgasm. Hormonal changes due to pregnancy and postpartum period, stress, emotional factors, relationship dynamics, and physical health conditions are just a few potential causes.

Encourage your wife to explore her feelings and consider seeking professional help from a therapist or healthcare provider to identify any underlying causes. They might recommend therapies such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, mindfulness-based stress reduction techniques, or hormonal treatments to help improve her sexual experiences and address any underlying emotional or physical concerns.

In the meantime, focus on fostering emotional intimacy and connection outside of sexual activity. Engage in activities and conversation that strengthen your bond. Remember to be patient and supportive of your wife throughout this process. It will take time, but with open communication and professional help, you can address these issues together.

The numbers you write are low compared to how much sex many other people would be satisfied having.The key is your and your husband's satisfaction with the amount of sex you are having.And, know if there are reasons besides low sex drive that possibly explain this.Knowing the other possibilities matter because a low sex life may mean one of you is being satisfied sexually outside the marriage or that one of you prefers sex with a same gendered partner.If you've ruled out these possibilities, and you are satisfied with your emotional and financial life in the relationship, then a low sex drive may simply be the norm for the two of you.

I understand how you might feel, given your concerns about being bothersome to others. It's not uncommon for people to have self-doubts or negative thoughts from time to time. However, it's important to remember that perceptions can vary greatly from one person to another. Your girlfriend's reassurance that you're not bothersome doesn't necessarily mean that everyone else feels the same way. I would encourage you to practice open communication with those around you, express your concerns and listen to their feedback. It might also be helpful to observe situations where you feel bothersome and consider if there are any patterns or triggers that could contribute to these feelings. Remember, no one is perfect, and we all have areas where we can grow and improve. But it's crucial to maintain a balance between recognizing our shortcomings and accepting ourselves as worthy of love and respect.

Hi Oklahoma, Listen to him when he says this is how he is. Your boyfriend's behaviours are about him; not you. At the start of a relationship it's easy to be loving and attentive; but it takes years to really get to know someone deeply. With time, people reveal who they are.For some reason, he is giving himself permission to detach from you and your son. This could be for several reasons; he may be avoiding intimacy and connection, he may be avoiding commitment, he may fear he isn't enough, or (and there is evidence of this one) he may have misogynist attitudes about male privilege that interfere with his ability to be the kind of supportive and respectful partner that you need. It seems that you've addressed this problem with him and told him what you need. Good for you. His response seems dismissive though, and this isn't a good sign. Any problem can be worked through if you have two people who care about, respect and listen to each other. It seems this basic foundation is missing here.I suggest a therapist might be able to help you sort out where to go from here. I wish you the best. :)

It's important to recognize that sexuality and sexual attractions can change over the course of a person's life. This is not uncommon, especially as people gain more self-awareness and experience new things. Your sexual orientation is not defined by a single experience or encounter, but rather a pattern of attraction, emotion, and feeling throughout your life. These feelings can emerge at any age and do not reflect any inherent flaw or problem. It's essential to be honest with yourself about your feelings and seek support from trusted friends, family, or mental health professionals as you navigate this new aspect of your identity. It may also be helpful to educate yourself about sexual orientation and the diverse ways it can manifest. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and there's no right or wrong way to explore and understand your sexuality.

It's important to recognize that depression is not solely defined by feelings of sadness. Depression can manifest in many ways, including apathy, loss of interest in activities, and feelings of hopelessness or emptiness, among other symptoms. While it's understandable that you may be unsure, it can be helpful to explore these feelings further with a mental health professional. A trained therapist or psychiatrist can help you understand your symptoms and make an accurate diagnosis, as well as provide you with effective treatment options if needed. So, it wouldn't be a bad idea to consider reaching out to a mental health professional for an evaluation. This can give you a clearer sense of where you stand and help you take the next steps if necessary.

I understand how you're feeling, it's not uncommon for couples to experience a decline in connection and intimacy over time. Communication is key in these situations. You can express your feelings to your husband in a calm and non-confrontational way. Here are some steps you can take:

1. Schedule a private and undisturbed conversation with him.
2. Share how you feel without being accusatory. Use "I" statements instead of "you" statements.
3. Be open to listening to his perspective and try to understand where he's coming from.
4. Work together to come up with ways to reconnect and strengthen your bond as a couple.

It's important to remember that relationships take work and require ongoing effort. If you feel that the disconnection is deep-rooted or if you've tried to communicate and the issue persists, it may be helpful to seek the guidance of a certified therapist or counselor. They can provide you with effective communication strategies and help you navigate any underlying emotional or psychological issues that may be contributing to your sense of feeling uncared for.

First decide what you truly would like in the current relationship. Understand your reasons for staying in the relationship.Three years is a substantial amount of time to be involved with someone.   Whatever attachment you feel toward this man is deep and complex.Instead of deciding to leave or not leave, change your question to figuring out your satisfactions and dissatisfaction with the man. Also important is to tell the man your feelings.Whatever problem you are feeling may become clarified by discussing what bothers you.At the very least, you will give the guy a chance to show how interested he actually is in the tension you currently feel and have felt for a while.
Though I don't know for sure, it sounds like anxiety to me. I think it would be helpful if you work with a therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders.

It is never too late to get help and begin making significant changes and improvements in your life.  The right time is when you feel ready and open to change.  Sometimes when we have a history of trauma, like sexual abuse, the impact of that trauma can affect many areas of our lives as adults.  Working with a therapist who specializes in trauma is a great way to begin developing skills to manage present day life, learn to regulate your emotions and nervous system when you become triggered, and then in a safe environment have the opportunity to process past traumas so you can live your present life with more ease and joy.  People can and do recover from the impacts of trauma at any stage in their life.  It is never too late and you can feel better

Crying due to a dissolution of a marriage, is normal.  Hating yourself may be a sign of extreme sadness, feelings of loss and uncertainty.Do you know why you hate yourself? Discovering your reason is the first step in knowing the obstacles and then the additional steps possible, to move from "hate" to "self-love".Divorce signals a loss of familiar life structure and daily routines.   As with any meaningful loss, crying is part of mourning what is soon to be gone.If you have confidence in your attorney's handling of the legal areas related to the divorce, and the "impossible" you reference is on facing and coming to terms with statements and behaviors from your wife that you never noticed before, then your best choice is to find a therapist whom you feel at ease in talking with, to sort through the emotional upheaval within yourself and your everyday life and world.Divorce is a wonderful time for learning about ones own emotional needs and expectations in relationships since these are the areas currently coming apart.The good news behind losing something that seems valuable, is that new space becomes open to attract what is more suitable for who you are.

Given your experience of being imposed upon against your will, and all the personal and professional loss that has come since, your fear of what will happen if you undergo treatment and trust a therapist is understandable. There is no technique or pill that can guarantee these thoughts will go away or be reversed, however, there are things that you can do which may help you to change your relationship to the thoughts and to the distress that they cause. I understand that working with a therapist sounds risky, given your experiences, and at the same time a good therapist may be a beneficial resource in helping you deal with the intrusive thoughts, cope with and alleviate the stress that they create, and perhaps even lead to the alleviation of the thoughts themselves. A therapist may also be able to help you discover strategies to work towards any goals you have around reconnecting with your children and working again. If therapy feels too unsafe at the moment, I would recommend looking into workbooks on how to deal with intrusive thoughts and coping with stress. Some popular approaches that you may want to look into are mindfulness techniques, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy. You may even be able to find some of these resources at a library, if affordability is an obstacle.

It can be frustrating when we send messages and don't get responses. However, it's important to remember that there can be many reasons why someone doesn't respond right away, or at all. It doesn't necessarily mean that there is something specific about you that they don't like. Here are some possible explanations:

1. They're busy: People have many commitments and responsibilities that can keep them from responding promptly or even at all.
2. They're engaged in another activity: Someone may be out and about, or engaged in a task that makes it difficult for them to respond right away.
3. They're distracted: Sometimes, we may be preoccupied with our own thoughts or feelings, making it hard for us to focus on responding to messages.
4. They're not interested: It's unfortunate, but sometimes people lose interest in maintaining a conversation or a relationship.
5. Communication style differences: Some people prefer shorter interactions, while others crave deeper conversations. There may be a mismatch in communication styles that could be contributing to the issue.

That being said, if you feel that this is a common occurrence for you and it's causing you distress, it might be helpful to try the following suggestions:

1. Be patient: It's important to give people space and time to respond.
2. Set clear expectations: If you need a response urgently, make sure to specify that in your message.
3. Consider other forms of communication: If texting isn't working, try reaching out via phone call or email.
4. Reflect on your own communication style: Is there a way you can adjust your communication style to better meet the needs of others?

Remember, everyone's communication preferences are different, and it's important to be respectful of that. If you continue to feel concerned or distressed about this issue, it might be helpful to discuss it further with a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional.

It's important to understand that financial issues can be a significant source of stress and conflict in relationships. In your situation, your fiancé may have felt taken advantage of or deceived because he was paying for insurance coverage on a vehicle that he no longer owned. This could have triggered feelings of anger or resentment, as he may have felt that you weren't being transparent or that you weren't acting in the best interest of the relationship.

To help prevent similar conflicts in the future, it might be helpful to establish clear communication and transparency around financial matters. This could include regularly discussing each other's financial obligations, keeping track of shared expenses, and ensuring that all financial decisions are made with mutual agreement.

It's also important to remember that it's normal for couples to have disagreements or misunderstandings from time to time. The most important thing is to listen actively to each other's concerns, validate each other's feelings, and work together to find a solution that works for both of you. In your case, you could try having an open and honest conversation with your fiancé about this issue, and see if you can come up with a mutually agreed-upon solution, such as adjusting the payment arrangement or finding a more cost-effective alternative for insurance coverage.

Ultimately, the key is to approach financial matters in a collaborative and transparent way, and to be open to finding solutions that benefit the relationship as a whole. By doing so, you can help build trust, strengthen communication, and reduce financial conflict in your relationship.

You may be pressuring yourself to be the one person who fixes the relationship.  This is impossible because the relationship belongs to both of you.Has he told you whether he feels about himself that how he interacts with you, is contributing to problems in the couple?Is he willing to understand what you're asking of him, without shutting down with whatever he is feeling when he feels blamed?Your feelings of distrust are the natural outcome of not being properly heard and understood.  He's not willing to listen to you, so of course you're frustrated and this frustration comes out in all sorts of uneasy feelings.Willingness to hear each other in a non-defensive way, sometimes requires a couples therapist's assistance.Ask your husband if he's willing to understand, not judge you.  Be willing yourself to do the same.If after trying and getting nowhere, you'll know when to stop trying on your own as a couple and to find a specifically trained couples therapists.Warning, not all therapists are trained to do couples therapy.  Ask the therapist if they've had specialized training in couples therapy.Otherwise, having a referee type therapy session of, "what do you think", "what do you think?", isn't going to do anything except frustrate both of you further.Good luck!

I understand that you're feeling anxious and worried about having sex. It's important to remember that everyone experiences sexuality in their own unique way, and there's no right or wrong way to be sexual. It's normal to feel anxious or have fears around sex, particularly if it's your first time or if you're in a new relationship.

As for your concern about being inexperienced or disappointing your partner, remember that communication is key. Openly discussing your feelings and concerns with your partner can help build trust and understanding in your relationship. They may have fears or concerns of their own, and having an open and honest conversation about them can help both of you feel more comfortable and confident.

Additionally, it's important to know that everyone has different expectations and desires when it comes to sex. What's most important is that you're both enjoying the experience and feeling secure and comfortable with each other.

Lastly, remember that everyone's body is different, and yours is unique and beautiful in its own way. Focus on appreciating your body and its capabilities, rather than focusing on any perceived imperfections. Remember, it's your body and your choice. Take your time and explore your sexuality at a pace that feels right for you.

I understand that your roommate's drinking behavior and emotional manipulation have been causing you distress. It's important to recognize that you cannot control another person's drinking or their emotional responses. This is not your responsibility. You are not required to make her feel validated, or to accept abusive or manipulative behavior.

It's crucial that you set healthy boundaries and prioritize your own emotional well-being. You can express your feelings to her, but make it clear that her actions have consequences and that you cannot continue to enable her behavior.

You've mentioned her suicidal thoughts, and it's important to take these seriously. If you feel she is a danger to herself, please encourage her to seek professional help immediately, such as a doctor or a mental health professional.

I recommend that you consider your own safety and well-being in this situation, as well. If her behavior is too much for you to bear, or if she is becoming physically or emotionally abusive, you may consider finding a new living situation.

In addition to setting boundaries with your roommate, consider talking with a therapist about your own emotional response to her behavior and how to cope with the stress it causes you.

It's not easy to be in a situation where someone you care about is struggling, but remembering that you can't fix things for her and focusing on your own emotional health and well-being can be helpful.

I understand that the PTSD you're experiencing following a past relationship is causing you significant distress, with feelings of anger, anxiety, and depression. It's important to acknowledge that PTSD is a legitimate mental health condition, and it takes courage to seek help. Your emotions are understandable given the trauma you've experienced. The healing process for PTSD can be long and challenging, but it is possible. Working with a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or therapist, can provide you with appropriate tools, techniques, and resources to help you manage your symptoms and move forward. Some common treatments include cognitive-behavioral therapy, exposure therapy, and eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) therapy. If you haven't already, consider reaching out to a mental health professional to discuss your symptoms and explore potential treatment options.

The question of right or wrong here can be complex, as every relationship and situation is unique. However, I can provide some guidance based on common principles of healthy relationships and boundaries.

First, it is essential to communicate openly with your partner about your friendship and its boundaries. If your boyfriend is feeling upset or uncomfortable, it's vital to acknowledge his feelings and explain the nature of your friendship with your ex.

Second, it is essential to respect the boundaries that both you and your partner have agreed upon in your relationship. This could include things like not spending significant amounts of time alone with exes or not engaging in behaviors that could be perceived as disloyal.

Lastly, as a general rule, it is healthy for friendships to exist beyond romantic relationships. While it is crucial to be considerate of your partner's feelings and communicate openly, it is also essential not to sacrifice healthy friendships or personal growth for the sake of avoiding conflict.

Ultimately, the decision of whether or not you were 'wrong' will depend on your ability to communicate effectively with your partner, respect the boundaries you have established in your relationship, and prioritize maintaining the health and well-being of both your friendship and romantic partnership.

I'm here to help you, patient. Listening effectively in a relationship involves giving your full attention to your partner without judgment. Here are some steps to improve your listening skills:

1. Look at your partner and maintain eye contact, if appropriate and comfortable.
2. Use open-ended questions to encourage your partner to share more about their thoughts and feelings.
3. Avoid interrupting or completing your partner's sentences.
4. Reflect back to your partner what you've understood to ensure you've grasped their perspective.
5. Use empathetic statements to show understanding and support, such as "I can see this must be difficult for you."

Regarding "getting yourself together," it might be helpful to:

1. Identify any underlying issues causing stress or confusion in your emotions or behaviors.
2. Practice self-care activities to manage your stress and anxiety, such as exercise, meditation, or hobbies.
3. Seek professional help if needed, such as therapy or counseling, to process difficult emotions or heal from past experiences that may be impacting your relationships.
4. Communicate clearly and effectively with your partner about your feelings and intentions, ensuring a mutual understanding and respect for each other's emotions.

In summary, improving your listening skills and regaining emotional control involves active listening and effective communication. I hope this helps and please don't hesitate to ask any questions or seek additional guidance if needed.

Are you a teen?  This is a really hard problem for more teens (and adults) than let on.  When I was about 15, I remember asking my parent's friend, Herman, whether life gets any easier when you get older.  He said the problems are actually harder, but you gain the ability to deal with them better.  I've been an adult a long time now, and that is so true. If you need someone to talk to, consider a teacher or a school guidance counselor or someone you respect, maybe in church.  If they're good and they don't know how to help you, they may know how to get you to someone who can.  Also, the idea of not being "good enough" is a common psychological event.  In CBT it's called a "core belief," but I call it a "core lie" in my book, Living Yes, a Handbook for Being Human.  If you are serious about changing yourself, read about it  at www.LivingYes.org and pick up a copy there or on Amazon.  I hope this was helpful.  The future is filled with possibility if we don't prejudge it!  ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

I understand that you're experiencing a sense of feeling like you don't want to be here and that life is a chore. This is a complex issue and I want you to know that it's not uncommon to have these thoughts from time to time. However, it's important that we explore these feelings further, as they can be a sign of something more serious. These thoughts are known as suicidal ideation and while you've stated that you don't have suicidal intent, it's essential for us to discuss these feelings in more detail.

Have you considered speaking with a mental health professional about this? They can provide you with additional resources and support to help you navigate through these difficult emotions. You're not alone in this, and it's important to remember that there are people out there who care about you and want to help.

Additionally, there are various coping strategies and techniques that can help improve your mood and overall well-being. For instance, engaging in regular exercise, eating a healthy and balanced diet, getting enough rest, and practicing relaxation techniques like meditation or deep-breathing exercises can make a significant difference.

Lastly, please know that seeking professional help does not indicate weakness or failure. It's a sign that you are taking the steps necessary to improve your life and overall well-being. Remember, talking about your feelings is an essential part of growing, healing, and ultimately reaching a better place in your life.

Hello, and thank you for your question. The question about
whether or not to cheat is based on personal values that can only be answered
by you. However, here are a few things to consider and questions to ask
yourself to help you find your answer:
1.    
Do you feel like you are violating your own
values or morals? This is important, because we all have different values and
morals surrounding sex, love, and monogamy. If you value monogamous
relationships and find yourself cheating on your partner, then you may feel
like you are living in contradiction to your values, and most people are not
happy when they do that. However, if monogamy is not something you value, then
perhaps it is time to re-evaluate the relationship and determine if it is still
right for you. Not all people want monogamous relationships, and that
is alright. Finally, if you value your husband’s feelings and know that the
affairs would hurt him, then your behaviors may again be in contrast to your
own values. That can only be determined by you. 
2.      Based on how you describe your relationship, it
sounds like you are not very satisfied with the way it is.  From the outside, it looks like the affairs
are a way to “get even” with your husband or to feel better after an argument. This
is something that can happen when mutual respect starts to fade in a
relationship and gets replaced with contempt. We can simply stop caring about
how our actions hurt each other, or potentially hurt each other. Perhaps the
question to ask here is, when you look out toward the future with your husband,
is this the pattern that you want to keep? The pattern of very little sex,
argument, and then satisfying the pain or dissatisfaction with affairs. 
 3.      What are your goals for this relationship? If we
start to become disconnected in a relationship, we can begin to do things on
autopilot. Get up, get the kids up, go to work, come home, and go to bed. None
of which requires any intimacy at all. Are you still able to see the hopes and
dreams you once had for this relationship?
 4.     
Have you considered seeking marital counseling? Not
having affairs won’t actually fix the part of the relationship that is leading
you to have them. If there is something broken, it sometimes requires some help
to get it fixed. 
 Hopefully these questions and thoughts will help you come to
some kind of conclusion about what is right for you and your relationship. I certainly
wish you well. 
 Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

I understand that the sudden change in your relationship with him left you feeling anxious and scared, leading you to react strongly when he doesn't respond quickly. Additionally, focusing on your own personal growth, hobbies, and relationships can provide you with a sense of fulfillment and independence, lessening your dependency on a single relationship.

Solo duerme y trabaja.Después de ocho años y dos hijos las  personas cambian.  Te sugiero que hables con tu pareja sobre cómo te dientes, déjale saber que aunque el esta fuera la mayoría del tiempo, su presencia como pareja y padre es requerida e importante. Pregúntale si el está dispuesto a comprometerse  ser parte activa de la familia y como lo haría.  Muchas veces cuando los papás están afuera las mamás desarrollan rutinas que luego ellos no quieren interrumpir.  Crea tiempo a solas para dedicarle a el para que puedan reconectar como pareja y luego como familia.

First off, it is great that you recognize that some changes need to be made. It is also really good that you understand where the source of your anxiety and stress comes from. Fortunately there are many self help books and internet sources that provide free tools to help you cope with life's obstacles, including anger management. There are several strategies that you can try to help control your anger, but the ones that I would recomend first are the following:1. Try a different way of communicating with your parents. Since arguing with them is a great source of anger for you, learning more effective ways of communicating with them will likely be of great benefit. Choose a time to talk with them about "heated issues" when everyone is calm and emotions are not heightened. Use "I phrases" by telling them how the arguments effect you, as opposed to placing blame on them. Validate what you hear your parents say in order to allow them to know that you understand their point of view.2. When you feel yourself becoming angry, take a break. Simply excuse yourself from the situation, find a quiet place to be by yourself, and do some deep breathing. Close your eyes, slowly count to four as you inhale, and exhale even slower, counting to 6. Focus on nothing except for your breathing and do this for 5 minutes.3. Stop any negative thoughts in their tracks. Often times when we get upset, we catastrophize and do not see things clearly. When you catch yourself thinking negatively stop the thoughts and ask yourself if your thinking is logical and rational. If you cannot find much or any evidence that your thoughts are valid, then let them go and replace them with realistic, logical thoughts.4. Finally, find a friend or someone to talk to and/or keep a journal. Keeping your emotions to yourself will not help you. Being able to express your feelings and problem solve will allow for some relief when feeling sad or angry.I wish you all the best!

I'm so sorry for your loss and for the pain you're experiencing. It's normal to grieve for a long time after the death of loved ones, especially grandparents and siblings whom we hold close to our hearts. The nighttime may be difficult for you due to the quietness and lack of distractions, making it easy for your mind to focus on your memories of them. Your tears are a natural response to the sadness and missing you feel. It's essential to allow yourself to feel and process these emotions, as they help in the healing process. Incorporating a consistent bedtime routine that includes relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing and meditation, can help your mind and body unwind and may make it easier to fall asleep. If your grief is impacting your daily functioning or preventing you from living your life effectively, consider seeking support from a mental health professional.

Ouch. It's really hard to deal with a spouse that isn't taking you seriously. In this case, I would plan for and schedule a time to talk with him about this. I would tell him that you need about 30 minutes to talk to him with minimal interruptions about something that is important to you. Schedule a time, write notes if you need reminders about what you need to express, and tell him how you feel. Ideally, you would focus more on I-statements instead of telling him what he is doing wrong. For example,  I feel ignored vs You always ignore me. By focusing on how you feel, he is less likely to feel attacked and get defensive. Some people go to couples or marriage counseling for help with communication. Chances are there are things that BOTH of you do that hurts your communication. Overall, try to talk to him directly and try not to get defensive. If he continues to say, you're always sad - then stay calm, say "okay, can you help me understand that more?" or "That's interesting. Tell me what you see."  Reach out to a couples counselor for more help with communication strategies. Sometimes a 3rd party can help you both see things in a different perspective. Hope this helps!

You need to have an honest conversation with each other about WHY you both want a threesome. Evaluate the status of your relationship with each other. Are you having issues? Fighting? Not feeling satisfied with each other? How has your sex life been with each other?  If there are any problems, insecurities, issues, introducing something like this may only make your relationship worse. Open relationships and threesomes rarely work out well. Sure, there are some who successfully live this lifestyle, but it only works when both people are completely secure in their relationship with each other, harbor no jealousies or insecurities, and aren't looking to someone else to satisfy needs that aren't getting met by their spouse. Let me say that again: This is not likely to work out well for you if either of you are insecure, jealous, or looking to have needs met by this other person that you aren't getting from your spouse. That empty feeling you're having - listen to it. Dig deep to find out where it is coming from. What thoughts are going through your head when you feel that way? You'll get the answer.The other thing that helps make something like this work is for both of you to listen and respect each other. If you don't like it that he paid more attention to the other girl, he needs to know that, and he needs to respect that.  If you're going to do it again, he needs to know what you're comfortable with and what you want. Set the limits before you're in the moment, before it's too late to take an action back. Turn it around and ask him what he would be comfortable with if it were a man instead of a woman.It is perfectly natural to be curious and want to experiment. A lot of people get that out of the way before settling down in a monogamous relationship. People who marry young and/or inexperienced may still feel that curiosity about things like that and want to experience them, but don't want to hurt their spouse. The REASON you are both doing this matters a lot. If there are problems in your relationship, this is likely to only make things worse.

I understand that being separated from your boyfriend for an extended period can be difficult. It's natural to feel emotional and anxious during this time. Try engaging in self-care activities, such as exercise, meditation, reading, or hobbies. Reach out to friends or family for support, and consider arranging activities that remind you of happy memories with your boyfriend. Remember, too, that effective communication is key in maintaining relationships. Make plans to discuss your feelings with your boyfriend when he returns.

I understand your situation, and it's not uncommon for people in high-stress jobs to feel overwhelmed and underappreciated. Here are some suggestions to help you manage your stress:

1. Prioritize your tasks: Make a list of your tasks and prioritize them based on importance and deadline. This will help you focus on what needs to be done first and avoid feeling overwhelmed by an endless list.
2. Take care of yourself: Regular exercise, a healthy diet, and adequate sleep are all essential for managing stress. Try to build these habits into your routine.
3. Practice relaxation techniques: Mindfulness meditation, deep breathing, and progressive muscle relaxation are all effective techniques for reducing stress and anxiety.
4. Ask for help: Don't hesitate to ask for assistance from your colleagues or supervisor if you're feeling overwhelmed. Communicating openly about your concerns may help alleviate some of the pressure.
5. Set boundaries: Be clear about your work schedule and set boundaries about when and how often you're available to work. This can help you establish a better work-life balance and reduce the risk of burnout.
6. Seek support: Reach out to friends, family, or a mental health professional if you're feeling particularly demoralized or overwhelmed. They can offer a fresh perspective and help you develop coping strategies to manage your stress.

It's normal to feel a little anxiety--after all it's an important encounter for you.  My suggestion is to discuss this with your therapist, let him/her know how you're feeling, especially if you feel as though your level of anxiety is impacting the quality and benefit of your sessions.  You might try some relaxation techniques prior to starting the session, deep breathing, progressive relaxation, core muscle dis-engagement--If you're not familiar with these techniques ask your therapist or write back.

I understand your desire to understand your conditions better, and it's commendable that you've done thorough research. However, self-diagnosis, especially with complex conditions like you've described, can be misleading. Mental health conditions carry a significant impact on an individual's life and have unique complexities. It's essential to have a proper assessment from a qualified mental health professional to ensure accuracy, develop a suitable treatment plan, and receive appropriate support. The DSM-IV and college psychology knowledge are valuable resources, but they are not as comprehensive as a professional evaluation. If you're struggling with symptoms consistent with what you've read, consider reaching out to a mental health professional. They can provide a proper diagnosis, offer evidence-based treatment options, and address any concerns you may have. Remember, taking the initial step towards seeking help is essential in managing and improving your mental health.

I understand that you're going through a difficult time with your anxiety and panic attacks, and the added concern about your relationship only makes things more confusing. Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) can indeed present with intrusive thoughts and doubts, and these can sometimes focus on relationships.

It's essential to note that these thoughts are likely a part of your OCD and not a reflection of the actual state of your relationship. That being said, it's always a good idea to communicate openly with your boyfriend about how you've been feeling. He may be able to offer reassurance or support.

Additionally, working with a therapist who specializes in OCD can help you learn strategies to manage your symptoms, including cognitive-behavioral techniques and mindfulness practices. These methods can help you challenge the intrusive thoughts and develop healthier ways to cope with anxiety.

Lastly, if you're feeling particularly overwhelmed, it might be helpful to speak with your psychiatrist about adjusting your treatment plan as needed. They can offer medication options or other interventions to help you better manage your symptoms.

Remember, you're not alone in this. Many people with OCD experience uncertainly and doubts about their relationships, and with the right support, you can learn to manage these feelings effectively.

Relationships can be extremely enjoyable and satisfying.  When relationships end, however, it can be devastating.  It is normal to go through a grieving process after a breakup.  Denial, bargaining, sadness, anger and eventually acceptance are all normal stages of grief.  You may experience these feelings all at once or one at a time.  Allow yourself time to grieve by expressing your emotions - talk to a friend or write in a journal.  Take care of yourself during this time by exercising, eating and sleeping well and spending time with friends.  After some time you should start feeling better.  If you feel like you're not feeling better and you don't know what to do, you can see a therapist to help you get through this difficult time.

A counselor decides to end counseling sessions when they believe that the client has achieved their therapeutic goals or made sufficient progress to no longer require ongoing professional help. This decision is often made in collaboration with the client, taking into account their individual needs, circumstances, and progress towards recovery or personal growth. Factors such as the attainment of specific therapy objectives, the client's readiness to manage their issues independently, and the counselor's confidence in the client's ability to cope with potential challenges may all contribute to this decision. However, it's essential for both the client and counselor to discuss the potential termination and work together to ensure a safe and effective transition to post-therapy life.

I'm sorry to hear that your treatment was discontinued without proper explanation. This may include discussing your concerns with the provider, seeking a second opinion, or even filing a complaint with the hospital or professional board, if necessary. Taking accountability for your actions and seeking help is an excellent first step. I wonder where the anger is coming from. Learning what is at
the root of it can shed some light on what the problem is and can provide some
relief in itself. I would also suggest doing some self-exploration and see a
therapist for individual sessions in order to gain a clearer insight as to what
the cause is. There are also several actions you can take on your own to help
control your anger and communicate more effectively. Here is what I would recommend
you try:
Take time outs: When you feel yourself becoming upset, excuse yourself and
take a time out to either think about the most appropriate course of
action or redirect your thoughts all together. Often when we become
angry, it is difficult to see the issue clearly, as our emotions get in
the way. 
Do deep breathing exercises: Close your eyes. Breathe in slowly to the
count of 4. Breathe out even slower to the count of 6. Practice this for about
5 minutes, 3 times a day and focus on nothing except your breathing during this
time. Once it becomes routine for you, it will be easier to apply during
situations in which you are angry or upset.
Change negative thought patterns: Try and recall or be aware of your
thoughts, particularly when you are feeling angry. What are these thoughts
telling you? Are they valid or logical? Is there factual evidence to support
the negative thoughts? Often the answer is "no." Learn to stop the
negative thoughts and replace them with logical and more positive
ones. 
Communicate effectively: As a speaker, you want to use "I"
statements by telling the other person how you feel instead of blaming him/her
by using "you" statements. For example, you might say something such
as, "I feel sad when you don't come home at a decent hour and I don't get
to spend time with you" versus "You always stay out late and don't
even care about me." The speaker should also avoid using black and white
language such as always, never, etc. As the listener, you want to validate what
you hear so that the other person knows that you are listening. You will also want
to be responsive and offer fair solutions.
I wish you luck in using these tools and learning about where your anger comes
from.

Hi, Ontario. I live in the other Ontario; in Canada. I'll try to help you sort this out. You have a long list of complaints about your boyfriend! It sounds like he's maybe a bit immature and moody, and these things affect you, for sure. I get it. It's got me curious, and if I was working with you, I'd want to know a lot more about how long you've been together and what's actually working well between you two. I would also ask a lot of questions about the details of your description. What tells you he's 'sneaky'? Does he lie? How do you know he lies to you? Also, are you wanting to make things better with him, do you just want an ear to vent to, are you looking for validation, or do you hope someone will help you wake up to an unhappy situation?  It helps me if I know what you want.Whenever I meet someone who has a lot of complaints about their partner or boyfriend, I encourage them first to look at the language they're using. Some of your words tell me that you think you know what he's thinking (that he wants to fight so he can leave, that he thinks he's perfect). It's always tricky when we assume what someone's thinking, and in an argument or dialogue, these kinds of statements tend to lead to defensiveness and an escalated argument. I'd encourage you to focus on his actual behaviours and how they affect you, rather than the motives or beliefs you think are behind the behaviours (because you really can't know what he's thinking unless he tells you). As a general rule, the "When you do X, I feel Y" sentence goes far in helping others understand what we feel.So, it's fair to say "when you lie to me, I can't trust you", or "when you end our date early to hang with your friends I feel like I'm not important to you", or "your mood swings are difficult for me", or "I don't seem to get apologies from you". Try to focus on his actual behaviour when you talk to him about this stuff. A relationship counsellor can help you each understand the other better beyond the surface behaviours if you want to improve the relationship.That said, I have to ask...if you haven't been with Mr. Not So Great for very long, is it maybe time to rethink the relationship? Unless there is a balance of really loving and positive behaviours that you're leaving out, you don't seem happy. A good therapist can help you understand why you are stuck in an unhappy relationship, if that is what's happening. There's a lot to sort out here...how to communicate about your needs, how to know when to call it quits if something doesn't feel good... I wish you the best as you continue to examine these questions with assistance from friends or professionals.
