I understand that you feel deeply for this person and value your relationship with them. It's common to feel intense emotions and a strong desire for reconciliation in situations like these. However, it's important to remember that actions must align with the sincerity of those feelings.

You mentioned that nothing you do seems to work, and that may be due to a lack of effective communication or perhaps not fully understanding the root of the issue that caused the hurt. In order to make progress, it's crucial to address the underlying problems and work through them together. This may involve discussing any negative patterns in your relationship, being open about your feelings, actively listening to one another, and committing to change.

It's also important to consider the well-being of all parties involved, including any children, and ensure that any reconciliation would create a healthy, nurturing environment for them.

Reaching out for professional help, such as couples therapy, can be an effective way to navigate this process with the support and guidance of a trained therapist. Remember, change takes time and effort, but it's never too late to learn, grow, and make things right.

I want to applaud you for taking this first step towards realizing that this is an issue and wanting to do something about it.  You are already on the road to a happier life with this realization.  A lot of women do not recognize that it may be something about them that continues to attract a man like this and will only blame it on the men for treating them that way.  Until you realize there is a problem you won’t start looking for a solution.Don’t misunderstand me!  The abuse is not your fault! You are seeing a pattern, though, so this does need to be addressed. First, go and buy the book “Boundaries: Where You End and I Begin” by Anne Katherine.  Read it.  This book describes many situations that are similar to yours, describes how a person came to be that way, and how to stop it.  You will have to learn to set good boundaries in your life and to maintain them.Be single for a while.  Stay single until you feel like a whole, healthy, happy person on your own.  Often we get in a relationship because of a need.  If you feel like you need a person in your life to make you a whole person then you are in a relationship for the wrong reasons.  The first step is to work on whatever it is in you that makes you feel like you need another person in your life.  Identify those needs and then learn to fulfill them on your own.I was doing a couples therapy session and the husband was being emotionally abusive to the wife.  This was a recurrent theme for her, like you are saying it is for you.  However, she had been doing a lot of work on her own and in private therapy, and this was a new relationship.  Obviously she still had not “gotten it right” because she did once again attract a man with these tendencies.  The difference this time was that she had done a lot of work on herself and had become a stronger person.  When she looked at him in our session and said to him “I don’t need you. I want you.  But not if you are going to continue to act like this.  So you leave the house and don’t come back until you are ready to make some changes.”  She stuck to that, too.  He didn’t leave for two more days because he kept telling her he would do different and begging to be allowed to stay.  She had drawn a boundary and stuck to it, and he left. She was fully prepared to be single again.  They actually did end up working things out in the end.You can’t let someone stay and continue to treat you badly.  Sure, a marriage takes work and compromise on both sides.  Couples therapy can help you both learn to communicate in a healthier way with each other and can help you realize what areas in the relationship need work.  You may not realize how some of the things you say to him comes across, and he may not realize how what he says does to you.  A therapist can help you with this so that you both learn how your words can hurt. But you need to know your boundaries and be prepared to stick to them and not compromise your boundaries.  That means following through on the threat to leave when he continues to abuse you.  Someone can’t do that if they are too scared to be alone.  If they feel they need the other person in their life. These patterns are developed in early childhood from what we learn from our parents.  When someone has grown up in a dysfunctional family, it is all they know.  Even when you can say that you realize it is a problem, you still don’t know how to stop it because you never learned any other way of interacting with people.  Something that took a lifetime to learn will take time and work to overcome.  Be patient with yourself and find a good therapist.  You can’t change your partner.  Work on you, and when you begin to heal and feel healthy, the right people will come into your life and stay.  The more you focus on trying to change the wrong ones to be what you want the more frustrated you will become.

I understand that you're going through a challenging time as you strive to maintain your sense of identity amidst your roles as a wife and mother. It can be a common experience for women in your situation.

The emotions you're describing, such as self-loathing, unhappiness, and feeling trapped, are normal responses to the transition of life roles. It's important to acknowledge that these emotions are valid and that there's no need to suppress them.

Societal pressures and expectations can sometimes contribute to feelings of guilt and inadequacy for women who prioritize their caretaking roles above their individual identities. However, maintaining your sense of self-worth and identity is essential for your overall wellbeing.

To help navigate this situation, consider the following steps:

1. Set aside time for yourself: It's crucial to make time for personal interests, hobbies, and activities that make you feel happy and fulfilled. Carve out small chunks of time in your schedule each day or a few hours each week for yourself as a sanctuary where you can pursue your passions.

2. Connect with others: Engage in social activities and surround yourself with supportive and understanding individuals. Fostering relationships with others who share common experiences or interests can help bolster feelings of connectedness and reaffirm your identity outside of your family roles.

3. Practice self-compassion: Be gentle with yourself and acknowledge that it's natural to have complex emotions as you navigate your identity. Focus on the positive aspects of your life, such as your loving family, and remind yourself that it's okay to feel unhappy at times.

4. Set meaningful goals: Set goals that align with your personal desires and identity, such as returning to school, volunteering, or pursuing a creative hobby. Achieving these goals can serve as a source of pride and joy, further nurturing your sense of self-worth and identity.

5. Seek support: If necessary, consider reaching out to a professional counselor or therapist who can help guide you through this emotional experience. Sharing your feelings with someone who is trained to listen and offer helpful resources can provide valuable insight and validation.

Remember, it's essential to recognize that taking care of yourself and maintaining your identity doesn't equate to neglecting your loved ones

It's important to note that I am an artificial intelligence language model and not a licensed psychologist, but I will do my best to provide some general suggestions based on your description. While it's understandable that you might feel hesitant about sharing your feelings with others, it's important to know that seeking help for depression doesn't have to involve telling everyone in your life. Here are some steps you can take to manage your depression on your own:

1. Self-Care: Prioritize taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally. This can include things like getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy.
2. Exercise: Regular physical activity, even something as simple as walking, can help improve your mood and energy levels.
3. Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques: Practicing mindfulness meditation or relaxation exercises like deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation can help you manage stress and anxiety.
4. Education: Learning about depression and how it affects the brain can help you better understand your experience.
5. Seek Professional Help: While you may not be ready to share your feelings with others, you don't have to face your depression alone. Consider reaching out to a mental health professional for support. They can help you develop coping skills and provide you with valuable resources.

Remember, taking care of your mental health is an important part of leading a happy and fulfilling life. If you find that your depression is overwhelming or interfering with your daily activities, it's important to reach out for help. Even if you don't feel ready to share your feelings with others just yet, a mental health professional can offer you support and guidance in a confidential setting.

I understand that you're experiencing intense emotional reactions and behavioral patterns that interfere with your daily life. Based on the symptoms you described, it sounds like you might be dealing with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD). BPD is characterized by volatile emotions, impulsive behavior, intense fear of abandonment, and a distorted sense of self. It's important to note that this is a complex condition that requires proper diagnosis by a mental health professional. If you haven't already, I would recommend reaching out to a therapist or psychiatrist who is experienced in treating BPD. There are evidence-based treatments such as Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) that can help manage the symptoms of this condition. In the meantime, practice self-care, reach out to supportive friends and family, and avoid triggers that might worsen your emotional state.

I'm sorry to hear that you experience sadness every winter. This feeling is known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), which is a type of depression that's related to the changing of the seasons. Here are some ways to help alleviate your symptoms:

1. Light Therapy: Expose yourself to natural sunlight or use a light box to simulate sunlight.
2. Regular Exercise: Incorporate physical activity into your daily routine as it can improve your mood and overall well-being.
3. Maintain a healthy diet: Eating a balanced and nutritious diet can help boost your energy levels and mood.
4. Engage in Activities: Participate in hobbies or activities that bring you joy and help distract you from feeling sad.
5. Keep a Journal: Writing down your thoughts and feelings can help you identify patterns and triggers.
6. Consider professional help: If your symptoms are severe, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can help you develop a personalized treatment plan.
7. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation can help you reduce stress and anxiety.
8. Stay Connected: Keeping in touch with friends and family can help you feel less isolated and lonely.

Remember, it's important to take care of yourself during the winter months and prioritize your mental and physical well-being. I hope these strategies help you feel more optimistic and energized. If you're still struggling, don't hesitate to reach out for additional support.

Good for you to know your daughter's friendship circles and to notice when these have changed.While friendships are key relationships, they are not the only indicator of someone not developing normally.Is your observation and opinion that your daughter isn't normal based on other factors or just this one?If this is the only factor then start with reflecting on what circumstances may be influencing your daughter to socialize with younger kids.Has she ben ostracized or bullied by her peers and may be retreating to avoid further emotional hurt?Is she keeping up with her school work?Sometimes kids who feel overwhelmed by schoolwork will regress into conditions in which they feel more success and control.Are there family circumstances such as the death of someone with whom your daughter felt close?  Or, is there a new younger sibling in the family or a younger sibling who due to their own circumstance receives more attention than your daughter may wish for herself.Once you've reflected on which areas may be affecting your daughter, gently ask her some questions about her comfort with what you theorize may be the source of the problem.Its also possible that offering her your extra time and interest may increase her sense of self so that she feels secure enough to increase her social time with her age group.

I understand how you're feeling, patient. It sounds like you're experiencing a high level of stress and anxiety. Jading and losing focus are common symptoms in times of stress. However, it's important to remember that these feelings are temporary and manageable.

To help you focus and reduce anxiety, there are several things you can try:

1. Practice mindfulness meditation: This involves bringing your attention to the present moment and accepting your thoughts and feelings without judgment. You can find many free resources online to learn how to meditate mindfully.
2. Identify and challenge negative thoughts: Try to recognize when you're having negative thoughts and challenge them with more positive and realistic thoughts.
3. Exercise regularly: Physical activity can help improve your mood and reduce stress.
4. Get enough sleep: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night. Lack of sleep can contribute to anxiety and poor focus.
5. Eat a healthy diet: Consuming a nutritious diet can help improve your overall mental and physical health.
6. Connect with supportive people: Talk to friends or loved ones about your feelings and seek their support.
7. Consider therapy: If your symptoms persist, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional for additional support.

I hope these suggestions will help you in managing your anxiety and regaining focus. Remember, it takes time and effort to change thought patterns and learn new coping mechanisms. Be patient with yourself and let me know if you have any further questions or concerns.

One theory is that instead of "fighting" your feelings, accept your sad feelings and work with them.   Feeling sad may open many doors to reflect and make peace with the source of your sadness.Also, I believe fighting against the natural cycle of rest and hibernation may not even be possible to succeed.   Winter for most creatures is a time of withdrawal and slowdown.  Our bodies and moods are part of nature as well.  Fighting what is part of nature seems like a tiring fight which the person will lose.Last point, there are the winter holidays to break up the dark and cold of winter.   Maybe you can invent some of your own winter celebrations so you'll have a few gatherings to look forward to hosting.

How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?Communication with our loved ones can be tricky, but it is the key to maintaining a healthy and functional relationship with them. At times, it seems difficult to communicate with our family because many feelings and “undercover” messages are attached. Especially with our mothers, who often provide advice and feel responsible for us, it may feel like they are making everything about themselves as they express their worries and concerns.So what to do? First will be important to practice active listening skills, to ensure that you are receiving and understanding the message, without filtering it trough your own emotions or preconceptions of the person who speaks.  Second, learn and practice assertive communication skills.  Those will help you to communicate a message clearly and in pieces.  It also emphasizes using I-statements to express how you feel at times when emotions become affected by the interaction.  Third, you should practice, by writing your I-statement or role playing with your counselor.   The trick with communication skills is that we need to practice them as often as possible until you to master them.  You can also contact a family therapist to improve those skills if it becomes challenging, or contact a mediator if more issues arise.¿Cómo puedo lograr que mi mamá me escuche sin alarmarse tanto?La comunicación con nuestros seres queridos puede ser dificultosa, pero es la clave para mantener relaciones saludables y funcionales con ellos.  A veces, nos parece aun más difícil comunicarnos con nuestra familia, porque hay muchos sentimientos y mensajes envueltos en la comunicación.  Especialmente nuestras  madres,  pueden hacer parecer que están convirtiendo el asunto en algo personal, cuando se sienten preocupadas y responsables por nosotros y nuestras acciones.¿Y qué hacemos?  Primero debemos aprender a escuchar activamente, para asegurarnos de que comprendemos el mensaje, y que no lo estemos filtrando a través de nuestras emociones e ideas de la otra persona. Segundo, aprende y practica comunicación asertiva.  Esto te ayudara a comunicar un mensaje claramente y en pedazos.  También te ayudar a aprender expresiones del Yo, para identificar sentimientos afectados durante la interacción.  Tercero, es importante que practiques estas destrezas, ya sea escribiendo o con tu consejero.  El secreto está en practicar las técnicas de comunicación cuantas veces sea posible, hasta que las uses espontáneamente.  Si tienes dificultad aprendiendo estas técnicas, o el conflicto con tu mama es uno muy difícil de resolver, puedes contactar un consejero o mediador familiar para que te asista.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this difficult time. It sounds like your husband's behavior is leaving you feeling upset, abandoned, and unsure of the future. These situations can be incredibly painful, and it's natural for you to have a lot of questions and feelings.

The fact that your husband has emotionally disconnected from you and moved on with someone else is likely making you feel rejected and confused. His words and actions are causing you emotional pain and may be affecting your self-esteem and overall well-being.

It's important to remember that people's reasons for leaving a relationship are often complex and multifaceted. While it may be easy to focus on the things you could have done differently or better, it's essential to understand that relationships require two people to work effectively. If your husband is finding happiness and fulfillment outside of the marriage, it may be a sign that the relationship had run its course.

It's also essential to recognize that healing from this type of pain takes time. It may be helpful for you to process your emotions with a therapist, who can help you navigate the feelings of sadness, anger, and betrayal that come with this situation. You might also find comfort and support in joining a support group or seeking understanding and connection with friends and loved ones.

In the meantime, focusing on your self-care through regular exercise, healthy eating, and pursuing hobbies or interests can help you cope with the emotional upheaval. Additionally, if the financial burden is heavy, it might be necessary to seek legal advice or consider alternative sources of support.

Remember that, ultimately, your happiness and well-being come first. The choices your husband makes are separate from your own journey towards healing and finding happiness. It's important that you be gentle with yourself during this time.

I hope this information is helpful and that you find the strength to move forward. If you have any more specific questions or if anything here isn't clear, please don't hesitate to ask.

If your son is reporting "extremely violent thoughts and dreams" please have an psychological evaluation done by a psychiatrist now before it gets even worse for him to bare.  Don't take his reports lightly.  For him  to tell you, he knows that something is not right.  He is seeking and needing help.  Get it immediately.  Best to be safe than sorry.

It is challenging to see one's parents age and to cope with the new demands.  Your mom means a lot to you, and that is why you get easily frustrated.  I'm guessing that it is not that she is making you do work or that her expectations are non-important to you because if that were the case, you would not feel any guilt.  Accepting the new stage will help you cope with the changes.  Take a deep breath every time you feel frustrated and think of the good times you shared with your mom before her getting Alzheimer's.  Remember that your mom as she was is no longer and that she has reverted to a more delicate phase.  Also, schedule time for yourself and do things that help you relax.  Caretaking of an elderly parent can take a toll on you, and it is essential to incorporate self-care.  Finally, look for an Alzheimer's support group in your area that will help you connect with other people going through the same thing.  You are a good daughter, and your mom is lucky to have you in her life.Sincerely, Mirella~Image and Likeness Counseling

That is a really tough situation that a lot of young people are experiencing right now.  The first thing to under is that you can’t change who your parents are and cannot change their behavior.  The thing to keep in mind is that you can control your responses and actions.  You may need to keep living at home with them for the next few months or years and the best way to do this is to have a plan. The second thing is to keep in mind that their controlling behavior is most likely not about based your behavior.  Controlling parents are often driven by their concept of what will keep their children safe and happy.  Unfortunately this is not always accurate but keep in mind it is not a personal attack.  There are ways you can deal with controlling parents – and most of them require creating a plan of action.Examples of action plans:Decide in advance how you’ll calmly and rationally respond to your parents when you feel they’re trying to control youArrange to phone a friend or trusted adult when you feel like you’re losing controlTalk in person to an adult you trust. There aren’t any quick tips on how to deal with parents who want to control you; you need to find strategies that are geared to your specific family situation.  Get specific coping tips from books about family dynamics, such as:Toxic Parents: Overcoming Their Hurtful Legacy and Reclaiming Your Life by Susan ForwardCutting Loose: An Adult's Guide to Coming to Terms with Your Parents by Howard HalpernA counselor can be a good resource and provide support and guidance about issues addressing normal growth and development during periods of transition.

This is actually pretty common. When winter hits, we tend to find ourselves huddled inside from the cold. Not to mention the sun is out for a much shorter time. I understand that you are feeling conflicted about your relationship with your girlfriend. You seem to care deeply for her, but at the same time, you are struggling with trust issues that are causing significant conflict in your relationship. It is important to address these feelings and consider whether staying in this relationship is truly beneficial for both you and your girlfriend.

It is essential to remember that trust is a fundamental component of any healthy relationship. If you cannot trust your partner, it can lead to significant emotional pain and suffering for both of you. Your insecurities and lack of trust may be hindering her happiness and preventing her from fully experiencing the relationship.

Your girlfriend's age difference and her lack of options may play a role in her decision to stay with you, but it is not a healthy foundation for a long-term relationship. It is crucial to evaluate whether your feelings of insecurity and lack of trust are likely to lessen over time or if they are rooted in deeper underlying emotional issues.

It may be helpful to consider seeking the guidance of a mental health professional, such as a therapist, to work through your feelings and identify any underlying emotional issues that may be contributing to your insecurity and lack of trust. With the help of a therapist, you may be able to develop strategies to address these issues and improve the health and quality of your relationship.

Ultimately, the decision to end or continue the relationship is a complex one that requires careful consideration. It may be challenging to imagine a future without your girlfriend, but it is essential to think about your own emotional well-being and the potential for both you and your girlfriend to find happiness. If you believe that the relationship is causing more harm than good, it may be necessary to end it, even if that means facing the difficulty of helping your girlfriend find alternative living arrangements.

I encourage you to take some time to reflect on these issues and consider seeking the help of a mental health professional if you feel that it would be beneficial for you. Remember, ending a relationship can be a painful process, but it is important to prioritize your emotional well-being and the potential for future happiness.

I understand that coming out as transgender can be a challenging experience, especially when we anticipate negative reactions from loved ones. It's important to remember that everyone's situation is unique, and there's no one-size-fits-all solution to dealing with gender dysphoria or coming out. Here are some suggestions that might help you manage your gender dysphoria until you feel ready to share this information with your family:

1. Create a safe environment: Consider finding supportive communities, either online or in-person, where you can connect with others who share similar experiences. These communities can provide a sense of validation and understanding that might be lacking in your current environment.
2. Practical strategies: Identify small ways you can express your true gender identity in your daily life. This could include using your preferred name and pronouns, dressing in clothing that resonates with you, or engaging in activities that align with your gender. These steps can help you feel more comfortable and at ease within your body.
3. Professional support: Seeking out therapy or counseling can help you navigate your feelings around your gender identity and explore your options for coming out to your family. A mental health professional can also offer guidance on coping strategies for managing gender dysphoria and addressing any related emotional challenges.
4. Self-care: Take care of your mental, emotional, and physical health. Engage in activities that bring you joy and make you feel good about yourself. Regular exercise, healthy eating, and getting enough sleep can help improve your overall well-being.

Remember, your journey is yours alone, and there's no need to rush into any decisions that don't feel right for you. It's normal to feel scared and uncertain, but you'll find that with time and support, the path forward becomes clearer. If you need additional resources or want to discuss your concerns further, don't hesitate to reach out.

I understand that you're dealing with a lot right now. It's natural for you to feel uncertain and have trust issues, given the situation with your boyfriend. However, it's important to remember that trust is built over time and takes effort from both parties. Here are a few things that might help:

1. Communication: Talk with your boyfriend about how you're feeling and what you need from him to start rebuilding trust. Be open about your concerns and ask him to be honest and transparent.
2. Boundaries: Set clear boundaries about what you're comfortable with in terms of his friendships, social activities, and communication with other women. Make sure he understands that boundaries are non-negotiable.
3. Accountability: Find ways for your boyfriend to be accountable for his actions and demonstrate his commitment to the relationship. This could involve things like regular check-ins, proof of trustworthiness through small actions, or even counseling or therapy.
4. Self-care: Focus on your own emotional and mental health as well. Find ways to build resilience, practice self-compassion, and engage in activities that bring you joy and help you feel good about yourself.
5. Consistency: Be consistent in your efforts to rebuild trust and be open to your boyfriend's efforts as well. Keep in mind that trust isn't something that can be fully restored overnight, but it can be worked on and rebuilt over time.

Again, it's important to remember that everyone's situation is unique, and these suggestions may not all apply to your situation. However, I hope they provide a useful starting point for thinking about how to navigate trust issues in your relationship. If you feel overwhelmed, consider seeking the help of a therapist or counselor who can provide personalized guidance and support.

I understand your concern, patient. It's important to remember that effective communication and emotional intelligence are key skills in any relationship. Listening actively involves giving your full attention to your partner when they speak. Here are some steps you can take to improve your listening skills:

1. Create a distraction-free environment where you can give your undivided attention.
2. Make eye contact and maintain an open body language.
3. Use verbal cues, such as "yes," "uh huh," "I see," or "that makes sense," to show that you are engaged.
4. Refrain from interrupting or offering solutions. Instead, paraphrase to demonstrate your understanding of their perspective.

As for getting yourself together, it might be helpful to:

1. Identify the root cause of your emotional instability. Sometimes this can be a physical or emotional issue that requires medical attention.
2. Practice self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, mentally, and emotionally can help you cope with stress and maintain a positive outlook.
3. Learn healthy coping mechanisms for managing your emotions, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or journaling.
4. Seek professional help if necessary. A therapist can provide support and techniques to help you manage your emotions and improve your relationships.

I understand that you're feeling overwhelmed with stress, and it's important to take active steps to manage it. Here are a few effective strategies:

1. Prioritize: Make a list of your tasks and rank them in order of importance. Focus on completing the most pressing tasks first, and don't hesitate to delegate or eliminate tasks that are not essential.

2. Exercise: Regular physical activity can help reduce stress and improve your mood. Aim for at least 30 minutes of brisk walking or another form of aerobic activity most days of the week.

3. Eat well: A healthy, balanced diet can help provide the nutrients and energy you need to cope with stress. Try to avoid sugary snacks and processed foods, and focus on incorporating more fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats into your meals.

4. Sleep: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night, and establish a regular sleep schedule. Aim to go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends.

5. Relax: Take time each day to relax and unwind. Try activities such as reading, listening to music, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises.

6. Connect: Build strong relationships with friends and family, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it. Social support can help buffer the negative effects of stress.

7. Manage your time: Learn to say “no” to non-essential commitments, and find ways to manage your time more effectively. Try using a planner or scheduling app to help you stay organized and on track.

Remember that it's important to be consistent in practicing these stress management strategies, as they may take time to become effective. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need additional support.

I understand that binge eating can be a challenging issue, particularly during periods of stress. It's important to remember that you are not alone, and there are effective coping mechanisms that can help you break this cycle.

Firstly, try to identify the triggers that lead you to binge eat, such as stress, emotional distress or specific food cravings. Once you become aware of these triggers, you can begin to develop alternative ways to manage them.

One effective coping mechanism is the practice of mindfulness, which involves staying fully present in the moment and focusing on your thoughts and feelings without judgment. Mindfulness practices, such as deep breathing exercises, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation, can help you to manage stress and emotional distress in a healthier way.

Another useful coping mechanism is practicing emotional regulation techniques, such as expressing emotions through writing or art, engaging in activities that bring you joy, or seeking support from friends, family or a therapist.

Additionally, you might find it helpful to establish a regular meal schedule, avoiding skipping meals or fasting for extended periods. Eating a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats can help stabilize your blood sugar levels, thereby reducing the urge to binge eat.

Lastly, consider enlisting the support of a healthcare professional, such as a therapist or nutritionist, to help you develop a customized plan for managing your binge eating. Remember that it's normal for progress to be slow, and setbacks are a natural part of the process. Keep in mind that every step you take towards managing your binge eating is a step towards greater self-care and overall well-being.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult situation. It takes great courage to reach out for help. Here are some suggestions on how you can cope with verbally abusive situations:

1. Develop a self-care routine: Taking care of yourself is essential in managing stress and maintaining good mental health. Ensure you get enough rest, exercise regularly, eat well, and practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation.

2. Use "I" statements: When your parents start abusing you, try to respond in a firm, neutral, and non-confrontational manner. Use "I" statements instead of "you" statements to express your feelings and concerns. For instance, instead of saying "You're making me feel..." say "I feel...".

3. Practice active listening: In these situations, it's natural to want to defend yourself or respond to their abusive comments. However, focusing on their abusive language can make the situation worse. Instead, try to listen attentively and acknowledge their emotions to de-escalate the situation.

4. Stay calm and composed: Regardless of what your parents are saying, try to remain calm and composed. Easier said than done, I know, but staying calm can help minimize the conflict and lower the emotional tension in the room.

5. Prepare a list of coping statements: Have a list of positive affirmations or coping statements ready that you can repeat to yourself during these interactions. This will help you to shift your focus away from the abusive words and towards more positive thoughts.

6. Seek support: Speak to a trusted friend, family member, or helpline to discuss your situation and gain perspective. Confiding in someone can help you feel less alone and may offer additional insights and resources for dealing with the abuse.

7. Create your exit strategy: Although it might be challenging, it's important to establish a plan for removal from the situation. This can include leaving the room, engaging in an activity that distracts you, or reaching out to a trusted friend or support system.

8. Consider counseling: Talking to a mental health professional about your situation can help you better understand the dynamics of the abuse and develop effective coping strategies. A therapist can offer a safe, confidential space for you to process your emotions,

As a psychologist, I would only terminate counseling sessions or end working with a client when I believe that they have achieved their therapeutic goals or have made significant progress towards their goals. Other factors that could lead to the termination of counseling sessions include:

1. The client's improvement and stabilization: If the client is no longer experiencing symptoms or has learned skills to manage their condition effectively, I may recommend termination.
2. Mutually agreed outcome: Both the client and I may decide that we have achieved a mutually agreed-upon outcome, and further counseling is no longer necessary.
3. Client's relocation: If a client moves far away or relocates to another area, termination may be required.
4. Ethical considerations: In some cases, ethical considerations, such as conflicts of interest or potential harm to the client, may necessitate the termination of counseling sessions.
5. Time and resource constraints: At times, time or resource constraints on my part may necessitate termination, although every effort will be made to ensure that the client receives referrals and access to other resources as needed.

In all cases, it's essential that we have open and ongoing communication about the rationale for termination and ensure that the client is well-prepared for the transition to the next phase of their therapy or recovery process.

People do cry in therapy sometimes, but it's not at all necessary to cry in order for most kinds of therapy to be helpful. When you start counseling you don't yet know your counselor very well, so it's normal to keep your feelings in check until you feel comfortable and a bit more relaxed with your counselor and with the situation. Sometimes, though, there are emotions that have been waiting and waiting to finally find someone who will listen with a kind ear. If you feel safe right away in the situation with your counselor, you might just cry in spite of your fears about it. Your therapist is used to people expressing how they feel and will keep strict confidentiality, so even though it's embarrassing, finally experiencing someone truly listening with empathy and kindness may just be worth it. It's okay too to let your counselor know right at the beginning that you're kind of freaked out about getting too emotional in front of another person.

I understand your concern, and it's important to acknowledge the challenges you're facing in your communication with this individual. Here are some suggestions that might be helpful:

1. Practice active listening: Try your best to fully understand their perspective without becoming defensive. It's essential to validate their feelings and show empathy toward their concerns.

2. Use a compassionate tone: It's essential to communicate in a respectful and understanding manner. While it may feel frustrating when they escalate a disagreement, try to keep a calm and compassionate tone of voice.

3. Clarify your intent: When they accuse you of negative communication, take a moment to clarify your intentions and explain that you didn't intend to harm them in any way. Apologize if necessary, and offer an alternative perspective or solution.

4. Use "I" statements: Instead of making accusations, use "I" statements to express your own feelings and thoughts. For example, instead of saying "Your tone of voice is hurting me," say "I feel hurt when you speak to me in a harsh tone."

5. Take a break: If you find that communication becomes emotionally charged, it may be helpful to take a break from the conversation and revisit it when emotions have cooled down.

6. Consider seeking professional help: If communication challenges persist despite your best efforts, it may be helpful to seek the assistance of a mental health professional who can help you navigate the situation and develop effective communication skills.

This behaviour, although it might get you the attention you want initially, will ultimately drive men away because it's not respectful of them. If you believed in your value as a person, you would be less afraid of deeper relationships and intimacy in general. If I were your therapist, I'd have many questions for you and I would need to understand a lot of things about you and your past to help you sort out where this idea about yourself came from. I'd suggest reaching out to a qualified therapist who can help you get to the root of this behaviour. Good luck!

I'm really sorry to hear about your partner's situation. It sounds like you've noticed some significant changes in his behavior, and receiving a cancer diagnosis can bring about a lot of emotions and challenges. I understand that it's difficult and confusing when someone we care about refuses treatment, but it's essential to remember that each person has the right to make their own decisions regarding their health. In situations like this, it can be helpful to focus on providing emotional support rather than dwelling on the things we cannot control. Communication and understanding are key. If you feel that you need additional guidance, please don't hesitate to reach out to me or a mental health professional.

Hi Dillon,I'm from Canada, so I don't know the laws in your state. Or is she already in therapy? A family therapist will typically meet with you alone first, in order to determine if therapy is a wise move for your child. It isn't always appropriate.

No, you do not have too many issues to address in counseling. In fact, the complexity of your challenges is common for many individuals. It's important to understand that mental health is multifaceted and can be influenced by various experiences and conditions. Addressing each issue within a therapeutic context can help you build a stronger foundation for emotional well-being. In counseling, we can focus on various aspects of your life, such as dealing with past traumas, developing coping mechanisms for insomnia and anxiety, and learning healthy ways to cope with low self-esteem. I encourage you to take the first step and reach out to a mental health professional for support. Counseling can be a valuable resource to help you navigate these challenges and improve your overall quality of life.

It's natural to feel upset and confused when there's a breach of trust in a relationship. The fact that your partner didn't tell you about this woman earlier is a sign of dishonesty and poor communication, which are significant issues. Lying and broken promises are red flags that suggest a pattern of behavior.

I encourage you to think carefully about where this relationship is headed and whether you feel comfortable continuing in it given the history of dishonesty and lack of trust. Communication and honesty are essential building blocks of a healthy relationship, and it's important to consider if these elements are present in your marriage currently. It might be helpful to speak with a therapist to process these feelings and to explore strategies for building trust and communication in your relationship.

Ultimately, only you can decide if you wish to continue in this marriage. I would suggest taking some time to reflect on your feelings and your needs, and considering what changes might need to be made for the relationship to be healthy and fulfilling for both you and your partner.

It's important to remember that every individual's experiences and reactions to consensual sexual dynamics are unique. What you're feeling could be due to various factors, such as:

1. Envy: Recognizing that your husband may have spent more time with the other person during the threesome could be eliciting feelings of jealousy, leading to the empty feeling when anticipating future experiences.
2. Comparison: Comparing yourself to the other person in the threesome and feeling insufficient or inadequate in some way may contribute to the feelings of emptiness.
3. Infidelity: For some individuals, the fear of infidelity, even when consensual and open relationships are agreed upon, may result in unwanted feelings of sadness or guilt.
4. Intimacy: Your need and desire for emotional connection during the threesome may not have been fulfilled, causing you to feel empty or unsatisfied.

In any case, this is a complex emotion with many possible underlying causes. It may benefit you to have an open and honest conversation with your husband about your feelings, discuss boundaries and future experiences, and potentially consult a mental health professional for further guidance and assistance. Remember that every individual has unique emotional needs, and a therapist or counselor can help you navigate your situation and feel more confident in making informed decisions for your relationships.

I'm sorry to hear that you're dealing with the challenging symptoms of PTSD. Recovering from PTSD takes time and effort, but there are steps you can take to get your life back on track.

First, it's essential to prioritize your mental health. This may involve seeking professional help such as therapy or counseling. Your mental health provider can work with you to develop a coping strategy and provide you with tools to manage the symptoms.

Second, self-care practices like getting proper sleep, eating a healthy diet, and physical activity can help improve your overall well-being. It's important to prioritize your mental and physical health as much as possible.

Third, communicating openly with your loved ones about your diagnosis and your journey towards recovery can help strengthen relationships and improve communication. There are also support groups and organizations for individuals with PTSD, which can provide a safe and understanding space for sharing experiences and connecting with others.

Finally, if you lost your job, consider exploring employment options that may be better suited for your current condition, or seek disability benefits if necessary. Remember, it's important to take things one step at a time and not rush the recovery process. Be patient with yourself and focus on the progress you make, no matter how small it may seem.

If you have any further questions or need additional support, please don't hesitate to reach out.

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this difficulty in your relationship. Recovery from drug addiction can be a challenging process, not only for the individual but also for their partners. This distance you're experiencing could be due to various reasons: stress from the recovery process, feeling overwhelmed, or even feeling guilty about past actions.

First, it's important to keep in mind that change takes time and effort. Be patient and understanding, as relapses or setbacks can occur in the process. Also, encourage him to continue with his recovery program and seek support from his network of friends, family, or professional help.

Communication is essential in a relationship, so try to have a calm and non-confrontational conversation with your boyfriend about how you're both feeling. Let him know that you care about him and want to support his recovery.

Additionally, consider seeking your own support network, such as a therapist, support group, or trusted friends and family members, to discuss any challenges or feelings that come up during this time. Remember that your wellbeing is also important in this situation.

For starters, commend yourself for being committed to working. You have no idea what is going to happen in the next second, so focusing on thinking you will never have a good career or amount to anything financially is creating a fictitious story.  Remind yourself of that every time the thought pops up.  The false belief that nothing good will happen is sucking out energy you can use on pursuing your career dreams. Next, do you know what you need to do to become an electrician or heavy machinery operator? If not, find out. Then, set up a realistic schedule for yourself to accomplish the steps. As you accomplish each step, see your progress.  Notice that you are moving closer to your goal.  Every day remind yourself why you are pursuing this career.  In fact, write it down and tape it on your bathroom mirror.  When you start to feel discouraged, remember your goal and remind yourself that you have no idea if you'll make it or not but you are going to give it everything you have to find out. Anything worth pursuing is going to take a lot of persistence and hard work. Stay with it! You and your family are worth it!

Focus more on your own life and less on the very heavy descriptors you wrote to describe your mom.All the words you wrote represent psychological conditions which are either lifelong or take a lot of motivation and effort to change.Since the only person who can change how your mom handles her life, is your mom, and you are the only one who can do the same for yourself, devote more energy and time to living your own life fully, despite the emotions you feel regarding her.

It's normal to have different relationships and attachment styles with each of your children due to various factors such as age differences and personal circumstances. The oldest child, being older and hopefully more independent, may have a more developed social and emotional competence that makes your connection stronger. With the middle child being younger but more verbal and interactive, you may have established a good bond.

However, your feelings towards the youngest child may change as she grows older. Infants require significant attention and energy, which may influence your thoughts and emotions towards them. Moreover, it's natural for parents to develop different attachment styles based on their own personal experiences and emotional states.

If you find yourself consistently feeling disconnected or indifferent towards your youngest child, it might be helpful to consult a mental health professional or seek resources from parenting support groups to explore potential underlying causes and develop strategies to strengthen your connection with her. Remember, parenting is a journey with ups and downs, and it's essential to take care of yourself in order to effectively care for your children.

I understand that the winter season can bring about feelings of sadness for some people. This condition is known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). Here are a few strategies you can consider to help manage these symptoms:

1. Expose yourself to natural sunlight as much as possible. Open your curtains wide, and take short walks outside, even if it's cold.
2. Engage in regular physical activity. Regular exercise can help boost your mood and overall sense of well-being.
3. Create a warm and inviting environment at home. Keep your living area cozy and well-lit. Consider using soft, calming colors and textures.
4. Make sure you are eating a healthy, balanced diet filled with nutritious foods to keep your energy levels up.
5. Consider trying a light therapy box. This device can simulate natural sunlight and may help improve your mood during the winter months.
6. Connect with friends and loved ones. Socializing can help reduce feelings of isolation and loneliness.
7. If your symptoms are severe, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for additional support and guidance.

Hi Brentwood, While our society tends to want to put us into categories...slots...when it comes to sexuality, because this is nice and neat and convenient...many people find that they don't fit perfectly into one or the other. All you have to do is exactly what you're doing; be aware of yourself and allow yourself to explore these thoughts and emotions both alone and in connection with a safe partner. The people who love you will continue to love you as you sort through this. You can resist the temptation to please others by giving yourself a label. We are attracted to, and fall in love with, people...and we can't always predict what gender they might be. I love how open you are to discovering yourself. Keep on that track. :)

It's never to late to let a person know how you feel.  You never know where it will take you.  You don't want to hold this regret of not letting your feelings known and wondering "what if" for the rest of your life.   That can be torturous.   Now prepare for whatever..if his feelings are the same or if they are not.  If they are the same...great.  If they are not, feel good that at least you let a person know they hold a special place in your life and wish him love, peace and happiness in his life.

Yes, it is normal to cry during therapy, it is a time of catharsis, letting things out, shedding our skin, dropping our weights and just to let you know, even therapists sometimes feel like crying in sessions. Although people often cry or become upset, it is in no way a measure of "good therapy". C

It is normal to feel some degree of anxiety or apprehension before attending therapy sessions, especially if it is a new experience for you. This feeling can be a result of the unfamiliarity of the situation, feelings of vulnerability, or past negative experiences. However, if the anxiety is so severe that it prevents you from attending the sessions or engaging fully in the therapeutic process, then it may be helpful to discuss this with your therapist. They may be able to provide you with additional support, coping strategies, or adjustments to make your therapy experience more comfortable and effective for you. Remember, it takes time to build trust and form a therapeutic relationship, but with consistency and effort, the sessions can become a valuable tool for personal growth.

It is a good thing that you have recognized that you have been in some unhealthy relationships and that you are wanting to break this pattern. You seem to have some good insight into the situation.The type of behavior that you are describing is usually rooted in childhood issues with insecure attachment bonds with your caregivers, childhood trauma and/or abuse or neglect, or dysfunctional family issues that did not allow you to develop healthy boundaries for yourself or a sense of self. This is something that is going to take some time to work through in therapy. I recommend a book titled “Boundaries: Where you end and I begin” by Anne Katherine. Another book that might be helpful is “Codependent No More” by Melody Beattie. In the meantime, until you can work through your personal issues, absolutely do not enter into another relationship. Take however long you need to and work on becoming a whole, happy, emotionally healthy person on your own. Needing another person to define you is problematic. That’s too much to expect from any individual.For a relationship to be healthy and happy, both people in the relationship first need to be a whole person on their own. That means having a clear sense of self, knowing who you are and what you want, knowing how to set healthy boundaries, and knowing how to meet your own needs. It is unreasonable to expect your partner to meet all of your needs all of the time. There will be times that they won’t be able to meet your needs. You have to know how to meet those yourself. When you are working on becoming the best you that you can be, eventually the right person will come into your life. Then you can CHOOSE to be with someone because you want them in your life instead of feeling like you NEED them to complete you.

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you, with a lot of feelings and complexities involved. The fact that you've been cheated on again after having been unfaithful yourself and being forgiven, adds an extra layer of complication.

Firstly, it's important to remember that healing from infidelity is often a long and challenging process. You're showing resilience and an authentic desire to work through this and move forward in your relationship. However, this may not be an easy fix and it's crucial that both parties are fully committed to the healing process.

Here are some steps you can consider taking:

1. Communication: Have a heartfelt conversation with your partner about how you feel, without being accusatory or judgmental. Tell her that you're open to forgiveness, but need transparency, trust, and commitment to repairing the damage.

2. Seek professional help: Couples therapy may help you and your partner work through this together. A therapist can help you explore both of your emotions and provide tools and techniques to rebuild trust and strengthen your relationship.

3. Patience and self-care: This process takes time, so be patient with the healing. Incorporate self-care practices, such as meditation, exercise, eating healthy foods, and engaging in hobbies to maintain your emotional and physical well-being.

4. Set some boundaries: Identify what you need from her and your relationship to feel respected, safe, and confident. Set clear boundaries and ensure your partner understands and respects them.

5. Consider the future: Take some time to reflect on the meaning and purpose of your relationship, and what you truly want for yourself and your family. Be honest about whether you believe this is the relationship you want to continue to invest in and move forward with.

Ultimately, it's your decision to make based on the unique circumstances of your situation, but I recommend taking these steps to begin addressing the issues and working towards a healthier relationship. Remember, healing takes time, but it's always worth the effort.

I believe that for results that last, the best approach is to understand why someone feels like doing a certain behavior."Coping mechanisms" are superficial instruction that people usually give up on when feeling extreme pressure from the problem behaviors.Take the slower road of understanding why you would deprive yourself of enjoying food.Also, if you consider the binging as a mistake of some kind, reflect on why doing something less than ideal, deserves harsh criticism and not tolerance and acceptance that people mess up occasionally.I'm glad you know that there are better ways of treating yourself.  This is a valuable awareness of realizing you deserve patience and respect, not humiliation and severe criticism when you are lost as to best ways of self-care.

From the little bit you wrote, my guess is you haven't figured out where and how to lay down your own set of roots.Usually people who have a university level eduction are old enough to work in order to support themselves.Unless you have a medical condition which limits or prevents you from working a full-time job, would you guess that the effort and thought involved in deciding in what professional area and geographic location to look for work, would offer you a way to establish your identity?My suggestion is to pay more attention to your own likes, dislikes, and interests.   To know these areas more deeply would define the type of people with whom you identify, have a common interest and with whom you'd like to socialize.The more you realize who you are, the easier time you'll have to find like-minded others and feel securely at home with them and yourself.Again, if you have a medical disability or condition which prevents employment or easily socializing with other people, then this advice would need to be modified for your specific strengths.

I'm glad you're reaching out for help, and I understand how challenging it can be to deal with feelings of worthlessness. It's essential to remember that these feelings are not a reflection of your true worth as a person. Here are some steps you can take to help address these thoughts:

1. Identify negative thoughts: Be aware of the negative thoughts that trigger feelings of worthlessness. Challenge these thoughts by asking yourself if they are based on reality or if they're an exaggeration.

2. Practice self-compassion: Be kind and understanding towards yourself. Treat yourself with the same care and compassion that you would give to a good friend in need.

3. Set small goals: Break down larger goals into smaller, manageable tasks. Achieving these small goals can help build self-confidence and a sense of accomplishment.

4. Connect with others: Surround yourself with supportive relationships. Reach out to friends, family, or a mental health professional when you need help.

5. Seek professional help: If your feelings of worthlessness persist, it might be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional coping strategies and support.

Remember, everyone experiences moments of feeling worthless, but these feelings don't define you as a person. It's essential to prioritize self-care and seek professional help when needed.

I understand that this is a very difficult situation for you. It's important to remember that your identity is a personal matter and ultimately, it's about how you feel inside. If you identify as male, it may be helpful for you to explore that identity further. This can include expressing yourself in ways that align with how you feel internally, such as dressing in a way that feels more masculine to you, using a male name and pronouns if that feels right, and seeking out supportive communities.

However, I also want to emphasize that it's crucial for your mental and emotional well-being to be true to yourself and live your life authentically, even if that means sharing this with your family may be challenging. You may want to consider reaching out to LGBTQ+ support groups or counseling services to help you navigate this journey. They can provide you with resources, information, and a safe space to share your feelings and experiences.

Keep in mind that your religious beliefs are an essential part of your identity, but your gender identity is equally valid and deserving of respect and understanding. There are resources available that can help you reconcile your faith with your gender identity if that's something you'd like to explore. However, ultimately, you have the right to live your life in a way that feels authentic and true to who you are.

Remember, it's essential to prioritize your emotional and mental well-being, and taking small steps can lead to significant progress. Good luck on your journey. If you have any further questions or need any more guidance, please feel free to ask.

Hi there. I have to commend you on reaching out to get some answers on why you are feeling the way that you are feeling. A lot of people secretly go about their lives every day feeling this way because they are too afraid of what the answer might be.First off, what stressors do you have in your life right now? Financial, relationship and unemployment are all common stressors for people. They can often make it difficult for us to sleep at night due to the constant racing thoughts and wonders of how you will deal with it all. Secondly, do you have a history of depression or does depression run in your family? Some of the symptoms listed here in this question (i.e. trouble sleeping, constant fatigue, too much sleep, anger & anxiety) are all common symptoms of depression. Often times, these symptoms can be overlooked and mistaken for "just being tired." Furthermore, it's important to ask yourself, if you are feeling worthless, problems with concentration and recurrent thoughts of death. If you are having these symptoms, please seek help IMMEDIATELY. Lastly, considering your stated symptoms I would recommend reaching out to your Doctor for further consult. It's always better to be safe and the earlier you catch the symptoms the faster you will get to feeling better! do Some helpful tips for the your Doctor would be to monitor your sleep habits (i.e. how much or little are you sleeping), make a list of your triggers for your anger outbursts as well as your triggers for your anxiety attacks. I hope this was helpful and the best of luck to you.

The most important agent of change in therapy is your relationship with your therapist. It is so important for you to find a therapist that you trust and feel comfortable enough to just lay everything out there and be vulnerable with. Therapy is really building a safe and healthy relationship with a professional that can then help guide you in some of the most intimate and emotional parts of your life. This relationship does take time to build, but usually you can get a sense of a therapist's personality and approach from their bio and website. Once you have found someone that you think you could really connect with, then it's about looking at do they have the expertise you need. Do they have training in relationship counseling or in working with anxiety, depression, or trauma? It is important to find an expert in the field so you are getting the best care possible...just like if you were to go to a general family doctor versus a specialist. I hope that is helpful!

First thing I'd suggest is getting the sleep you need or it will impact how you think and feel. I'd look at finding what is going well in your life and what you can be grateful for. I believe everyone has talents and wants to find their purpose in life. I think you can figure it out with some help.

I understand that your experience has left you feeling deeply distressed and violated. It's important for you to remember that your feelings are valid and that what you've gone through is not normal. It's understandable for you to feel wary of therapy and other procedures that may involve altered states of consciousness.

First and foremost, I want to make it clear that there is no credible scientific evidence to support the claim that organizations can implant thoughts in people's heads with technology. Such a process would be a violation of ethical guidelines and human rights.

You've experienced a significant loss and it's important for you to find a way to move forward. Although you may feel hesitant to engage with therapists or other mental health professionals, I believe that seeking help from someone you trust and feel comfortable with can be beneficial.

You don't have to go under hypnosis or any other kind of procedure if you're not comfortable with it. Instead, you can explore other approaches such as psychotherapy, where we can work collaboratively to help you process your experiences, understand your emotions, and develop coping strategies to deal with your current situation.

If finding a therapist is a challenge, I would recommend exploring online resources, such as support groups or mental health organizations, to find someone who specializes in trauma recovery or dissociative disorders. These professionals have experience working with individuals who have been through similar experiences and will be able to help you in a safe and supportive environment.

Ultimately, the most important thing is for you to take care of yourself and prioritize your emotional wellbeing. I encourage you to reach out to family, friends, or support groups to share your experiences and build a network of people who can provide you with understanding and care.

I'm here to help in any way I can, and I'm committed to providing you with a safe and supportive environment. Let's work together to help you find a path forward.

I understand that ending a relationship can be difficult, especially when you're finding it hard to move on. Here are some steps that might help you in this process:

1. Acceptance: Accept that the relationship is over. Denying the reality of the situation will only prolong your pain.

2. Grieve: It is normal to feel sadness, anger, and other emotions after a significant relationship ends. Allow yourself to feel these emotions instead of suppressing them.

3. Refocus: Engage yourself in activities that bring you joy and help you grow as an individual. Focus on personal hobbies, relationships with friends and family, and career goals.

4. Distance: Minimize contact with your ex as much as possible. Social media can create the illusion of connection, so consider unfollowing, unfriending, or taking a break from these platforms.

5. Seek Support: Surround yourself with people who care about you and understand what you're going through. Reach out to friends, family, or a mental health professional for guidance and support during this time.

6. Practice Forgiveness: Forgive yourself and your ex for any mistakes made during the relationship. Holding onto anger and resentment will only cause more emotional pain.

7. Self-Care: Making time for self-care is essential during this period. Practice stress management techniques like meditation, deep breathing, or yoga to improve your mental and emotional health.

8. Reevaluate: When you feel ready, reflect on what you've learned from the relationship and consider what you'd like in your future relationships. This process can lead to personal growth and an increased sense of self-worth.
All you can do/control is work on yourself. When you have enough sense of self, you will know how to deal with your family. Therapy is an investment in yourself, which affects your family.

Behavioral interaction with someone who has severe autism requires highly specialized training, both for any professional staff involved with the person and for the family members.It is an unfair situation for both the person who has autism as well as the campers who do not, to expect both sides to get along harmoniously.In order to achieve this, the campers would need specialized training to know how to respond to distress in the camper who has autism.This would obviously stretch and burden the summer camp budget as well as provide an activity which usually isn't part of summer camp for children.What you can do which may be productive in helping the camper who has autism, is to point out the interaction difficulty to the summer administrators.Ultimately it is their problem to only take campers who are able to reasonably adjust to socializing together and from what you write, the administration has overreached whom they consider reasonable camper mates.

Sometimes it's helps to have a name for a problem - it can make you feel less alone as in, "oh there's a name for this and other people have this experience too." On the other hand naming the problem can also make it stick around longer as in "now I have a special problem that has a special name, and that's an important part of who I am."Bottom line, whether it's a disorder or not, you would like life to be easier and not have to be pulled so much by other people's energy and feelings. You might want to try imagining that you have a volume dial on your empathy (just like the volume dial or button on the tv) that you can gently turn down to the point where you still feel what's going on but it's not so "loud". You can also try imagining pulling your own energy back as if you were drawing your energy back home to the center of your own body and being, letting go of the other people or characters that pulled your energy out so far. This is a way create better boundaries and protect your own vulnerability. Just like on an airplane where they tell you to put on your own oxygen mask first before helping anyone else, your empathy will most likely not really help others if you allow yourself to be depleted.

Both you and your mom are in a tough spot.  She has returned to parenting after she thought she had raised her kids, and while I am sure you'd like to be supportive, you recognize that listening to her complaints really does not help her and drains you.  In addition to that, it sounds like Mom's complaining has become "the" conversation she has with you, leaving other, more fulfilling conversations out of your relationship.Think about what you want instead with your mom.  More time with just her?  A chance to offer true help,not just listen to complaints? When you have some idea of what you want, tell her.  You can do this kindly and respectfully, with a concern for both her and your relationship with her.  It might go something like this..."Mom, you really have your hands full.  Sis dumped your grandbaby on you and I bet this isn't how you imagined grandparenting would look.  It's got to be hard and I am not sure how I can be helpful.  Beyond that, I really miss talking to you about other things.  So, Mom, is there something I can do that would be helpful?  If not, let's talk about something else".In addition to that, if your mom is open to other resources, help her find them - she needs some emotional support from a non-family member.Good luck to you both - and to your niece.  It is a hard situation for you all.

I understand that caring for someone with a chronic illness can be a challenging and emotionally taxing experience, especially when the person you're caring for is behaving in a way that makes it more difficult for you. It's important to remember that the behavior of the person you're caring for may be a result of their condition, and not a personal attack on you. At the same time, it's vital that you take care of yourself and set healthy boundaries to avoid burnout.

First, consider the possibility that her behavior may be related to her medical condition, and communicate your concerns to her healthcare provider. In the meantime, try to find ways to manage your stress and practice self-care, such as taking breaks, getting regular exercise, eating healthy, and getting enough sleep.

If you feel safe to do so, try using "I-statements" when communicating with her, rather than accusatory language. For example, instead of saying "You're always complaining," you could say "I feel overwhelmed when you complain a lot."

It's also important to explore alternative care options, such as respite care or hiring a professional caregiver, if they're available to you. Ultimately, taking care of yourself is necessary for the well-being of both you and the person you're caring for. I recommend speaking with a counselor or support group for further guidance and resources.

I understand that you're experiencing difficulty with controlling your food intake, particularly with sweets. This condition is commonly known as food addiction, or binge eating disorder. It's essential to remember that you're not alone in this experience. Food addiction can be a complex issue with various contributing factors, including emotional, biological, and environmental influences. The good news is that with proper treatment, which may include therapy, support groups, and lifestyle modifications, you can learn to manage your relationship with food and create a healthier, more balanced eating pattern.

It's also essential to explore any underlying emotional or psychological issues that may be contributing to your difficulty with controlling your food intake. For instance, do you tend to eat as a coping mechanism to deal with stress, anxiety, boredom, or negative emotions? Understanding and addressing the root causes can be a powerful step in overcoming food addiction.

In conclusion, take things one step at a time. Seek professional help and implement the strategies and tools they provide, such as creating a meal plan, practicing mindfulness eating, and developing healthy coping mechanisms. Be patient with yourself, and know that setbacks and relapses are a normal part of the recovery process. The goal isn't to be perfect, but to make progress, even if it's small steps. You can conquer this challenge and reclaim control over your eating habits.

I would like to offer my compassion that you are struggling with with these feelings. With the information provided and not knowing what your childhood was like or what you've experienced, I will say that from my experience working with people, these feelings are normal, and a normal part  of the process  of healing and just by posting your question tells me you're aware and desire to change this. Very good! I commend your strength. Your feelings are not uncommon and the feelings of abandonment, or second guessing or loss of happiness are also not uncommon.  It's also not uncommon for these issues to arise and trickle into our adult life and relationships. Again, with little information about your situation, it is hard to give an exact answer. However, those who have experienced a dysfunctional childhood or trauma, often present with the issues and feelings you've described. The great news, is that with good therapy, you can regain your happiness, self worth and begin to feel  empowered, you deserve to be happy. Be patient, gentle and kind  to yourself. Therapy can be incredibly helpful and life changing. I wish you the very best! Laura Cassity, LMSW, LMAC

It does sound like your roommate may have a drinking problem, and the short answer is that you can't do anything about it, only she can. We can't change what other people say, think, or do. We can only change our reactions. It does sound like your roommate may be having a hard time. You can suggest that she enter counseling or therapy. You can reassure her that you like her (if that's true), but you don't have to pity her.

First, be aware that each end every one of us has anxiety at some point. That certainly seems to fit what you're describing here, but that doesn't mean you have an anxiety disorder, necessarily. That's where there is a difference. Anyone who has a hard time with public speaking or feels uncomfortable in large crowds, for example, is experiencing anxiety.It sounds like it would be helpful to look at the differences between the days when you are more comfortable on the days that you are not. If you notice your anxiety is keeping you from doing things that you need or want to do, it may be helpful to talk with and mental health professional.I wonder also whether your appetite and sleeping patterns are the same or similar to how they were before you experienced this anxiety, when your anxiety started, and whether you feel more comfortable when someone you trust is there with you.If you have an idea of times or situations in which you feel anxious, consider carrying a small smooth rock or another object that makes you feel calm and centered. Perhaps you can keep it in your pocket and remember specific comfortable times while you have it in your hand.

I understand that you're experiencing symptoms of anxiety when in public speaking situations or large crowds. This is a common condition known as social anxiety. It's important to remember that these feelings are normal and many people experience them to some degree. There are several ways to manage social anxiety, including practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing, visualization, and progressive muscle relaxation. Cognitive-behavioral therapy can also be helpful in identifying and challenging negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. Sometimes, medication can be used in conjunction with therapy to help manage symptoms. Would you like more information on any of these approaches?
