Life sounds extremely frustrating for you right now.As long as you've reached your conclusion that your parents do not take you seriously when you would like to speak with them on a serious topic, and that you feel unable to trust either of them, then work with your own information.Many people don't know how to listen and aren't trustworthy.  As painful and aggravating as having parents who fit this description, you're better off to honor what you realize than to continue fighting what is not in your hands to change.Since you write about having a similar problem with friends, then maybe this comes about because you pick friends who are similarly unsatisfying to be with as are your parents.The first step out of this dilemma would be to accept how crummy you feel about the way your parents are toward you.If you're able to live with the sadness and resentment of having parents who don't want to know how to understand you, then you'll start to develop a new and more satisfying definition of what you expect from the behaviors of your friends.Trust yourself that what you feel and see is accurate, then it becomes easier to trust and welcome new people who are formatted differently than either your parents or your friends who sound very similar to your parents' ways.

Yes, counseling can help people.How this happens is bc the counselor can guide the person or couple into deeper areas of their thoughts and emotions than the person or partners would typically avoid or not even realize they are avoiding.Also, a counseling session offers emotional safety because the therapist will intervene with thoughtful questions if someone's strong emotions overwhelm them.This is different than in everyday circumstances.  When someone feels overwhelmed by their own or someone else's feelings, there is no one who asks reflective questions.Last, people get better in therapy because often therapy is the first time the person has a chance to trust someone with their confidential information and know this information will always be protected.

I understand how difficult it is to adapt to new situations, especially when they involve travel and being away from your family. It's not uncommon for people to experience anxiety in this situation, as it can be overwhelming to deal with the unknown and the fear of being unable to provide for your loved ones if something were to happen.

First, it's important to recognize that experiencing anxiety doesn't make you weak or abnormal. Anxiety is a natural response to stressors and it's a common experience for many people. Here are some strategies that may help you manage your anxiety during this transition:

1. Prepare as much as possible: Make a checklist of the things you need to do before leaving for your trip. This may include packing your bags, making travel arrangements, and getting any necessary documents or visas.
2. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation are all effective relaxation techniques that can help reduce anxiety. Try practicing these techniques daily, especially when you start to feel anxious.
3. Stay connected with your family: Keep in touch with your family as often as possible, whether through phone calls, text messages, or video chats. Let them know how you're feeling and encourage them to share their thoughts and emotions with you as well.
4. Seek support: Consider joining a support group or working with a therapist to help you manage your anxiety. Talking to others who have had similar experiences can be very helpful, and a therapist can provide you with strategies and tools to cope with your anxiety.
5. Prioritize self-care: Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating healthy foods, and engaging in regular physical activity. These things can all help reduce stress and improve your overall well-being.
6. Stay flexible: Remember that it's normal for new experiences to bring up uncomfortable feelings, and it's okay if things don't go exactly as planned. Try to stay flexible and open-minded, focusing on the things you can control and letting go of the things you cannot.

I hope these strategies help you manage your anxiety during this transition. Remember, it's normal to feel anxious, but there are things you can do to get through it. And keep in mind that with time and effort, you will likely become more comfortable with your new situation.

It's normal to feel some apprehension or anxiety when starting therapy, especially if you're dealing with difficult emotions or experiences. This feeling can be a sign that you're facing challenging issues and making progress. However, if your anxiety is so intense that it prevents you from attending sessions or making meaningful progress in therapy, it might be helpful to discuss this with your therapist. They might be able to suggest strategies to help reduce your anxiety and make therapy a more positive experience for you. In any case, remember that therapy is a process, and it's okay to feel uncomfortable sometimes. Your therapist is there to support you through the ups and downs.

Sorry to hear of your situation.Possibly you are overlooking that your own Self is someone worth talking to as well.None of us are ever really alone because we are always with ourselves.Self-talk is a major part of what guides our decisions and how we make sense of relationships and situations.    Even after telling people the stories or activities, hearing their comments, it is always within ourselves that we decide if the way we were received by these others, the comments we heard back, feel right and accurate to our lives.I hope the feeling of a hole in your stomach would decrease by enjoying your Self.    I am guessing that hurting yourself makes the stomach hole feel less bad because the physical pain you create in yourself distracts you from feeling it.Enjoying your Self by talking kindly, loving, and having inner dialogue may very well decrease the feeling of a hole, altogether.Sending lots of good luck!

As a psychologist, I cannot make this decision for you. However, I can suggest a few things to consider that may help:

1. Communication: Are you able to communicate openly and effectively with your partner? Are your needs being met in this relationship?
2. Respect: Do you and your partner show each other mutual respect? Are you able to support each other in a positive and uplifting way?
3. Emotional Safety: Do you feel emotionally safe in this relationship? Are you able to express your feelings and be heard?
4. Compatibility: Are your long-term goals and values compatible with those of your partner?
5. Happiness: Are you generally happy in this relationship? Do the positive aspects outweigh the negative?

Ultimately, these are questions that only you can answer. It's important to take your time, reflect on your answers, and perhaps seek the advice of a trusted friend or mental health professional.

It is normal to feel some degree of anxiety or apprehension when starting therapy or attending therapy sessions, especially if you're new to the experience. This is a common reaction and can stem from feelings of vulnerability, fear of judgment, or simply unfamiliarity with the process. However, if your anxiety is overwhelming or persistent, it might be helpful to discuss this with your therapist so they can work with you to develop strategies to help you manage your anxiety. Remember, the therapy room is a safe and confidential space where you can express yourself openly and honestly, and where your therapist is there to support you throughout your healing journey.

Yes, feelings of nervousness or anxiety before therapy sessions are quite common, especially for individuals who are new to therapy or have severe anxiety. This reaction can be attributed to the fear of the unknown, the perception that therapy is a sign of weakness, or simply the discomfort of sharing personal thoughts and feelings with a stranger. However, if your anxiety is so intense that it prevents you from attending sessions or engaging in the therapeutic process, it's important to speak with your therapist about it. They may be able to provide you with additional support or adjust your therapy approach to make you feel more comfortable. Keep in mind that over time, as you build a trusting relationship with your therapist and gain a better understanding of the therapeutic process, your anxiety is likely to decrease.

I understand this is a difficult situation for you, and it's essential to process the emotions and events surrounding your husband's emotional affair. Based on what you've shared, it appears that your husband acted in a deceptive and dishonest manner. The fact that he initially lied to you about his whereabouts and then later disclosed that he stayed with his ex-wife, even when he knew you were aware, indicates a breach of trust.

Regarding your specific question, infidelity often involves physical intimacy, but it's important to remember that emotional intimacy can also be damaging to a relationship, especially when it's hidden from a partner. Based on your husband's account, it does seem that they slept in the same bed, which could indicate physical intimacy, albeit not necessarily sexual. However, it's essential to note that even without that explicit detail, the emotional connection and manipulation surrounding the affair could be harmful to your relationship.

Given this context, it may be helpful for you and your husband to address the underlying issues that led to his emotional affair, such as communication, trust, and potential unresolved feelings or needs. Counseling could be a useful tool to help you and your husband explore these issues and work towards restoring trust and rebuilding your relationship. It's crucial to remember that healing from infidelity is a process, and it can take time, effort, and dedication from both partners to create a strong and secure bond once more.

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you. Your girlfriend is going through a challenging time after quitting drinking, and the onset of depression may make her feel that moving away is the best solution. However, it is essential to understand that her decisions are influenced by her feelings in the moment and may not necessarily reflect her long-term needs.

First and foremost, offer your support and encourage her to seek professional help from a mental health professional. Depression can be a debilitating condition, and she may need additional resources and guidance to cope.

Communicate with her openly and empathetically. Let her know that you care about her and that you are there for her, no matter what. Be a listening ear, validate her feelings and reassure her that you are committed to the relationship.

Help her find healthy ways to cope with her depression, such as engaging in regular physical activity, practicing mindfulness meditation, or participating in hobbies that bring her joy.

If she is open to it, suggest attending couple's therapy to work through any challenges and strengthen your relationship. Remember that change is not easy, and recovery from addiction and depression takes time and patience. Be persistent in your support and communicate effectively.

I understand that you're in a difficult place right now and it can be overwhelming to feel sad and alone. It's important to recognize that self-harming behaviors, like cutting, are a way to cope with intense emotional pain. However, it's not a healthy or effective coping mechanism in the long term. I'd like to encourage you to consider alternative ways to manage your emotions and find relief. Some effective coping strategies include practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in physical activity, reaching out to trusted individuals for support, and engaging in creative pursuits. If you find that the urge to self-harm is too strong, or if you're feeling suicidal, please reach out to a mental health professional for further support and guidance. You are not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help you through this difficult time.

I'm glad you've reached out for help, and it's important to remember that many men experience this issue at some point in their lives. There can be various causes for erectile dysfunction (ED), and it's essential to address both physical and emotional factors.

Physical causes may include underlying health conditions like diabetes, cardiovascular disease, or nerve damage. In some cases, prescription medications or substance use can contribute. It's crucial to have a thorough medical examination by a healthcare professional to rule out any underlying medical conditions.

Emotional or psychological factors may also play a role. Stress, anxiety, and relationship issues can contribute to ED. Feeling pressure to perform, depression, and insecurities about your body image can all impact your ability to achieve or maintain an erection.

Fortunately, there are several treatment options available:

1. Lifestyle changes: Regular physical activity, a healthy diet, and avoiding excessive alcohol and tobacco use can all help improve erection quality.
2. Medications: Several classes of medications, such as phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDIs), can help improve blood flow to the penis and increase the chances of achieving an erection.
3. Therapy: Counseling or therapy can help address any emotional or psychological factors contributing to ED. These may include techniques to manage stress, improve communication with your partner, or address any underlying relationship issues.
4. Sexual techniques: Experimenting with different sexual positions, using sex toys, or incorporating sensual activities like massage can help rekindle sexual desire and intimacy.
5. Alternative therapies: Acupuncture, herbal supplements, and penile injections are some alternative treatments that have shown promise in improving erectile function.

It's essential to address both physical and emotional factors when dealing with ED. I strongly recommend that you consult a healthcare professional for a thorough examination and to discuss which treatment options may be best for you. Remember, it's important to maintain open communication with your partner throughout this process and work together to find a solution that strengthens your relationship.

I understand that this is a complicated situation. From a psychological perspective, communication and respect in relationships are key elements for a healthy partnership. If your fiancé feels uncomfortable with her partner entering the house without being informed or invited, then this should be addressed between them. Open communication about feelings and needs is essential in any relationship. Encourage your fiancé to express her concerns and discuss possible solutions together to find a compromise that works for both of them. Remember, it's important that each partner feels respected and valued in their relationship.

I understand that dealing with a loved one's behavioral changes due to Alzheimer's can be challenging and frustrating. It's important to remember that their behaviors are often a result of their disease and not a deliberate attempt to upset you. Here are some suggestions to help you cope with your feelings:

1. Practice empathy: Try to put yourself in your mother's shoes. She may be confused and disoriented, which can lead to her behaving in ways that are not typical for her.
2. Set boundaries: It's important to establish clear boundaries for what behaviors you will and will not tolerate. Communicate your feelings to others who are caring for your mother and work together to create a consistent approach.
3. Seek support: Connecting with others who have gone through similar experiences can be helpful. Consider joining a support group for caregivers of Alzheimer's patients or speaking with a counselor to help you process your emotions.
4. Find ways to manage stress: Engage in activities that help you relax and reduce stress, such as exercise, meditation, or hobbies.
5. Be patient and kind: Remember that your mother is still the person you love and care for. Try to find ways to connect with her in meaningful ways despite the challenges.

Keep in mind that these suggestions may not completely eradicate your feelings of frustration and guilt, but they can help you find ways to manage them and find greater peace and understanding in your caregiving journey.

I understand how distressing it can be to experience nightmares and flashbacks after ending a relationship. These symptoms are common among people who have been through a significant emotional trauma. The first step to managing these symptoms is to acknowledge that they are a normal part of the healing process.

To reduce the frequency and intensity of these experiences, try implementing the following self-care strategies:

1. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and meditation can help you relax your body and mind, reducing the symptoms of anxiety and stress that can trigger nightmares and flashbacks.
2. Get sufficient sleep: Ensure that you are getting enough sleep each night. Establish a regular sleep routine and avoid caffeine, alcohol, and electronic devices before bedtime.
3. Stay active: Regular physical activity can help reduce symptoms of anxiety and improve your overall mental and emotional well-being.
4. Connect with supportive people: Share your experiences with trusted family members, friends, or a mental health professional. This can help you feel less isolated and provide a sense of validation and healing.
5. Challenge negative thoughts: Identify and challenge any negative or distorted thoughts that may be exacerbating your symptoms. You may find it helpful to keep a journal to track your thoughts and emotions.
6. Seek professional help: If your symptoms are severe or persistent, consider speaking with a mental health professional. They can help you develop coping strategies and provide you with additional resources and support.

Remember, these symptoms will not last forever, and you don't need to go through them alone. Be kind to yourself, and try your best to practice self-compassion and patience as you navigate the healing process.

I understand that this is a difficult situation for you, but as a psychologist, I would strongly advise you to consider the emotional well-being of all parties involved. Your current situation is complex and involves several ethical dilemmas. You must first consider the impact of your actions on your ex-wife and your young son. You have a moral obligation to be truthful and transparent about your actions, especially when it comes to your children. Lying or hiding the truth can lead to mistrust and further emotional pain.

Regarding the woman you're currently dating, it's important to acknowledge your feelings, but also to consider the potential consequences of your actions. Entering into a romantic relationship while still married and with a young child at home can be seen as irresponsible and inconsiderate, not just to your current partner, but also to your ex-wife and your children. It may be appropriate to have an open and honest conversation with her about your feelings and your plans for your family situation. You may also want to consider seeking the help of a therapist or counselor to navigate this complex situation. Ultimately, it is essential that you make decisions that are in the best interest of yourself and your family.

Absolutely, talking to a therapist or counselor about this can be very beneficial for you. You're in a situation where it's difficult to distinguish between your own desires and your mother's expectations. This can lead to feelings of guilt and anxiety when you don't meet her expectations. In therapy, you can learn assertiveness skills, set boundaries, and work on building self-confidence. These skills will help you make decisions that are right for you instead of just trying to please your mother. The thought of making changes can be scary, but with the support of a mental health professional, you can take it one step at a time.

I'm really sorry to hear about the pain and confusion you're experiencing in your relationship. The question of whether or not to respect someone's decision to leave can be complex. It may be helpful to consider the long-term impact on your emotional well-being. If staying in a relationship where your partner is inconsistent and unreliable is causing significant distress, it might be worth examining if this relationship is truly beneficial for you. Respecting someone's decision to leave may mean acknowledging that continuing in this relationship may not be the best choice for you, even if it's painful. However, this doesn't mean you should stop communicating or caring for yourself in the process. It's essential to prioritize your emotional health and well-being. If the situation persists, seeking support from a mental health professional or a trusted support system can help provide you with additional perspective and coping strategies.

I'm glad you're reaching out for help, and I understand how difficult it can be to manage depression and mood swings. Living a more balanced life involves consistent self-care and making lifestyle changes to support your mental health. Here are some suggestions based on your concerns:

1. Maintain a consistent routine: Establishing a reliable daily schedule can help regulate your energy levels and mood. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, eat your meals at regular intervals, and include regular physical activity in your routine.

2. Prioritize self-care: Make sure you get enough rest, eat a healthy diet, and engage in activities that you find enjoyable and relaxing. These may include hobbies, exercise, reading, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or socializing with friends.

3. Seek professional help: If your depression and mood swings are significantly impacting your daily life, it might be helpful to work with a healthcare professional. They can help you develop coping strategies, identify triggers, and explore treatment options such as therapy or medication.

4. Practice stress management techniques: Techniques like deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization exercises can help you react more adaptively to stressors and improve your overall well-being.

5. Engage in activities that bring you a sense of purpose: Fulfilling work, volunteering, or engaging in hobbies that give your days structure can help elevate your mood and provide a sense of accomplishment.

6. Connect with others: Maintaining strong relationships can improve your mood, help you feel more supported, and provide valuable opportunities for socialization.

7. Set realistic goals: Identifying attainable goals and breaking them down into manageable tasks can help you feel more in control of your life and boost your motivation and sense of achievement.

Remember, living a balanced life can be a challenging journey, but with the right support and commitment, it's possible to create positive changes in your life and manage your depression and mood swings effectively.

I understand that you're experiencing distressing dreams that leave you feeling uneasy, and your sleep pattern is affected. This could potentially be a sign of anxiety, especially if you're trying to avoid falling asleep and can only manage short durations of rest. It's essential to create a relaxing sleep environment, try relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation. You could also consider writing down your dreams to understand their meanings better. If your condition worsens, you may want to seek professional help, such as a mental health specialist or a psychologist, for further exploration and potential treatment options. Sleep deprivation can lead to serious health issues, so I recommend prioritizing your sleep to promote overall well-being.

I understand how difficult and distressing it can be to experience bullying, especially when it seems that the teachers aren't taking appropriate action. Here are some suggestions that may help you cope:

1. Build a support system: Reach out to trusted friends, family members, orother adults like coaches, religious leaders, or counselors. These people can offer you understanding,encouragement, and advice.
2. Practice self-care: Make time for activities that make you feel good about yourself, such as sports, music, dance, or art. Eat healthy meals,get plenty of rest, and avoid harmful substances like drugs or alcohol.
3. Find safe spaces: Identify places within or outside of school where you feel safe and secure. This could be a specific area in the school, a friend's house, or even an online community.
4. Report incidents confidentially: Speak with someone in authority about the bullying, such as a school counselor, administrator, or studentaffairs representative. They might be able to help even if teachers haven't taken action in the past.
5. Consider change: If bullying continues despite your best efforts and the support of adults, consider transferring to another school or program. Sometimes removing yourself from a toxic environment is the only way to protect yourself and improve your mental health.
6. Seek professional help: If you're extremely sad for long periods and find yourself struggling to cope with everyday life, it might be helpful to talk to a mental health professional like a psychologist or a therapist. They can offer you guidance and support for managing your emotions and building resilience to cope with the bullying. Remember, you are not alone in this, and help is available. You deserve to be treated with kindness, respect, and dignity.

I understand that you're going through a complex emotional situation with your ex-boyfriend. It's not uncommon for individuals to experience strong emotions towards past relationships, even when those relationships exhibit unhealthy patterns.

However, it's important to acknowledge that continued involvement in a relationship with someone who exhibits narcissistic behaviors can have negative consequences for your emotional well-being. Repeatedly going back to someone who lies and cheats can reinforce unhealthy patterns and contribute to feelings of low self-worth and insecurity.

It's important to prioritize your own emotional health and consider setting clear boundaries for your relationship with your ex-boyfriend. This could involve limiting communication or refraining from engaging in behaviors that enable his narcissistic behaviors.

You might also benefit from exploring why you feel drawn to him in spite of these unhealthy patterns. This could involve speaking with a mental health professional or engaging in therapeutic practices such as journaling or mindfulness meditation.

Ultimately, it's important to remember that you have the power to make choices that prioritize your emotional well-being and overall health. If you continue to feel stuck or need support making a decision, I encourage you to consider seeking out the guidance of a mental health professional.

It is completely normal for people to cry during therapy sessions. Therapy is a safe space for expressing emotions, and crying is one way that people may release deeply-held feelings or react to difficult emotions or memories. If you find yourself crying during therapy, you can rest assured that it is a normal and natural response, and your therapist is there to support you through this process. If you have questions or concerns about this, feel free to bring them up during your session.

It's normal for a child to be so angry she wanted someone to die, but this seems to be heading into a dangerous realm. I think it would be wise to have her seen by a child psychologist just to rule out anything more serious.

I understand that this situation is concerning and potentially dangerous for your daughter. Aggressive behavior towards a younger sibling can have various causes. Here are some possibilities:

1. Developmental Issues: At 8 years old, the stepchild may be experiencing developmental issues, such as temper tantrums, lack of impulse control, or difficulty in social interaction.
2. Power Struggle: The stepchild might be seeking attention or power by dominating or bullying your daughter.
3. Learning from Experiences: He could be learning this behavior from his environment or past experiences.
4. Emotional Distress: He may be dealing with emotional distress or trauma that is causing him to lash out.

It's important to note that my analysis is based on the limited information provided. I would recommend seeking professional help from a child psychologist or therapist who can conduct a thorough assessment and provide strategies tailored to your specific situation. You may also consider implementing safer interventions, like supervising interactions between your children or teaching healthy conflict resolution skills.

I imagine that it's pretty disconcerting to feel as though you lost yourself.When you said that you are jaded, I'm not sure whether you mean that you are jaded toward someone, something, life in general, or some combination thereof.One of the difficult things about anxiety is that anxiety can lead to more anxiety because of being concerned about having another panic attack. Consider remembering that panic attacks usually only last a few minutes and the reason they don't go away right away is because of the way your brain releases chemicals because some part of your brain is reacting as if you are in danger in some way.As far as finding yourself, you may consider looking at what parts of each day you can control as a way to stay centered. You could also focus on something that makes you feel happy and/or comfortable.You may also consider the list of values here to give yourself an idea of what is most important to you, what it is that you are living by now, and what values you would prefer to live by. http://www.therapistaid.com/therapy-worksheet/values-clarificationIf this proves to be difficult, consider seeing a local therapist.

I'm truly sorry for the loss of your father, and it's completely normal to feel the weight of grief long after such a significant event. Given that you mentioned you've been carrying this burden for five years without support, I would encourage you to seek professional help. A mental health professional can offer different therapeutic approaches, such as cognitive-behavioral techniques or psychotherapy, to help you process your emotions, develop coping skills, and improve your overall well-being. You don't have to carry this burden alone any longer. Please reach out to a mental health service provider near you, or consider online therapy as an option if those are more accessible to you. Keep in mind, there's no shame in asking for help, and it's essential for your healing process.

It's important to recognize that every relationship dynamic is unique, and there's no definitive answer to whether your actions were right or wrong without considering all the specific details of your situation. However, some things to keep in mind are:

1. Communication: Having open and honest communication with your boyfriend about your feelings and intentions towards your friend is essential.
2. Trust: Consider whether spending time with your friend could potentially hurt your boyfriend's trust in your relationship.
3. Boundaries: Establishing and maintaining clear boundaries with your friend, such as limiting excessive time spent together, can help ensure a healthy friendship dynamic.

Ultimately, it's up to you and your boyfriend to find a solution that works for both of you, and that maintains trust and respect within your relationship. If you're having difficulty navigating this situation, consider seeking guidance from a mental health professional.

Being in this position is tough. If seeking another career opportunity isn't viable, there are a couple of things you can do to manage stress on the job.  1. Have a ritual to begin the day:  Consider setting a one sentence intention and plan tasks for the day2. Take the breaks you are offered. I know it can be difficult to step away from your desk to eat lunch or take 10-minute breaks during the day, but prioritize this if you can. Sometimes 30 minutes of downtime and fresh air can help you feel better. 3.  Have a ritual to end the day:  If you commute by car consider an end of the day playlist.  Take a walk. Light a candle.  Clear your desk and write tasks for the next day. Whatever it is, send a signal to your brain that it is time to end the day.4. If you do work from home or are expected to be available after hours, set boundaries where you can.  Set a timer for answering emails and stick to that.  Have phone free meals.    Try to engage in activities that are rejuvenating like spending time the friends and family.  5. Try to limit alcohol/ drugs.  Move as much as you can.  Get outside in natural sunlight.  These are just ideas/ suggestions.  Even doing one of these things could be a step in the right direction.  Best of luck!

Hi Moore, Underneath all your anger is a lot of hurt. The hurt is there because you are being disrespected. Your boyfriend (unless you've only told me a small, disproportionate part of the bigger picture) doesn't tend to treat you like you're important and he dismisses your emotions. This is happening because this is the level of ability (disability?) he has right now in a relationship. You can expect more of this behaviour (because that's who he is; it has nothing to do with you), and I hope you think carefully about whether it's working for you to be in this. You could try telling him that you are hurt, because people tend to listen more to hurt than to anger, but my guess is with him it might not make a difference. I hope you talk to someone who knows and supports you about how you're feeling in this relationship.

I understand that this is a difficult topic to discuss, but it's important that we talk about it. These thoughts you're having are not an uncommon experience, and they don't necessarily mean that you're a harmful person. It's possible that these thoughts are a manifestation of deep-seated emotional pain or discomfort. They may be related to various underlying emotional issues, such as anger, frustration, or even a feeling of powerlessness. It's also important to note that these thoughts don't necessarily equate to action. In fact, most people who have such thoughts do not act on them. I would encourage you to speak with a mental health professional about this, who can help you explore the possible causes and provide you with appropriate resources and coping strategies. Remember that it's okay to ask for help and support when you need it.

Initially, everything is a reminder because there is a trace of that other person present in everything in your life. When we lose someone, we're saying goodbye to what we thought our future was going to be.  Accepting that's changed and allowing ourselves to envision a new future is necessary to "move on". Start learning something new or try a new activity that you've always wanted to do.  Find whatever is "good" about being out of the relationship and focus on those things.  This can be an exciting time of transformation for you.   As time goes by, you'll add new things in your life that aren't entwined with this relationship and those things will begin to crowd out those things associated with the relationship.  Give yourself a little empathy, no one goes through a breakup without being sad.  It's ok to be sad.  It's even ok to feel devastated.  Loss of a relationship touches a primal need we have to belong.  It makes us feel insecure, unanchored.  In truth, we are ok, safe even.  This experience will open different perspectives for you.  There are lessons you'll take from it that will add another facet to you as a person.  Maybe in time, you'll even appreciate this experience.  I'm sorry you're hurting right now.  Best wishes to you, Allison

I understand your frustration and disappointment, patient. It's natural to feel a range of emotions when dealing with a loved one's Alzheimer's disease. This disease can be challenging not only for the person diagnosed but also for their family members and caregivers. It's important to remember that their behaviors are a result of the disease and not willful disregard. Your mother may not be able to remember or understand your opinions and wishes as she once did. Instead of focusing on the disappointment and frustration, try focusing on the things you can control, such as the way you respond to the situation or your own self-care. Consider seeking support from other caregivers, support groups, or professionals to help navigate these challenging emotions. Be patient and compassionate with yourself and your mother during this process.

I'm really sorry that you're feeling this way, but I can't provide you with the help that you need through this text-based interaction. It's important to acknowledge that feeling worthless is a common experience for many people, and it's not uncommon for people to have negative thoughts about themselves.

However, it's important to remember that these thoughts are not necessarily a reflection of reality. Instead, they are a product of your current mental state. One effective way to challenge these negative thoughts is to practice cognitive restructuring. This involves identifying the thinking patterns that are contributing to your feelings of worthlessness and replacing them with more realistic and positive thoughts.

Another helpful strategy is to engage in activities that bring you joy and make you feel good about yourself, such as exercise, hobbies, or pursuing a creative interest. It's also important to surround yourself with supportive people who make you feel valued and appreciated.

If your feelings of worthlessness are persistent and overwhelming, it's important to seek professional help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with the tools and resources that you need to manage your emotions and improve your overall well-being.

That's a difficult question to answer. Dreaming is a normal (and healthy) part of the sleep cycle. The current thought is that we all generally
experience roughly the same number of dreams - the difference often is just
whether we remember the dreams or not.An increase in the number or frequency of distressing dreams
(or nightmares) can be a symptom of stress, anxiety, or PTSD.  If the dreams are disturbing to you, talking to a local
counselor could help. If the dreams themselves
are not troubling, you may just be remembering them more than most people do.

I understand your situation, and it's not an uncommon issue for couples. Firstly, it's essential to create an open and non-judgmental environment for him to express his feelings and concerns. Encourage him to communicate about the sources of his insecurities and discuss the role that his past experiences might play in shaping his reactions.

Secondly, it could be helpful to emphasize and validate the positives in your relationship, focusing on the present and the qualities and characteristics that you admire and appreciate in your partner. You can also remind him that we all have pasts, and it's not possible, nor necessarily desirable, for everyone to be a virgin when getting married.

Lastly, you might suggest couples therapy to explore these and other issues that could be affecting your relationship more deeply. It could be beneficial to work with a therapist to learn skills, communication techniques, and to work together on strengthening your bond. Additionally, working with a therapist could help him gain a better understanding of his own underlying emotions, insecurities, and help him learn how to manage them more effectively.

Not liking someone is not cruel - even if it is a family member. There is nothing wrong with you for not liking your sister. Some people are fortunate to have siblings that they get along with really well, other don't. We all have different personalities and we are not going to like everyone - even if they are related. In fact, sometimes being related makes it harder because you know all of each other's flaws and imperfections. With that being said - it may be worth it to make an effort to talk about the things that get in the way of having the kind of relationship that you might ideally want with your sister. Sometimes it is hard to like someone if we have a lot of old frustration and resentment and being able to talk about it in a constructive and kind way can lead to more understanding and respect, and sometimes actually liking each other.

I understand that you're feeling worried and uncertain about your boyfriend's behavior towards other women. These incidents of sending compliments to other women, even while denying his involvement, could be a sign of infidelity or disrespect in a relationship. It's important to address this issue directly with your partner, expressing your feelings and fears. Communication and honesty are essential for building trust and maintaining a healthy relationship. However, keep in mind that every situation is unique and it might be helpful to seek the guidance of a professional counselor to gain a better understanding of your relationship dynamics and how to effectively express your concerns.

I'm sorry to hear about your friend's situation. It's important that you care and are concerned. However, I strongly advise against taking direct action or confronting her about this without professional intervention. If you feel comfortable, you could encourage her to seek help from a healthcare professional or a trusted mental health expert. Additionally, you may want to explore support groups for friends and family members of individuals struggling with substance abuse. Remember, the road to recovery often requires a team effort and a compassionate support system.

I'm glad you're seeking help for your relationship concerns. Listening effectively is a crucial skill in any relationship. Here are some steps to improve your listening skills:

1. Give your full attention: put away distractions like phones or laptops and focus on your partner.
2. Maintain good body language: make eye contact, nod, and use open body posture to convey attentiveness.
3. Reflect back: paraphrase or summarize what your partner said to ensure understanding.
4. Validate: acknowledge your partner's feelings.

As for "getting yourself together," emotional regulation is crucial. Here are some techniques that might help:

1. Mindfulness meditation: practices like deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or visualizations can help you stay calm in the moment.
2. Self-care: eat well, exercise regularly, get enough sleep, and engage in activities you enjoy.
3. Identify triggers: recognizing what sets off strong emotional reactions can allow you to prepare coping strategies.
4. Seek professional help: a mental health professional can provide additional guidance and support.

Remember, change takes time and patience, so be kind to yourself throughout the process.

If the only way the relationship you have with your mother feels "okay" is when she is the only one who makes decisions concerning your life, then this only seems ok.In fact it is not okay for one person to be the authority for another person unless the one for whom this is being done, does not have their own ability to think for themselves.Separating your own wishes and way of handling life matters, from your mother's point of view, may be difficult.First, realize you need to get familiar with feeling at ease with the idea of deciding matters for yourself.You'll need practice until you feel comfortable.Unless, if you've been thinking through decisions you'd like to make and the idea of your mother's anger is the only point which stopped you, then you may almost instantly start living in a liberated way of running your own life.Basically, it is right and fair for you to have the chance to live your life the way you feel is best.   Be prepared that your mother may disagree with you and that her disagreement is not a reason itself to not do what you believe is in your best interest.

I understand that it can be challenging to balance your desire for independence with your current living situation.It's important to communicate openly and respectfully with your mother about your concerns. Consider expressing your feelings in a non-confrontational way, focusing on how her rules affect you personally, rather than criticizing her. You might also consider negotiating compromises, such as setting your own curfew or being responsible for certain household chores in exchange for more autonomy. Remember that, ultimately, it's important for both you and your mother to be respectful of each other's boundaries and needs. It may also be helpful to explore alternatives for living arrangements, such as finding a roommate or exploring subsidized housing options. If you continue to struggle with the living situation, it may be beneficial to speak with a mental health professional for additional support and coping strategies.

It's important to acknowledge that everyone's experiences and reactions to sexual encounters can be complex and multifaceted. Based on what you've shared, here are a few possibilities for your feelings.

First, it's natural to feel a sense of excitement or pleasure during new experiences, especially when they provide a sense of connection and intimacy with your partner. At the same time, it's also common to feel a mix of emotions, including guilt, jealousy, or anxiety, particularly when these experiences involve other people.

In your case, it seems that you are experiencing a range of emotions. On one hand, you mentioned feeling better after the experience and craving more of it. This could be due to the fact that the threesome helped you feel closer to your partner and brought some excitement into your sexual relationship.

On the other hand, you also mentioned feeling an empty or sad feeling before the experience happens. It's possible that this emotion stems from feelings of jealousy or insecurity, or from a fear of rejection or abandonment. It's also worth noting that alcohol can be a factor in these emotions, as it can lower inhibitions and cloud judgment, making it harder to process emotions in the moment.

As a psychologist, I would encourage you to explore these feelings with your partner. Talking openly and honestly about your emotions, thoughts, and concerns can help strengthen your relationship and deepen your intimacy. It's also important to remember that there's no one "right" way to feel about sexual experiences, and that everyone's emotional reactions can be different. It can be helpful to practice self-compassion and focus on what feels good for you and your partner, rather than external pressures or societal expectations. If you find that your emotions are becoming overwhelming or interfere with your daily functioning, it may be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional.

Your partner loves you but must have fear that keeps standing in his way. Breaking up can be a very difficult thing.  I'm sorry you're feeling badly.    The first thing is to be really sure you are taking care of yourself --- that means eating well, exercising, getting good sleep, spending time with friends/family and making sure you are taking care of important things like work, rent, bills etc.    Secondly, it's important to do things that make you feel better and not worse.   If looking up your ex on social media makes you feel worse stop doing it!   It's important to concentrate on you and not them.    Thirdly, it's super important to make sure you're really looking at the situation accurately and look for the good things that still exist in your life ---  what is still good?   Even though your emotions are hurting and you are feeling badly, can you see the light at the end of the tunnel?  Do you feel hope?  If you do try to concentrate on that hope feeling.   If the obsessing continues and really gets in the way of living your life?   Maybe contact a therapist or counsellor that can help you through this difficult time?

The behaviors you describe are boundary violations.  You can not change your spouse, but you can respond to his behaviors in ways that protect your boundaries and ensure your safety.  This is very hard to do without support.  Finding a therapist who understands the dynamics of abusive relationships may be helpful.  If you are not ready to do this, I recommend the book "Boundaries" by Dr. Henry Cloud and Dr. John Townsend.  It's a great resource for helping one recognize boundary violations and learning how to respond to them in ways that are constructive!

Good questions! The paradox of thinking about forever is that you can become more motivated to live only in the present. Enjoy your journey!

The good news in the way you're feeling is recognizing that your husband's trust of your actions, makes a difference to you.The typical therapy formula for restoring trust between two people after some sort of betrayal, is for the one who has broken the trust, to earn it back.Restoring trust requires both persons to actively involve themselves in this process.The person who tires earning back trust, must know what standards for this, of the one who was betrayed.The person who feels betrayed must willingly be open minded to accepting the efforts of the one who tries earning back their trust.As simple as this formula sounds, the actual process of restoring trust raises a lot of emotion on both sides, therefore causing difficulty in keeping discussions in this area, on track.The best way of success in restoring trust between partners, is utilizing a couples therapist who would be able to guide your conversations back on track, and also open emotions for discussion when relevant to restoring trust.Good luck in establishing new terms with your partner!

It's natural for feelings to be complex in friendships that have romantic pasts. From what I understand, you had a brief romantic relationship with your friend in the past, and it has since turned into a platonic friendship. The fact that you spent a weekend with him upset your current boyfriend.

As a psychologist, I'd like to clarify that whether you were wrong or not is not the most important question. Instead, it's essential to reflect on the reasons behind your actions and how they impacted your relationships.

In this situation, spending time with a friend, especially one with a romantic past, is not inherently wrong. However, it's critical to be open and honest with your current partner about your intentions, the nature of your friend's relationship, and how you manage the emotional and relational boundaries.

If you believe your interactions with your friend could potentially harm or upset your current relationship, it may be helpful to engage in open and supportive communication with your boyfriend, as well as establish guidelines and boundaries to ensure that your friendships do not interfere with your current romantic commitments.

Ultimately, it's essential to maintain trust and transparency in romantic relationships while also respecting the importance of friendships and old connections from the past. By fostering open and honest dialogue, maintaining clear boundaries, and focusing on building a strong foundation of trust and commitment, you'll be well on your way to navigating these situations effectively.

It's important for your fiancé to understand that everyone's past experiences shape who they are today, and that includes both positive and negative experiences. You can't change the past, but you can focus on the present and future.

You might suggest that he work on building self-acceptance and self-forgiveness, as this could help him better accept you and others as well. Encourage him to engage in activities that help him build self-esteem and confidence, such as therapy, reading inspirational books, or seeking support from trusted friends or a support group.

You can also encourage open and honest communication in your relationship. Encourage him to express his feelings and concerns about your past, and try to understand where he's coming from. Practice active listening and empathy, and validate his feelings while also expressing your own.

Additionally, remind him of the reasons he loves and values you in the present, and remind yourself of the reasons you value him. Focusing on the positive aspects of your relationship can help mitigate the negative feelings that arise from past experiences.

Lastly, be patient with him. Change doesn't happen overnight, and it can take time for him to work through his feelings and insecurities. Offer him support and understanding as he works through this, and continue to prioritize the strengths and positive aspects of your relationship.

Terrible things do happen in life, and I am sorry to hear about what happened to you. Please rest assured that you are not a sociopath, and that your reactions are normal responses to traumatic events. I'm guessing you are experiencing a sense of numbness, which is a common response to trauma. The best thing you can do is to get some trauma counseling with a professional counselor.  As you process your experience, you will be able to feel emotions again. However, the first feelings to come back may be related to trauma, such as fear, panic, and a sense of hyper vigilance. A professional counselor will be able to help you tolerate these feelings, manage them, and heal from your trauma.

I understand that you're experiencing bouts of anger that seem disproportionate to the situations causing them. this is a common issue, especially during adolescence, as your body goes through significant hormonal changes. However, the frequency and intensity of your emotions could be indicative of an underlying emotional or psychological condition, such as Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED) or other anxiety or mood disorders.

It's important to remember that you're not alone in experiencing these feelings, and seeking professional help can be beneficial. A mental health practitioner, such as a psychologist or therapist, will be able to assess your situation and provide you with evidence-based strategies and treatments to manage and potentially resolve these emotions.

In the interim, there are several coping mechanisms that might help you:

1. Identify and avoid triggers: Be aware of situations, emotions, or thoughts that trigger your anger and try to stay away from them whenever possible.
2. deep breathing: Taking a few moments to focus on your breath and practicing diaphragmatic breathing can help calm your mind and body during moments of anger.
3. Progressive muscle relaxation: A relaxation technique that involves tensing and releasing muscles throughout your body to help release tension and promote relaxation.
4. Engage in regular physical activity: Regular exercise is a proven way to manage stress and help regulate emotions.
5. Practice mindfulness: Be present in the moment and focusing on your thoughts and feelings non-judgmentally can help you gain a better understanding of your emotional reactions.
6. Express feelings in a healthy way: Write down your feelings, talk about them with a trusted friend or family member, or engage in creative outlets like art, music, or writing to help process your emotions.
7. Seek social support: Connecting with peers, loved ones, or a mental health professional can provide a sense of validation, understanding, and encouragement.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help, and taking steps towards understanding and managing your emotions is a brave and important step towards improved mental and emotional wellbeing.

I will admit that I'm not specifically familiar with this from my own experience.My best educated guess is that you could have a seizure during which you have some sort of symptoms similar to a hallucination (which is one of the psychotic symptoms) when you hear or see things that aren't really there.In looking briefly online, I was able to find some information here: http://www.epilepsy.com/information/professionals/about-epilepsy-seizures/psychiatric-and-behavioral-aspects/psychiatric-2It sounds like this would be a symptom in addition to an already existing seizure disorder, not a seizure disorder in addition to a mental health problem. If it is the other way around, I'm not sure how that would work. It is common with some types of seizures to have an altered state of reality during or shortly after the seizure, so that could also be related.I would suggest you talk to your physician about this directly so that if they are worried about this, you can learn more about what is making them concerned about it and what, if anything, you could do to lessen the likelihood of it or how to handle it if it does happen.

Hi Oak Harbor,My heart goes out to you. Sometimes when I'm working with a client who experiences depression or anxiety, I ask them for a glimpse into their worst moments in their minds. "What are the worst thoughts that run through your head?". Often they struggle, perhaps out of shame; maybe they don't want me to know their worst thoughts. But I can help them better if I do know, because then we have a place to work from. You are feeling hopeless and worthless, and your thoughts support these intense emotions. I don't know you, but I strongly believe that you have someone in your life who, if they heard your thoughts, would say "That's not true. I know where her value is." I believe that there are people who would see your value clearly, even if in small things. Can you imagine those voices?You mentioned God, so let's invite God into the conversation. What might God say to you? What evidence might God...who sees all..have of your worth? What hint might God give you about your purpose? You suffer from severe anxiety, and the agoraphobia works together with fear; they're a tag team. Fear tells you perhaps that people will reject you (or something equally bad), and then agoraphobia steps in and traps you and uses as evidence the fact that no one seems to be reaching out to you to convince you that you have no worth. Do you see their plan? Make her scared... keep her here alone...convince her it's hopeless. They both try to convince you that they are your only friends, except they're lying to you. They only want power over you.You forget your worth. You forget that we all have worth. No one is a waste. I believe all God's creatures have worth, and that we're here to use our gifts to improve the world, and to remind each other of our value. There are people out there needing your support as much as you need theirs. Can you find them? My guess is you've been alone and isolated for a very long time and it's impossible for you to see your worth in this situation. We need mirrors to see our worth and other people are our mirrors. We see our value in their eyes. Do you remember the first time you questioned your worth? What was happening that you blamed yourself for? Can you speak to that child and tell her (or him) that whatever's happening isn't her fault? It's that child who cannot see her own worth, probably because someone treated her as though she had none. That's only a story though; not the truth. Can you find another thread of a story? Who might tell a story of your worth?Oak Harbor, I believe that there is help closer than you think. Fear wants you to believe it's hopeless. You reached out here...can you reach out again? Start with just one person, and that will lead you to somewhere. We don't know where that somewhere is but could it be better than sitting alone? You've stopped living. You can choose any moment to start. I wish you peace and hope. :)

As social creatures, we humans all long for deep human connection. To know that we belong and are part of something larger. It is so important to us that when we feel alone - it can feel almost unbearable. You are not alone in feeling alone. While it can take time to build deep relationships there are moments in each day where we have the opportunity to interact with other people who may also feel lonely and scared and want to be seen and acknowledged. I wonder what it might be like for you if you took on an experiment of trying to really see the people around you and make little attempts to acknowledge and connect with them - fellow humans on this journey of life. A "good morning" at the bus stop or really looking at the person who you buy your groceries from or thanking or complimenting someone for something that you notice and appreciate. While this is not a substitute for close relationships these moments of real connection with the people who we share our communities with can go a long way to realizing that we are not as alone as we may have thought.

It is brave of you to speak out, PTSD is not a joke and it can quickly take a toll on all aspect of life. Please, know that you are not alone and with the right help you can overcome these challenges. Living with PTSD can be very emotionally exhausting, but you can learn ways to cope with its challenges and find fulfillment in your life again. This means being proactively involved with the process, learning about the problem and positive ways to manage it can be a good start. This can also mean seeking professional help. It is important to address the problem both at the physiological and psychological level, this can mean using medication that is prescribed by a MD to reduce the intensity symptoms and also working with an experienced licensed professional. Having healthy life habits such as good sleep hygiene, healthy diet, staying away from self-medicating with drugs and alcohol, and exercising can help reduce the intensity of the symptoms as well. Please, consult with a licensed professional close to you to get more information on resources you can possibly find helpful to you.

I understand that you're experiencing self-harm behavior in the form of head banging and that you're concerned about it. It's important to note that self-harm can be a way of coping with difficult emotions or experiences, especially when one feels overwhelmed or Powerless. The fact that you have anxiety and experienced a challenging childhood may be contributing factors.

First, I would recommend reaching out to your healthcare provider for a comprehensive evaluation to rule out any underlying medical conditions. After that, some strategies that may be helpful include:

1. Identify triggers: Keeping a diary or journal to help you identify the situations, emotions, or thoughts that lead to head banging.
2. Distract yourself: Engage in activities that occupy your mind and body and take your focus away from the impulse to harm yourself. This can include reading, painting, taking a walk, or listening to calming music.
3. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation are effective tools for managing anxiety and stress.
4. Develop a support network: Connecting with friends, family members, or a support group can provide a sense of connection and understanding.
5. Consider therapy: Talking with a mental health professional about the underlying emotions and behaviors can help you understand the root causes and develop coping strategies.

Remember, it's important to be gentle and patient with yourself during this process. Change takes time and effort, and it's okay to stumble occasionally. The most important thing is that you keep trying and look for help when you need it.

A counselor decides to end counseling sessions based on several factors. These factors may include the client achieving their therapy goals, the client's progress no longer requiring ongoing therapy, a stable mental health condition, or the client expressing a desire to self-manage their symptoms. However, it's important to remember that these decisions are made collaboratively between the counselor and the client. Counselors also terminate therapy in cases of lack of progress, severe crisis, or ethical issues. If a client has concerns about the therapeutic process or the ending of therapy, they are encouraged to communicate openly with their counselor about their feelings and thoughts.

A counselor considers several factors when deciding it's time to end counseling sessions. These include: the client's progress towards goals, the client's readiness to continue the process without counseling, the client's stability, and the counselor's availability. Additionally, some counselors have a set number of sessions or timeframe in their contracts with clients. Ultimately, the safety, wellbeing, and autonomy of the client is the primary concern when considering termination.

I understand that facing your fears can be a challenging but essential part of personal growth. Here are some steps you can take to help you face and overcome your fear:

1. Identify your fear: Be specific about what you fear and why. Understanding the root cause of your fear can help you gain clarity and perspective.

2. Break it down: If your fear is a large and overwhelming one, try breaking it down into smaller, more manageable parts. This can make the fear seem less daunting and help you approach it in a more gradual and effective way.

3. Start small: When you're ready, begin taking small steps towards confronting your fear. This might mean doing something small that relates to your fear, or exposing yourself to a harmless reminder of it.

4. Practice relaxation techniques: Before you confront your fear, practice techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or visualization to help you calm your mind and body. These techniques can help you stay focused and centered as you face your fear.

5. Seek support: Sharing your fear with trusted friends, family, or a mental health professional can help you feel less alone and can provide you with valuable insight and encouragement.

Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time, and to ask for help when you need it. Overcoming a fear takes time and effort, but it's a worthwhile and rewarding experience that can lead to increased confidence and personal growth.

Trust is a necessary factor for an intimate relationship to feel safe.The person who must repair the trust is the one who has broken this trust.The best way to find out if your husband wants to restore your trust in him, is to ask him this question.  He may not be willing to meet your request.If he hesitates or becomes defensive about the need to restore your trust, then ask him to think his decision through and tell him the serious consequence you are considering.Ask him to reflect for a few days or a week and then to address the topic again.If you and he consistently find that he is unwilling to do anything at all to regain your trust, then I agree you have serious thinking to do as to whether or not you'd be able to live within a partnership based upon trust, in which you don't trust your partner.

I understand that you're experiencing a cycle of depression, anxiety, and compulsive skin picking, which is causing interpersonal conflicts. This behavior is known as Body-Focused Repetitive Behaviors (BFRBs), such as dermatillomania or skin picking disorder. These behaviors often serve as coping mechanisms for managing negative emotions, stress, and anxiety.

First, it's essential to recognize that your feelings of sadness, anxiety, and the urge to pick are not your fault. I encourage you to explore healthier ways to cope with your emotions, such as:

1. Exercise: Regular physical activity, even a short walk, can help alleviate stress and improve your mood while providing a distraction from negative thoughts.
2. Mindfulness Practices: Engaging in mindfulness meditation, deep breathing, or progressive muscle relaxation can help you become more aware of the present moment and reduce mental and emotional stress.
3. Creative Outlets: Diverting your attention to a creative hobby, such as drawing, painting, or writing, can help improve your mood and decrease your anxiety levels.
4. Social Connections: Reach out to friends, family, or support groups to share your experiences and build a strong support network that can help you navigate challenging situations.
5. Therapy: Consider professional help from a trained mental health professional, such as a psychologist or a therapist.

Together, we can explore these strategies and tailor them to your specific needs to help you manage your depression, anxiety, and compulsive skin picking effectively. It's important to remember that change takes time, effort, and patience, so be gentle with yourself during this process.

I understand that ending a relationship can be a difficult process, and it's normal to have lingering emotional and psychological effects, such as nightmares and flashbacks. These symptoms can be a result of unresolved emotions and feelings associated with the past relationship.

First and foremost, it's essential to practice self-care and prioritize your own well-being. This includes getting enough sleep, eating a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, and setting aside time for relaxation and activities that bring you joy.

You may also find it helpful to explore the underlying emotions and memories that are contributing to the nightmares and flashbacks. Consider seeking the support of a mental health professional, such as a therapist or counselor, who can help you process these emotions and develop coping strategies.

Additionally, there are several techniques that may help reduce the frequency and intensity of nightmares and flashbacks. These include:

* Relaxation exercises, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation
* Imagery rehearsal therapy, which involves visualizing and rehearsing calming and positive scenarios in place of distressing dreams
* Cognitive restructuring, which involves challenging negative thought patterns and replacing them with more positive and constructive ones

Lastly, it's important to communicate openly with your current partner about your experiences and the impact they're having on your relationship. I recommend approaching this conversation with a spirit of vulnerability and honesty, and expressing a willingness to work together to find solutions and support each other through the healing process.

I hope this information is helpful, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns. Best wishes on your healing journey.

But ultimately, the decision of whether to reconcile or move on is up to both you and your husband. If you've exhausted all viable options, it may be time to accept the separation and focus on healing and moving forward on your own. Remember, there is no single "right" answer to this question, and the healing process can be different for everyone.

I hope this gives you some perspective and direction. If you need further support, please don't hesitate to reach out.

I understand that you are feeling rejected and frustrated due to a decrease in your sexual relationship with your husband. It is normal for sexual frequency to fluctuate in long-term relationships. However, the sudden and significant change can be distressing. It's important to communicate your feelings with your partner and express your concerns in a calm and non-confrontational manner. You may also consider other factors that could be contributing to this change, such as work stress, health issues, or emotional distance. Together, you and your husband may want to explore solutions to strengthen your physical connection and address any underlying issues that may be impacting your relationship. Additionally, if you find that communication alone is not effective, consider seeking the help of a couples therapist or counselor.

I understand your concerns, and it's important to acknowledge the impact that your environment can have on our emotions and behavior. Your experience of heightened anger, particularly in response to trivial issues, is not uncommon. The fact that you recognize that your partner's behavior may be influencing yours is a critical first step.

Anger is a complex emotion that can be influenced by various factors, including personal experiences, biology, and interpersonal relationships. In your case, you mentioned that this issue started after you began a relationship with your soon-to-be husband. Anger can sometimes be a learned behavior, especially when it is modeled by significant others.

It's essential to take steps to manage your anger, not only for your own wellbeing but also for the sake of your young children. Here are some suggestions:

1. Identify Triggers: Be aware of situations, thoughts, or people that consistently trigger your anger. Once you can identify the triggers, you can begin to take steps to manage your reactions.

2. Practice Mindfulness: Mindfulness meditation and deep breathing exercises can help you become more aware of your emotions and reduce stress and anxiety, making it easier to respond to triggers in a healthier way.

3. Set Boundaries: Communicate your emotional needs and limitations to your partner, setting clear boundaries for what you find acceptable and not acceptable behavior. Be consistent in enforcing these boundaries.

4. Develop Coping Skills: Identify coping strategies that work for you, for example, engaging in physical activity, listening to music, or writing in a journal. Make sure you have a list of several strategies so that you can choose one that suits the specific situation.

5. Seek Support: Connect with friends, family, or a mental health professional for additional support and resources. Remember, it's okay to ask for help when needed.

6. Practice Self-Compassion: Be gentle and compassionate toward yourself. Remember that change takes time and patience. Allow yourself to make mistakes and grow from them rather than chastising yourself for every slip-up.

Anger management is a process and will require committed effort. Remember, small changes can make a big difference in managing your anger. Stay consistent with your efforts, and observe the positive impact it will have on your relationships and overall wellbeing.
