You're probably not going to like my answer.Your question says a lot about what YOU want rather than what she wants or what may be best for her. Sometimes, what's best for a person is the hardest thing to do, and may be completely opposite of what YOU want.Addictions don't happen in a vacuum. If you've had any experience with addicts at all, then I'm sure you've heard the term "enabler". A lot of the times, when people think they're "helping", they're actually enabling the addict to continue their self-destructive behavior. Tough love and clear boundaries are needed in a lot of situations, but especially with addictions. Family and friends are often the biggest contributing factor to someone choosing to use/drink, continuing to do so, or relapsing back into it.You said she recently quit. You said she is depressed. She wants to move. When a person receives counseling for addictions, they are encouraged to make changes like this. They need to break the habit, and this means removing people from their lives at times. It means moving to new locations. Anything that may trigger a relapse needs to be identified and removed. Not only that, but the addict needs to do a lot of personal reflection to figure out WHY they use/drink in the first place, and not only break the physical addiction to it, but deal with whatever is the root cause that led them to use in the first place. She may need some time alone to figure out who she is as a person, time to make some decisions for herself and do what she needs to do to be healthy.Don't pressure her to stay. Let her have the freedom to do what she needs to do. If she stays, the decision needs to be hers and hers alone. It doesn't need to be made under pressure. That will only lead to resentment. Support her, but don't try to change her or make her do anything, especially for selfish reasons. Let her go. It sounds like she needs some time to focus on herself right now. It wouldn't be a bad idea for you to do the same.

I'm really sorry to hear that you've had to go through such experiences, and it's commendable that you're taking steps to cope with the triggers in your daily life and in your relationship with your partner. Coping with triggers related to sexual abuse can be challenging and sometimes overwhelming, but there are several strategies that may help.

First, it's essential to identify your triggers and become aware of the physical, emotional, and behavioral responses they elicit. Only then can you begin to develop effective coping strategies. Some people find that deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation can help manage the physical responses to triggers. Others may find that grounding techniques, such as focusing on the present moment or engaging in a sensory activity, can help refocus the mind and reduce feelings of anxiety or fear.

It's also important to have a plan in place for dealing with triggers when they arise. This could include identifying safe places or people whom you can turn to for support, engaging in a comforting self-care activity, or using a coping statement to remind yourself of your strength and resilience.

Finally, seeking support from a therapist or other mental health professional may be helpful. A therapist can provide you with additional strategies for coping with triggers and can help you work through the emotional and psychological challenges of sexual abuse survivorship. They can also help you develop a more comprehensive treatment plan that addresses any underlying trauma or other mental health concerns.

I would also recommend exploring resources such as RAINN (Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network) or other organizations that offer support for sexual abuse survivors to learn more about coping strategies and to connect with others who have had similar experiences. These resources can be an invaluable source of information and support as you work to manage the impact of triggers on your daily life and relationships.

Yes, it's normal to feel nervous or anxious before a therapy session, especially if you're new to the experience. In fact, this is a common reaction and it's called the "pre-session anxiety." It's a sign that you're engaging in a helpful and important process for your mental health. However, if your anxiety is extremely intense, lasts for a long time after the session has ended, or interferes with your ability to attend and fully participate in the session, it would be helpful to discuss this further with your therapist, as they may be able to offer you additional support and coping strategies. Remember that with time and consistent effort, things do get better. Keep attending and be gentle with yourself during this process.

It's important to recognize that relationships involve commitment, trust, and open communication. The fact that you're having trust issues and fighting frequently suggests that there may be deep-seated emotional difficulties preventing you from forming a healthy and respectful bond with your partner.

However, it's also essential to understand that relationships are about growth and mutual improvement. It's unrealistic to think that you or your partner will never face challenges or that feelings of insecurity and jealousy will magically disappear.

That being said, the mere fact that you express concern for her happiness and well-being indicates that you care for her deeply. But keeping her in the relationship out of fear or convenience isn't sustainable and will only lead to greater discomfort and dissatisfaction for both of you.

I strongly recommend considering couples therapy to help address the trust issues and underlying emotions causing your fights. This can provide a safe and structured environment for the both of you to learn effective communication skills and explore any underlying fears or insecurities.

Ultimately, making the decision to end a relationship is never an easy one. Still, if you do feel that it's best for your partner's happiness and your own personal growth, then it's crucial to have open and honest conversations about your intentions – even if it may be difficult. Remember, giving someone the freedom to explore their potential for a fulfilling life outside of the relationship could potentially be the most loving thing you can do.

I appreciate your sharing this experience with me. It's not uncommon for people to have strange or unexplained actions from time to time. In this case, it sounds like you experienced an impulsive or unusual behavior that seems to be causing distress for you now. However, if these feelings of distress and unease persist or intensify, it might be helpful to explore the possible underlying reasons for your actions and reactions. For example, there could be some underlying emotional issues, trauma, or stress that might be contributing to this behavior. It might be useful to speak with a mental health professional to help you process these feelings and develop coping strategies.

In the meantime, try to focus on self-care and supportive relationships, and refrain from engaging in potentially harmful behaviors or situations. Remember that everyone makes mistakes and it can be a normal part of growing and learning about ourselves. The important thing is to take responsibility for our actions, learn from them, and seek help when needed.

I see. It sounds like you are dealing with a significant traumatic experience and the resulting anxiety. It is entirely normal to have fear and apprehension after a life-threatening event, especially when there are loved ones involved. These feelings are a natural response to the situation.

However, it's essential to understand that constant fear and worry can impact your overall wellbeing and ability to care for your children effectively. I would suggest discussing your concerns with your healthcare provider as they can help manage your medical condition and address any anxiety-related symptoms. Additionally, they might recommend therapies such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or mindfulness practices to help you manage your anxiety and improve your coping strategies.

Furthermore, I encourage you to explore available support systems, whether it be friends, family, or support groups. Sharing your experiences and feelings with others can provide a sense of validation and relief. Remember that it takes time to heal, both physically and emotionally. And lastly, implementing self-care practices, such as regular exercise, good nutrition, and adequate sleep, can help improve your mood and overall wellbeing.

I understand that this situation is difficult for you, and it's natural to feel hurt and confused when your children favor their other parent over you. It's important to remember that their loyalties may shift as they grow up and develop their own relationships with both parents.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge the sacrifices you have made as a single mom and the strength it has taken to raise your children on your own. Their behavior towards you may stem from a complex web of emotions, including loyalty to their biological father, feelings of guilt, or simply a desire to assert their independence.

It's also essential to remember that their behavior doesn't define your worth as a parent or as a person. While it may be challenging to observe, try to focus on the positive aspects of your relationship with your children. Open communication is key – have a conversation with them about your feelings and express how their behavior affects you.

Remember, too, that even if they gravitate towards their father, it doesn't negate the impact you've had on their lives and the role you continue to play. Keeping open lines of communication and showing unconditional love and support for your children is vital. I know it's easier said than done, but it's essential for your own emotional well-being. Consider seeking support from a therapist, support group, or trusted friends and family to help navigate these complex emotions.

People do cry in therapy sometimes, but it's not at all necessary to cry in order for most kinds of therapy to be helpful. When you start counseling you don't yet know your counselor very well, so it's normal to keep your feelings in check until you feel comfortable and a bit more relaxed with your counselor and with the situation. Sometimes, though, there are emotions that have been waiting and waiting to finally find someone who will listen with a kind ear. If you feel safe right away in the situation with your counselor, you might just cry in spite of your fears about it. Your therapist is used to people expressing how they feel and will keep strict confidentiality, so even though it's embarrassing, finally experiencing someone truly listening with empathy and kindness may just be worth it. It's okay too to let your counselor know right at the beginning that you're kind of freaked out about getting too emotional in front of another person.

Generally, the ethical codes only prohibit relationships with clients. There are however a few types of counselor-to-counselor relationships that are prohibited by the ethics codes. Such prohibited relationships include those between supervisors and supervisees; between professors and students; or any time the relationship might negatively impact your (or their) clients. Lastly, some workplaces have rules against dating coworkers. It would be a good idea to check if there is such a rule that applies to you.

Starting the counseling process begins with recognizing the need for change or growth. The therapist will then assess your needs and develop a customized treatment plan to help you achieve your goals. Remember, taking this first step requires courage and is a sign of strength.

Good luck!

That's a common experience for many people, particularly those with high emotion sensitivity or a strong reaction to stressors. This reaction is known as an emotional outburst, and it can be challenging to manage. It's essential to identify the triggers that cause these intense emotional responses, as well as effective coping mechanisms to prevent or manage outbursts. Practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation, can help reduce the intensity of emotional responses. Additionally, cognitive restructuring and problem-solving skills can help put things into perspective, allowing you to respond to situations in healthier ways instead of reaching a "100" emotion level. Remember, it's okay to have emotions, but it's also essential to learn how to manage them effectively.

Anxiety and fear of relationships can have various underlying causes. Based on what you've shared, it appears that you might be dealing with social anxiety, fear of rejection, or fear of intimacy. These experiences are common in individuals with anxiety disorders.

It's important to note that everyone has different triggers for their anxiety. In your case, as you've noted, entering into a relationship causes anxiety, depression, and even physical symptoms such as vomiting. This could be due to a fear of losing control, fear of rejection, or fear of being vulnerable in a relationship.

You've mentioned that you've had this experience before. This may suggest that you have a pattern of avoidance when it comes to relationships. Engaging in avoidant behaviors can create a cycle where fear and anxiety lead to avoidance, and then more fear and anxiety.

It's crucial to remember that seeking professional help is not a sign of weakness. Talking with a mental health professional can help you identify the underlying causes of your anxiety, provide you with coping skills, and create a plan to help you manage your anxiety so that you can enter into relationships feeling more confident and less anxious.

It's also worth considering that you may benefit from exploring the reasons behind your fear of relationships in a safe and supportive therapeutic environment. This can help you gain a better understanding of your thoughts and emotions, and provide you with tools and resources to manage your anxiety and move forward in your relationships.

In the meantime, you may want to consider practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, engaging in physical activity to help reduce stress, and maintaining a balanced and nutritious diet. These self-care behaviors can help you manage your anxiety on a day-to-day basis while you work on the underlying issues with a mental health professional.

I hope this information is helpful to you, and I wish you all the best on your journey towards understanding and managing your anxiety. Let me know if you have any questions or if you'd like to explore any of these ideas further.

What a beautiful discussion of guilt and shame Lynda offers! Those
two demons start out as pesky and little when we are young, then grow with us to
become quite formidable. I'd like to throw in a technique I learned from Randy
Rausch (author of The Last Lecture) called The 3-Step Apology.
I teach this important bit of wisdom to my clients when they need to apologize
to someone else but more importantly when they need to forgive themselves.Yes, when we have trouble forgiving ourselves we sometimes forget
that there is part of us that just doesn't know how to apologize effectively.
Here goes:Step One: Say what you did and the damage it caused.Step Two: Say you're sorry and accept full
responsibility (no excuses, no explanation, no defensiveness: “It was all my
fault.”)Step
Three: Ask what you can do to repair the damage.Step Three is the one many of us didn’t learn growing up. And when
we add it to an apology, we are usually surprised that the penalty is as light
as it is. Of course, sometimes the apology is not accepted and no way to atone
is offered. So be it, we can’t control this. But if we are apologizing to
ourselves, we can. There is always a way to make amends if we put our heart
into it.
Give this a try the next time you’re reluctant to let yourself off
the hook. You might surprise yourself when how benevolent you can be when
invited.

I understand that you are concerned about someone's well-being and may have heard about The Baker Act. The Baker Act is a Florida statute that allows for the involuntary assessment and treatment of individuals who pose a risk to themselves or others due to mental illness or substance abuse.

However, as a psychologist, I cannot directly admit or commit someone to a facility. You would need to contact your local mental health authority or emergency services for assistance in initiating a Baker Act evaluation in Florida, or an equivalent process in other states. Be sure to have clear evidence of the individual's need for intervention, and remember that it's crucial to approach the situation sensitively and respectfully.

I hope this information helps. If you have any more questions, please don't hesitate to ask.

Being able to accept your partner's influence is a key relationship skill. And it's very two sided.  Chances are if you don't feel your partner is being influenced by you, they likely don't feel you are being influenced by them either. The best fix you can practice is to soften yourself into your partner and see how much more open you can be to their influence.  Play with it.

It is important to recognize that only you can define your sexual orientation. However, based on what you have shared, it is possible that you could identify as bisexual, or even explore other labels that may feel more accurate to you. Remember, sexual orientation is not defined by your attractions alone, but also by how you identify and the ways in which you express yourself sexually.

It's important to note that labeling yourself is a personal choice and it's okay if you don't feel the need to label yourself at all. The most significant thing is to respect yourself and your feelings, and to make sure you're considering your own wellbeing. You may choose to consult with other mental health professionals or support groups to gain a better understanding of your sexual orientation and help you navigate any related feelings or challenges.

Remember, there is no 'right' or 'wrong' way to identify your sexual orientation or express your sexuality. What matters is that you are true to yourself and live your life authentically. You might also find it helpful to learn more about sexual orientation and the different ways it can present itself. This understanding can lead to greater self-acceptance and understanding.

It is always hard when we feel as if we are losing somebody close to us. Feeling sad over these losses are normal. Keeping yourself distracted in healthy ways and processing your feelings of sadness will likely help with lifting your mood. Good luck to you!

I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a tough time right now. It's completely normal to feel sad and helpless during times of change or adversity, especially when it comes to something as significant as a parent's divorce. But I want you to know that you don't have to go through this alone. It's important to reach out to trusted friends, family members, or a mental health professional for support during these difficult times.

As a mental health professional, I would not recommend using substances to "lull yourself" or cope with your feelings. Instead, I would suggest engaging in self-care activities that can help promote your emotional and physical well-being. This might include things like getting enough sleep, eating healthy foods, engaging in regular physical activity, practicing relaxation techniques, writing in a journal, connecting with supportive friends and family, or seeking out professional counseling.

Remember, it's okay to feel sad and it's okay to ask for help. Please know that I'm here to support you in any way that I can. If you need someone to talk to, don't hesitate to reach out. I'm always here for you.

Anxiety can cause such a feeling of discomfort in our bodies that it can seem unbearable. The concern that I can hear in what you have written is that the thought of having some anxiety has now left you uncomfortable with any anxiety at all - and that can become a problem, indeed. As opposed to thinking about your anxiety as something much bigger than you, it could be helpful to start breaking it down. What are the things specifically that cause you anxiety about this new job? Is it being away from your family? If so, why? Once you start breaking down what causes you to feel anxiety into smaller "mouthfuls", then we are far better able to understand what has led to discomfort and start to problem solve the issue.

As a past sufferer of anxiety myself, I have learned that it is a natural part of life, it is a natural part of us, the longer we try to run from it the more it entangles us in its clutches, if we deny certain parts of ourselves we will become depressed or even oppressed, the only way to deal with anxiety is to embrace it and accept it, and in fighting the fight without fighting we will eventually win, I would encourage you to look into Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, your answer I think lies in that area of research. Hope this helps,C

I understand that you're feeling frustrated and disappointed with yourself for procrastinating and performing below your usual academic standards. I understand that the winter weather can sometimes bring on feelings of sadness for some people. This condition is commonly known as Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). Here are some suggestions that may help:

1. Light Therapy: Exposure to natural sunlight is important for many people, so consider using a light box during the winter months to simulate sunlight.
2. Exercise: Regular physical activity can help improve your mood and reduce symptoms of SAD. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity a day.
3. Healthy Eating: Eating a nutritious diet can help maintain good physical and mental health.
4. Social Engagement: Staying connected to friends and family can help combat feelings of loneliness and isolation.
5. Consider Counseling: If your symptoms are severe, consider meeting with a mental health professional for counseling or therapy.

These are just a few suggestions. I encourage you to try some of these strategies and see what works best for you. Remember, it's okay to ask for help during the winter months. Let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.

I understand your concerns, and it sounds like you're going through a difficult time in your relationship. It's important to recognize that everyone has different needs, and that patterns can change over time. I understand your situation can be difficult and emotionally challenging. It is natural to feel upset when we experience a change in our relationships, especially when there is a significant shift in the amount of communication or time spent together. The feelings you describe - sadness, feeling lost, and unwanted - can be symptoms of separation anxiety.

First, it is important to remember that being in a long-distance relationship requires adjustments and communication efforts from both partners. Given your boyfriend's new job demands, his increased traveling might be temporary. In situations like this, find ways to cope and maintain your emotional well-being.

Here are some suggestions to help you cope with the current situation:

1. Stay connected: Make the most of the communication channels available to you. Write emails or letters, send messages, or talk regularly using technology. Share your thoughts, feelings, and experiences with one another.

2. Establish a routine: Maintain consistent routines in your daily life. This could involve regular exercise, set times for meals, or engaging in hobbies and activities that bring you joy. Having a routine provides stability, which can help alleviate feelings of anxiety.

3. Refocus your energy: Distract yourself with other things; this could involve taking up new hobbies, volunteering, focusing on your career or personal growth, or connecting with friends and family.

4. Practice self-care: Make sure to take care of yourself both physically and emotionally, such as eating well, getting enough sleep, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress relief.

5. Seek support: Talking to friends, family, or a mental health professional can help you process your emotions and receive guidance, which can lead to a better understanding of your situation and personal growth.

It is also important to have an open and honest conversation with your boyfriend when he is next available to express your concerns and discuss the impact his absence is having on you. Remember to be understanding, as it may take time for both parties to adjust to the new circumstances. Your feelings are valid, and acknowledging and addressing them with open and effective communication can strengthen your connection.

While change can be scary, it is crucial to remember that every relationship faces challenges, and how we navigate and cope with these challenges can deepen our bond and understanding with one another.

I can’t give you legal advice, but employers can suggest you see someone if your behavior is affecting your job. Is it possible that you're not aware of how your interactions are affecting others? Maybe this “forced counseling” can be an opportunity for some introspection on your part.

Therapy does not work overnight, oftentimes it is a lifelong struggle, the therapists job is not to "cure" you or to remove something but rather to make you strong enough to live your life with your own peculiarities and struggles, remember we are human and constantly fallible. Another important thing to note is that although you go to therapy, that is just a room, most of the magic and work takes place in your real life outside of that room.

Hopefully both the client and counselor would together decide when to terminate counseling sessions. It's really helpful for the client to leave counseling with a solid sense of what he or she has accomplished in counseling, so it can be a good idea to spend some time acknowledging that in the last session or sessions. Sometimes, however, a client has needs beyond the scope of the counselor's expertise. That's a good time for a conversation about those needs and ideas of  how best to meet them, whether by adding in care with an additional mental health professional or transferring care entirely to a new mental health provider.

We're all wonderful, imperfect, complicated people and we're at our best when we're all helping each other. I'm glad you wrote this question, because a lot of people have this feeling sometimes. I can tell that you're smart, because you seem to sense that the two things you wrote about are connected...you "not being yourself", and then how you felt when your grandma died. When Grandma died, you needed and deserved extra love and support, but the people around you didn't seem to give it to you, maybe. My hunch is that they wanted to, but that they didn't know how much you needed it, or what you needed exactly. The older you get, the more you will have to take charge of letting people know what you need. Maybe this is one of the suckier parts of being mature, but that's how it works. When you started middle school, it sounds like you changed; you got more quiet, right? That must have felt weird, to not be acting like yourself. It sounds like fear tricked you into thinking people wouldn't like you. Fear can be silly. So then, fear got you to not show yourself, and when we don't show ourselves, people can't see who we are; they don't know us as well and then they don't know what we need and they can't care for us as well either. Fear of not being liked isolated you from the people who love you. It does that to a lot of us. So, where you're at right now is because of what fear did to you, and also because when Grandma died you were already isolated so people couldn't see your pain and know that you needed support. There's a simple solution, but you'd have to be brave enough to look fear in the face and say "Get off my back!". "You're not helping me by telling me lies." Can you be brave enough to go back to your old, louder, self? If you talk to the people closest to you...tell them what you think and how you feel, then they'll be able to give you the care that you want and deserve. I wish you well as you try this!

I understand that breaking up with a significant other can be a difficult and painful process. It's natural to feel hesitant to open up to someone new after a past relationship ended. However, it's important to realize that everyone is unique and that you deserve a fulfilling relationship.

One way to approach this challenge is to focus on your own personal growth and healing. You've mentioned that you know you're over your ex, but it may be helpful to explore any lingering emotions or beliefs that are holding you back. This could include fears of vulnerability or past relationship patterns.

It's also important to remember that building a new relationship takes time and effort. You don't have to rush into anything – take things at your own pace and be open to new experiences. Consider engaging in activities that bring you joy and helping others in order to feel more connected to the world around you.

As a psychologist, I would be happy to help you explore these thoughts further and develop strategies to build healthy relationships in the future.

Hi Brookfield, It can be unsettling when we feel something as fundamental as our sexual orientation shifting. I like that you're honest enough with yourself to say "I'm struggling with this". To accept that there is a question is a brave place to be. And...it doesn't necessarily mean you're gay.Unfortunately, we live in a culture that wants to put people in slots...male or female, straight or gay...we tend to not like those grey areas so much as a culture. The truth is that, if we grew up in a society where there wasn't this categorization...if we felt free to explore and grow sexually, we might be surprised at who we are attracted to. You don't have to put yourself in a slot. Our sexual preferences are more fluid than we think, and it can change over time.We also live in a culture where there is prejudice against homosexuality or "differentness" in general. The wish to not be gay can be powerful. Many people who are gay spend years believing they were heteroxual...fighting against, repressing  or ignoring their gay thoughts. This is needless pain. If you are gay, there is no shame in that and you can still have a glorious life filled with love and passion.Having said all that...just because you have thoughts about men or get turned on by gay porm doesn't mean you're gay. Many heterosexual people have thoughts and fantasies about the same sex; it's arousing because it's naughty...we're curious about the forbidden, or we're just curious. Becoming aroused by gay porn is normal for many heterosexual men. Sexual orientation isn't just about sex either. A different gauge of who you are sexually can be found in your emotions towards men or women. Are you drawn into emotional connections with men more than women? Who do you feel the urge to explore and be close to?Exploring your sexuality through being open to different experiences can help too. How does it feel to kiss a man, to touch a man, as compared with a woman...sometimes this feels like such a big and forbidden step that it's a barrier to discovering ourselves. We don't want to open that door. I wish you well as you do exactly what you are supposed to be doing...exploring and discovering yourself. It's an exciting journey and you might want to find a trusted person to talk more about this with.

I understand how frustrating and disheartening it can be when you feel unheard or disbelieved, especially when dealing with important matters such as your safety and experiences. It's unfortunate that your attempts to seek help have been met with challenges due to your age. Here are some suggestions that might be helpful:

1. Find a supportive adult: Look for an adult you trust and feel comfortable with. This could be a teacher, a mentor, or even a trusted neighbor. Share your experiences and concerns with them. They can offer advice, support, and may be able to help you in ways you haven't considered yet.

2. Document your experiences: Keep a journal or records of your experiences. Write down the details, including dates, times, and any relevant information. Consider saving any physical evidence, such as texts, emails, or drawings. Having concrete evidence can be helpful when discussing your experiences with others.

3. Report the incidents to authorities: Keep trying to report the incidents to the police or other appropriate authorities. You may consider discussing the challenges you've faced with your school counselor or principal, who can help advocate for you.

4. Seek professional help: There are therapists and counselors who work specifically with children and adolescents. Consider looking for a therapist in your area who specializes in trauma or abuse. Ask for their assistance in finding an adult to attend sessions with. Even if you can't attend sessions alone, your presence with a trusted adult can be beneficial.

5. Reach out to support groups: Connecting with others who have had similar experiences may help you feel less alone and give you a better understanding of your situation. There are various support groups dedicated to victims of abuse, available both in-person and online.

6. Don't give up: Continue seeking help and advocating for yourself. Remember that it's normal to feel unsure, scared, or frustrated, but never give up on bringing your situation to light. Stay strong and keep pursuing the resources and support you need.

I understand your dilemma. I believe it's essential to maintain transparency and honesty in your relationship with your children while also considering their emotional well-being. You could approach this situation by having an open conversation with them about the reality of Santa. You could explain that Santa represents joy, love, and the holiday spirit, and that many people choose to believe in him as a cherished tradition. This approach allows your children to maintain the essence of the holiday magic while also understanding truthfulness. I'm sorry to hear about your feelings of disconnection in your marriage. It's important to recognize that relationships do require effort from both parties to stay strong and healthy. Here are some steps you can take to try and reconnect with your husband:

1. Open Communication: Have a heart-to-heart conversation with your husband about how you've been feeling and express your concerns about the current state of your relationship. Be sure to speak in a calm and non-judgmental manner.

2. Active Listening: Make sure your husband feels heard and understood by practicing active listening. This means giving him your full attention, avoiding interruptions and focusing on his words.

3. Take Responsibility: Reflect on your own contribution to the distance between you and your husband and take responsibility for any part you've played. Apologize for any mistakes and make a commitment to working on improving the relationship.

4. Spend Time Together: Schedule regular quality time with your husband to rebuild your emotional connection. This could be regular date nights, vacations, shared hobbies or activities, or anything else that you both enjoy.

5. Set Boundaries: Communicate your boundaries about work relationships that make you feel uncomfortable. If necessary, set rules about what's appropriate in terms of emotional investment and time spent outside of the marriage.

6. Seek Professional Help: If you've tried these steps and feel like you're still not making progress, consider seeking the help of a marriage counselor or therapist. They can provide you with practical tools and techniques to improve communication, build emotional intimacy, and restore the feeling of connection in your relationship.

I imagine you are trying to figure out a way to be "fair" to your adult kids.  The key word is "adult".  If your daughter can afford to join the family for a vacation that's great, she's welcome to come.  However, as you pointed out she took a vacation by herself last year - she chose to put her resources (time off work and money) into doing that.  Good for her - she did what she wanted.  If she wants to budget time and money for a family vacation she will.As for feeling guilty, let me echo the sentiments already offered - vacations are lovely, but not a survival need.  Your girl is in her 20s and it's her turn to provide for herself.  You did your parenting - now go enjoy your vacation with whoever can, and wants to, join you!

Wanting to make changes and asking for assistance is the first step. Overcoming anxiety and depression is not an easy feat to do on your own, especially if it's been something you have been battling for years.  There are some different routes you may go down in order to start the healing process:Therapy - find a therapist who has a lot of experience with anxiety and depression. You can do this by googling "anxiety depression therapist " in your city.  CounselChat also has a directory of amazing therapists, as does Psychology TodayMedication - Depending on what other symptoms you may be struggling with depends on what medication you will be prescribed. Be 100% honest with the doctor and ask about different side effects or potential risks associated with the medication. You more than likely will be prescribed an SSRI.Therapy & Medication - The outcomes are very good for those who decide to do both. Medication can help level out out your mood and therapy can help you process through your emotions and keep you accountable for you goals , as you will be seeing your therapist more often than your psychiatristTherapy & Homeopathy - Homeopathy could potentially be a good tool to use alongside with therapy in case you are not interested in going down the medication route. Arsenicum album is most commonly given to those who struggle with anxiety and depression.The choice is yours. My recommendation is to start with therapy and explore your options more in depth with your therapist.

Patient, it's important to remember that no single therapist may be a perfect fit for everyone. The quality of therapeutic relationship and progress often depend on various factors such as compatibility, trust, and mutual understanding between the therapist and the patient.

Regarding the first part of your question, you can explore the following suggestions to help determine whether a specific therapist is suitable for you:

1. Comfort level: You should feel comfortable expressing your thoughts, feelings, and concerns to your therapist. It's crucial to discuss your needs and see if they align with the therapist's approach and style.

2. Empathy: Check if your therapist empathizes with your experiences. Empathic connection is vital to build a trusting relationship in therapy.

3. Collaboration: Evaluate if your therapist is collaborative and open to your feedback. They should involve you in making informed decisions about your treatment goals and be willing to adjust their approach if necessary.

4. Responsiveness: Observe how quickly and thoroughly your therapist responds to your concerns and needs. A good therapist should be accessible and attentive to your emotional and psychological needs.

Now, for the second part of your question, I would like to clarify that you do not train your therapist in the same way that a coach or a personal trainer works with a client. Instead, you can communicate openly and honestly about your preferences, expectations, and fears to help build a strong therapeutic relationship.

Feel free to share your thoughts and any further concerns you might have. If anything in this conversation resonates with you, please know that I am always here to support you.

I understand that you're going through a difficult time and feeling trapped in a gender that does not align with how you identify. I understand that you feel overwhelmed with the various challenges you have faced in your life including a history of sexual abuse, surviving breast cancer, dealing with insomnia, depression, and now anxiety. The are two ways that such anxiety can be dealt with. One is an attempt to replace maladaptive thinking by examining the distorted thinking and resetting the fight-or-flight response with more reasonable, accurate ones. As an example "I'm scared of spiders." But if you change the thinking from being scared to "I'm bigger than the spider," it allows the mind to reach a calmer state of mind. Mindfulness-based therapy can also help  focus on the bodily sensations that arise when you feel anxious. Instead of avoiding or withdrawing from these feelings, remain present and fully experience the symptoms of anxiety. Instead of avoiding distressing thoughts, open up to them in an effort to realize and acknowledge that they are not literally true.Although it may seem counter-intuitive, fully realizing the experience of anxiety enables the release of over identification with negative thoughts. You can practice responding to disruptive thoughts, and letting these thoughts go.By remaining present in the body, you'll learn that the anxiety being experienced is merely a reaction to perceived threats. By positively responding to threatening events instead of being reactive you can overcome an erroneous fight-or-flight response.

Have you discussed this issue with your primary care physician yet? They may be able to identify any underlying causes and suggest potential treatments. You didn't say what or how many medications you've tried. Certain anxiety medications can make you feel nauseous, but I haven't heard of any that cause mouth blisters, so there may be some other underlying medical issue there. I would definitely talk to your primary care physician and whoever has prescribed the medication as well as a neurologist if you've suffered a severe head injury. There are so many medications available for anxiety or insomnia or even depression that there may be others with lesser side effects.But beyond that, have you tried any other treatments such as deep breathing or meditation? Meditation can be very effective, but it takes practice and you don't have to sit cross-legged for hours chanting "Ohm" to meditate. It's about focusing on your breath, rather than all the thoughts that are racing through your head. And when they do take your mind off your breath, simply refocus (and refocus and refocus). Like I said, it takes practice, so don't give up. You can find many sites offering different ways to meditate, so look around and see what works best for you. Like medication, you just have to find the one that works best and that might take some experimentation.I hope this helps and best of luck to you.

I understand that these thoughts are distressing for you. They may be a sign of an internal struggle, possibly related to feelings of low self-worth or self-criticism. These thoughts are not uncommon, particularly in individuals dealing with anxiety or depression.

First, let's acknowledge that having thoughts you don't want doesn't make you weak or define your worth. I encourage you to practice self-compassion. Be kind to yourself and understand that everyone experiences negative thoughts and self-doubt at times.

To help manage these thoughts:
1. Practice mindfulness meditation: Focus on your breath, the present moment, and acknowledging thoughts without holding onto them.
2. Challenge negative thoughts: Whenever a negative thought comes up, ask yourself if it's based on facts. Refocus on the positive aspects of yourself and your life.
3. Engage in activities that make you feel good: Do things that bring you joy and help boost your self-esteem.
4. Consider seeking support: Talking with a mental health professional can provide valuable insight and tools for managing these thoughts.

Remember, it takes time and practice to develop mental resilience, but with consistent effort and self-compassion, you can learn to manage negative thoughts and improve your overall wellbeing.
